Title: Coronavirus: How Dubai, Saudi returnees slipped under radar, leading to spike in cases
Content:
More on Covid-19

CHENNAI: When Dubai’s health authorities began door-to-door screening on Saturday for Covid-19 cases in Naif, one of the city’s most populous localities, public health officials in Kerala felt a stab of anxiety. Nearly 70% of those who have returned to the Kerala’s Kasargod district in the past few days lived in this crowded commercial-cum-residential area of the Gulf metropolis.These returnees — Kasargod accounted for 34 of the 39 new cases reported in Kerala on Friday — have now been categorised as “high-risk” and are being tested for the novel coronavirus infection. “These people have become the biggest concern for the state,” said Dr Amar Fettle, Kerala’s state nodal officer for infectious diseases.Many of those who returned from Gulf countries to India in February and early March were neither screened at airports nor advised to quarantine themselves. The focus then was on passengers from China, South Korea, Iran , Spain, Italy and Germany. Dubai and Saudi Arabia weren’t even on the radar. Orders for screening passengers from the Gulf did not come until March second week.As a result, in the past 10 days, several states are seeing a spike in the number of patients with a history of living in or transiting through Gulf countries.In Maharashtra, for instance, the novel coronavirus arrived with a group of 40 people who had gone on a six-day trip to Dubai and Abu Dhabi. “At least 15 from the group have tested positive so far,” officials said.After Kasargod became Kerala’s Covid-19 hotspot in a single day, the district administration put 6,511 people who came into the district after February 20 under observation, of which 127 people are in isolation in hospitals. “The number of people in isolation will increase in the coming days. The results of 215 samples are expected in a day or two,” Dr Fettle said.Public health officials and experts across the country say screening of passengers from the Middle East should have started much earlier in March. “A large number of professionals and skilled workers from across India migrate to the Gulf for employment. It is also one of the most popular transit hubs. That by itself makes it a high-risk zone,” said public health activist Dr Sumanth Raman.Kerala now is observing nearly 300 contacts of these travellers who landed in Mumbai on March 1 and dispersed to 10 districts, including Belagavi district in the bordering state of Karnataka More than three-fifth of the Covid-19 patients in Maharashtra have an international travel history. Most patients travelled from the UAE, according to an analysis by the Maharashtra state department of medical education. Tracking the case sheets of 122 positive cases, officials found 67 people with travel history. Around 28 of them had travelled to the UAE.In Bihar , a 38-year-old, who died on March 21 before he tested positive for the virus, had landed in Kolkata from the Gulf and returned home to Munger district on March 13 by car. He went to Patna Medical College and Hospital with symptoms, and doctors there referred him AIIMS-Patna. All his relatives who took his body in a private ambulance were exposed. Four people, including two private hospital staff, have since tested positive, forcing the Patna district administration to seal the private hospital, where he first visited.In Gujarat, more than half the patients with a travel history have come from Dubai or Saudi Arabia. Among 47 people who tested positive, 27 had returned from abroad. Of these, seven were from Dubai and eight were from Saudi.Last week, after the department of immigration handed over names and travel history of all passport holders, the states are beginning to isolate those who travelled into the country since February.Some of them who are still asymptomatic may be infecting the elderly or people with low immunity, said officials. In Tamil Nadu, for instance, a 60-year-old man from Rajapalayam, who tested positive on Saturday, did not have any travel history. “But he told us he met one of his relatives who came from Dubai. The relative showed no symptoms,” said Tamil Nadu joint director for public health (epidemic diseases) P Sampath. Officials have asked the relative to remain in quarantine. In the past week, at least three people with a history of travel to Dubai have tested positive for the virus in Tamil Nadu.Epidemiologists are noticing interesting patterns. For instance, health workers in Kerala found that most people who tested positive had visited a mall at the airport. The mistake cannot be undone now, but experts say testing more people is the only option for the government. “Track, test, isolate and treat,” said public health expert T Sundararaman, former dean of School of Health Systems Studies, TISS.(Pushpa Narayan and Rajiv G with inputs from centres)

Title: Muslims take body of Hindu neighbour for cremation in UP
Content:
Ravi Shankar, resident of Anand Vihar locality in UP's Bulandshahar district died of cancer on Friday. Deceased, ha… https://t.co/eZFFlmE4Tu — Piyush Rai (@Benarasiyaa) 1585460144000

MEERUT: A crowd of mourners, most of them wearing white and brown skull caps, baffled onlookers as they carried a body to the cremation ground in UP's Bulandshahr amid chants of "Ram naam satya hai".Ravi Shankar, in his late 40s, had died on Saturday afternoon after a prolonged battle with cancer at his home in Bulandshahr’s Anand Vihar area, leaving behind his wife and four children. With relatives stuck due to the lockdown, Shankar’s distraught wife didn’t know whom to turn to.It was then that a group of neighbours approached the family and offered to take out the funeral procession. Soon, amid Hindu chants, scores of Muslims of the area lifted the cot on which the body was lying and took it to the ghat for the last rites.Videos of the funeral soon went viral on social media platforms, drawing accolades from hundreds of users.The cremation took place according to Hindu rituals and practices."People from the entire locality came forward to support the family. Both communities have always stood with each other in times of need," said Mohammed Zubaid , a local resident."Given the prevailing condition, people are reluctant to come out of their homes. And in cases of deaths, people are more cautious, unwilling to take part in big gatherings. But here people came out in large numbers though they took care to maintain social distance," another resident said.

Title: Seniors in a lather as TV soaps run dry
Content: Ganesh Krishnamurthy, 76, sits back on his couch in Chennai, worried about Sreemoyee and her estranged husband Anindya in Kolkata. “Anindya needs a stent for his heart, Sreemoyee’s former love interest has reappeared in her life while their son wants to leave them and go away to another country... Things are at a critical juncture and I don’t know how long I’ll have to wait to see what happens to Sreemoyee and her family,” he rues. ‘Sreemoyee’ isn’t a relative but the title character of a popular Bengali serial who keeps the septuagenarian company for a few hours every evening. Or at least she did till the coronavirus lockdown shut down television production across the country.Unlike the younger tech-savvy population which relies on the web and OTT platforms to stave off boredom while locked down, one cannot underrate the role of television in the lives of the older generation that grew up in an analogue era, navigating channels instead of the web. Now, they are trapped in a cycle of reruns since TV networks have no new episodes to telecast.“It’s quite depressing that I am left with nothing these days,” says Patna resident Sarita Sinha , 62, for whom a diet of Bhojpuri soaps was her only escape from monotony and the darkness of the ongoing pandemic. Thankamani A, a 50-year-old homemaker in Thiruvananthapuram, is “mentally preparing for the coming weeks” after her son told her that her favourite serials may soon stop airing while those like Ashok Mangalkar from Nagpur, who sought refuge in the comfort of Marathi soaps, feels a void. “I miss those evenings of watching daily soaps and afterwards discussing the stories and the character with my wife,” he says.Leena Gangopadhyay, writer and creative director of popular Bengali soaps, has been receiving countless messages from anxious viewers. “All the social media sites are flooded with messages. The mother of an executive of the channel that telecasts ‘Sreemoyee’ is so addicted that she has personally requested for the serial’s storyline,” says Gangopadhyay.How long the delays will continue depends on how long the lockdown lasts. But it’s wise for viewers to come to terms with the fact that the next month (or more) will not follow their usual TV rhythm. Pretty much all prime-time scripted series and non-fiction shows across languages have exhausted their banks of unaired episodes and are now trying to figure what to do in terms of content.If Doordarshan brought back 80s cult hit “Ramayana” to keep its viewers occupied, Hindi channels like Zee TV have decided to dip into their collaboration with ALTBalaji’s OTT repository and dig out three new “finite shows”. “It felt like the right time to see if audiences take to these three finite series which feature very popular television faces of all time,” explained Aparna Bhosle, business head, Zee TV. “Also, it made sense to offer finite series in the current context. The lockdown is temporary, post which we would resume shoots and continue with our usual line-up of daily fiction shows.”Some of the leading Tamil and Malayalam television channels, like Star Vijay , Zee Tamil and Colors, internally assessed the available content and a few found a way to judiciously manage fresh content by cutting down on viewing time of the episodes to prolong shows for a few more days. Content providers for Sun TV even opted to work double-shifts that went well into the early morning of March 19 to capture as much fresh content as possible after the Film Employees Federation of South India’s announcement to stop shoots much before the three-week lockdown came into force.With more than 60-70% content of the channels suspended, according to Ranjan Satapathy , head of Tarang, an Odia entertainment channel, channels have resorted to dubbed versions of popular Hindi serials apart from reruns of soaps and reality shows, old Odia films, and religious programmes. The Kannada television industry that usually keeps a larger reserve of 20 shows too is facing uncertainty with production on pause.In the Telugu-speaking states where the popularity of TV serials often overrides the publicity given to new film releases, fresh episodes came to a grinding halt from March 21, with at least 70 fiction and 20 non-fiction shows not being telecast, according to Telugu Television Producers Council president A Prasada Rao The last time that the Indian television industry had taken such a hit was back in 2008 when more than 100,000 workers had gone on an indefinite “non-cooperation” strike against low wages, late pay and long hours.“But unlike the past when production houses would keep a bank of at least 10-15 unaired episodes, today one doesn’t keep a backup of more than one or two,” says Ashoke Dubey, general secretary, Federation of Western India Cine Employees. “It’s mainly because TRP ratings fluctuate and determine the nature of the next few episodes that are shot a day or two prior to being aired,” he explains.As the entertainment industry stares at loss and disarray, Radikaa Sarathkumar, who heads the Tamil production house Radaan Mediaworks, says: “We did not expect the virus to impact our lives to this extent.” The audience probably echoes that.

Title: COVID 19 India: Onus put on DMs, SPs to check influx
Content:
More on

NEW DELHI: In a move to curb the movement of migrant workers on roads and highways, the Centre on Sunday used the Disaster Management Act to fix responsibility on district magistrates and senior superintendents of police to seal district and state borders while making arrangements for those on the roads to be housed in shelters besides also dissuading such workers from leaving their current place of stay.The measure followed concerns that continued movement of lakhs of migrant workers from various cities to the hinterland could lead to a problematic spread of Covid-19 in rural areas and was accompanied with directions to ensure salaries were paid and employment was not terminated during the ongoing national lockdown and the ensuing shuttering of economic activity in large parts of the country.Responding to questions whether the government was caught unawares by the migrant outflow, Lav Agarwal , joint secretary in the health ministry, said the entire situation due to the global and national spread of coronavirus was unprecedented in scale and the Centre had done its best to anticipate as well as respond to the developing situation on the ground.Apart from enforcing the lockdown, states were directed to ensure all employers, be it in the industry or in shops or commercial establishments, shall make payment of wages to their workers, at their workplace, on the due date and without any deduction for the period their establishments are under closure during the lockdown.It was also said that wherever workers, including the migrants, are living in rented accommodation, landlords shall not demand payment of rent for a period of one month. If a landlord forces labourers or students to vacate premises, the state police have been told to make him liable under the Disaster Management Act.In a fresh order issued by the Union home secretary under Section 10(2)(l) of the Disaster Management Act, 2005, states and UTs were told to ensure proper screening of migrants on the move for Covid-19 and keep them in government quarantine facilities for a minimum 14 days as per standard health protocol. Health ministry sources said migrant workers were less of a risk as compared to foreign travellers and their immediate contacts, but would need tracking as some could be carriers of the disease.As per the order, which entails punitive action if violated by any person or anyone in authority, states and UT governments shall ensure adequate arrangements of temporary shelters and provision of food for the poor and needy people, including migrant workers stranded due to the lockdown.“Whereas, to deal with the situation and for effective implementation of the lockdown measures, and to mitigate the economic hardship of the migrant workers, in exercise of its powers (under Section 10(2)(I) of the Disaster Management Act), the undersigned, in the capacity as chairperson, National Executive Committee hereby directs states/Union territory authorities to take necessary action and to issue necessary orders to their district magistrate/deputy commissioner and senior superintendent of police/superintendent of police/deputy commissioner of police to take following additional measures,” the order said.“It is further indicated that in case of violation of any of the above measures, the respective state/UT government shall take necessary action under the Act," it said.The home secretary in a separate letter sent to the chief secretaries on Sunday sought “strict implementation of the measures to stop the movement of migrants and providing them with quarantine facilities, food, etc and ensuring payment of wages and non-eviction by their landlords”.

Title: Delhi borders cleared, but screening poses challenge
Content: NEW DELHI/GHAZIABAD: An evacuation carried out on a war footing through Saturday night and Sunday ensured the thousands of migrant workers who had gathered at Delhi’s borders with Ghaziabad and Noida and at Anand Vihar ISBT had either been put on buses to take them home or moved to shelters in either of the three cities.But while the border crisis was solved, the huge sweep of migration across north India now presents a stiff logistical challenge of screening these travelling masses who will mingle with the local population in their respective cities, towns and villages during a lockdown enforced specifically for social distancing to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus infection.Through Sunday, people continued to pour out of Delhi, towards the Noida and Yamuna expressways and UP Gate in Ghaziabad, jumping over barricades put up at the border in the desperation to get home. Among themselves, they spoke about the lockdown lasting three months — echoing WhatsApp messages doing the rounds — and their savings would run out much before that.Ghaziabad district magistrate Ajay Shankar Pandey said around 90,000 people were sent in 850 roadways buses and scores of private ones on Sunday, after which the bus service was stopped. The borders have been sealed again. From Ghaziabad alone, 2,000 buses had been run since Friday night to evacuate people. Of these, 650 buses were provided by Haryana.At Anand Vihar ISBT, which had on Saturday thrown up shocking visuals of thousands crowding round the bus station for a ride home, around 1,000 people was all that remained on Sunday of the sea of humanity. The Kaushambi bus depot, in UP territory on the other side of the road, was disinfected and closed.In an eight-hour-long overnight operation, the Delhi government transported 30,000 people, who had reached the area despite fervent appeals and assurances from chief minister Arvind Kejriwal to stay back, were transported to Lal Kuan in Ghaziabad, from where the UP bus service picked them up. Senior Delhi and UP government officials remained stationed in the area.Delhi transport minister Kailash Gahlot said the government decided to deploy buses after it realised people were not willing to turn back despite the appeals.“It was important to provide transport to the swelling crowd, considering the stampede-like situation. The exercise started around 9pm (Saturday) and continued till 5am on Sunday,” state transport officer Kailash Gahlot told TOI. “We pressed about 600 buses into services and covered 8-9 locations, including Hapur, Sikandrabad, Modi Nagar, Muradnagar, Ghaziabad and Bulandshahr. Maximum trips were made to Lal Kuan in Ghaziabad,” Gahlot said.The UP bus service from Lal Kuan started around 8am. Officials said the buses took people to Bareilly, Jhansi, Hamirpur, Mirzapur, Hardoi, Lakhimpur and Aligarh, among other UP cities. Some also headed further into Madhya Pradesh and Bihar Delhi Police, civil defence volunteers and others arranged for food, especially for women, the elderly and children. Gahlot said the operation took place in coordination with Delhi Police and the East Delhi Municipal Corporation (EDMC).“Despite lockdown, many people managed to reach Anand Vihar and now strict orders have been issued that only those with curfew passes would be allowed to board DTC and cluster buses. There has been a complete clampdown in the city and strict action will be taken against anyone found loitering on streets,” said a Delhi government official. “Nearly 40% of workers had come via national highways from Haryana and Rajasthan. They have been sent to our night centres so that no one faces any difficulty,” the official added.Those who tried to reach Anand Vihar ISBT on Sunday were relocated to various industrial areas from which they travelled by Delhi Police. “They were provided food packets. We dropped people from Haryana at night shelters,” a police officer said.Starting Saturday night, police made announcements asking people to contact them for help. Police officers simultaneously also alerted neighbouring districts about the movement of workers.“Over 50 DTC buses took rounds and transported the workers from near Anand Vihar to their respective destinations. In order to ensure social distancing, we did not let people crowd the buses and no one was allowed to stand in the bus.” said a senior police official.In a wireless message to the ranks, Delhi Police chief SN Shrivastava said, “Since the lockdown is underway, strict legal action would be taken against people who join a gathering or decide to march. If any labourer is venturing out, provide them food, speak to them and drop them back to their location in the bus. Let them know that no buses are plying towards Uttar Pradesh and in view of the pandemic all must stay put wherever they are.”During picket checking at Dhaula Kuan flyover, three buses found carrying passengers in violation of lockdown were seized by Delhi Police and their drivers were arrested. The owners of the buses were also later arreste

Title: Coronavirus in India: Protective gear delivery only after 25 days, govt hospitals told
Content:
PTI photo.

NEW DELHI: Government hospitals seeking personal protective equipment (PPE) are being told that it will take a minimum of 25-30 working days for them to be delivered. The Covid-19 emergency procurement cell of HLL Lifecare, the public sector unit acting as the central procurement agency for the government, has told them this is due to short supply of raw materials required to manufacture PPE and the prevailing transportation situation in the lockdown.

For government health facilities grappling with acute shortage of PPE, this cannot be good news. In many places doctors, nurses and other healthcare workers are worried and beginning to protest as the shortage is forcing them to work without protective gear.

More on Covid-19

Coronavirus pandemic: Complete Coverage 21-day lockdown: What will stay open and what won't How to quarantine yourself at home Trust the newspaper for your daily verified news

According to HLL sources, components for PPE kits are made by different manufacturers and supplied erratically as most makers are in the small and medium sector. With just a few designated collection centres where components are assembled into kits, there is further delay in getting them from these centres to where they are needed, said the sources.

Coronavirus lockdown: Latest updates

The sources said over 80,000 PPE kits have been dispatched and the textile ministry claims that 10 lakh masks have been supplied till now. TOI had reported how the textile ministry has roped in 11 Indian firms to produce PPE suits and two for producing masks, including N95 masks, spread across Gujarat, Tiruppur in Tamil Nadu , surrounding areas of Delhi including Gurgaon and Ghaziabad , as well as in Bangalore and Kolkata. Efforts are on to add more manufacturers in the coming days. Nodal officials from the government have been posted at factories to oversee production and to smooth transport problems. However, according to textile ministry officials, firms have been producing 5,000 protective suits in two days. They hope to push it up to 8,000 per day by March 30.

On March 23, the indent was for 10 lakh protective suits. Even at the optimistic estimate of producing 8,000 PPE suits per day, it would take four months to produce 10 lakh of them.

Perhaps more worrying is the question of whether even the 10 lakh PPE suits will be sufficient.

There are over 250 medical college hospitals across India. At the moment, only a few are being used for Covid patients. If the crisis reaches a stage where the others also need to be pressed in service, even if just 50 medical personnel in each hospitals were to require full PPE suits, it would work out to 12,500 suits per day. People working in two shifts would mean double that number or 25,000 PPE kits per day or 1.75 lakh per week. There are hundreds of government hospitals not attached to medical colleges whose staff too will require not just PPE but lakhs of masks.

Title: Frontline medics fume over protective gear
Content: The Covid-19 pandemic has brought to the fore that all is not well with the country’s medical staff. A dozen doctors in five states have contacted the highly contagious virus — mainly due to lack of masks, gloves and personal protection equipment (PPE) — and there are many resident doctors and interns who feel they, as the frontline medical soldiers who handle patients every hour, are “sitting ducks”.In Kolkata, young doctors are upset because they have to run fever clinics wearing a plastic raincoat for protection. “We are raring to go and realise that there is a scarcity of PPEs. But if even one of us is infected, it will be a blow to the morale of the healthcare fraternity,” said a doctor who is part of the Covid-19 team at the Medical College Hospital in Kolkata. (Experts say plastic raincoats offer protection against viruses, but should be customised and discarded every 4-5 hours).“Do you send soldiers on the warfront without guns? Then why are you sending doctors to fight this war without proper kits,” said Dr Ravi Ranjan Kumar Raman of Nalanda Medical College and Hospital in Patna.“My parents and sister cry every day when I leave for work. They ask me not to go to the hospital but I can’t skip my responsibilities. Somewhere in my heart, I know that even if I die, it won’t affect the system,” said Dr Raman.Junior doctors at Nalanda believe they are sent to the front line “while senior and experienced doctors are on the back foot”.In Chennai’s private hospitals, resident doctors are “absconding” from work saying their parents don’t want them to report for duty.The central health ministry and state governments had a two-month notice about Covid-19 in the form of the goings-on in China’s Wuhan province where over 3,000 died in three months. Yet, the task of gathering PPEs, special N95 masks and gloves has been sluggish in all states. A central health ministry drew up a wish-list just 10 days ago, stating the country needs 7.25 lakh body overalls, 60 lakh N95 masks and one crore three-ply facemasks.The fear of contracting the virus is so high that NMCH Junior Doctors’ Association wrote to the Bihar principal secretary (health) on March 25, asking senior doctors from other government medical colleges and private hospitals be put on duty while junior doctors be kept as “reserved manpower”. Bihar has 11 COVID-19 patients at present.They alleged their principal had quarantined himself in his home and has ignored their demands. “All Covid-19 positive people are in NMCH, still we do not have hazmat suit and mask. Instead, we have been given normal gown worn in operation theatre. Our principal has also stopped coming now for his safety and has left us to die,” said another junior doctor.In Mumbai, the former president of Maharashtra Association of Resident Doctors Kalyani Dongre wrote to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray about resident doctors forced to wear single-use three-ply mask for three to four days. “If a doctor doesn’t have protection, how can she or he protect others?” asked a Mumbai doctor.The PPE shortage is compounded by the shortage of manpower, again resulting in student doctors being forced to put in extra hours. Holidays have been cancelled for all doctors, including residents who are required to work 24-hour shifts once or twice a week.In Tamil Nadu, the directorate of medical education has asked deans of medical colleges to extend the one-year internship of MBBS students by another month so that they can help out in tackling the Covid-19 crisis.In states such as Orissa where medical manpower is a serious problem, the government is planning to deploy MBBS students of 7th, 8th and 9th semesters (fourth year and fifth year) on Covid-19 duty. There are 1,500 such students in the state.Some students are apprehensive. “My seniors said there are no masks or PPE available for doctors. Pushing us to the forefront in such a situation could create problems for us,” said an MBBS student of a government-run medical college.In a private medical college, which has partnered with the state government to open a separate 500-bed Covid-19 hospital, two doctors have threatened to resign after the management asked them to work in the corona-care facility.

Title: PSU charges govt hospitals high margins on PPE
Content:
HLL Lifecare, the public sector company that acts as the government’s central procurement agency for personal protective equipment (PPE) for healthcare workers is charging mark-ups of up to 50% on components of the protective gear it is providing to government hospitals. With HLL having floated tenders for 10 lakh coveralls and 40 lakh N95 masks recently, that would amount to almost Rs 22 crore as mark-up on coveralls alone and Rs 8 crore on N-95 masks.

Sources in HLL said that the mark-up was to account for transportation costs, which was high especially in the period of lockdown when it was difficult to find truckers willing to transport the kits. HLL’s letters to institutions states that the rate includes cost of road transport of the items.

In some cases, HLL might also need to send kit by airfreight, which would cost more, said HLL sources. However, HLL letters to institutions state that if airfreight was required that would be “charged extra” to the institution placing the order.

HLL has also told institutions that they cannot order most components of the PPE kits separately, N95 masks being an exception. Thus institutions could get stand-alone consignments of N95 masks, which have the highest mark-up of 50%.

The letters also warns that since “there is acute shortage of the items in the market”, the price is highly volatile. If the purchase price changes, accordingly the final price will change, it added.

Many PPE kit component manufacturers, who are bearing the cost of transporting the finished items of PPE kits to collection centres identified by HLL, expressed surprise at the high mark-ups by HLL. Their contracts state that the price they are being paid by HLL includes transportation cost to collection centres. This has raised questions about how a public sector company can levy such high mark-ups on supplying to government institutions during a national health crisis. HLL has been under a cloud over recent controversies about lack of transparency in their procurement process.

"It is indefensible that the public sector company is making a high profit on supplying government health institutions during a national health emergency," said Malini Aisola of All India Drug Action Network ( AIDAN ).

Despite the high mark-ups, doctors in hospitals struggling to get PPE said that HLL prices are possible only because it is buying in such huge volumes, as the price of an N95 mask has shot up to more than Rs 200 in the open market and even at these prices it was difficult to find any.

Title: 743 beds for corona patients at railway hospitals in Patna districts
Content: PATNA: The East Central Railway (ECR) has reserved 743 beds at its hospitals in five divisional headquarters – Danapur, Mughalsarai, Dhanbad, Sonepur and Samastipur – for the treatment of coronavirus patients.ECR chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar said of the 743 beds, 645 have been segregated to quarantine the coronavirus-affected people and 98 will be used as isolation wards. “About 100 doctors and 250 paramedical staff, including nurses, are in readiness to render their services,” Kumar said, adding 347 other medical staff have been provided a comprehensive training to take care of the Covid-19 patients during isolation period.Kumar said 21 isolation beds have been set up at the Danapur railway hospital in Khagaul, 23 at Samastipur railway hospital, 18 at Dhanbad railway hospital, 16 at Sonepur, 10 at Mughalsarai and 10 at Hajipur. Danapur railway hospital has 316 additional beds to quarantine Covid-19 infected people. There are 196 such beds at the railway hospital in Dhanbad, 62 in Samastipur, 60 in Mughalsarai and 13 in Sonepur.According to the CPRO, the railways has also started counselling frontline railway staff, including track men, signal men, electrical men, water men and security personnel about precautionary measures required to be taken while performing essential services. These staff have also been told to maintain social distancing on duty and ensure full implementation of the safety guidelines and advisory issued by the Railway Board.Meanwhile, railways continued to run goods trains uninterrupted to maintain supply of essential commodities in the state during lockdown period. While 12 rakes of the goods trains reached different terminals located in the Danapur division on Saturday carrying essential commodities and medicines, altogether 200 rakes of the goods trains with consignments like coal, iron, wheat and other commodities left for far off places in the country from the ECR jurisdiction, the CPRO said, adding food packets for community service will now be prepared at the Rajendra Nagar base kitchen of the IRCTC for distribution among the needy people.

Title: Daily wagers want to come back home to Bihar
Content:
PATNA: Many migrant workers from Bihar stuck in different parts of the country have almost run out of food as well as money.

One Chandan Singh from Aman Nagar in Ludhiana told TOI over phone that eight from Bihar were stuck in their rented accommodation there. “After the lockdown, we are managing with one time meal to save our limited ration. Police gave us food at 11pm on Saturday after we informed them but we received nothing today. We also went to a langar nearby, but food exhausted quickly and we were unable to eat,” Singh from West Champaran said. He said around 100 youths from the district were facing the same situation and wanted to go back home.

“Several of them have left for Bihar on bicycles. We are also planning the same,” he added.

Omprakash Kumar from Buxar said on phone from Indira Nagar in Jodhpur that police were announcing about bus services being provided to them to reach Uttar Pradesh border. “They said we would be dropped at Bharatpur. We are worried that how to reach Bihar from there. We are now only left with rice, don’t know how we will manage in days to come,” he added.

Kundan Kumar from Vijay Nagar in Ghaziabad said he along with 70 others boarded a truck to reach Aurangabad in Bihar. “Each of us paid Rs1,000 to the truck driver. We are near Prayagraj. The truck would drop us on Bihar border,” he said, adding that community food was being provided to them at Vijay Nagar but supply was irregular and the system was to pick up food and eat.

Meanwhile, CPI-ML state secretary Kunal, in a press statement, said many of the daily wagers from Bihar were facing hunger.

Meanwhile, additional chief secretary (home) Amir Subhani said the government was thinking of fixing a deadline for people to reach Bihar from other states.

Title: Man violates quarantine, booked
Content:
Vadodara: An offence was registered against a man from Dahod for breaking home quarantine directives. The man had returned from Dubai and was asked to stay in isolation at home for two weeks.

Kamlesh Bamaniya, a resident of Kharoda village of Dahod district, had returned from Dubai on March 19. Initially, he came to Vadodara and then went to Kharoda. He was advised home quarantine and health teams used to keep a tab on his health. On Friday Bamaniya had left home and had gone to different villages in Garbada taluka. On Saturday too, he had gone to Rentiya village where he was confronted by health workers. An offence was registered against him and he has been sent to a quarantine facility in Dahod.

Title: Migrant workers start walking towards their homes in UP & MP
Content:
Aurangabad: On Sunday, several groups of industrial and construction workers, who were employed in Waluj and other areas in the region, were spotted walking back to their homes of Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh.

One group of 20 people, including women and children hailing from Khandwa in Madhya Pradesh, will have to cover more than 350 km on foot. The group began their walk on Sunday morning after the contractor who had brought them to Aurangabad said he will not be able to feed or pay them during the lockdown.

Locals and some policemen on duty were seen handing out food packets to the families.

Some workers, who had reached Abdimandi after walking about 30km, were provided assistance by Daultabad-based journalist Kishore Patil, who along with the village’s deputy sarpanch Ismail Pathan, made provisions for food packets and water. Police personnel from Waluj police station, led by inspector Sandeep Gurme, also helped arrange food packets for the group migrant workers. They were seen helping stranded truck drivers. Similar scenes were seen across MIDC Waluj and Chikalthana police station limits.

Many other groups of workers were seen passing through Aurangabad and making their way towards highway stretches in Nagpur, Solapur and Beed to get out of Maharashtra.

Senior authorities said the groups are mostly of daily wagers who have been left without any pay during the lockdown.

The Centre has urged state governments to ensure housing or temporary shelters for those trying to get home. The states have also been told to quarantine these workers for a minimum of 14 days.

There was also an advisory ordering employers not to cut or stop wages of these workers during the lockdown. But at many places, contractors have not paid the workers.

Title: Social media usage jumps 87% as people spend over 4 hours daily
Content:
Chennai: The first week of lockdown saw Indians spend more than 280 minutes a day on social media, a spike of 87% over the previous week, as people remained indoors. Streaming platforms and televisions also saw a rise in viewership, while out-of-home (OOH) media and radio were neglected, according to a survey.

Social media usage, on average, before the lockdown was nearly 150 minutes per day. In the first week of lockdown, that figure jumped to 280 minutes per day, with 75% people spending more time on apps like WhatsApp, Twitter and Facebook compared to the week before. The survey respondents said they accessed social media often to consume news, and to communicate amid the lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic.

According to the Hammerkopf Consumer Snapshot Survey conducted on March 28 across 1,300 people in New Delhi, Mumbai, Bengaluru and Chennai. Over-the-top (OTT) media consumption too saw a spike, with 71% people watching more than a week ago. The prime time for streaming platforms this week began at 7pm, unlike a week before, when it was between 10pm and 12am. Meanwhile, 76% of those surveyed said they watched TV in the morning between 8am and 9am.

The study was aimed at capturing behavioural change in digital media consumption, as India stayed indoors.

“Undoubtedly, when we look back at the coronavirus pandemic, we will clearly see two distinct time periods: An India before the virus, and a new one in the post-virus era. The digital habits are undergoing a dramatic change, with a fresh slew of consumer apps, benefiting from strong network effects, in communication, entertainment, food and fitness, and enabling Indians like never before,” said Namagiri Anand, managing partner, Hammerkopf, a firm that is engaged in analysing emerging technology shifts.

“During this unprecedented situation and lockdown across various parts of the country, we want to be sure that we don’t devoid our audiences of their daily dose of entertainmen,” Tarun Katial, CEO, Zee5 India, said the platform has witnessed an increase in over 80% in subscription and over 50% in watch time in the last five days.

Meanwhile, there was also a rise in the number of people downloading cooking guides (89%) as compared to health and fitness apps (88%), and edtech apps (88%).

“Given the changing consumer pivot to new digital media, we are advising our clients to leverage the new opportunities. In the new homebound economy, brands are in a position to gain consumer mindshare and confidence, by being infotaining and informative, and, by being creative and connecting. Brands that are proactive and ahead of the curve will survive in the times ahead,” added Namagiri.

Prior to the lockdown, the peak time for smartphone usage was during work (41%), and at night (31%), with moderate usage in morning and early evening. With work-from-home being implemented by several companies, last week, smartphone usage during work surged to 62%, with moderate rise in the rest of the day.

Internet browsing too saw of 72% spike, compared to a week ago, with people turning to it for information and news amid the Covid-19 outbreak.

With the lockdown in place, impacting commute, related media consumption lost significantly. While radio and music streaming consumption saw a significant decline this week with 89% of those surveyed said they listened to it less often, compared to a week ago, OOH media lost more eyeballs this week, with 91% of consumers seeing less billboards compared to a week ago.

Title: Evening rains again raise corona fears
Content:
Nagpur: In the second spell of heavy showers in a span of three days, the city received 3.8mm rain on Sunday. The rainfall started in the evening and continued till around 8.30pm in some parts.

While the surprise showers were a welcome respite with the weather turning pleasant, it once again created tension among citizens with the chances of spread of viral infections being more in this weather, as per doctors.

Sunday’s rains were accompanied by gusty winds at many places in Vidarbha. According to the officials of Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC), Nagpur, the region is expected to witness more rains in the coming two days.

“A trough extending at 0.9 km above sea level from north Kerala to south Chhattisgarh across Marathwada, Vidarbha and Karnataka caused the rainfall,” officials said.

They added that some parts of the region might experience light rainfall on Monday and Tuesday.

Wani in Yavatmal was the wettest in the region with 15.3mm rain. Other parts of the region like Akola, Chandrapur and Washim too received rainfall.

Despite rains, the mercury was on the higher side. Nagpur recorded a maximum temperature of 37.6 degree Celsius on Sunday. Akola was the hottest at 38.8 degree Celsius.

Stating that virus can survive for longer duration in humid weather, doctors have advised people to stay indoors.

Title: IGGMCH, GMCH start Covid-19 OPD; latter begins freeing up beds
Content: Nagpur: Both Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital ( IGGMCH ) and Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) have started separate Covid-19 out-patient departments (OPDs) from Monday.At IGGMCH, the Covid-19 OPD is running at the old casualty ward while it is near casualty ward at GMCH. The suspected cases are being checked for fever. Doctors said in case they fit the criteria, the patients are moved to the isolation wards for further investigation.Earlier, the suspected cases were directly taken to the isolation ward where positve patients too were admitted. This led to three patients fleeing the wards even while their test results were awaited.GMCH has also started taking measures to free up beds occupied by recovered patients. As of Wednesday, GMCH had 70 additional beds for corona positive cases. Doctors said other patients who have recovered are being asked to take discharge.Earlier, such patients would seek additional hospital stay. Mayo and GMCH beds are occupied by patients admitted by police or social workers. When they recover, they continue to stay back as most are destitute or can’t recall their names and addresses. But, with number of accidents going due to the lockdown, inflow of such patients has already dropped.While IGGMCH authorities said they had sufficient beds for Covid-19 patients, GMCH had been keeping track of all such patients who could be advised discharged at the earliest since January.Three major focus areas are ensuring enough N95 masks, more ICU beds and freeing up beds occupied by recovered patients.They said GMCH has got 1,000 washable cloth masks stitched to be used in general OPDs. This will preserve N95 masks that are actually needed by doctors and paramedics working in isolation wards.GMCH is also in the process of setting up 150 ICU beds in a new building near the superintendent’s office. Another 50 ICU beds will be available at a ward that will be converted into isolation facility as per need.Doctors said 70 beds were already available at Ward 49 and 25 after advising “delayed patients” to take discharge.“Looking at best clinical scenario and without causing any damage to patient’s health, these beds were vacated at the earliest,” they said.

Title: When education goes virtual
Content:
Ahmedabad: No student is allowed to miss Prof Nigam Dave’s lectures at SLS, PDPU – even when it happens online.

“With advanced tools embedded on platforms such as Zoom online classes, Canvas or Google classroom, we can capture screenshots or gather data on students’ engagements during the virtual classrooms,” said Prof Dave, director of SLS, PDPU. “Discussion forums and assignments have also gone online completely.”

The Covid-19 global pandemic has changed the way several sectors work, perhaps forever, and one of the most obvious fields is education. More and more institutes have switched to online mode during the national lockdown. In the premier educational institutes in Ahmedabad and Gandhinagar, virtual is the new normal for both lectures and evaluation.

Chirayu Bhatt, deputy provost (academics) at Cept University, said that several online platforms are utilized to connect faculties and students for studios. “All sessions are being conducted according to scheduled time slots in the regular semester. Students also interact with faculties in real time, completing the online class experience,” he said. “One-on-one video conferencing is also taking place to provide feedback on student projects.”

At MICA, the annual curriculum presentation to the second-year students of PGP course was made online where the faculty members presented their proposed elective courses and held a discussion. “Respective instructors have volunteered to design online examinations for their courses and the examinations are in progress. Assignments, which are part of planned evaluations, are to be submitted online,” said a MICA official.

Soman Nair, registrar of DA-IICT, Gandhinagar, said that there are several ongoing research projects where students and faculty members collaborate. “Our PG curriculum relies heavily on research work. In this lockdown period, the students and faculty members are collaborating online to work on research papers and simulations where labs are not required. Online meetings are conducted for the same,” he said.

Title: Kolkata’s 1st Covid-19 patient, two others on recovery path
Content: KOLKATA: Amidst the increasing number of Covid-19 positive cases in the state, three infected patients who had been under treatment are on the path to recovery. The swab samples of the trio have tested negative to the virus in the first test conducted during treatment. However, doctors at ID Hospital, where the three are admitted, said their samples will go through another round of assessment before they are declared free of the virus. They will continue to be treated at the hospital till they test negative in the second confirmatory test.“Two consecutive reports have to confirm that the patient is negative to the virus. The first test can show a sample negative to Covid-19 due to intermittent shedding of the virus. In that case, the consecutive test might show positive. That is why a second test is necessary,” said a doctor.The first patient to test negative was the Oxford-returned 18-year-old boy who tested positive on March 18. The other two were a 22-year-old youth from Ballygunge and a 23-year-old woman from Habra. The two returned from London and Scotland, respectively, and had tested positive to Covid-19 on March 20 and 21.“A hard-working and dedicated medical team is taking care of the Covid-19 patients in our hospital. Though the three have to undergo another round of tests, we are hopeful of their complete recovery. Once the second test confirms they are negative to the virus, we will be ready to send them home, following protocol,” said Anima Haldar , principal of Infectious Diseases and Beliaghata General Hospital.The trio had to be given only supportive medicine to treat their symptom. “The good thing about these three patients is that they are young and none showed any aggressive symptom during treatment,” said another doctor.Though none of the positive patients are critical, doctors are concerned with the 76-year-old woman from Egra who tested positive on Saturday and was subsequently admitted. She had attended a wedding with a 56-year-old woman and a 66-year-old man, who also tested positive to Covid-19. The 66-year-old was admitted to Peerless Hospital and is responding to the treatment of Covid-19-induced pneumonia. His urine output had been low on Saturday night, indicating a kidney problem. But there has been improvement with medication. Doctors, however, said his condition was still critical.“There is no new infection in the lungs and no increase in demand for oxygen. The patient is also maintaining blood pressure and his urine output is improving. But despite the marginal improvement, his condition remains critical,” said Sudipta Mitra of Peerless Hospital.The two women were brought to ID Hospital on Sunday. Immediate family members of the 66-year-old Nayabad resident have, however, tested negative to the virus.

Title: Union Bank MD: Focus is on zero disturbance
Content:
What can customers and employees of merging banks expect when they visit the bank on April 1?

What are your plans given the uncertainty caused by the Covid-19 outbreak and the lockdown?

Will officers of the merging banks continue to have the same authority as before in all matters?

What about the head office functions of the treasury?

What is your continuity plan if the situation worsens?

Will there be any transfers?

MUMBAI: From April 1, Mangalore-based Corporation Bank and Hyderabad-headquartered Andhra Bank will merge into Union Bank. The merger , which was announced and planned last year, comes into effect amid the Covid-19 lockdown. In an interview with TOI, Union Bank MD & CEO Rajkiran Rai explains how the focus is on zero disruption.Customers will see the same branch and the same staff. The systems and processes will be the same. In the case of Union Bank, since all account numbers are unique, all customers will retain their account number after the merger. Internet banking portals and mobile banking apps will continue to operate separately. Deposit products may change slightly, but it will not make any difference to staff in terms of data input. Every branch has been linked to a ‘buddy branch’ of Union Bank for any assistance. A microsite has also been developed for employees with the facility to gets queries addressed.It is difficult to answer this when there is no good view of the future and a lot of things are not in control. Right now, the focus is on how to protect staff and keep branch operations going. As far as the amalgamation is concerned, the focus is on zero disturbance for customers and keeping staff comfortable so that operations continue. For the future, we do have a business plan, but there will not be any strategy meeting now. The biggest variable is the Covid virus. How long will the lockdown continue? How long will it take for a business to come back? We need to assess the damage that has taken place and look at different sectors, what kind of restructuring is required, what is the funding requirement. Even the RBI policy focus has been on preventing default and maintain the status quo for three months. On the back-end, there is work going on for integration, so that when things normalise, we can go ahead with amalgamation.As far as sanctions are concerned, we have maintained status quo by retaining the reporting authority structure. Up to the level of the GM, there will be no change. If approval beyond the GM is required, each GM’s reporting is now mapped to one of the four EDs in Union Bank. As far as rules regarding branch operations are concerned, each state has a different system and the state-level bankers’ committee takes a call on operations and timing. Over 90% of branches are operating, except in some pockets of Rajasthan and Punjab. There, too, we are in discussions with authorities to restart.We have integrated the treasuries and all treasury operations will be undertaken from Union Bank of India. Two other locations we have kept as backup as part of our business continuity plan if there is a complete shutdown for any reason.We had a couple of cases where the branch was shut by authorities and staff quarantined. We are drawing up district-level lists of healthcare and testing facilities that will be available to branch staff. If the situation continues and people are unable to travel, we will allow them to report to the nearest branch.We will not be doing any transfers now. There will be some transfers at a senior level in the future. Where employees who have been transferred out of their home state have completed their term, we are allowing the transfer orders to be issued with a condition that they would not be relieved for a month, which could get extended to two.

Title: Sidbi offers cheap loans to some companies
Content: MUMBAI: Small Industries Development Bank of India has launched ‘Sidbi assistance to facilitate emergency response against coronavirus (SAFE)’, a scheme through which businesses can get loans up to Rs 50 lakh at 5% interest rate. Sidbi , which has been set up by the government for promotion, financing and development of micro and small Enterprises (MSEs), has promoted this scheme specifically for small companies that are manufacturing products or offering services to fight the coronavirus pandemic.Small businesses engaged in manufacturing of hand sanitisers , masks, gloves, headgear, bodysuits, shoe-covers, ventilators , goggles, and testing labs can avail collateral-free loans up to Rs 50 lakh at a fixed interest rate of 5% for up to 5 years. These are collateral-free loans and can be sanctioned within 48 hours of applying and submission of documents.“In a situation which the country is going through right now, we felt that there is a need to immediately support and encourage those MSEs that are helping the country fight the menace,” said Mohammad Mustafa, chairman, Sidbi. The scheme will fund the purchase of equipment, plant, and machinery or raw material required for production or delivery of services. The loans will be disbursed through a digital interface and MSEs can apply for the loan online itself.

Title: No dance of ‘nagar vadhus’ at Manikarnika
Content:
Varanasi: The land of Lord Shiva, where even death is celebrated, will not be holding its age-old tradition of nagar vadhus (sex workers) performing on the banks of the Ganga this year due to corona threat.

Every year on the 7th night of Chaitra Navratra, ‘nagar vadhus’ of the city used to gather at Manikarnika Ghat and dance till midnight amid burning pyres after offering prayers to Mahashmashan Nath, the Lord of cremation ground.

But this year, the 7th night of Navratra on March 31, will miss the celebration due to the nation-wide lockdown to check the spread of coronavirus. The unique celebration has been an attraction for local residents as well as foreigners.

“As the entire country is in lockdown to break the chain of Covid-19, this celebration has been cancelled,” said temple manager Gulshan Kapoor.

However, the three-day ‘Shringar Mahotsava’ of Baba Mahashmashan Nath symbolically started on the 5th day of Chaitra Navratra on Sunday with vedic rituals and recital of Sunderkand of Ramcharitmanas. It would be followed by a special puja on Monday praying for the end of corona virus and a tantric puja on Tuesday.

“Since the country is under lockdown, all the programmes have been cancelled. Only temple priest Pt Lallu Maharaj and members of temple management will perform the rituals to maintain the tradition,” said Kapoor.

According to him, the tradition has been continuing for about five centuries after the Mahashamshan Nath temple at Manikarnika Ghat was renovated by Raja Sawai Man Singh of Amber, who had also built Man Mandir Ghat in 1585 near Dashshwamedh Ghat.

It is a common tradition to hold music programme on the inaugural day or special occasions. As the nagar vadhus offered their services on the inauguration of the temple, the tradition has been followed since then.

Title: Tuli college converts its premises off Koradi road into hostel for migrants
Content:
Nagpur: Tuli Public School, situated off Koradi road, has opened up its premises for migrant labourers who find themselves without any means of transportation to return back to their villages. From Monday onwards, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) will start shifting migrant labourers to the premises where almost 300 people can be accommodated.

Mohabbat Singh Tuli, the school’s owner, said, “On Sunday, the cops came and inspected the place and tomorrow, NMC officials will send the first batch of migrant labourers. My son Vikram and I wanted to help those who are struggling in the current situation. All arrangements are being made so that these people do not suffer during this long lockdown.”

It all started a few days ago when Tuli was near his resort at Deolapar. “On the highway I saw so many workers walking or cycling. They said that they can’t stay in Nagpur hence were heading back to their villages in Madhya Pradesh. Imagine walking for hours, even days, with children in tow.”

Tuli immediately rushed back to his resort where they cooked food and came back on the highway. “We started a langar at the bus shelter on the highway. We not only fed people, but also told them to take parcels. After that I decided that my resorts, school and colleges will now be offered to the government as shelter homes. NMC has now decided to make use of the school building and we are glad to be of help,” said Tuli.

Urvashi Yashroy, director of Tuli Group of Educational Institutes, said, “We had initially planned accommodation only for women from the migrant community, but the authorities gave us feedback that only families will come. So we are going by what NMC is saying and by Monday, or at the most by Tuesday, we will be fully operational.”

Title: Zoho accuses Freshworks of stealing, misusing information
Content:
Chennai: In an ugly battle between Zoho and Freshworks, the poster boys of SaaS in Chennai, Zoho has filed a lawsuit against Freshworks accusing the latter of attempting to poach customers, steal and misuse confidential information.

The lawsuit filed at the US district court, Northern district of California says that Freshworks has breached 2 acts - including Defence of Trade Secrets Act and California Uniform Trade Secrets Act. “Freshworks is contacting Zoho’s Partners and asking them to convert to Freshworks’ Partner programs,” the suit said.

Founded by two former Zoho employees, Girish Mathrubootham (formerly a VP of product management at Zoho) and Shan Krishnasamy (formerly a Zoho Technical Architect working under Mathrubootham), Freshworks secured initial funding through use of Zoho’s non-public financial information and has since engaged in a systematic practice of poaching Zoho’s employees, using Zoho’s confidential customer and competitive marketing information, planning press releases to coincide with Zoho’s undisclosed product launch dates, and pressuring Zoho’s business partners to divulge Zoho confidential customer information, Zoho contended in the lawsuit whose copy was accessed by TOI. Among other allegations, Zoho said that after leaving to start Freshworks, Mathrubootham improperly included Zoho confidential revenue figures in early Freshworks investor pitch materials to secure initial investments, leveraging his work at Zoho and suggesting his new start-up would perform like Zoho. “As recently as February 24, Freshworks has been systematically contacting Zoho’s customers using Zoho confidential information. In some of these instances, Freshworks contacted Zoho’s customers at email addresses the customers created solely for registration with Zoho’s cloud-based offerings. The only way Freshworks would have knowledge of the email addresses it used to contact Zoho’s customers is through unauthorized direct access of Zoho’s confidential CRM database,” a statement from Zoho said in the lawsuit.

In a statement to TOI, Zoho said that it had compelling evidence that Freshworks has stolen customer data from Zoho and attempted to contact its customers. “We are investigating the extent of the data theft. In order to protect customer data, we were compelled to immediately sue Freshworks to stop their illegal and immoral behaviour” the statement said.

Freshworks added that they are taking the allegations seriously and are planning to defend themselves.

Title: More foreign returnees in Patna to undergo test
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Amid increase in number of coronavirus cases , the state health department on Sunday decided to test blood samples of all those who came to Bihar from foreign countries on or after March 18. The details of those who came to the state from abroad between March 10 and March 18 will be verified.

Earlier, samples of only symptomatic people were being sent for test. State health department principal secretary Sanjay Kumar said now samples of those who came to the state on or after March 18 will be tested. “We will first start with those who came to the state on or after March 21,” he added.

Sources in the health department said the move would help trace the Covid-19 suspect.

Bihar on Sunday not only reported four fresh cases, but also witnessed maximum number of passengers enrolling for observation in a day. According to state health department, 469 people were put under observation on Sunday, taking total number of such people to 2,376.

Title: Bihar government in dilemma over prisoners’ release on parole
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: The prisons department is in a dilemma over how to release undertrial jail inmates on parole amid complete lockdown.

The Supreme Court had issued orders that state governments should consider releasing undertrials, whose offences attract seven years or less imprisonment. The order was issued to decongest the jails in the wake of Covid-19, but a nationwide lockdown was enforced thereafter.

Prisons sources said around 9,000 undertrials in state jails come under the category to get relief in form of parole in the present situation. Home department collected a data from all prisons on Wednesday and Thursday.

Sources said a high-level meeting was held between additional chief secretary (home) Amir Subhani and IG (prisons and correctional services) Mithilesh Mishra on Saturday on the issue of releasing prisoners on parole, but no concrete decision was taken immediately due to several practical problems, which might further aggravate the situation.

A senior IAS officer of home department said now the state government will take a call as how to release prisoners as a precautionary measure. “There are several practical problems in releasing undertrial inmates. One is that how they will reach home as there is no transport facility available. Several times prisoners are shifted from one jail to another in different districts. Amid such a scenario, how will one be able to reach home in another district,” he said.

The officer said the matter has further complicated as the state government has decided to quarantine migrant workers coming home from different districts in special camps on state borders. “Then how prisoners can be allowed to go home. Separate yardsticks could not be used,” he said.

Meanwhile, a central jail superintendent, preferring anonymity, said several undertrials are senior citizens and it would be risky if they have to walk for several kilometres to reach home after getting released from jail.

At present, there are eight central and 32 district jails besides 17 subjails and one open jail in Bihar with total sanctioned capacity of around 43,000 inmates against which around 40,000 are in prisons. However, some of the jails are overcrowded.

Title: FIR against Muzaffarpur labour superintendent
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Muzaffarpur district magistrate has ordered to lodge an FIR against the district labour superintendent for not only defying the orders of the state government in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak but also for his misconduct with serving public servants.

The FIR has been lodged with the Town police station at Muzaffarpur under sections 2,3,4 of Epidemic Disease Act, 1897. City SP Neeraj Kumar Singh confirmed that the FIR was lodged against the labour superintendent on the directive of the DM.

In addition, the DM, Chandra Shekhar Singh , has recommended suspension of the labour superintendent, Vivek Kumar , and initiate a departmental proceedings against him for remaining absent in an official meeting to assess the situation. “Vivek is staying in Patna ever since lockdown announced in the state on March 23. He didn’t attend the meeting held on Saturday to review the situation and told the officials concerned that he wouldn’t come to Muzaffarpur come what may,” the DM added.

According to a letter sent to the labour department, copies of which have also been addressed to the commissioner of Tirhut division , the labour superintendent was deputed at the control room on the Sadar hospital premises to monitor the return of migrant labourers to Bihar from outside the state.

The DM said that Vivek left the district headquarters without any prior approval and had not applied for leave. “The official leaves of the government employees have been cancelled . But the labour superintendent continues to stay in Patna without sanctioned leave,” he added.

Title: Three kilometre containment zone at Khemnichak
Content: PATNA: The district administration has created a containment zone in the three-kilometre radius of a private hospital at Khemnichak on Bypass Road where the Covid-19 victim from Munger had gone for treatment. Several localities in the neighbourhood of Khemnichak fall under the containment zone.Two employees of the hospital had been tested positive for coronavirus . A woman relative of one of the hospital staff was also tested positive. The hospital was sealed on Friday.Patna deputy development commissioner (DDC) Richie Pandey said there are at least 2,000 houses in the containment zone. “We are trying to identify people suffering from normal flu like symptoms or acute respiratory syndrome in the locality so that they could be isolated,” the DDC said, adding door-to-door survey is being conducted in the containment zone.“Teams of WHO and health department officials, including doctors and auxiliary nurses, are involved in the survey,” he said.Pandey added that the Patna Municipal Corporation has been urged to disinfect the area. “A sector magistrate has been deployed in the area to for strict enforcement of lockdown,” he said.

Title: Dispose of biomedical waste through CBWTF, says Bihar State Pollution Control Board
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: In a bid to ensure safe disposal of biomedical waste generated during treatment and diagnosis of coronavirus patients, the Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) has issued certain guidelines prescribed by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB).

In a letter to all the district magistrates, Alok Kumar, member secretary of BSPCB, said biomedical waste generated from quarantined camps/homes should be properly treated and disposed of through the common biomedical waste treatment facilities (CBWTFs).

He instructed the urban local bodies to ensure engagement of CBWTF for disposal of biomedical waste. “Biomedical waste should be collected separately in yellow bags provided by CBWTF. These bags can be placed in separate and dedicated dustbins of appropriate size,” Alok said.

The Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) has decided to start distribution of yellow bags to households in next two days. “The yellow bags are being prepared by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Bihar,” said Harshita, public relations officer of.

Dr Bimal Karak, superintendent of Patna Medical College and Hospital , said, “We first burn the biomedical waste and other things used by the Covid-19 suspects and then bury the residue by digging a hole in the backyard of the hospital.”

Dr Nirmal, superintendent of NMCH, said biomedical waste used by doctors are currently put in a separate red dustbin.

Title: ‘Involve senior doctors too’
Content: PATNA: Junior doctors at Nalanda Medical College and Hospital (NMCH) have urged the state government to rope in senior doctors of other medical college and hospitals to handle Covid-19 cases. The NMCH has been made the state’s dedicated Covid-19 hospital with around 700 beds for such patients. “Junior residents, postgraduate medical students and interns have been put on the front line instead of senior and experienced doctors,” said a junior doctor.In a letter to the health department principal secretary, NMCH Junior Doctors’ Association said senior doctors of Patna Medical College and Hospital Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences and other government medical college and hospitals as well as private hospitals should join the fight against coronavirus . “Junior doctors should be kept on standby,” it said.

Title: E-tail to take $1 billion hit in lockdown
Content:
More on

BENGALURU: The 21-day lockdown will lead to a loss of at least $1 billion in gross sales as India’s largest online retail platforms like Amazon and Flipkart stop selling non-essentials till at least the middle of next month, based on current government directives. What’s of further concern is that the online retail players are expected to grow only by 5% this year, in the most optimistic scenario, compared to about 26% growth in the previous year to reach $23-24 billion in gross sales. Overall e-commerce sales, including movie tickets and other platforms, was $32 billion in 2019, according to market research firm Forrester’s data exclusively shared with TOI.While online grocery is seeing a spike in orders, it constitutes only about 10% of overall sales for e-tailers. Last year, e-grocery sales stood at about $2 billion. Online platforms see $50-60 million in daily sales around this time of the year, which for several players is down to zero. Smartphones, large appliances, electronics and fashion are the top drivers of gross sales for e-tailers, contributing 60-70% of the total. To be sure, these data points are based on current circumstances and may evolve further, for better or worse, based on how India manages to deal with the pandemic.“If they (online retailers) can grow by 5% this year, they should feel lucky. Even after the lockdown ends, consumer spending will be hit. Even with EMI waivers, people will push many of their spendings to next year,” said Satish Meena, senior forecast analyst at Forrester. According to Meena, retail sales in China were down 21% in the last two months and e-commerce sales grew by only 3%, but grocery is a big part of online sales in the country, unlike India.Investors tracking the space feel the April-June quarter could be a washout for the sector. Some e-commerce executives said that electronics and other items would also need to be allowed for deliveries if the lockdown lasts longer than April 14 as the groceries segment by itself is not sustainable in terms of margins. Some sector-focused e-tailers like fashion website Myntra and baby care products seller FirstCry have stopped taking new orders. Others such as beauty products seller Purplle and furniture seller Pepperfry are taking fresh orders but offering delivery only after April 15.Even before the outbreak of the coronavirus , overall consumer spending was muted owing to broader economic challenges. But the virus spreading at this pace brought online commerce to a screeching halt. Last year, 140 million Indians shopped online at least once, according to Forrester. This might not grow significantly in 2020 even though online grocery and medicine delivery platforms are seeing new customers sign up.“During a meeting for 2020 projections at the end of 2019, Amazon India leadership team was told about economic and policy challenges in India, which might be a hindrance to growth. The mandate was to grow despite those issues. But now, with Covid-19, it looks virtually impossible,” an Amazon executive recently told TOI when the number of confirmed cases started to rise in India. Flipkart and Amazon India spokespersons declined to comment.Investors said that the next few months will be tough for the business and there will be a slowdown in discretionary spends even after a potential recovery. But the development could increase penetration of online shopping, like in grocery, which has largely remained offline till now. “There will be some permanent behavioural change in consumers due to coronavirus and they will come back after getting used to purchasing online, especially for must-have categories,” said T C M Sundaram, MD at venture capital firm Chiratae Ventures.

Title: Making sure their blood remains pure
Content:
Nagpur: Lockdown is throwing many challenges for those who need to visit hospitals regularly for blood transfusion or kidney dialysis. While travelling for medical purpose is not banned, many patients find it difficult to get any means of public transport for this. Kidney patients in particular, who are already at high risk for covid-19 due to their low immunity, find it risky to take an autorickshaw or cab. Amid all this, a young entrepreneur has emerged as a hero for hundreds of such patients who need kidney dialysis regularly.

Prashant Nair has already established a brand MyCapello, a chain of luxury salons in Nagpur. Recently, he started a new venture Laundryfy which provides free pick-up and drop service for your laundry. Nair had to discontinue this service during lockdown. But, he decided to dedicate his resources to a constructive work.

“I came to know from a friend based in Mumbai that kidney patients need to visit the urology center for regular dialysis. Public transport is not available at hand, and not every patient has his/her own vehicle. So, we decided to drive in our vehicles for such people,” Nair said.

Laundryfy has Maruti Vans with drivers and a manager who handles their movement. This entire set-up used to deal with house-to-house collection and delivery of laundry. Now, they are free. So, Nair converted this vehicle into a transport service for kidney patients.

“We consulted with senior nephrologists in the city and fully sanitized our car. Drivers were trained to follow safety practices. I also got permission to commute kidney patients in this van from Amabazari police,” said Nair. After completing all legal formalities, Nair launched this free service on March 27. He received 10 phone calls on March 28 and he completed all requests.

“We are offering free pick-up and drop facility to people in need of dialysis. The facility will be provided from 10am to 8pm till April 14, the last day of lockdown. All you have to do is call our associate Girish on mobile number 9607979797 and the van will reach your doorsteps to help you,” Nair said.

This van has police permissions for commuting people. It’s safe for kidney patients as the vehicle is regularly sanitized. “Our drivers are trained to deliver and pick-up at least 30 orders daily. I think we can provide service to least 20 patients a day,” he said. Nagpur has around 600 patients who need regular dialysis.

Nephrologist Dr Dhananjay Ookalkar, who welcomed the first patient through this free service on March 28, said that it’s a commendable job. “We have many patients who come from poor families. They used to come by autorickshaws or buses. But, it’s not safe for them amidst coronavirus threat. Such sanitized vans will reduce their risk,” he said.

Moreover, the service is free. So, poor patients will benefit a lot,” he said.

Title: Despite ban, stream of migrants continues to flow into MP
Content:
CORONA VIRUS AND OLD MAN INDORA SQUARE

Khawasa (Madhya Pradesh): It was raining and the scene at Madhya Pradesh-Maharashtra border here reminded of footages from Partition time or some international refugee crisis. A day after Maharashtra government issued directions to bar the movement of migrant labourers from the state while promising them food and shelter, the exodus continued. The migrating groups had infants, children and even elderly with them.

Migrant workers poured into MP on foot, bicycles, and even stuffed in coal dumpers and goods containers. TOI travelled 80 kms to Khawasa, the entry point to Madhya Pradesh on Seoni/Jabalpur road on Sunday.

The order on restricting movement was issued from Maharashtra side on Saturday. MP side had no communication about it. Finally at 5pm, after 5,000 had already crossed, Khawasa checkpoint got an order to stop. The entry was stopped right then. A couple of bikers who were stopped begged with folded hands to be allowed to go. The officials relented as six more containers and trailers passed in next one hour. Each one had at least 60 persons.

Khawasa is one of the two major entry points to Madhya Pradesh from Maharashtra. The highest traffic was from here.

From Nagpur to Khawasa, TOI could spot at 1500-2000 migrants. These included people stuffed in two coal dumpers three mini trucks, one container and scores on foot at every kilometre. They included casual labourers, those working on Samruddhi Expressway or ones with WCL.

Most were going to Balaghat, Seoni and Jabalpur in MP but a sizeable number was heading further to Uttar Pradesh too. Despite ban from the Maharashtra side, the flow continued unrestricted. Although TOI saw the Maharashtra police stopping a family coming from Madhya Pradesh as they had home quarantine stamp on their hands. There was no bar on Madhya Pradesh bound traffic.

The officials at Khawasa checkpoint accepted the situation was out of control. Social distancing norms were forgotten by both the workers and officials. An official of Madhya Pradesh state public service said the exodus began from March 21 and so far 30,000 had crossed over from Khawasa checkpoint alone.

MP officials had parked buses to take them further inside. Officials said they had run short of buses and even private containers and trucks passing from the highway were asked to accommodate passengers. TOI saw workers from a bus being made to alight and as ked to get inside a container. It was bound for Delhi, which gave hope to those heading towards UP. After some truckers dropped the workers mid way, cops began accompanying each vehicle.

At the checkpoint each one was scanned for temperature and other symptoms but none was found with any symptom. From Khawasa it was another 100 kms to the districts like Balaghat and Seoni. From there vehicles of respective districts take over. There is a strict vigil and even the villagers are not allowing migrants back without a stamp. The stamping is done at the villages, said an official at the checkpoint.

At Kamptee, TOI saw workers being stuffed in a coal dumper through a narrow opening in the rear. “We are providing free service,” said Chandan Singh who helped people board, along with his friends.

It was 2:30pm when Singh and his friends had dispatched five dumpers and five mini trucks as two more took off. A dumper had 70 persons and a truck carried 35. The dumpers were deployed in WCL. A few kms ahead, Gopi and 5-6 others managed to come over 40 kms on their bicycles as they waited to get in a truck or dumper after that.
