Rang Bahadur and 10 other working for Afcons, a company engaged in construction of Samruddhi Expressway, walked with shoes in their hand. They had started from Pulgaon and covered nearly 200km when TOI caught up with them. They were heading for their villages 50 kms away from Allahabad. Meaning another 800km. At 6.30pm they were seen nearing Khawasa border along with others.

Thousands housed in shelters

More than 13,000 migrant workers have been stopped from going and accommodated in shelters across Vidarbha as on Sunday morning, said the commissioners in-charge of Nagpur and Amravati divisions.

Sanjeev Kumar, divisional commissioner Nagpur, said there were 73 shelters in the division having 5500 persons. The migrant workers are being provided food and shelter with social distancing also being maintained. Apart from it, shelters are being run by NGOs and religious organizations too. Nagpur district alone had 16 shelters, he said.

In Amravati division, 8,000 persons were kept in various shelters. Amravati divisional commissioner Pravin Singh said, the division has districts bordering both Telangana and MP.

“We are retaining all workers of Samruddi Mahamarg and they have been asked to stay where they are,” Singh said.

The labouers heading from there or from Maharashtra towards Rajasthan or other states have been stopped too.

Areas like Burhanpur in Buldhana, Dharni in Melghat have borders with Maharashtra and Yavatmal borders Telangana.

Title: No entry: Kolhapur, Satara & Sangli dists seal borders
Content:
Kolhapur: In a serious response to the returning migrant workers, the local administration on Sunday announced that not a single person or vehicle would be allowed to enter the districts of Satara, Sangli and Kolhapur.

Satara district collector Shekhar Singh issued an order on Sunday morning, after which, the police presence was further strengthened at the district’s entry points. Singh also issued a warning that stated individuals trying to enter will face legal action.

Kolhapur district collector Daulat Desai has asked police superintendent Abhinav Deshmukh to take legal action against individuals caught violating lockdown orders to enter Kolhapur district. Desai said many people, particularly those employed in Pune and Mumbai, were currently making their way back into Kolhapur, which itself was illegal.

“I have ordered the police to arrest such people, confiscate their vehicles and to put them in institutional quarantine,” Desai said. The collector’s strict orders followed reports of people using emergency vehicles such as milk tankers and ambulances to enter the district.

District guardian minister Satej Patil also has asked the administration to use force, if necessary, to put those coming from Pune or Mumbai under institutional quarantine. Both Desai and Patil have said that strict measures are in place to limit transportation during the lockdown.

Desai went a step ahead to announce that legal action will also be taken against elected representatives who allow travel permits to individuals. “In such cases, the vehicle in use will also be confiscated,” he said.

Similar orders have been issued in Sangli and Solapur disricts. No one is allowed to leave the districts either. The Solapur administration has posted a special team to secure its border with Sangli because of the high number of cases detected there.

These orders are significant as Satara, Sangli, Kolhapur and Solapur districts have been experiencing large-scale reverse-migration, mostly of workers returning home from Pune and Mumbai.

Satara district collector Shekhar Singh told TOI that the number of people coming in has substantially dipped since the curbs on transport were put in place. He said the orders were issued to stop people from traveling during the lockdown.

Rough estimates reveal that nearly 90,000 people have entered Satara district over the past few days. A majority of them are registered with local authorities.

In Solapur district, around 40,000 people — many employed in Pune and Mumbai — have returned. In Kolhapur, that number is around 51,000. In the district of Sangli, estimates put the number of returned at around 40,000. All these people have been asked to quarantine themselves at home.

Title: Students living in hostels, on rent face survival challenge
Content:
Kolhapur: With exams deferred amid lockdown , students from rural areas studying in the city are facing grave inconvenience.

Karthik Patil, who is currently preparing for a civil service exam, is thinking of returning is hometown in Chandgad tehsil since he is unable to manage food and other essentials in the city. “I have small gas ylinder which needs to be refilled to cook food at home. Last month, I had bought the cylinder as there is no mess near my house. Now, the cylinder needs to be refilled. I had placed an order for the same at a local gas agency which is already facing delays in providing cooking gas to its regular customers.”

“The hotels are closed, mess services in the city have been shut and I have no relative in the city where I can stay for some time. My family members are ready to send a vehicle to take me back home. However, the authorities are not permitting us to do so," Karthik said.

He said that some of his friends managed to escape with the help of vehicles carrying vegetables and milk.

The district authorities have decided to act against such transporters. Owing to lockdown, the dates for competitive exams as well as college exams have been deferred. Students come to city to seek guidance for medical entrance as well as engineering entrance exam. The classes too have been closed. Teachers are sending notes and test papers through Whatsapp. Some coaching institutes have approached local NGO's to provide food to students. However, students live on rental basis at different places in the city and delivering food to each of them is a difficult task.

Working people who come to city every day from villages by public transport service too are facing problems.

Suvarna Kamble, a regular commuter from Chandgad, works for a legal firm in Kolhapur city. She was at the Central BUs Stand when the lockdown was announced. She was informed that al buses have been cancelled. She is currently staying at a women's hostel in the Takala area.

“I reached the bus stand a little late on the day when the lockdown was announced. My other colleagues left earlier and they could get on the bus. With the help of some local contacts, I am now staying in a women's hostel. There is no facility to cook and i am surviving with difficulties.”

Title: Bihar: Thousands screened, kept at special camps in border districts
Content: PATNA: Thousands of migrant workers reached Bihar from Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Punjab and Haryana and other states during the last 24 hours on Sunday. They were screened for Covid-19 symptoms and kept for 14 days in the ‘disaster relief camps’ set up by the state government in the border areas.Over 3000 daily wagers at Karmanasa checkpost in Kaimur and 5000 at the checkposts in Gopalganj, Saran and Siwan districts were screened after reaching there on way back home in Bihar.Additional chief secretary Amir Subhani said 2000-3000 workers of each district in the state were expected to return from outside in the next few days. “The state government is making arrangements for their stay and proper screening at the camps set up in the districts along the UP border,” Subhani said, adding that arrangements for migrant workers were being monitored from the state headquarters.Some migrant labourers created a scene at an isolation centre in Siwan to highlight the lack of basic facilities like drinking water, electricity and medicines. Those staying at the RBTS School camp in Siwan demanded immediate visit of senior administrative officers. Similar reports of ruckus created by workers poured in from Gopalganj also.“There is no electricity, drinking water and medicines,” a worker staying at the SS Balika School camp in Gopalganj district said.However, the situation was brought under control after BDO Dheeraj Dubey, CO Rakesh Kumar and SHO Manoranjan Kumar assured them to apprise the senior officers of their grievances. Earlier, 83 migrant workers were screened by a team led by pharmacist Arvind Kumar and medical officer Sabbir Ahmad.Sabbir said none of them have so far shown the coronavirus symptoms. “Yet they have been quarantined as per the directive of the state authority. They are under observation of a medical team. Free food and lodging facilities have been provided to them,” he said over phone.Most of them were stated to be residents of Sitamarhi, Madhubani, Siwan, Saran and Vaishali districts. Gopalganj DM Arshad Aziz said altogether nine camps have been set up in the district headquarters town. “The number of people returning home from outside has suddenly increased. Yet we are trying to cope with the situation at our level best,” he said.In Kaimur, a special camp has been set up near Karmanasa checkpost. Kaimur DM Nawal Kishore Choudhary said a magistrate, police force and a doctor with paramedical staff have been deputed at NHAI toll plaza near the UP border and migrant labourers on way back home were screened there.Around 3000 people reached the Karmanasa border in buses from Delhi and other places till Sunday morning. They are from Kaimur, Rohtas, Aurangabad, Nawada and Gaya districts. The DM said some of the workers also hailed from neighbouring Jharkhand . A group of 28 daily wagers had reached the border near Khajura from Delhi in a bus on Saturday evening. “Though they were screened earlier, medical test was conducted for the second time,” additional SDM of Mohania, Sanjeet Kumar , said.One Randhir Yadav, a bus driver, who carried 28 people of Koderma in Jharkhand, said he left Delhi around 2am on Saturday and reached Mohania where the district officials intercepted the bus on Sunday morning.A huge flux of migrant workers was seen on the UP border in Gopalganj district on Sunday. “People have reached more than expected from other states,” said a senior officer deputed at Gopalganj camp.The workers said that they wanted to go home. “We are facing hunger. We have neither money nor transportation facility to reach home,” said Sanjay Kumar from Sasamusa shelter camp in Gopalganj district.

Title: Good Samaritans, cops come to the rescue of needy in Patna
Content: PATNA: Several individuals and organisations in the city have come forward to help homeless people and jobless daily wagers amid lockdown to prevent spread of coronavirus Many Good Samaritans are taking initiatives to deliver essential commodities, such as milk, vegetables and grocery to people struggling to meet their basic needs. The district administration and police personnel are also extending support to the poor and daily wagers by supplying eatables and providing accommodation to the homeless.One Sharmila Agarwal, a resident of Exhibition Road, who has been providing home-cooked food to at least 100 homeless people since last four days along with her husband, said, “Several people, including rickshaw pullers, don’t have access to meals due to the sudden lockdown. We are trying our best to reach out to these people in our locality and provide them food,” she said.Another Good Samaritan, Kamal Nopany, is also providing free food to the destitute. “Around 350 families from Rajasthan and Haryana, who used to sell clothes on the roads, have become jobless and are on the verge of starvation at Karbigahiya. We distributed food packets to them. On Saturday, we gave them grocery items for one month. Since these people have kids with them, we will also provide milk to them,” he said.Nopany, who is also getting help from several NGOs and individuals, said he is being helped 21-year-old Vikas Surekha , who works throughout the day to help the poor in the city. “I feel shattered whenever I see poor people struggling for food. While most break down in front of us when we give them food packets, others shower us with blessing,” Vikas said.Social worker Mukesh Hisaria from Patna is providing necessary items and even transport facilities to financially weak people, who are facing difficulties in reaching riverbanks to perform last rites of the dead. Apart from this, he is also providing masks to the poor people. Patna district administration has also provided shelter to the homeless at various locations in the city. A district administration official said homeless people from Bihar and other states are being provided accommodation in schools. “The shelter homes have all basic facilities, including blankets, bed sheets and drinking water,” he said.Even the police personnel have extended their helping hands to the homeless. Cops can be seen supplying food to the poor and stranded people. Around 500 stranded daily wagers were provided lunch plackets by the police on Saturday alone.DSP (police lines) Ashish Singh said arrangements for food were made on the direction of SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma.SHO of Khagaul police station Mukesh Kumar Mukesh said the daily wagers, who were provided food in the city, hailed from Araia, Kishanganj, Jamui and some other districts. “They were provided ‘puri-sabji’ and other items,” he said.Patna SSP Sharma said food was being provided to stranded people by SHOs of Kadamkuan, Kotwali, Bypass and Kankarbagh police stations.

Title: Patna residents rue rise in prices, traders blame short supply
Content: PATNA: High prices of essential items continued to bother the residents on the 5th day of the nationwide lockdown due to Covid-19. Several shopowners said short supply of essential commodities was still a major concern, leading to price rise.The lockdown has adversely impacted the movement of trucks and other vehicles used to transport essential commodities such as foodgrains, spices, vegetables, fruits, medicines and other goods.Vishwajeet, a grocery shopowner on Boring Canal Road, said, “I have no control over the price. The demand of goods is high and the supply is low. We have increased the prices on pulses, flour and spices by 10% only, while the packaged food items were being sold at its original price. Even the supply in wholesale market is hit due to lockdown,” he said.Kishan Kumar, a vegetable seller at Bazar Samiti, said onion prices increased by Rs15 to Rs45/kg. “Potato is selling at Rs48/kg, brinjal Rs40, ginger Rs210/kg, cabbage Rs60 and cauliflower at Rs100. Since the public transport has been stopped, we find it difficult to bring the vegetables to market place from the wholesale mandis,” he said.“We have to bring all the vegetables on private cabs and they charge high rates. This forced us to increase the prices of vegetables,” Kishan added.Sonu Kumar, a fruit seller at Sabzibagh, said the police personnel stopped our pickup van at several points and extorted money from the drivers. “We are forced to increase the rate of apples, oranges, grapes and bananas, as we pay extra money for transporting fruits,” he said. Bihar Truck Owner’s Association’s president Bhanu Shekhar Prasad told this newspaper on Sunday that manufacturers, transporters, distributors, wholesalers or e-commerce companies are facing difficulties in transportation and distribution of goods.Rising prices are also affecting the kitchen budget during the ongoing lockdown period.Garima Singh, a homemaker from Rajendra Path area, said, “We are forced to cut down on meal as the prices of essential items are getting higher. We have prepared a diet chart so that we can eat more proteins and carbohydrates in meals.” Archana Gupta of Bank Road area said the unscrupulous shopkeepers were minting money in this situation in the name of shortage of essential goods. “The rate of 5kg of packed ground flour has increased to Rs300 from Rs180. These grocery shops are openly looting people even though the government assured that the supply of essential goods would not get affected,” said Anand Prakash of Rajiv Nagar.

Title: Coronavirus Cases in West Bengal: 12 of 21 Covid-19 patients are from three families
Content:
TimesView We seem to be entering a critical phase in our fight against this disease. So it is important that we do not repeat those mistakes that some of us made when the disease was yet to have a Bengal footprint. It is imperative that we stay careful and safe.

KOLKATA: More than half of Bengal’s Covid-19 patients till Sunday — 12 out of 21 — belong to three family clusters who were infected by individuals with a history of foreign travel, which underlines the importance of keeping social distance even at home. Three individuals who returned from the UK have transmitted the virus to 12 people in these clusters and led to the quarantine of 45 people, some of who have tested negative. Experts felt the number of infected could have been curbed had the families acted more responsibly and stuck to the distan-cing norms. Ballygunge youth who got infected in the UK — the first to test positive in the state on March 20 — spread the virus to his parents and a domestic help. Eleven members of the family were quarantined. A 67-year-old who tested positive last week had picked up the virus from a family member at a wedding in Egra. Later, two other members of the family tested positive. On March 27, five members of a family from Tehatta, who had been infected by a UK-returned relative at a gathering in Delhi, tested positive.Even though the norms had been laid down and an alert had been sounded throughout the country, none of these families bothered to follow them, rued virologist Amitabha Nandy.“They must have known that anyone returning from the UK was a suspect even if there were no symptoms. But they chose to ignore it and risked the lives of several around them. What’s more shocking is that they didn’t even care to insulate themselves from the suspect, resulting in a spread. Had they stuck to the home- quarantine rule, they could have prevented the transmission . It will now take a considerable effort to break the chain,” said Nandy.Once the quarantine norm and the rules of social distancing are flouted, transmission will be inevitable, making it difficult to trace those who have come in contact with the patient, said infectious diseases consultant Rahul Jain.“Some people tend to infect more than the rest. The ones that transmitted the virus in Bengal turned out to be effective spreaders. A Bollywood singer, though she had come in contact with several others, did not infect anyone. So there is no alternative to following the distancing norms at home,” said Jain.Amiya Hati, former director of School of Tropical Medicine, Kolkata, said, “Social distancing is a must at home too, especially when there is someone suffering from flu-like symptoms or someone who is asymptomatic but has come from an affected area.”“Everyone in these three clusters are educated and well informed. But they broke the guidelines and made mistakes. For example, in the Ballygunge case, the youth could have infected more people because of his movements after returning from London. Luckily, he infected only three. If we do not learn from such mistakes, more cluster infections will happen,” said pulmonologist Dhiman Ganguly, who is part of the 12-member expert committee set up by the state to combat Covid-19.“In the Tehatta case, the five infected had mingled with a US-returned relative who was in the risk category. Now, they may have infected others in Tehatta. Currently, we have identified 16 such high-risk contacts,” said a state health department official.

Title: Coronavirus less severe in kids, but they may be silent carriers: Doctors
Content: KOLKATA: With three children — aged nine months, six years and 11 years — from an extended family in Bengal testing positive to Covid-19 on Friday, it seems clear that the disease has now started affecting kids. All three children and their mothers are being treated at ID Hospital. However, though doctors have said the virus is known act less severely on children, they are being flooded with calls from anxious parents on how to keep their wards safe.“Since the virus is just about three months old, there is very limited data about its severity on children. But so far, Covid-19 is believed to cause less severity and fatality among children,” said paediatric intensivist Prabhas Prasun Giri.According to healthcare experts, so far only China has come out with data on children affected by Covid-19, which says out of the 3,000 affected initially, only 2.4% were under 15 and the mortality was at 0.2%. “We do not have any data on children under one, but in general, other coronavirus have spared children largely in terms of infection rate and mortality during SARS and MERS,” said Raja Dhar, pulmonologist at Fortis Hospital , Kolkata.However, since the virus spreads through the respiratory route and kids’ lungs are immature, doctors said infected children need to be closely monitored. “While caring for infected children, we should keep an eye on the oxygen saturation level and ensure they get sufficient fluids,” said ICH director Apurba Ghosh “Children are susceptible to the virus, but are known to have better prognosis than adults, according to the literature available,” said paediatrician Pallab Chatterjee of Columbia Asia Hospital Many children with lung conditions like asthma are also at risk. Experts have advised extra caution for them. Additionally, because kids show less severe symptoms, doctors warn they could act as silent carriers. “They can pass the virus to the elderly in the household,” said Ghosh.

Title: Adani, Sajjan Jindal pledge Rs 100 crore each, Kotak Rs 60 crore
Content: MUMBAI: India Inc’s list of contributors supporting the fight against the coronavirus crisis is expanding every day.Billionaires Gautam Adani, Sajjan Jindal and Uday Kotak are the latest to announce commitments worth crores of rupees to help India flatten the virus curve. Adani Foundation and Jindal’s JSW Group contributed Rs 100 crore each to the Prime Minister’s relief fund, while Kotak and his financial services group together pledged Rs 60 crore to the PM’s and Maharashtra CM’s relief funds.“Funds have also been earmarked to source ventilators, testing kits and protective medical gear, such as masks and gloves,” said JSW Group, adding that it will also be “converting its facilities” across India into “isolation wards” in order to limit the stress on community hospitals.Kalyan Jewellers and Financial services firm Motilal Oswal too have joined the contributors’ list by committing Rs 10 crore and Rs 5 crore, respectively, to Covid-19 rescue and rehabilitation efforts.Digital payments platform Paytm and its rival PhonePe have launched a donation drive, saying that they aim to contribute Rs 500 crore and Rs 100 crore, respectively, to the PM’s relief fund. Both said that for every contribution made via their respective apps, they will contribute Rs 10 each.Marico Innovation Foundation has announced a grant of Rs 2.5 crore for med-tech entrepreneurs coming out with cost-effective respiratory solutions like ventilators which are currently in short-supply in the country.“The Adani group will further contribute additional resources to support the governments and fellow citizens in these testing times,” tweeted chairman Gautam Adani. On similar lines, JSW Group chairman Sajjan Jindal said, “These immediate contributions are what we see is the need of the hour, and we have earmarked further monetary and non-monetary contributions so as to dynamically respond to all societal requirements in future.”

Title: Bank of India passes on RBI’s rate cut
Content:
(File photo)

MUMBAI: Bank of India (BoI) has passed on the RBI ’s 75-basis-point (100bps = 1 percentage point) repo rate cut to borrowers whose loans are linked to the bank’s external benchmark rate. BoI has also cut its marginal cost of lending rate (MCLR) by up to 25bps.

“The external benchmark lending rate, which is linked to the RBI’s repo rate, has been reduced by 75bps to 7.25%. With this, the bank has passed on the benefit of the rate cut announced by the RBI on March 27, 2020 to its home, vehicle and small & medium enterprise borrowers,” the bank said.

The reduction in interest rates will be effective from April 1, 2020. SBI was the first to bring down its lending rate after the RBI cut rates on Friday. Most of the other public sector banks will also announce rates effective April 2020, which will make it available to customers of the merging banks as well.

Title: Power consumption slides by 50% following lockdown
Content:
Gandhinagar: The energy sector has been one of those hit hard by the lockdown aimed to contain the novel coronavirus outbreak. While industrial power demand has fallen drastically, the overall electricity demand has witnessed a 50% reduction in the nine days of the lockdown.

According to official data of the state energy & petrochemicals department, the minimum demand of power in the state was 13,120 MW on March 18, which reduced to 10,361 MW on the day of the Janata Curfew on March 22. The minimum power demand in the state fell drastically to 6,386 MW on March 27.

Data provided by the government says that the maximum demand on March 18 stood at 16,193 MW, which fell to just 8,962 MW on March 27.

With most industries shut because of the lockdown, industrial power demand has fallen most drastically. On March 18, industrial power demand stood at 129.32 million units (MUs), which fell to 30.271 MUs on March 27.

According to official figures, there is a reduction in power consumption under the Jyoti Gram Yojana as well, with consumption under this scheme falling from 41.99 MUs to 35.731 MUs between March 18 and 27. During the same period, urban/town demand went down from 38.36 MUs to 30.2 MUs while agriculture demand has gone down from 82.02 MUs to 63.122 MUs per day.

A source in the state government said, “The state-run power companies and private companies are likely to incur huge losses because of the lockdown. In addition, the state government is expected to bear a loss of around Rs 500 crore in the form of electricity duty income in the lockdown period.’’

Title: Over 300 came in contact with Islampur’s first 4 Covid-19 patients
Content: Kolhapur: More than 300 people are believed to have come in contact with the four family members from Islampur who were the first to test positive for coronavirus in Sangli district.The four individuals — all above 50 years of age — had returned from Saudi Arabia on March 14 and had developed symptoms by March 19. They were then isolated from other family members.Their throat swab samples were sent to the Pune-based NIV on March 21 and results confirmed they had Covid-19 on March 23.State health minister Rajendra Patil-Yadravkar told TOI that after their return from Saudi Arabia, the family had organised a get-together and served food. The extended family and even non-relatives attended this event and came in contact with the patients.Yadravkar added that while contact-tracing, the medical authorities were making every effort to track down every person who could have been exposed to the infected family members.“The health department authorities contacted the family members and even the neighbours for accurate data. Fortunately, many have tested negative for the infection,” he said.Ranjit Shinde, a newspaper vendor from Islampur, said nobody in Islampur had thought that the place would have so many positive cases. It is high time citizens abide by all the prescribed guidelines and stay indoor.Ajinkya Adake, a resident of Walva town, around 10 km from Islampur, said people are concerned. “Everybody seems more cautious these days,” he said.Islampur, meanwhile, remains under the close watch of the district administration. The neighbourhood of the Covid-19-hit family is under lockdown with six entry and exit points. As many as 500 other homes in the area were told to adhere to strict guidelines of home quarantine and the health department is surveying the area.

Title: Cops booking those venturing out alone
Content:
Ahmedabad: The city police commissioner has imposed Section 144 barring the assembly of more than four persons to prevent the spread of coronavirus. But city cops are not sparing even those who are venturing out alone, if they are roaming without any concrete reason.

On Saturday, a case each was registered with Paldi and A division traffic police. Anandnagar police registered two cases.

In these cases, cops have cited the notification of the state home department imposing a lockdown between March 23 and March 31 which bars any unnecessary movement. It needs mention that the city has reported three corona deaths.

The highest number of such cases, 10, were registered at Madhavpura police station. All the FIRs say that more than four persons had gathered at one place when cops were patrolling. The cops then claim that in all cases, four people fled and one was caught. In each case, the apprehended person has been charged under IPC Section 188 for disobeying notification issued by a government servant.

Ellisbridge police filed two FIRs against two persons for roaming.

An official of the city police said that it has become necessary for them to file cases against persons as they showed negligence towards not only their health but also against other people’s.

People should not venture out because even if they are spared by cops, they will not be spared by corona, said the official.

Title: Internal roads of rural areas closed
Content:
Aurangabad: Police has restricted the movement of vehicles and people in internal roads of different rural areas on Sunday.

Authorities informed that this move is aimed at effective imposition of lockdown.

Since the announcement of lockdown about a week back, Sunday was the most deserted in the rural areas, which otherwise remain abuzz with weekly Sunday markets.

After being convinced by the police, several internal roads were closed down by the villagers, while at some places, the police restricted the movement.

In Pachod, attempts were made to set up Sunday market, but the police and the village sarpanch foiled the plan.

Police closed the Jamgaon – Vaijapur road, which eventually cut down the access to Jamgaon, Pagdi, Mamdapur and Kanadgaon villages. The same was witnessed in Sillod, Kannad, Gangapur, Soyegaon, Karmad. Police station in-charge appealed to villagers to remain indoors, unless there is an emergency.

Aurangabad rural superintendent of police Mokshada Patil said, “We appeal to the civic sense of fellow citizens for self-regulation. With planning and honest execution at the family level, we can get through this phase.”

The officer said that rural police have roped in community leaders and elderly people from the village to keep a check on the youths and prevent them from stepping outside their homes for no valid reason.

City police have registered about four dozen offences on Saturday for violating lockdown orders. The process of registering offences against violators continued on Sunday.

Title: Sanitiser is fine... so long as flame isn’t at hand
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: While advice about using alcohol-based hand sanitisers if soap and water are not available is sound, a 44-year-old man found out that there is additional advice that should be given to such users. He was brought to Sir Ganga Ram Hospital on Sunday night after sustaining 35% burn injuries. While doctors said a sanitiser evaporates 2-3 seconds after application and so poses little direct threat, immediately lighting a flame or perhaps a cigarette after using sanitiser can be risky.

Being treated in the department of plastic and cosmetic surgery at Sir Ganga Ram Hospital, the patient is in stable condition. Doctors disclosed that the resident of Rewari in Haryana was at home at the time of the incident. He was cleaning his keys and mobile phone with a hand sanitiser and carried the bottle of the liquid to the kitchen, where his wife was cooking. There some sanitiser spilled on his kurta. “The fumes were ignited by the gas flame and the kurta caught fire. The patient suffered burns on his face, neck, chest, abdomen and both hands,” a doctor confirmed.

Dr Mahesh Mangal, chairman of the department, stressed that though absolutely essential at this time, hand sanitisers needed to be handled with care. “The high ethyl alcohol content of up to 62% makes a hand sanitiser highly flammable. Never use sanitisers near a fire or heated place. Use a limited quantity and allow it to dry,” Mangal instructed.

Another doctor added that alcohol-based sanitisers posed no great risk on the skin because it evaporated in seconds. “Only if spilled in fires or on your clothes do sanitisers catch fire easily. People can cook or use a sanitiser near a flame, but need to be careful,” he pointed out. “In any case, one should ideally wash hands with soap before cooking and not rely on sanitisers.”

Dr P S Bhandari, consultant, burns and plastic surgery, Lok Nayak Hospital, reiterated that the chances of catching fire through sanitisers was low. “Deodorants, repellents and other sprays also have alcohol content, making them flammable. Like them, sanitisers are generally safe to use. But remember not to light a flame or come close to a fire immediately after using it,” he said.

Dr Bheem S Nanda, senior consultant in the department of plastic & cosmetic surgery at Sir Ganga Ram Hospital, suggested relying on scent. “Most sanitisers are scented and the smell vanishes after a while. This is generally an indicator that the alcohol in your hand has evaporated and you can then light a cigarette or agarbatti or begin cooking,” said Nanda.

Title: From arranging staff shelters to clearing stocks, police ensure smooth supply to med shops
Content:
People queue up in front of a medicine shop on Sunday afternoon

KOLKATA: Hours after Kolkata Police commissioner Anuj Sharma assured Kolkatans that pharmacy shops will remain open, several police stations in Kolkata — especially in the added areas — held meetings with local pharmacists and worked out methods to ensure that supply remained normal at these retail shops . Sources said police stations like Patuli and Thakurpukur even chalked out a seven-point plan — from arranging temporary stay for staffers in the area to getting stocks cleared at police naka points — to ensure that locals do not have to run around for medicines.

“We arrived at a few decisions after discussing the situation. There were mainly two issues — supply was not steady from wholesalers and staff availability issue.

A simple application at the police station should settle staff movement issues. It was also agreed that crowding must be avoided at the shops at any cost,” an officer said.

“We have reassured them of help in getting the supplies cleared in case it gets stuck in any naka point. We have also offered them help in arranging a temporary shelter for their staff in the locality in case the staff are unable to travel,” the official added. An officer at Patuli said WhatsApp groups have been formed with all local medicine shop owners and distributors so that they can reach them immediately in case of any need.

Almost 85% medicine shops across the city were open on Sunday. “Around 3,500 retail shops and 150 stockists were open on Sunday. With adequate staff at the shops we expect services to normalise by next week,” said Manik Lal Das, south Kolkata secretary of the Bengal Chemists and Druggists Association.

In north Kolkata, supplies are getting stabilised slowly and shop owners were asked to keep outlets open. There are 200 retail shops between Hedua and Sinthi. We have briefed them about how to download and print e-passes. That will help the staff to resume duty from Monday,” said Subir Sen, south Kolkata secretary of the association.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Migrants examined, stamped before being ferried to homes
Content:
With the arrival of migrant workers in east UP districts from Delhi and NCR, officials are ensuring that no on... Read More

VARANASI: With the arrival of migrant workers in east UP districts from Delhi and NCR, officials are ensuring that no one goes home without thermal scanning and stamping of home quarantine instructions.

Chief medical officer Varanasi Dr VB Singh said that the buses ferrying migrant workers started reaching Varanasi via Rajatalab and Pindra borders from Saturday night. Before the arrival of the buses, three teams were placed at each point of Pindra and Rajatalab. These buses, headed to Varanasi, were stopped at the borders and each passenger was examined with thermal scanners. Most of them were also asked to fill a form and allowed to go after stamping instructions of home quarantine on their hands.

Regional manager Varanasi of UPSRTC SK Rai said that nine buses were arranged at Pindra border on Saturday late night. Of these three buses left for Sonbhadra, two Naubatpur (UP-Bihar border) in Chandauli and one to Ghazipur after the arrival of passengers from Ghaziabad and Noida. All these passengers were allowed to board buses for their native places after proper examination by the health department team.

Rai further said, “We are arranging replacement of the buses which are unable to move forward if any driver is unable to drive further after a long-distance journey.”

After a driver expresses inability in continuing journey after reaching Varanasi, the bus is replaced by local depots of UPSRTC.

Rai said that on Sunday nine more buses for different districts of the region had been sent till late afternoon while entry points are being monitored for further arrangements.

There is no crowding at entry-cum-checking points on Varanasi borders as the migrant workers are reaching here after district-wise segregation, said officials.

District magistrate Ballia Hari Pratap Shahi said that all those who reached here from Delhi and NCR areas were properly examined and stamped before allowing to leave for their native places. Details of each passenger were collected after queuing up them at 10 counters ensuring that they maintain distance as per the prescribed norms and then they were allowed to move ahead with mask, gloves, and slips of home quarantine. Arrangements have also made for those quarantined at gram panchayat and school buildings, said Shahi.

As the influx of migrants from Delhi and NCR had increased since Saturday night and continued on Sunday, the exodus of labourers from Varanasi and neighbouring districts of east UP towards their villages in Bihar also continued. In Lohta area a large number of labourers could be found moving on foot to their villages in Bihar. Another group of labourers, who were engaged in different units of Varanasi, also walked to their homes.

Many policemen in bordering areas helped the labourers, who were rigid to go to their native places despite arrangements of food and lodging made at temporary shelter homes by local authorities.

ADG Varanasi zone Brij Bhushan said that in view of the directives of the government to stop the migration of people, all necessary arrangements are being made in government primary schools along highways with availability of food.

Title: Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation shelter lacks amenities
Content:
Gota Awas Yojna

AHMEDABAD: Casual labourers and daily wagers who were shifted to a facility provided by the AMC on SG Road moved out on Saturday because the facility lacked amenities.

From Friday, the city police started moving casual labourers to houses of Rajiv Awas Yojna behind Rajpath Club on SG Road. These labourers were picked up mainly from Chiloda Circle and Odhav Circle on SP Ring Road after they started walking out of the city because they were running out of money to survive here.

“Nearly 3,000 persons were shifted to the AMC facility,” said an official of the city police. “Though they were provided food and water they did not have fans and running water. They raised objections on Saturday night after which they were told by the cops and the civic body that they could leave.”

The police official said that the houses were not maintained due to which it was difficult for the labourers to stay there. Another police official said that the facility provided by the AMC was not proper which led the labourers to create an uproar.

“The labourers were dissatisfied with food quality and the condition of the houses,” said the official.

Title: Mass donation, stock from Jalna help city blood banks
Content:
Aurangabad: Blood banks in the city have overcome the shortage of blood, which they recently faced amid the Covid-19 outbreak.

Hanumant Rule, in-charge of the blood bank at Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), said the state-run facility has sufficient stock available now. “After a shortage of blood for a brief period, the government had appealed to masses to donate the blood and many responded to such call. Also, we received sufficient stock from Jalna district,” he said.

Rule said the average daily requirement of blood has also gone down amid the outbreak of COVID-19.“The daily requirement has gone down by more than one-third. A certain drop in planned surgeries is one of the main reasons behind such reduced demand. The casualty department is witnessing a lesser number of patients meeting with road-accidents and it is another cause behind lower demand for blood,” he said.

Manju Kulkarni, in-charge of Dattaji Bhale blood-bank, said that the number of volunteers donating blood as a social responsibility has increased post-outbreak of coronavirus. “There is no more shortage of blood now. In fact, we have put a cap on the number of donors donating the blood as there is reduced demand. We are accepting blood from only 40 donors every day and requesting others to wait for their turn.,” she said.

Kulkarni added that every donor is asked to fill a special consent form in the wake of the outbreak. “The National Blood Transfusion Council (NBTC) has issued special guidelines while receiving blood from a donor. It involves self-declaration that donor is not having any COVID-19 like symptoms as well as certain lab tests,” she said.

Authorities at different blood banks also said that they have strictly stopped camps to collect blood. “The blood donation camps have been stopped in order to practice social distancing norm advised by the government,” authorities said.

Pravin Bhandekar, a government employee, said he voluntarily donated his blood post-outbreak.

Title: Ahmedabad: CCTV to spot lockdown violators
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Devendra Vanzara, 21, a resident of Krishnanagar, was booked on Saturday by cops for venturing out during the lockdown.

According to a senior police official, he started abusing the police and also had a scuffle with the police officer on duty at Baliyakaka Chowk in Krishnangar.

“We called extra enforcement from the police station and booked him under Section 186 of the IPC,” said a police official.

Police have now started booking those violating the lockdown on the basis of CCTV camera footage from nearby areas.

“We will now be strict and nobody violating the lockdown rules will be spared,” said police commissioner Ashish Bhatia.

Title: Back from abroad after Mar 10? Get corona tested
Content:
Varanasi: The rising coronavirus tally in state despite nationwide lockdown has forced the administration to take stringent steps to contain the spread of virus in eastern UP.

After the detection of second Covid-19 positive case on Saturday evening, the district administration made the coronavirus test mandatory for all those returning from abroad after March 10. The tests will be conducted at DDU district hospital and SSL hospital from Sunday till March 31.

People in large numbers started gathering at city hospitals especially at DDU hospital, where the daily turnout of those seeking coronavirus test doubled.

Talking to TOI on Sunday, chief medical officer Dr VB Singh said, “Till Saturday, around eight persons were visiting DDU district hospital to give samples but after DM’s orders the number of people increased up to double on Sunday and it may further rise on Monday and Tuesday.

On Saturday evening the second positive case of Covid-19 was confirmed in Varanasi after which the 30-year-old patient was admitted to the isolation ward of DDU District hospital. This resident of Chhatripur locality in Shivpur area, had been doing a job at a call centre in Jabel Ali town in UAE since June 2019. He had returned to Varanasi through a direct flight from Sharjah on March 20. From the airport he went to his home in a taxi and remained home quarantined. Having flu-like symptoms, he went to the hospital and gave his sample which tested positive on Saturday.

Earlier, two cases one from Varanasi and one from Jaunpur district tested positive at the BHU lab.

With the rise in positive cases, the DM issued an order asking all those who returned from abroad after March 10 to turn up at DDU district hospital and SSL hospital of BHU to give their samples from Sunday till March 31.

Clearing that such screening had been mandatory for all of them he said, on failing, FIRs under section 188 will be lodged against them. Persons who have been examined already at district or BHU hospitals, have been exempted. He said that even those, who had consulted private hospitals, would have to go for test.

On being contacted, incharge of BHUs microbiology laboratory Prof Gopal Nath said, “The laboratory will get two new machines for the test of samples being sent from 16 districts of east UP region. This will improve the efficiency of the laboratory, which is currently operating with single machine.”

Title: 500 families screened so far, no person with symptoms found
Content:
Kolhapur: Over 500 families from Mangalwar Peth and nearby areas were surveyed by teams deployed by the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation ( KMC ) to check for possible Covid-19 suspects.

The move was taken after a person from a locality in the Mangalwar Peth area tested positive for Covid-19 on Thursday.

Four teams led by doctors have been asked to check the health status of the people living in the cordoned localities. No person with coronavirus symptoms have been found apart from 11 suspects who came in direct contact with a Covid-19 patient.

A senior health official of the municipal corporation, on the condition of anonymity, said, “People with symptoms will be screened. There are over 4,200 families in the locality with total population of 21,000. So far, we have checked the health status of 2,650 people. As per our enquiry, the coronavirus positive person was indoors since he arrived in city and, therefore, apart from his family members, no one has been in contact with him. However, as a precautionary measure, and to follow the guidelines, all people from the locality will be checked.”

The district administration has marked 500 meters of restricted zone in the locality. People are not allowed to move in or go out of the restricted zone. The civic body has set up a panel under local corporators to look after the needs of people. The localites in thge said area have been provided with the contact details of grocery shops, medical stores and milk vendors. All their orders will be delivered at their doorstep. The KMC has also deployed a team of doctors who regularly visit people with minor ailments.

Title: Docs not opening clinics will lose licence: Collector
Content:
Kolhapur: District collector Daulat Desai on Sunday warned all doctors , who fail to reopen their clinics immediately, of cancellation of practising licences and sealing of the clinics.

Even two days after chief minister Uddhav Thackeray’s appeal to doctors to reopen their clinics, that had been shut due to the coronavirus scare, very few have complied.

Desai said: “We are aware of the situation. Yesterday (Saturday) we met some doctors. We have asked them to follow the orders. They claimed that around half of the clinics have reopened. However, we are yet to check. If the doctors fail to follow the orders, then we will take stringent actions such as sealing the clinics and cancelling their practice licences.”

The collector said the doctors’ demand for providing protective equipment is under consideration. The doctors carrying out general practice should also have gloves and wear N95 masks. The doctors claim there is a shortage of protective gear.

Meanwhile, patients with diabetes, eye-related issues, dental problems, minor injuries, blood pressure etc. are facing inconvenience. Even the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation-run clinics are of not much help to them as most of the doctors and staff have been assigned to check suspected coronavirus patients who are under home-quarantine. The civic body’s health officials said that for minor complaints, doctors are advising patients to get the medicines and stay at home.

People are angry since all other essential services are operational such as retail grocery shops, pharmacies, milk outlets, but clinics are closed.

Doctors with N95 masks and gloves are attending the clinics. They have been provided with a chart by the apex medical body that instructs the use of protective equipment before checking patients. The doctors fear that a patient with coronavirus may spread the infection. The district administration has said that such patients should compulsorily be referred to the Covid-19 screening centres immediately.

Title: Two-year-old tests positive; 25 relatives now infected
Content: KOLHAPUR: A two-year-old child from Islampur , who had earlier tested negative for Covid-19, has now been confirmed as a positive case. The baby is part of the same family , from which 24 people have already tested positive for the novel coronavirus.The number of positive cases in Sangli is now at 24. Another infected member of the family is a resident of Kolhapur district.Sangli collector Abhijeet Chaudhary confirmed that with the inclusion of the toddler — the grandson of the first positive patient — 25 members of the family now have Covid-19.Choudhary added that the toddler’s test results, confirming the positive status, came out late on Saturday night.The collector told TOI that the first four positive patients from the family are of varied ages. Three of the patients are above 50 and the fourth person is under 40. The other positive cases, who had come in contact with the first four, are all above 50.“They all are doing fine and responding well to the treatment,” Chaudhary said.Sangli district civil surgeon Sanjay Salunkhe, said: “The patients are being treated in the isolation ward of the Miraj Government Medical College. They are all in stable condition. People who came in contact with them are also being monitored.”Chaudhary said 47 swab samples of the family members have been tested so far and 25 of the samples have been confirmed as positive. Around 32 other close contacts of the family are under institutional quarantine and nearly 300 people — tracked down after vigorous contact tracing — have been asked to remain under home quarantine, he said.Meanwhile, the two relatives of the Islampur family from Satara, who were put under institutional quarantine on Friday, March 27, have tested negative. These individuals had come in contact with the family members of the positive patients.

Title: Three more test positive in Saurashtra
Content:
Rajkot: Three more people more tested positive for COVID-19 in Saurashtra on Sunday.

While Porbandar recorded its first positive case, one each in Rajkot and Veraval were confirmed infected.

According to Rajkot health department officials, a 36-year-old man who returned from France on March 18 tested positive, taking the total number of COVID-19 patients in the city to nine.

The man was kept in home quarantine but shifted to isolation on March 26 after his health deteriorated. His first report in a laboratory of Rajkot was unclear, so the samples were sent to the government-recognized lab for coronavirus testing in Jamnagar for confirmation on Saturday. His two close contacts have been shifted to government quarantine facility.

In Porbandar, a 48-year-old woman, who had returned from Dubai four days ago, tested positive. She first went to see a private doctor, but approached the government hospital on Saturday. District development officer V K Advani said, “We have also taken the sample of her daughter and sent it testing for testing as precaution because she was always with her.”

The coastal town of Veraval reported its second COVID-19 case with a 65-year-old man, whose wife had tested positive on Saturday, getting infected. According to district administration, five members of this family were kept in isolation, out whom four have tested negative. There are 56 other people who had came in contact of the couple and they have been put under observation. Of these, nine are kept in government quarantine facility created in Lilavati guest house and others are in home quarantine, official sources said.

Title: Businessman who drives through Jaipur streets to feed strays
Content: JAIPUR: Fifty-five-year-old Sanjiv Sankhla used to spend time with animals on a daily basis. Feeding the strays was part of his daily routine. However, what was a 20-minute activity has now expanded into a dedicated few hours to feed the stray animals during the ongoing lockdown An exporter, whose own business has been affected by the lockdown, Sankhla is busy mapping closed thadis (roadside stalls), eateries and waste points in the city in his pick-up van stocked with fodder, biscuits and medicines for stray animals. Sankhla goes from area to area to feed the stray dogs, cats, cows, bulls and pigs that come his way.It was his love for animals that made him start an NGO Help Suffering Animals a few years ago and now he is spending his time fully in taking care of the animals. “It is good that the government has made all arrangements for humans, and it is our duty to help the stray animals in any way we can,” said Sankhla, whose voluntary work has doubled ever since people were confined indoors.Ever since he received a permit from the city administration to carry out his distribution work on March 25, he and his team feed stray animals at 45 points in the city.“For cows, people are compassionate and they offer leftovers, but for stray dogs and cats, who need non-veg food in their diet are starving,” said Sankhla. He and his team travels in areas like Mansarovar, Raja Park, Malviya Nagar, C Scheme, Pratap Nagar, Sodala and Vaishali Nagar.“Our focus is on urban areas as our experience has shown us that people on the outskirts are a little more compassionate and are feeding the strays,” he said. Every morning, he gets fodder from the nearby villages for cows and buffaloes, while for cats and dogs, the challenge remains as meat shops are closed. They have to depend on branded food, which comes with a cost. “However, once I started, a lot of my relatives, friends and even strangers voluntarily came forward with donations,” he added.Sankhla ensures his team members take all precautions by wearing masks, use sanitisers, clean their tools with sanitiser and before entering their house, they change their clothes and shoes. “Our families have been very supportive. My elderly parents, teen daughter and wife wait for me to tell them about the day’s work every evening and also spread the word on our work,” he said.What Sankhla finds a concern is that many people, even educated ones, believe that their pets or stray animals pose a threat. “I have lost count of people who call me to ask what they should do to ensure they don’t catch Covid-19 from their pets or animals. Some even asked if they should stay away from their pets. Animals are not carriers and the lockdown should not be a reason to mistreat them,” he said.

Title: People with nowhere to go living on Central Avenue, KP
Content: Nagpur: Shyam Kazare, who runs errands at a chartered accountant’s office in Mumbai, was asked to deliver a parcel to a person at Nagpur railway station . Before he could catch the train back home, the lockdown left him stranded here. The Rs2,000 he had have been spent, Kazare now spends his time on the footpath near Kasturchand Park , living on the charity of do-gooders, who are distributing food around the city.Kazare says his job was to only deliver the packet to the person, and had no idea who was he or what was inside the packet. “The chartered accountant’s office is at Camay Towers, Marine Lines, and my boss stays somewhere at Andheri. I called up the office but they told me to wait here till April 14,” says Kazare.Kazare had also gone to Raipur for similar work, but by the time he returned all roads were closed. Kazare says, “I had no money to stay in a hotel, what I had was spent in buying food. I stay here in the morning and go to sleep at the railway station, because its not safe on the footpath in the night.”Later, when TOI contacted him again in the evening, Kazare had been contacted by NMC officials, who said they will make arrangements for him.Next to him was Satyam, who worked as a chef in Bhatinda, Punjab, and was returning home at Raipur, Chhattisgarh. “After reaching Delhi from Bhatinda, I took the Chhattisgarh Express that goes till Raipur. When the train reached Nagpur, people started saying it will not go further, so I got down, only to find out later that the train had gone ahead. Now, I am helpless,” he said showing the ticket.A drive along the road shows many others like Kazare and Satyam. On Central Avenue , the shaded footpath along the automobile spares shops is full of people. As a vehicle approaches some of them eagerly come forward, hoping that food packets are being distributed.Section 144 is in force but there is hardly any social distancing happening here. The crowd increases in the evening, said a local living near by.Most of those waiting here are daily wagers who used to gather there to take up odd jobs. From Ramtek and Tumsar nearby, there are people from as far as Gwalior in Madhya Pradesh. The practice among the labourers is to work here for a week or fortnight and return home for some days.“Some of us had planned to go back but are now stranded due to the lockdown. We wait for food packets to come and are managing somehow,” said Pawan Selokar from Bhandara, “We could save barely Rs100 to 200 a day from our wages, which have been exhausted long ago,” he said. TOI spotted over 50 such persons in a patch of less than 20 to 30 meters.Munnal Lal, who is from Gwalior, said he had planned to go for a marriage which too has been called off.Dinesh Thakre looks slightly better off among them. “I was a waiter at a restaurant near Hingna. As it closed, I was asked to go. I have no other place to stay,” he says.

Title: JEE prep module now on IIT digital platform
Content:
Kolkata: With the JEE Mains and JEE Advanced exams being postponed till the last week of May, IIT Kharagpur has developed preparation modules and made them available with the National Digital Library, the largest online library in the country, which is situated inside the institute, to help students prepare themselves during the lockdown phase.

The decision to postopone the exams is posing a problem for the students who have to mostly depend on coaching centres or other tutorials because of the physical distancing. They are finding it difficult to depend on online resources and e-learning materials to continue with their preparation. IIT Kharagpur has developed a preparatory module for JEE and JEE Advanced, available free for students on the NDLI platform. Students can visit the NDLI website https://www.ndl.gov.in/ or https://ndl.iitkgp.ac.in/ or log on to the NDLI mobile application.

The website of NDLI now has a special section called, ‘Corona Outbreak: Study from Home’, which students can access. The repository contains NDLI Tutorial for JEE Advanced for 12 years and Practice Questions and Solutions for JEE Preparation. Content for JEE Mains for the past five years is also getting readied and will be added to the site soon, said experts. “The solutions have been prepared by subject matter experts and doctoral students in related areas. Hence, the solutions are diverse and students can opt for their preferred methods. Further we have provided reference materials for related problems, so students can explore further,” said Partha Pratim Das, a faculty and joint-principal investigator, NDLI.

Students can browse the “School” option under the ‘Corona Outbreak’ module or search by relevant keywords. The developers recommend registering on the portal for better user experience, though the resources are available without any restrictions.

Title: Miles to go before they sleep, no end to daily wagers’ woes
Content:
Prayagraj: The influx of migrant labourers stuck in various parts of the city due to the lockdown announced to check the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) continued in the city on Sunday as well.

Civil Lines bus stand was thronged by daily wagers from different parts of the city and arriving in roadways buses. A group of 14 migrant labourers who started their journey for Sasaram in Bihar from Kanpur on Sunday reached Prayagraj by travelling over 200km on foot.

One of them, Dilip, said, “We started walking from Kanpur on Thursday and reached Prayagraj on Sunday. We couldn’t stay in Kanpur as we were laid off. We have had just one meal in the past three days.” Another labourer Ramendra arrived in Prayagraj from Pratapgarh along with others as they wanted to go to his hometown in Sonbhara. The migrant labourers arrived at Civil Lines bus stand, where they were made to undergo a medical check up and offered food packets by the police.

Labourers from Etawah, Etah, Shikohabad and adjoining districts also reached the city after travelling over 400 kilometres on foot. Most of them had a single penny on them and urged district administratin to arrange for vehicles to take them to their native towns.

On Sunday, around five police teams distributed food packets among the poor and homeless in areas like Civil Lines, Baihrana, Shankargarh, Meja, Manda, Naini and Dhoomanganj. “Police deployed on inter-district borders at Phaphamau, Dhoomanganj, Shankargarh, Naribari and Jhunsi have been directed not to stop vehicles carrying essential items from entering the city,” SSP Satyarth Aniruddh Pankaj said.

Title: AI to fly home Germans stuck in Kolkata tomorrow
Content: KOLKATA: On Tuesday, a passenger aircraft will touch down at Kolkata airport for the first time since international flight operations were suspended on March 22, followed by domestic flights three days later. Only cargo aircraft have been flying to the city since.According to sources, an empty Air India Boeing B-787 aircraft will come to Kolkata on Tuesday and pick up German nationals, including the envoy and diplomatic mission staff as well as select staffers of other European missions in the city. The plane will then head to Delhi, where more German citizens and those from other EU nations will board the flight that will then depart for Frankfurt.“This evacuation flight is one of nine chartered flights that AI will operate from Delhi and Mumbai to Frankfurt, following a request from the German chancellor Angela Merkel to Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Following the lockdown, German nationals are stuck in Kolkata, Bengaluru, Goa, Trivandrum, Chennai, Delhi and Mumbai. AI will operate these one-way flights to help them return home,” a source in the national carrier told TOI.According to airline sources, AI will operate five flights on March 31, one flight on April 1, two on April 2 and the final one on April 3.With a capacity of 236 seats, the nine B-787 flights can evacuate over 2,000 Europeans. There will be no passenger on the return flights. The crew will wear personal protection equipment (masks and gloves) during the flight and on-board services will be limited to avoid exposure and infection. Sources said pre-packed meals are likely to be kept in the seat pockets for passengers. On their return, the crew will undergo health checks at a hospital before being put in home isolation for two weeks. The evacuation aircraft will also carry hazmat suits in the cockpit for the crew in case any Covid-19 suspect is on board.Days before India suspended international flights to control the coronavirus spread, entry of flights from EU, the UK and Turkey had been barred. While Germany appears to have an edge in the fight against Covid-19, other countries are still struggling to control the virus and prevent its spread.While AI has evacuated Indian citizens stranded in Covid-19-affected countries, it has also helped repatriate expats stranded in India. Last week, AI flew 317 Israelis to Tel Aviv. It also operated flights to Colombo and Sharjah to help Lankans and UAE citizens return home.AI has also being operating cargo charter operations, carrying primarily medical equipment, masks and ventilator kits all over India using its fleet of A-320, B-787 & ATR aircraft.

Title: Maharashtra to get 1 lakh protective gear kits from South Korea
Content: PUNE: State health minister Rajesh Tope on Sunday said the government would procure one lakh kits of personal protection equipment (PPE), including body suits, goggles and N-95 masks, from South Korea at the earliest for the doctors and health workers combating the spread of coronavirus.The minister told TOI that funds for the equipment would come through the corporate social responsibility programme. The number of coronavirus cases in Maharashtra increased to 197 on Sunday.Amid a global shortage of such equipment, the state’s medical fraternity had written to the health minister about a similar situation in Maharashtra and stressed the need to address the crisis at the earliest. With over 1,000 hospitals set to admit Covid-19 positive patients, the requirement of personal protection equipment has increased and the state is reaching out to all local manufacturers, besides those abroad, to urgently address this issue.Tope said he has received complaints about the shortage of such equipment in the state and the government was reaching out to top companies to procure such kits through CSR funds. “I have urged many of our existing players to make this supply available. There should not be any shortage of these kits as doctors and other medical staffers would not be able to work in the absence of these protective gear,” he said.The minister also assured medical insurance cover for all Covid-19 patients under Mahatma Jyotiba Phule Jan Arogya Yojana from April 1. “This is a flagship health insurance scheme in the state and all Covid-19 patients will be covered,” he said. The scheme allows the coverage in over 1,000 private hospitals.Indian Medical Association state president Avinash Bhondwe said there was a dearth of personal protection equipment in both the government and private sectors. “We have been repeatedly saying that this shortage should be addressed. Besides requesting the government, we have also created a corpus to tide over the crisis,” he said, adding that elected representatives could also come forward with the MLA and MP funds for the purpose.Another point raised by a health worker is that the manufacturers have increased prices ten-fold and the government needs to intervene into it. The health minister vowed to look into the issue.For any hospital treating Covid-19 patients, there should be at least 5,000 personal protection equipment for a month.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Railway hospitals to handle government employees
Content:
Representaive Image

GORAKHPUR: The railway ministry has decided to provide health services to all central government employees .

“Following the instructions of the rail ministry, NER railway hospitals and health centres will provide health services to all central government employees. The employees will have to show their identity cards to avail the service,” said CPRO Pankaj Singh.

“Services will be available at NE Railway hospitals in Gorakhpur, Lucknow’s Badshah Nagar, Varanasi’s Izzatnagar, and at al other railway health centres,” he added.

“Deoria Indian Medical Association (IMA) of Deoria has appealed to people not to step out of their homes and take medical counselling on phone,” said Deoria IMA secretary Umakant Pandey.

Title: Over 5,000 sent to home quarantine in Gorakhpur
Content:
Gorakhpur: In order to contain the spread of Covid-19 in Gorakhpur, outsiders entering the district are being screened and stamped at two spots. More than 5000 people have been sent to home quarantine.

Thousands of migrant workers returning from metro cities to their native towns, are being screened and provided with food packets at Nausad Crossing and at Railway Bus Station.

“People arriving from outside are being screened and stamped at the two spots before being permitted to carry on the forward journey. They have also been directed to stay in home quarantine for at least 14 days,” said Gorakhpur CMO Srikant Tiwari.

“If anyone is found running a temperature, or shows other symptoms of Covid-19, the person is send to the district hospital. So far, more than 5000 people have been sent to home quarantine and 10 samples of suspected corona patients were sent for test, but all of them tested negative,” added Tiwari.

“As many as 80 teams have been deployed for screening outsiders. Each team goes door to door to screen families—especially those with outsiders—and, sticks notice outside the house for home quarantine as per need,” said the CMO.

Title: Over 10 MT freight loading at SCR in 6 days
Content:
Aurangabad: The South Central Railway (SCR) has registered freight (goods) loading of 10.17 million tonne (MT) for six days from March 22 to March 27, using 270 freight trains, averaging to around 1.70 MT each day.

The SCR has handled inter-change operations of 961 freight trains originating from other zones and passing through its network, around 160 freight trains in an average daily, as per an official release said.

Chief public relations officer of SCR, Ch Rakesh, said the zone has decided not to levy demurrage (the charge for the detention of any rolling stock after the expiry of free time, if any, allowed for such detention) or wharfage (the charge levied on goods for not removing them from the railway after the expiry of the free time for removal.) for goods and parcel freight traffic from March 22 to April 14 in keeping with the directive from the Indian Railways, amid the coronavirus outbreak.

“The waiver initiative of the Indian Railways relaxes the norms of the earlier decision to bring the demurrage and wharfage rates to half of the prescribed tariff. No charges will be levied for stacking, detention and ground usage in case of container traffic too,” he said.

The commodities primarily ranged from coal to thermal power plants for electricity, fertilizers used in the agricultural sector, food grains to ensure uninterrupted supply and transporting of milk to Delhi. “An extensive coordination is being maintained with various state governments to seek their involvement in the smooth running of trains and to deliver their own needs,” Rakesh said.

SCR general manager Gajanan Mallya, said, “With the looming threat from the global pandemic, SCR is trying to overcome various challenges to ensure freight trains reach their destinations,” he said.

The SCR authorities said medical attention is given for all railway employees and staff. “The working places and rest houses are continuously sanitized. To negate any possibility of contracting infections, the mandatory breath analyser test has been done for crew operating freight trains,” Rakesh said.

Title: Sanitiser manufacturing begins in Udaipur
Content:
Representative image

At the Centre’s directions to the state governments to direct distilleries to start manufacturing sanitisers themselves, the production work has begun in Udaipur . The manufacturing is being done in order to enhance the production of hand sanitisers and to ensure its easy availability to consumers.

Title: Milk supply likely to be normal from today
Content:
Daily milk supply at a South Kolkata shop

KOLKATA: Milk supply in Kolkata and its adjoining areas is likely to become normal from Monday after dairy owners met animal husbandry department officials at an emergency meeting in Nabanna on Sunday. The rationing of two packets for each buyer, imposed by the retailers in view of the supply shortage, is also likely to be lifted.

Metro Dairy, which had to increase production to accommodate the sudden surge in demand after supplies from the market leader Amul dipped sharply, will continue with its usual production level. Faced with a sudden surge in demand, the government had requested the private dairy to increase their production by 30,000 litres per day. It had taken the government’s help to despatch the excess production to retailers across the city. The company will go back to its normal production of 2 lakh litres per day from Monday, sources said.

“We are continuing with our usual production level of 2.2 lakh litres. There is an excess supply of fresh milk in the market as the sweet shops are closed. But we are unable to accommodate that as we are not sure of the quality of that milk,” said Narayan Majumdar, director of the company. The dairy owners, who have been facing the shortage of staff, were also assured of help by the state government. “We expect to operate with the normal supply fleet from Monday,” Majumdar added.

Meanwhile, the state government-run Mother Dairy has also increased its procurement of fresh milk and raised its supplies. It has enhanced the quality of the most economical, toned milk, at no extra cost. “Not a single booth in Kolkata is running dry now. We are sending milk directly from the factory at Dankuni to each of the 200 booths in Kolkata to ensure unrestricted supplies. Vehicles are leaving twice in a day to assure that booths have enough milk supply,” said an official of the Mother Dairy.

“Production of fresh milk at the cow sheds in Kolkata and surrounding areas has dipped in the past two days. Farmers are taking the excess production to far-off areas and continuing with the distress sell. Some of them are trying to convert the produce into paneer (cottagecheese) and dahi to minimise their losses,” said Rajesh Sinha, president of Jorasanko Dugdha Byabsayee Samiti. Amul, hit hard with shortage of staff, will continue with restricted production of its Gold variety. The toned variety , however, is likely to resume increased supplies soon.

Title: Lockdown brings city to standstill, but migrants’ march to safety continues
Content:
(Clockwise from top right) Migrant workers on their way back home in trucks and buses, being screened by medic... Read More

Prayagraj: Adequate police force was deployed at Civil Lines bus station and adjoining areas on Sunday to regulate flow of migrant labourers who are reaching the city from different parts of the state. Two medical teams have also been deployed at the bus station to examine their health condition.

As the nationwide lockdown enforced in view of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic entered the fifth day on Sunday, over 70 city residents were booked for flouting rules. The accused were charged under Section 188 (violation of norms) of the Indian Penal Code.

SSP, Prayagraj, Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj told TOI that around 20 buses have brought scores of migrant labourers at Civil Lines bus station. “A large posse of policemen, including an additional SP, two deputy SPs, five inspector and 200 constables, were deployed there to regulate migrant workers,” he added.

Besides, two medical teams were engaged to check migrant labouers who were later shifted to temporary shelter camps in different parts of the city. The local thana police with the help of NGOs are taking care of migrant labourers and offering them eatables and other necessary items. Netram, a migrant labourer, said “I arrived Prayagraj from Lucknow on a government bus and wants to go to my native town in Satna. However, I and my family members have been asked to stay at a shelter home. We are offered meal by some people.”

Balak ram, another migrant labouer, said “ I reached lucknow from Barielly on foot and wanted to go Rewa”. He added, “A roadways bus brought us to Prayagraj. We requested police authorities to arrange another bus so that we would reach Rewa. However, the cops brought us to a temporary shelter point.”

More migrant labourers were spotted moving on Varanasi-Kanpur highway as they wanted to walk down to Jalaun. Mukesh , a migrant worker, said“ We started our journey from Varanasi on Saturday morning and reached Prayagraj on Sunday and would be travelling on foot to Jalaun”. He also said that he had no money. “Some people gave us food at Handia when we were on way to Prayagraj.”

Migrant labourers, however, demanded local authorities to make arrangement to send them to their native towns in Rewa, Satna, Meja, Manda and adjoining areas.

Meanwhile, eight police teams were deployed at wholesale vegetable markets, including Mundera Mandi, Daraganj and Hashimpur crossing, on Sunday for better crowd management. Vendors were also asked to maintain proper distance from one another.

SSP, meanwhile, said mobile police teams have stepped up checking in areas like Shivkuti, Muttiganj Nawabganj, Khuldabad, Shahganj, Khiri, Mauaima and Manda. He added that over 5400 vehicles were checked in different parts of the city. “While 635 of them were challaned for flouting rules, 25 vehicles were seized,” he added.

Like the past four days, city streets wore a deserted look on Sunday as local residents stayed indoors. Shops selling medicines and groceries were open from 7am to 10pm.

Meanwhile, the district administration on Sunday issued corona medical control helpline numbers 0532-2266098 and 0532-2266099, corona administrative control room numbers 0532-2641577 and 0532-2641578 and in-charge of control room 9544178813.

Title: Lockdown affects cattle feed production
Content:
Kolhapur: The problems of dairy farmers in the sugar bowl of Maharashtra is likely to increase in next few days as the raw material for producing cattle feed is getting exhausted and the industries producing the feed would have to discontinue production . The farmers have enough fodder for their cattle, but need cattle feed to increase the nutritional content.

Gokul, one of the major milk procurers and cattle feed producers in the district, is facing an inter-state supply problem to source raw material.

Cattle feed is used to increase the quality and nutrition of the milk. Most farmers get the cattle feed through the dairies that are attached to Gokul through its cattle feed-producing plant.

Gokul’s cattle feed plant sources raw materials like deoiled cakes of rice bran, corn, millet — which has high protein content — and molasses from other states like Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat and Karnataka.

Ravindra Apate, the chairman of Gokul Dairy, said: “Since the lockdown , we have been unable to get the supply of these raw materials. Without the raw materials, we cannot continue production. Usually, we produce 600 tonne of cattle feed every day. But now we have reduced the production to half. With the available raw material, we can sustain for the next few days. If the situation continues, we will have to discontinue production from April 15.”

Rahul Khade, a dairy farmer from Kolhapur city, said, “We have enough fodder. The government has allowed the supply of fodder in the market and there is no scarcity.
