The fields along the banks of the Panchaganga river also have sufficient fodder that can be cut and supplied to the major markets for livestock. What we are fearing is the shortage of cattle feed. We are not getting enough supply of the cattle feed for our buffaloes and cows.”

Ramesh Malgonda Patil, the chairman Laxmi Vikas Seva Society and a dairy farmer from Gadhinglaj, said, “Usually we need one 50kg bag per cattle per month. The price is around Rs 1,150 per bag. We usually procure cattle feed from the dairy we supply milk to. Though we asked for two bags of cattle feed, we got only one. The dairy officials have asked us to use the feed judiciously.”

Title: Social distancing ignored as crowds throng markets
Content:
Trichy: All the meat outlets in the city were seen crowded on Sunday with people competing against each other to wind up their purchase at the earliest, and thereby throwing to the wind social distancing .

As Janata Curfew was observed the previous Sunday, all the chicken, mutton and fish stalls in the city were shut. Since people usually purchase meat on Sundays to preparing non-vegetarian delicacies at home, residents who were deprived last week were determined not to miss the opportunity this week.

Despite the lockdown, meat stalls in Gandhi Market, Woraiyur, Palakkarai, Kattur and Subramaniapuram were flooded with residents. The footfall was such that mutton stalls had completed sales by around 11am. “Customers did not listen to our instructions to maintain social distancing. As people continue to flout restrictions, we are worried about clampdown on us in the coming days,” J Prabakaran, a meat stall owner from Palakkarai said.

The price of one kg of boneless mutton was Rs 900, up from Rs 700, while chicken was sold at Rs 80 to Rs 120 per kg. People, however, did not hesitate to shell out more.

While a one metre gap is mandatory between people in public places, the rule was deliberately flouted. “Compared to last few days and last week, the sale this Sunday was decent. The business is gradually picking up,” said S Nagarajan, a chicken stall owner from Bhima Nagar.

Trichy Corporation and city police had instructed the meat stall owners to ensure social distancing during the sales. “We repeatedly told people not to crowd, but the footfall was high. If only people can realise the gravity of Covid-19, they will stop crowding and cooperate,” a Trichy Corporation official said.

Title: Showers lash Pune; rainfall to taper out from Monday, says IMD
Content:
A puddle of rainwater at Baner on Sunday

PUNE: Shivajinagar received yet another “intensive” shower on Sunday, adding 4mm to the area’s total rainfall this summer, while Lohegaon received 1mm.

Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather at India Meteorological Department (IMD), Pune, told TOI that Madhya Maharashtra and Marathwada, including Pune city, are likely to receive very light rain at isolated places on Monday as well, along with thundery activity. “Rainfall activity is likely to reduce from Monday, with only partly cloudy skies on Tuesday followed by mainly clear skies in Pune for a couple of days,” Kashyapi said.

He said the city was experiencing intensive showers, which are usually intense and fall within a short period of time. “The reason for the showers is a trough-line passing through Marathwada and Vidarbha. Hence the areas adjacent to these regions are receiving rainfall. The high temperatures as well as the moisture flow into parts of Maharashtra due to the prevailing weather systems have been resulting in local-level instability, leading to convective rains,” IMD said.

On Sunday, locations like Katraj and adjacent areas also experienced hail. Two days ago, the sudden rainfall interrupted power in many areas of the city, severely affecting the schedule of many citizens, who are working from home due to the prevailing Covid-19 lockdown.

Title: DGP visits Walled City curfew areas
Content: JAIPUR: Curfew continues in Walled City area though no untoward incidents were reported on the third day since it was imposed.On sunday, DGP Bhupendra Singh inspected the areas which have been under curfew since Friday. Police are ensuring that basic essentials like milk is supplied to the residents.According to officials, Singh took stock of the situation in the curfew area and motivated police personnel to continue the vigil. He also asked them to ensure that residents of the area do not face problems in getting essential items.“Anyone who needs milk, vegetables and other essential items can call up local police stations who will make sure that the required products reach their doorstep. We are trying all possible measures to ensure that the residents adhere to curfew but at the same time do not face shortage of essential items,” said a police officer.After a Covid-19 positive case was found in Ramganj police station area, authorities imposed Section 144 from Friday evening. The areas under curfew are Ramganj, Subash Chowk, Manak Chowk, Kotwali and all the areas under Galta Gate, Brahmapuri and Nahargarh police stations.The order prohibits movement of people outside their houses. Barring emergency health services, all commercial establishments will remain closed in the area. Hospitals and medical stores will remain open. Essential services will be provided at the doorstep.

Title: No community spread in Nagpur, but stay alert to avoid it
Content: Nagpur: After more cases of Covid-19 were detected in Nagpur in last three days, authorities have increased the testing and active surveillance of the relatives and close contacts of patients. However, looking at early trends of test results, doctors have stated that the spread is still limited to family members and very close contacts.Since Thursday, NMC checked more than 100 close contacts of positive patients. Of them, only six have tested positive.For example, manager of the Khamla businessman who tested positive had travelled along with him to New Delhi. A shop assistant who tested positive used to attend the shop daily and was with the owner for most of the day between March 18 and 21. On the other hand, other two shop assistants who were not in that close contact have tested negative.Khamla businessman’s family members including his mother, wife and son tested positive but his daughter tested negative. Similarly, all family members of the assistant tested negative and only his 17-year-old daughter was positive. Most importantly, neither maid servants, nor neighbours of any of these patients have tested positive so far.“As far as Nagpur’s cases are concerned, we can definitely trace the infection source of every new local patient. Only those who are into close or long time contact of the positive patients have been infected so far,” said a senior doctor working in the laboratory of IGGMCH.More than 85% of the total samples tested in this lab have been negative. It has till date tested 730 samples including 20 on March 29. Of these, 711 have been negative and 19 positive.Municipal Commissioner Tukaram Mundhe also stressed this fact in his video message. “Most first phase patients in Nagpur have the infection source somewhere outside Nagpur. Those who have received infections in second phase have been infected by these first phase patients. There is no evidence of local or community spread yet,” he said.A senior pulmonologist in city claimed this was the perfect time to restrict the coronavirus . “Only those in close contact of positive patients are getting infected. If we follow social distancing strictly, we can restrict the spread. Following the lockdown rules is important for next two weeks,” he said.

Title: For UP techie, quarantine just doesn't end, even after 2 months in isolation
Content:
Meerut: Piyush Vashist, 29, will not forget the weeks leading to his 30th birthday, which falls on April 18. Never diagnosed with Covid-19, his quarantine just doesn’t seem to end, even after two months.

Piyush, a software engineer in a Gurugram firm, was one of the 3,700 passengers on-board the Diamond Princess, a cruise ship which at that time -- in February -- carried the largest cluster of coronavirus cases outside mainland China. Over 700 people aboard the luxury liner had contracted the virus then. After spending 23 days of the quarantine period on the ship, he was allowed to return to India. But soon after landing, Piyush was taken to a government facility in Manesar for another 14 days. That was not the end of it.

Piyush returned to Meerut and was advised to spend another fortnight locked inside his house. And then, before his self-imposed quarantine could end, the nation went into lockdown.

“And all this when I never tested positive for the disease,” said Piyush, who is currently working from home for his company

Recalling the ordeal, he said, “I had boarded the ship on January 25. And quarantine in the ship started on February 3 after one of the passengers, who disembarked, was later found to be Covid-19 positive. I was kept in the ship till February 26, for 23 days. I was again in quarantine after reaching India on February 27 at the Manesar facility. It ended on March 12. I returned to Meerut on March 13. But again I was told to be in quarantine for another 14 days. The 14-day period ended on March 27. And now I can't go out due to the lockdown till April 15. It's a long, long journey ahead.”

His travails notwithstanding, Piyush cautions people against taking the contagious disease lightly. “From my nearly two-month-long quarantine period, all I have learnt is that if anyone has coronavirus-like symptoms, he should inform concerned officials immediately so that steps can be taken to contain the disease and stop its spread," he said.

Title: PMC starts home survey in slums to check Covid-19 spread
Content:
edited

Pune: The civic administration has started home-to-home survey in the dense slum pockets that accommodate over 30% of the city population.

Officials said the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has taken the step to extend its surveillance and contain the spread of coronavirus in the slums.

The surveyors are getting the forms filled by residents with basic information of members in every family, their recent history of outstation travel and if any one of them have come in contact with anyone with an international travel history. Details of women and those working in nearby housing societies as domestic helps, especially those visiting the homes of people with recent international travel history, are also being collected.

The surveyors are also collecting information on the health status of people living in the slum pockets, especially those with symptoms of cough, cold or sneezing. The symptomatic people would be immediately referred to the medical staffers for help, officials in the administration said.

The city has slum pockets in almost all areas. Some of the major slum areas are Patil Estate, Janata Vasahat, Kasewadi, Market Yard and Indiranagar. All these pockets are densely populated with small-sized homes.

A senior official said anticipating some resistance from citizens in furnishing information, the surveyors have been provided with identity cards and letters explaining the reasons for collecting the information.

The official said, “People sometime do not want to reveal details about family or ailments. We are appealing to all citizens to provide necessary information. This is vital to curb the spread of Covid-19. The administration is strict about the home quarantine of those who have come in contact with the people with international travel past. Any such cases identified during the survey will be immediately referred to the medical teams.”

The PMC has appointed staffers from its various departments, besides the Asha workers, clerks and officials from the education department for the survey. Separate teams are being appointed to visit the slum pockets in each ward.

The officials said besides gathering information, the surveyors would conduct awareness drives to educate people on the practices to be followed to restrict the spread of coronavirus.

Title: Good Samaritans help cops have virus-free lives
Content:
Police commissioner Anupam Singh Gahlaut helps himself to some hand sanitizer offered to him while he was on f... Read More

Vadodara: Many in the city are distributing food and grocery kits to poor, some drinking water while others masks. But there are some who have taken the onus of providing free disinfecting services to police stations and giving sanitizers that are difficult to find to the cops.

Police stations witness movement of both police personnel and others. They cannot be shutdown like other offices and cops remain on duty overtime. Cops also come in close contact with many while distributing food or preventing them from violating the lockdown.

In the wake of the situation, a city-based entrepreneur has started disinfecting police stations and even vehicles used by the police. “We had introduced disinfecting as a service as we are already into laundry services, house cleaning, sofa and upholstery sanitization,” said entrepreneur Pradeep Sharma.

However, when their team was returning after sanitizing a school in Warasiya area, cops stopped the team on seeing the equipment. “They asked us details and then requested us to do the same for their police station. The lockdown began the very next day and we decided that we should provide the service for free to the police as they were at risk,” he said.

Sharma’s team has so far sanitized the police commissioner’s office, his residence, police stations and outposts as well as police vehicles. “They are working overtime and we cannot afford to let them fall ill,” said Sharma.

At the other end, Savli-based company Indo Amines Ltd has arranged 20,000 bottles of sanitizers for policemen and other personnel out in the field. The employees and top management of the company started distributing 200ml bottles on Monday and will continue doing so. They are also flooded with demands for arranging more such bottles. The company has ordered more bottles of sanitizers and assured the men in uniform that the supply will continue.

Title: Due date for electricity bill extended to April 15
Content:
Panaji: The Goa electricity department has extended the due date of payment of electricity bills to April 15. In another move that will come as relief to power consumers, no new bills will be generated during the lockdown period, the department has said.

“Meter readers will not be able to go about their duty of recording meter readings,” an official said

The consumers have also been advised to pay their electricity bills online.

Though the department has introduced various online payment platforms, a large section of the population still continues to pay their bills over the counter and at banks. Now, with banks and department offices shut, this will not be possible.

To ensure that citizens are not inconvenienced by any power-related problems during the lockdown period, the department has also appointed taluka-wise nodal officers who can be contacted. A total of 30 nodal officers – 18 for North Goa and 20 for South Goa – comprising executive engineers and assistant engineers have been appointed to ensure uninterrupted power supply during the lockdown. Depending on its size, each taluka has one executive engineer and multiple assistant engineers who have been appointed as the nodal officers.

“The helpdesk number, 1912, can also be accessed round the clock and will be monitored continuously by an officer specifically posted for the purpose,” chief electrical engineer Raghuvir Keni stated in the order.

Title: Police thrash five GSIDC workers
Content: Five workers of Goa State Infrastructure Development Corporation (GSIDC), who were on their way to complete some work on the Covid-19 designated ESI hospital in the run up to its commissioning, were thrashed by cops on Saturday. “The workers had travel passes, but were beaten for defying the lockdown,” a GSIDC official said. With lockdown in force, the GSIDC said they faced difficult time in sourcing labourers for taking up works at the hospital without notice. tnn

Title: Man threatens woman of acid attack, booked
Content:
Prayagraj: An unidentified man allegedly threatened a woman of splashing acid on her on the 12th of this month.

The matter came to light when the woman lodged an FIR under Section 504 (intentionally insults, and thereby gives provocation to any person) and 507 (criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication) of IPC against an unidentified person at Mutthiganj police station on Sunday.

In her FIR, the victim, a resident of Malviya Nagar, alleged that an unidentified man had called her on the evening of March 12 and threatened to splash acid on her.

The FIR also stated that the man hurled expletives on her when she asked him to mend his ways.

Prayagraj SSP Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “A police team was directed to catch the offender. His location has been traced and the arrest will be made soon.”

Title: Duler locals irked over ‘failed’ grocery service
Content: Saligao: Residents in Duler, Mapusa have expressed resentment over the grocery home delivery system introduced by the Mapusa municipality as some commodities did not reach houses in their area.They also claimed that some shops were reselling these items at inflated ratesA few days back, the Mapusa Municipal Council (MMC) had commenced the service within its jurisdiction in the wake of the 21-day lockdown announced by the Centre to curb the spread of Covid-19.The locals claimed the delivery vendors’ phone numbers are either switched off, or were not attending to calls altogether.“Whenever we tried calling the vendors, they cite shortage of items. Even the local councillors are not answering our calls,” Albert de Sa, a resident, said.He also said that one shop at Mapusa was selling vegetables at exorbitant rates - cluster beans at Rs 80 per kg, brinjals at 80 per kg, tomatoes at Rs 100 per kg, drumsticks at Rs 100 per kg and cabbage at Rs 50 per kg.“Many houses in Duler have not received any goods. This scheme launched to provide relief for locals has miserably failed,” another resident Shekar Naik said.Speaking to TOI, MMC chairperson Ryan Braganza said some areas in Mapusa did not receive the commodities due to lack of stock.“We expect that sufficient stock will arrive as trucks which have permits will be allowed to enter the enter the state,” Braganza said.

Title: 28 quarantined in RUHS, no positive case reported from Walled City
Content:
50 quarantined in pvt hospital

Medicine at doorstep

JAIPUR: In all, 28 people from Walled City were sent to RUHS quarantine facilities on Sunday. The good thing however is no more persons tested positive for Covid-19 from the area in the past two days.After reporting two cases of Covid-19 from the Walled City area recently, the health department has intensified screening of people for the virus.“We have identified 28 people who came in contact with the second Covid-19 case reported from Phhuta Khurra in Walled City. They have been sent to RUHS quarantine facility,” said a senior health department official.However, the health department has found two persons who came in contact with the second patient and now have complaints of fever and cough. They have been sent to Sawai Man Singh Hospital. The doctors admitted them and took their samples. The report is awaited.In two days, the health department’s teams conducted survey of the houses have conducted screening of 1 lakh people of the Walled City. The health department has adopted the same strategy in Jaipur which they had planned for Bhilwara to contain the spread. They have completely blocked entry of any person inside the Walled City and also outward movement is restricted. The health department has created a containment zone in Walled City area to allow the health department’s team to visit houses of the people to find out if anyone is suffering from influenza-like illness.Roads in the Walled City are wearing a deserted look as curfew entered its third day on Sunday.Police said they were allowing supply of essential commodities in areas where curfew had been imposed. The vendors under public distribution system are supplying grocery and other items such as milk, bread and vegetables have been made available at door steps of the people.JAIPUR: In all, 50 people from Ramganj have been quarantined in a private hospital. The authorities counselled them and they agreed to stay in quarantine for 14 days. They were served with idli sambhar. Most of them called their homes and got books to pass their time and other glued to mobile phones.Health department has introduced a facility to provide medicine at the doorstep of patients at a time when the entire state is under lockdown . For helping patients, who are at home, a control room has been set up with the number 0141-2228600. A patient can call the number and provide information about medicines he requires. The control room will provide Whatsapp number of the chemist close to his house. The patient will send the information to the Whatsapp number of the chemist who will supply the medicine to the patient at his doorstep.

Title: Cops accused of preventing feeding of ‘homeless’ animals
Content:
Trichy: Even as the animal husbandry department has issued directive allowing animal lovers/NGOs to feed homeless animals, incidents of people being prevented from feeding animals by police personnel continue to take place in the city.

A Antony Raj, 51, has been feeding about 40 dogs in his street, a daily routine that he has been doing the last five years. He runs a coconut shop near his house and also raises four dogs.

On Friday night, when he went to feed the dogs, he was picked up by Palakkarai police for coming out to feed them.

He usually goes out after 11pm at night to feed dogs with cooked poultry waste like legs and intestines to ensure that no one is disturbed. However the police personnel on rounds on Friday night were not convinced, following which an altercation ensued and he was even slapped.

The union home ministry had on Thursday clarified that inter-state transport of animal feed and fodder was exempted from the lockdown. Also, the state animal husbandry department directed to allow feeding homeless animals.

The animal husbandry department also asked the respective district administrations to identify genuine feeders and issue passes in consultation with local body authorities and police. A senior official from the district administration said that it may not be possible to issue pass or identity cards as it may lead to duplication and misuse.

A Thangaraj, 52, from Sanjeevi Nagar, said that despite furnishing necessary documents, which allows feeding dogs during the lockdown, police from Malaikottai police station are refusing to even read the documents.

“They simply said that they would arrest me if I continue to feed dogs for violating section 144. I have approached the district administration with a petition a few days back. It would be helpful for people like me if district administration issues an identity card or a letter allowing us to carry on with our service,” he said.

Such incidents only reflects the general aversion among most people in the society towards homeless animals, says honorary district animal welfare officer G Ramakrishnan from the Animal welfare board of India. “It is important to understand that foods from eateries and restaurants have been cut-off in the wake of lockdown. The sudden stoppage of feed will lead to starvation and other harmful menace,” he said.

Title: Mumbai doctor rides 20km to clinic, advises others to serve people
Content: MUMBAI: At a time when a majority of private medical practitioners have shut their clinics across the city, five patients are eagerly awaiting their turn at this small space on Datta Mandir Road in Bhandup West on Sunday. Their faces show signs of pain due to their ailments but they are glad this doctor has chosen to open his clinic at a time when many others have shut theirs in the wake of Covid-19 Dr Ganesh Jaiswal (39), who prefers to be low-profile, travels more than 20km one way to reach his clinic daily.“I will keep coming here as I have vowed to serve citizens in times of need,” said the doctor, who lives in Matunga with his wife and daughter and travels to Bhandup by scooter “There are so many patients in the area who need to see a doctor for not just flu-like symptoms but other illnesses and ailments as well,” he said on Sunday while examining a patient. His clinic timings are 10am to 2pm and 5.30pm to 10.30pm. “I prefer to eat and rest in the clinic in the afternoon before starting the evening shift,” said the doctor who has been getting around 50 patients daily for a week now.Savita Marathe, a resident of Village Road near the clinic, said, “In these stressful times, we cannot just go to a chemist and ask for medicines. We need a doctor.”Dr Jaiswal said all private practitioners in the city should come out and start their clinics.

Title: Despite technical snags, nearly a lakh attend Sunday mass online
Content:
KOLKATA: The Sunday prayer service (mass) streamed online from the Archbishop House was viewed not only by parishioners of 65 churches under the archdiocese of Kolkata but also by around one lakh Catholics with roots in the city settled across the globe. It gave them an opportunity to pray with family and friends in Kolkata.

The mass started at 8am, and was relayed live via YouTube. But there were a few technical snags that interfered with archbishop Thomas D Souza’s sermon. The video was later uploaded online. In his sermon, D Souza delivered messages on hygiene as well.

“It was unbelievable…we all sang hymns sitting in New York. We will be saying the Good Friday and Easter prayers with family back in Kolkata as well!” said Joseph Gomes from New York. “Seeing the archbishop praying gave us goosebumps. We will pray together on Good Friday and Easter too,” Sadhana Gomes wrote from Birmingham, UK.

“On Good Friday too, the celebration of the Lord’s Passion will be streamed live from the Archbishop House at 3pm,” said vicar general Dominic Gomes . Since no one will be in church, parishioners will organize the Way of the Cross at home. For Easter Vigil on April 11, the Easter Vigil Liturgy will again be streamed live from the Archbishop House.

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Morning walkers violate lockdown order, booked
Content:
Bapu Waghmare, a 68-year-old daily wage worker, sits on his handcart on Sunday in the hope that some work will... Read More

PUNE: The Pune rural police on Saturday registered offences against four morning walkers in Narayangaon. Another person found wandering on the road in Kamshet in the evening was also booked.

“During the lockdown, people are expected to stay at their homes, not head out for their daily morning walk,” said inspector Arjun Ghode Patil of Narayangaon police station. The officer added that the police teams have been appealing to people to remain indoors.

Even so, some people were seen stepping out of their homes early in the morning. “On Saturday, we fanned out teams to trace morning walkers. We found four people and registered offences against them,” Ghode Patil said.

“They claimed that they had stepped out of their homes when there were hardly anyone on the road. People should know that they will remain safe indoors,” the officer added.

Similarly, an officer from Kothrud police station noticed a few elderly people on an evening walk on Saturday. “I requested them to return home as they are the most vulnerable right now,” the officer said.

PMC corporator Alpna Varpe too has appealed to people to put morning walks on hold for now. She warned that the police will take action against morning walkers.

Title: Pune: Fresh arrival of produce at Market Yard to ease supply
Content:
The market is expecting another round of arrivals on Tuesday

PUNE: The availability of vegetables in the city improved on Sunday with the fresh arrival of 14,850 quintal of produce at the Agriculture Produce Marketing Committee (APMC) in Gultekdi as well as its five sub-markets in Uttamnagar, Pimpri, Moshi, Hadapsar and Khadki .

Balasaheb Deshmukh, the chief administrator of APMC, told TOI, “The fresh arrivals are sufficient to meet the city’s vegetable requirement for the next two days and another round of arrivals is expected on Tuesday. In normal circumstances, the daily arrival of vegetables is in the range of 15,000 to 17,000 quintals. On Monday, the market will open for onion, potato and fruits.”

The APMC and Shree Chhatrapati Shivaji Market Yard Adate Association, a body of the commission agents which facilitate auction of produce for farmers and wholesale traders, are yet to reach a consensus on the need to open all shops in the Gultekdi Market Yard. On Sunday, barely 10% of the 450 shops belonging to the commission agents were opened. Vegetables like coriander,spinach and fenugreek were sold in the range of Rs4 to Rs8 per bunch. Other vegetables like tomato, and cauliflower, among others were sold at average rates, the authorities said.

The vehicles came to the market between 9pm on Saturday to 4am on Sunday. “Only license holder traders and staffers are allowed inside market,” Deshmukh said.

He said, “We expect a better response going ahead. The commission agents need to understand that meeting people’s requirement is a priority. Our discussion with the association is under way and we hope they will respond positively.”

However, Vilas Bhujbal, the president of the commission agents body, said, “Our concerns relating to the health scare are genuine and our members won’t open their shops till March 31.”

Title: Finally, ESI Covid-19 hosp starts, 5 patients moved in
Content:
Panaji: The ESI hospital at Margao, which was designated a Covid-19 hospital a few days ago, was finally commissioned on Sunday with all patients transferred to it. With two new cases detected today, the number of confirmed cases of Covid-19 has risen to five in the state.

Until Sunday afternoon, only one patients was being treated in ESI hospital while two were in the isolation ward of the Goa Medical College (GMC). The GMC authorities, who were ready to shift the two patients under its care to the ESI hospital earlier, had to defer plan until today.

A senior government official said an anesthetist attached to GMC had certified that the ESI hospital was adequate for the treatment of Covid-19 patients, but the government requested former GMC dean V N Jindal to conduct an inspection with other members.

“Hence, the two patients could not be transferred there immediately even though the GMC had the ESI hospital inspected by an ICU expert. The expert did not point to any discrepancies and there was no need for a fresh examination. The commissioning of the hospital was delayed,” the official said.

The 60-bed hospital is relatively new. Provision for ten ventilators have been made,” he said.

Secretary, department of health and family welfare, Preeti Sudan had written to chief secretaries of all states and Union territories to create a fully dedicated standalone hospital for Covid-19 patients as it will able to provide specialised care for the unique needs of the confirmed cases and prevent risk of transmission.

Professor and head of medicine department, Dr Edwin Gomes has been appointed nodal officer of the ESI Covid-19 hospital. A team of frontline doctors comprising physicians, anaesthesiologist, pulmonary specialist, ENT experts and expert nurses for ICU have been posted there, the official said.

Title: App-based food delivery execs told to obtain ID cards
Content:
Trichy: After restoring food delivery services, the city police have instructed delivery executives of Swiggy and Zomato to obtain identity cards by submitting applications immediately. The services of the food aggregators had been suspended as part of the Covid-19 lockdown.

The state government has now allowed them to deliver food to ensure food for the elderly and those unable to cook, a statement from the police commissioner office said. They would be allowed to deliver food from 7 am to 9.30 am, from noon to 2.30 pm and 6 pm to 9 pm.

Those delivering food should obtain ID cards issued from the police department. Food aggregators should ensure that delivery executives health is monitored every day. Those who want ID cards should apply for the same along with their two passport size photographs.

The applications should be submitted to the office of deputy commissioner of police, crime and traffic regulations, functioning from police quarters in Beema Nagar in Trichy along with required documents. They may call 0431-2416710 for further clarifications, the statement said.

Title: Pune: Head nurse at forefront of H1N1 fight battles Covid-19
Content:
Saroj Pillai

PUNE: From sleepless nights at home after completing the day’s duty to watching out for her own health with blood pressure and sugar issues, Saroj Pillai, head nurse of the Naidu hospital’s out-patient department, is fighting battles on two fronts.

Pillai was also at the forefront of operations tackling cases of H1N1 in 2009 at the infectious diseases section in Naidu hospital, and with her vast experience, she is once again at the current situation with Covid-19 cases.

“I have two daughters. Both are married. But, one daughter has sacrificed her own family, and come to help me at home knowing I spend several hours at the hospital. They know that I must take care of myself. So my daughter has been staying with me since January. She cooks for me and takes care of the house while I am away,” Pillai said.

Pillai said Naidu hospital began getting ready to fight the coronavirus ever since the outbreak in China. The staff had undergone several training sessions on precautions, treatment, handling patients, maintaining their own health, wearing the safety kit to other aspects of the disease.

“We have also experienced H1N1 in 2009. I was head of the OPD even then so although there was a lot of panic outside when the first couple in Pune was diagnosed with Covid-19, we at the hospital were calm as we know exactly how to handle the situation. We do not have any fear in us any more,” she said.

In the initial days, when the first patients were admitted to Naidu hospital, the staff would spend over 12 hours at the hospital getting things right. Now, that it is more streamlined, Pillai said she is able to return home after the eight-hour duty.

“When I come home, I first go to the washroom, take a bath, wash all my clothes then I move around the house. That’s the protocol we must follow. This disease is more dangerous than H1N1. It is spreading like wild fire and all the steps put down by WHO must be followed judiciously,” she added.

At home, Pillai, said she is unable to sleep. “I get constant thoughts of hospital, patients and I keep hoping everything is alright there. Even the eight-hour duty is highly stressful, both mentally and physically.”

Her neighbours and people in the locality are cooperative and check with her about her health and the situation at the hospital. The hospital has provided vehicles to pick and drop the nursing staff so she does not have to worry about commuting, she added.

Title: Jaipur: Inmates of Sanganer open jail join fight against pandemic
Content:
Around 60-80 inmates are involve in manufacturing and packing of sanitisers in the jail.

JAIPUR: On usual days, the inmates of Sanganer situated open jail are allowed to go out and work as mechanics, tailors or other random jobs with a condition that they will get back to jail at 6pm. However, during the ongoing lockdown while they were not having their usual jobs, the jail authorities have roped in a private company for which the inmates are manufacturing and packaging 5,000 litres of sanitisers every day. With this initiative, at least 80 inmates with their families are able to earn Rs 350 per day in this tough time as well. Inmates, including convicted prisoners had earlier prepared 4,000 masks.

Sanganer open jail in Jaipur is for prisoners who have a very good conduct. At this jail they are allowed to live with their families in different quarters. They are allowed to move out of jail for various small jobs.

“After lock down was announced, they were sitting idle. Though we have engaged them in some other work, still there was a need to channelise their energy in some work. A private company involved in manufacturing of sanitisers came to us since they witnessed a problem of short staff. So, we asked them to bring their machines and raw materials and provided them our men,” said NRK Reddy , director general of police(Jails).

Also, inmates would be working in shifts and work for 24 hours for this job. 49-year-old Ram Naryan, who is convicted in a murder case and serving life imprisonment, is happy to be into this job. “We too will think that while country is facing a crisis, we are contributing with our ways and means. It is a wonderful idea by authorities,” he said while talking to TOI over phone.

He said that authorities started the work on Friday and will continue. “Everyday, about 60 to 80 inmates are involved in manufacturing and packaging of sanitisers in 100 ml to 500 ml bottles. This has provided us a source of earning,” he added.

The idea to involve the inmates into such kind of work struck into mind of Vikas Kumar, inspector general of police (Jail) when he was asked by an inmate about how can he contribute to the society in this tough time. “It touched me. Apart from sanitisers, we have so far made 40,000 masks. Some of them have been distributed among the inmates and our staff,” Kumar added.

Jail authorities are also mulling over giving manpower to agencies and NGOs who are into distributing grocery items to the poor people. “We are in touch with some agencies. In a day or two our manpower of inmates will also start packing of grocery,” he said.

Title: Man guns down elderly father over land dispute in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A family dispute over land took a deadly turn on Sunday, when a 45-year-old farmer from Baramati shot dead his father before turning the gun on himself. The man — Deepak Khomane — survived the suicide attempt.

The incident occurred at 10.30am at Korale village in Baramati taluka. The man’s father, Dhanvantrao, died instantly as he was shot at a close range.

“Deepak was first taken to a private hospital in Baramati and later shifted to a private hospital in Pune. His condition is critical,” Navnath Lande, assistant inspector of Vadgaon Nimbalkar police, said.

Lande said that Deepak had an old dispute with his father over land. On Sunday morning, when his father was in his sugar cane farm, Deepak arrived there and picked up an argument.

“After a heated argument, Deepak whipped out his licensed pistol and shot his father from a close range, killing him on the spot,” Lande said.

Deepak then shot himself in the head. Khomane’s relative Uday has lodged an FIR with the police.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 20-year-old woman killed by husband
Content:
Representative Image

PRAYAGRAJ: A 20-year-old woman was allegedly killed by her husband in Pathak Ka Pura under Nawabganj police station in Trans Ganga area here on Sunday morning.

The accused husband identified as Babloo, a resident of Mauaima , was arrested. The deceased, identified as Savita , was a resident of Nawabganj.

“Savita got married to Babloo about a year back and had a two-month-old baby with him,” said Nawabganj police. “Savita had returned to her parents’ house a month ago and was not ready to go to her husband’s home due to problems best known to her,” added police.

“On Sunday morning, Babloo arrived at his parents-in-law’s house. As soon as Savita opened the gate, he allegedly attacked her with a stone and left her profusely bleeding. Hearing the cries of Savita, family members and neighbours rushed to the spot and caught the accused red handed. They thrashed him before handing him over to the police. A case has been lodged in this connection,” informed police.

Title: PCB to start vegetable market at Golibar Maidan
Content:
Pune: The Pune Cantonment Board (PCB) will set-up a vegetable and fruits market in Golibar Maidan to house the vendors being temporarily shifted out of the Shivaji market in Camp.

The PCB and the city police officials on Saturday surveyed the Shivaji market and found the place to be extremely crowded. The delegation found the area prone to easy contagion spread in light of coronavirus outbreak in the city.

“We cannot stop the market completely as it will cause inconvenience to the residents,” PCB’s joint chief executive officer Rahul Gajbhiye said.

“We discussed the matter with the vendors. They have some logistic issues. The market will start functioning from Golibar Maidan once those issues are addressed,” Gajbhiye said.

“In this prevailing situation, we had to shut the market and start at the new location with proper earmarking between two vendors. Besides, we will make the necessary arrangement to maintain the required social distancing between vendors and customers,” he said.

Elected board member Priyanka Shirigiri said, “The vendors operating at the Shivaji Market do not pay heed to any instruction or notice issued by the board. The police and the board should take stern action against the violators to send a stern message.”

Title: Bootleggers cash in on depleting liquor stocks of confined tipplers
Content:
A closed liquor shop on Lenin Sarani on the fifth day of lockdown

KOLKATA: Depleting liquor stocks at homes have given the bootleggers an opportunity to make a fortune by selling whisky and rum at a huge premium. With more than a fortnight still to go before the lockdown is either lifted or extended further, suggestions have emerged on how to make a restricted availability of liquor for home consumption to not only rein in the risk of adulteration but also resolve the issue of stocks that retailers and clubs have as the excise department’s deadline of March 31 looms large.

As the lockdown in Bengal was initially scheduled till March 27, many consumers had stocked up booze for a week. But with the Centre announcing later the extension of the shutdown till April 14, there was no way consumers could buy and stock up any more. With stocks now getting depleted, a section of regular tipplers has started making frantic calls to retailers, displaying signs of the onset of withdrawal symptom.

“I have been getting calls from almost everyone — the customers whom I know and strangers. The call usually begins with any information as to when the store would open and is followed by a request to purchase a bottle or more on the sly. They even offer huge premium on the MRP. But I have had to turn them down because I don’t want to risk a crackdown,” said US Roy who runs a liquor store in a shopping complex off EM Bypass.

Some people in the city had last purchased liquor on Monday when the shops were open till 5pm. “I was shocked when the PM announced the 21-day lockdown. I have been judiciously consuming one peg and a half in evening. But my friend came to my place one day and we polished off half of the bottle. Now, I am out of stock,” said Gaurav Talukdar , a Parnashree resident and a central government employee.

A bootlegger in Behala has got five youths in his team to step up supply of liquor in keeping with the increasing demand. “Considering the risk I am taking and the bribe I am paying, I am not supplying booze at exorbitant prices,” said the man who is charging Rs 100 to supply bottles.

Title: NMC brings 35 contacts of 14th positive person for tests
Content:
Nagpur: Immediately after learning about the 14th Covid-19 positive patient in city, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) launched a containment drive in his residential society, and brought 35 people, including family members and close contacts, for testing.

The NMC team led by additional medical health officer Dr Praveen Gantawar rushed to the society near Gandhisagar Lake. “The patient resides with wife, son and daughter. We got list of close contacts from the person and family members, and brought others too in for testing. This is very essential for controlling further spread of Covid-19,” he said.

As per information available from the NMC team and other flat owners in the society, the person is a lawyer and income tax consultant. His son is studying in a residential school run by Iskcon at Vrindavan in Uttar Pradesh. The person, his wife and daughter had gone to Vrindavan on March 15.

They offered services at Iskcon Temple , which is visited by a large number of people, including foreigners. They returned with their son on March 18, travelling in the Telangana Express, the same train in which the Khamla businessman and his manager, who too later tested positive, returned to the city from New Delhi. However, this person and his family were in 3rd AC compartment while the Khamla businessman and manager were in sleeper class.

The boarding station of the family could not be exactly confirmed. One of the flat owners in the society said they might have boarded from New Delhi while NMC team members said they took the train from Mathura.

The patient also runs an office from his flat. Two assistants and one office boy work there, and the family also has a housemaid.

Gantawar said, “The patient is a member of Iskcon and used to regularly take part in activities at the Iskcon Temple in his society. Therefore, we identified other members of Iskcon and brought them too for testing.”

The patient’s parents reside at Kamptee. NMC is planning to bring them too for testing on Monday.

NMC has conducted door-to-door containment drive in the society with 80 flats on Friday and Saturday. The person had gone to Mayo Hospital for testing, probably after getting guidance from the NMC team.

After tests of 42 persons, NMC has stopped identifying more contacts of the Khamla businessman, his three family members and manager, with a containment drive in 3km radius of Khamla.

On Sunday, two staffers of the businessman were picked up from Khamla and admitted in MLA Hostel Quarantine Center. They had tested negative on Friday, so had returned home. However, the latest orders of collector Ravindra Thakre says all suspected cases have to stay in quarantine centre.

At Jaripatka, NMC had sent 16 persons, including family members and friends of staffers of the Khamla businessman, for testing on Sunday. The staffer has tested positive. Reports of three others are awaited.

NMC has come to know about another six persons who were in constant touch with the staffer. The NMC’s containment drive has started to trace these six persons, and they will be brought in for testing on Monday.

Also, the civic body launched the containment drive in 3km radius of Jaripatka.

Title: Families huddle to ‘quaran-binge’ on old TV shows
Content:
Prayagraj: They say history has a way of repeating itself. The words couldn’t be truer in Prayagraj resident Vinay Mehrotra’s case. He has fond memories of being hooked to the television while watching shows like Ramayana and Mahabharata on Doordarshan as a child back in the 1980s.

Now 45, Mehrotra is reliving those days as he sits down to watch the same shows this time with his children. Following the announcement of the 21-day lockdown to arrest the spread of the novel coronavirus contagion, Prasar Bharti decided to re-telecast many of its popular shows including Ramayana, Mahabharata and the Shahrukh Khan-starrer Fauji, almost 25 years after they first aired on Doordarshan.

Forced to stay indoors, residents are using the time to bond with their families by watching these iconic shows together.

“These shows were a part of our lives. I am delighted to watch them again with my family,” Mehrotra said.

Lukerganj resident Rajul Bhargava said, “It feels good to relive those days. Arun Govil and Deepika Chikhalia, who played Ram and Sita in the drama, became household names after the show.”

“Watching these re-runs is a great way to keep the monotony of staying at home during the lockdown,” he added.

Ramayana first aired on Doordarshan in 1987.

For many like Meerapur resident Anil Kumar Mishra, it is a flashback to the time when television was still a luxury.

“We used to live in Old City in the 80s and our family was the one of the few which owned a television set. More than two dozen people used to gather in our home every Sunday morning to watch these shows,” Mishra said.

The 46-year-old’s wife Manorama said her children, now aged 22 and 18, were familiar with stories from Ramayana and Mahabharata thanks to these shows.

Civil Lines resident Kunal Sharma beleives the lockdown has given families a reason to spend more time together. “Otherwise, most of us are too busy to just sit back and relax with our near and dear ones.”

Then there are many others who are using the free time to explore fun-filled activities.

Be it trying out new hobbies or working on creative projects together, Prayagraj residents are all for using this time constructively.

Old city resident Pankaj Singh said that he is utilising the time by reading books penned by his favourite authors.

Aditi Pandey, a teacher by profession, said, “We are living in difficult times and therefore must follow the state government’s advice to stay indoors. We should the use time to bond with our family members in the best way possible.”

Title: Trichy: Farmer supplies vegetables to families free-of-cost
Content: TRICHY: Over the last two days, S Moorthy, 51, an organic farmer in Pudukottai, had distributed over 1,000 kg of vegetables to under privileged families in Pudukottai town. He made free door-to-door supply of vegetables worth Rs 15,000, of which a portion was grown on his own farm.Acknowledging that the preventive lockdown has affected lives of daily wage labourers, Moorthy said he was attempting to compensate their losses by providing them essentials free-of-cost.People have been thanking Moorthy for this gesture as it will save them some money to manage during the lockdown.“On the one hand Moorthy has been saving us from the possibility of getting infected with Covid-19 by bringing to us vegetables and on the other hand helping us save some money to manage several weeks of lockdown that we are likely to face,” said S Mahendran, a resident from Bose Nagar.Moorthy said that it was this section of people who need utmost care during such a crisis as they depend on daily wages to run their families.Saying that he would continue to help them in the coming days, he also took it as an opportunity to propagate organic farming to the people.He brings around eight types of vegetables from the wholesale market apart from onion, tomato and garlic which are essential. He also brings snake gourd grown on his farm.Moorthy who was running a restaurant in Pudukottai town for 20 years took to organic farming five years ago after a snake gourd curry prepared in his hotel went sour which made him realise the effect of chemical fertilisers used to raise vegetables. He then started raising vegetables in his farm through organic farming techniques. Now there are about 20 farmers who have adopted organic farming after abandoning chemical fertilisers.

Title: Covid-19 lockdown: Farmer who could not harvest banana bunches ends life
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: A 65-year-old banana farmer from Kuzhumani village, who consumed pesticide four days ago distressed by crop loss, died at the Mahatma Gandhi Medical College Hospital on Saturday night.

Family members of K Periyasamy of Mela Kuzhumani said he resorted to the extreme step as he could not harvest Nendran banana cultivated on half an acre of leased land following the nationwide lockdown. He had raised Ela Arisi banana on his one acre and Nendran on the half acre.

Periyasamy was upset that he could not harvest and sell his crop and it had started to ripen on the tree itself. He was found consuming pesticide at his house on March 25 and was rushed to MGMGH where he died on Saturday. Deputy superintendent of police Jeeyapuram C Kokila told TOI that the loss sustained in banana cultivation had caused some domestic issues. Jeeyapuram police registered a case under 174 IPC based on a complaint from his family members. He is survived by his wife P Krishnammal, a daughter and son.

TOI had reported how the fall in demand for Nendran in Kerala had hit Trichy farmers hard leading to a crash in the price of the variety to about Rs 10 to 15 a kg. The outbreak of Covid-19 dealt a huge blow to the distressed farmers as it halted the transport of the entire consignment of Nendran to Kerala. The 21-day lockdown only made matters worse. Farmers’ leaders have appealed to the state government to compensate the victim’s family appropriately

Title: ‘Police told not to stop vehicles with essentials’
Content:
Panaji: Chief minister Pramod Sawant said he has issued instructions to Goa police not to stop vehicles transporting essential goods, or those going to pick up food supplies.

Sawant said that the supply chain of essential commodities may have been affected because of fear in the minds of distributors and retailers to send their vehicles to get the stock, as police may stop them.

He warned wholesalers that action would be initiated against them if they do not open their godowns to maintain the supply chain.

Sawant also said action would be taken against traders who try to increase the prices of essential commodities and vegetables.

Food delivery apps can only deliver prepared food, and not essential commodities, he clarified. He also said that the state government has started a ‘food bus’ to supply food to the needy.

“There are some villages that have blocked the roads leading to their villages to keep people out. They should not do it,” he said.

He also said that 2.5 lakh labourers wanted to cross the state borders and leave, but that the government has made the necessary arrangements to keep them in the state. Sawant also said that three people entered the state using a letter from the embassy, but were asked to leave soon after.

Sawant said the state has appointed the excise commissioner as nodal officer and foreigners in distress should contact him for evacuation.

Title: Police deliver essentials to lonely seniors’ doorsteps in Kolkata and satellite townships
Content: KOLKATA: At a time when the entire country is under lockdown to beat the novel coronavirus , a section of elderly people, whose children stay away from them, are finding it difficult to manage groceries themselves.On realising their situation, cops have started reaching out to the senior citizens stuck at home and helping them with daily essentials and medicines delivered at their doorsteps.Golpark resident Chhanda Roy (77), who is suffering from severe arthritis, lives with her husband (81). The couple has been facing problems to get daily essentials in the absence of their domestic help. On Saturday, they found their medicines had finished while the online facilities were not taking orders. When they called Rabindra Sarobar police station for help, cops reached their home with the medicines in next 40 minutes. “My idea of Kolkata Police is undergoing a sea change after this incident, a reminder that they care for the senior citizens. They were very methodical and even crosschecked from the pharmaceutical stores with me when they found a certain brand of medicine was out of stock. They waited for me to speak to the doctor and arrange an alternative medicine," she said. Another woman, who works in Mumbai, said that she was amazed when her relatives in Gariahat received unprecedented help from the police. In Bidhannagar too, cops are reaching out to elderly residents and handing essential items over to them. Retired TELCO official Anandajyoti Mukhopadhyay (83) and his wife Ranu (75), residents of Rajarhat, whose two sons stay in the US and Singapore, said they got milk, fruits and rice delivered at their doorsteps in two hours after stating their problems to the police.

Title: Colonies enforce new rules to #FlattenTheCurve
Content:
Bhopal: Responding to the call of #FlattenTheCurve, Bhopal colonies have come up with new rules to keep themselves and other safe during the pandemic.

Most colonies have banned entry of outsiders — other than essential services — and are ensuring that those who enter wash their hands with soap before coming inside. The security guards have been provided masks, sanitisers and hand wash and advised to wash their hands every hour. Treasurer of Fortune Estate Phase-2 CB Churiya said, “There is a notice board on the colony gate where we have written that all outsiders, even relatives and friends of the residents have been banned to enter amid the corona scare. The guard has also been instructed to not let people go out until it is a real emergency. We have made a special request to the residents to not go out for groceries every day and stock things for the next two weeks.”

Harish Kumar, of Uma Enclave, Kolar added, “Ours is a very small colony with only 30 families. So, we have kept a bucket of water at the gate and clearly told the guard to make residents wash their hands before entering the colony and wash their clothes as soon as they enter the house, before greeting the children.”

Many colonies have also formed committees to ensure proper supply of water and other necessary items in absence of the colony management staff. “I live in the new residential colony developed by the BDA in Katara Hills. As we understand that there is a shortage of the management staff, we have formed teams to ensure that if in case the staff doesn’t come, we know how to turn on the water supply for the buildings so that people don't face problems. We will also form an emergency fund in case we find the virus has affected some residents,” said Bhagwan Singh, member of the committee of Gaurishankar Parisar.

Ravi Galkate, resident of Fortune estate, Trilanga said that all the members of the locality have been asked to stay indoors and skip their morning and evening walks to ensure that the lockdown is followed properly.

Title: Delhi: Online classes, two per day, for Class XII students
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal said the government will provide money to buy internet data packs (Photo: ANI)

NEW DELHI: Delhi government will begin online classes for around 1.4 lakh Class XII students to compensate for the classes curtailed by the Covid-19 lockdown. Students from nursery to Class VIII will, however, be promoted to the next class without sitting for exams under the no detention policy of the Right to Education Act.

These announcements were made by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and deputy chief minister and education minister Manish Sisodia on Monday. Sisodia said, “The main decision we have taken is for Class XII students appearing for the board exam next year. We will start online classes for them with two subjects per day. The students will be provided with a link through SMS. They will have to register for the class.”

An education department official explained, “Teachers who teach the main Class XII subjects have been shortlisted. They are being given orientation on how the online classes are to be conducted.” The online facility is on the lines of a Zoom app session and a private firm has been consulted for holding these classes. The state government will provide the students money to purchase internet data packs.

“The online classes will begin from the first week of April,” said Sisodia. “Later, we will start similar classes for Class X students. For Class IX, we are discussing the format with CBSE.”

Students can post their query in a chat box for teachers to answer them in the next class. Even though the eight lakh students from nursery to Class VIII will be given promotion, there will still be continuous assessment for Delhi government, aided and municipal corporation schools.

Sisodia said, “The exams were first hit by the riots and now the coronavirus pandemic. This is the reason why we are promoting them. But the students will have to study with the help of parents and technology. We will send them basic activities through SMS and IVR, one activity per day. This will be in the form of a project and will have to be submitted once the school reopens. Internal assessment will be based on their work.”

Title: When police fed hungry migrant labourers in Jaipur
Content:
JAIPUR: Amidst the long march of migrant workers from various states passing through the state capital, a police jeep comes to an abrupt halt just below the flyover at Transport Nagar junction around 2.30pm on Sunday.

There were three policemen in the front — two constables and an officer. For a couple of minutes nobody got down just as flying patrol teams do — just watch and leave. Soon, the officer comes out followed by the constables including the driver. They open the rear door of the vehicle. Inside, there are at least 500 food packets. With hordes of people passing by, circle inspector Gayasuddin Khan shouts out to people to collect the packets. In five minutes, the food is gone.

“For the last two days, a lot of organisations, especially trade bodies, are dropping food packets in the police station for distribution. Since movement is restricted, they are coming to the thana and requesting us to distribute the packets,” Gayasuddin said. “Since morning, we have distributed over 2,500 food packets among migrant workers. A few of them hadn’t had any food since yesterday night. It feels good to help them,” he said.

The officer said a number of traders’ bodies were also distributing food packets in their localities. “To ensure that there is no chaos while distributing, we are deploying a couple of constables there,” he added. In addition to giving food packets away, the constables were also helping the labourers to board buses going to various destinations.

“I am from Agra and want to know where I will get a bus,” asked Praveen Sharma , a construction worker from Sikar to the constable. “Please stand here for a while. The state government is operating a number of buses. You will surely get one,” the constable, who refused to be identified, said.

Gayasuddin expressed fear that with most people not wearing masks, one infected person could wreak havoc in the days to come. “They aren’t lucky like us. Most of them don’t have masks. All they can do is to cover their faces with towels and handkerchiefs. But since they are walking for miles, the heat is preventing them from covering their faces,” Gayasuddin said.

Title: Old hobbies become survival mantra for many during lockdown
Content:
Bandana Bhattacharya

Surat: The nationwide 21-day lockdown to contain spread of COVID-19 has made some people feel as if they are under house arrest. However, it has also provided an opportunity to many others to revisit old hobbies and undertake health pursuits which were not possible earlier for them due to their busy schedules.

Spending quality time with family

For diamond baron, Hitesh Patel, the lockdown has come as a blessing in disguise. His busy schedule at the diamond company and frequent travelling kept him away from enjoying family life, which he is trying to live during the lockdown. “I was yearning to stay home with my family. The lockdown has given me a golden opportunity to fulfil my dreams. I keep myself engaged reading Bhagavad Gita, playing board games with my kids and doing a bit of gardening in our bungalow,” Patel said.

“Every evening, all the family members gather in our garden and sing bhajans and do aarti after offering special prayers to the almighty for the well-being of people in our nation,” he added.

Back to reading and cooking

Bandana Bhattacharya, renowned fashion designer, was not getting time from her busy schedule to read books and cook food for her children at home. Though she is very much concerned about the spread of COVID-19, lockdown has given her an opportunity to be at home with her children and husband. “Our cook is on leave, so I am preparing delicious dishes for my children, including traditional Bengali dishes,” Bandana said. “I was not getting time to even read books, which I am doing now staying at home,” she added.

Bonding with children over games and dance

Sanat Relia, hotelier, was missing an emotional connect with his grandchildren due to his busy schedule managing his three hotels in the city. But, lockdown has come as a blessing in disguise for him.

“My grandchildren were not much attached to me as I was unable to spend time at home. As I remain at home during lockdown, they now have an emotional bonding with me. Now they play indoor games and dance with me. They have found a new friend in me. In the evening, all the family members gather at the dinner table, which we missed since long, and enjoy the delicious meals,” he said.

Keeping healthy and cooking for the needy

Pramod Choudhary, textile entrepreneur, sees an opportunity in lockdown to keep himself healthy with exercise and Yoga. “We all are passing from the toughest phase of our lives where we don’t know what is going to happen in next few days. So, I am practising Yoga, meditation and doing gardening to keep myself fit. In the evening, we cook food for about 60 poor people living on the footpath near my residence,” he said.

Title: Renovatio: Leading social renewal through service
Content:
The seeds of this NGO were sown after a march organized through a call given by Nakul Agrawal to protest Nirbhaya gang rape in 2012. The group expanded its horizon to offer services in education, child welfare, waste management, disaster relief and other social causes. At present, the group is holding Facebook live sessions daily to help those stranded by coronavirus and will launch an app soon

Nagpur: In 2012, the brutal Nirbhaya gang rape shook the country’s soul. While protest marches demanding justice for Nirbhaya were happening across the country, Nagpur’s poor protest culture hit the consciousness of a young city boy.Nakul Agrawal, then 21, felt the need to show support to the victim. Two weeks after the incident, Nakul decided to organize a march in the city. The news spread like wildfire. He managed to bring together thousands of people to show solidarity with the victim.This was when he realized that Nagpur, too, “stood for good.” Tells Nakul, “After the rally, I realized that citizens wish to do good; all they need is a platform through which they can do so as not everyone has the vision to initiate things.”With this understanding, Nakul went ahead to form the NGO ‘ Renovatio ’ which is a Latin word for renewal, restoration and rebirth.Initially, the young group started by teaching children in municipal schools, orphanages and slums. “We focused on holistic education by teaching them mathematics, science and English experientially, along with meditation, yoga, dance and arts. We also created libraries and playrooms in some schools and shelter homes,” says Sonal Hikare , who manages the outreach of Renovatio.Simultaneously, the group organized numerous awareness and educational campaigns in the city. These included Ecycle your Ewaste, No Honking, Helmet and Road Safety Awareness, Project Muskaan for rescuing child labourers & beggars, waste collecting mobilizing campaign, RenoYoga, sanitary napkins’ usage and disposal etc.The young lot also conducted ‘Share the Spare’ drive across the city in which they would collect clothes, toys, books, food grains, medicines and send them to disaster affected areas.Under its project ‘RenoCare’, the organization distributed resources to other organizations like Goonj, and Baba Amte’s Anandwan. “We also extended the project to the city slums wherein we would attract slum dwellers by giving them the required resources and then educate them about several important aspects like education for children, sexual abuse, menstrual hygiene,” says Manpreet, a volunteer who conducts informative sessions for children and women.The NGO is also part of the national initiative ‘Alliance for Rivers’ which is trying to save the water bodies in the country.The organization has now expanded its operations to five cities. And all this, without raising any funds or asking for donations. “I used to work and whatever money I would make, I utilized it to run the organization,” says Nakul who has studied chartered accountancy.Since last three years, core members of the organization are conducting sessions on spirituality and meditation for thousands of people across the country including the paramilitary forces and prisoners in Central Jail. “Every day, we try to answer people’s questions through social media and motivate them. We have managed to save some people from committing suicide,” says Abhishek Jaiswal, who manages back end operations.At present, the group is holding Facebook live sessions daily to help those stranded by coronavirus. “We are also working on a mobile application named ‘Somebody’ which will be launched within a week. This wellness app will encourage people to help themselves mentally and physically as well as others during the lockdown,” says Sagar Zodape, who is in-charge of Renovatio’s technical and marketing work.The young group envisages to reach a million people in three years. “We want to help them become physically healthy, mentally more aware, compassionate towards others, and responsible members of the society. A very important yet missing piece of the current education system is that a person is taught about the world outside but nothing about the inside, despite the fact that it’s the inside of a person which determines the quality of life. We want to empower people live a happier, meaningful and beautiful life,” adds Nakul.

Title: 450 students stuck in Kakadeo coaching centres sent to home
Content:
Kanpur: Scores of students who were residing in Kakadeo area of the city were sent back home on Sunday due to coronavirus scare. The arrangement for sending these students back home in different districts of the state was made by the local authorities.

These students were stuck up in hostel rooms due to lockdown and were a troubled lot since they had exhausted their money and also their coaching centres had temporarily closed down. Authorities said some 450 students were sent back home to districts like Gorakhpur, Ambedkar Nagar.

Kakadeo area is also called ‘Coaching Mandi’ and houses thousands of coaching centres where students take classes for various competitive exams such as IIT-JEE, NEET among others. Such students stay in private hostels in this area.

The students were thermally screened in the presence of district officials and were made to board buses that were parked in the area.

This was also done to reduce the human presence from an already packed and crowded Kakadeo area where coaching centres these days are closed due to the ongoing lockdown. The students were also facing difficulties such as no delivery of food, all eating joints were closed and that they were simply locked in the hostel rooms, officials told TOI.

The students were provided with snacks and water by the authorities which made them shower praise on the officials.

A student waiting to board the bus told TOI that his parents were worried for him and wanted him to come back home but he was unable to go due to lockdown. He said that he was happy that the authorities were sending students like him home.

Other students also had happiness on their face since they were going home. Students also praised arrangements such as snacks and water provided to them.

Station House Officer, Kakadeo, KK Dixit said, “About 450 students, after proper thermal screening, were allowed to leave for their respective cities.”

He said that the students staying in private hostels in Kakadeo were stuck up and were getting worried. Therefore, they were on Sunday allowed to proceed to their native place such as Mirzapur, Gorakhpur, Balia, Ambedkar Nagar, Lucknow, Unnao, etc.

Title: Jaipur residents bank on music to lift morale at this colony
Content: JAIPUR: A man breaks into an old Hindi film song from his balcony. Soon, others in the locality join from their respective balconies, many even using microphones and amplifiers. The area echoes with music , sounds of cheering and applause.Even as the world grapples with a grave health emergency and as the country goes into lockdown mode, this locality in Jaipur has made peace with their time being spent in the confines of their homes. Singing and music have come as their respite in times of paranoia, shortage of groceries and everyday items, and helps them cope with the crisis well.TOI on Sunday visited Shyam Nagar, a posh locality in Jaipur which has more than 800 houses, and found that the people there instead of complaining, have rather well adjusted to the lockdown period.The residents are getting groceries, dairy products and vegetables in a planned manner through wholesalers, who are selling these to them at subsidized rates. In the evenings, the residents of the locality gather in their respective balconies, lawns and terraces and start singing to kill time.Kishor Saraogi a businessmen living in the locality is a known singer within his locality. Some of the residents over phone urged him to organize something for them, while still following the social distance norms.“I have been singing since my school and college days and have been brought up in an era where we had singers like Mukeshji, Kishoreda and Rafi saab. So, last evening, all of us sang together. In these times when people are being inundated with negative messages on social networking sites and everyone is scared of Covid-19, my singing will hopefully work as an anti-depressant,” Saraogi said.Like him, Kavi Sharma, another resident of the colony and an automobile dealer, plays the guitar and sings. “This lockdown is inevitable. Thus, rather than complaining we should make certain adjustments in life,” Kavi said.What is more satisfying and relieving for the people here is the fact that they are getting dairy products, bakery items like breads, vegetables, fruits and milk at a reasonable price. “Our resident welfare association tied up with a wholesale vegetable seller of Mohana Mandi, a dairy and a wholesaler of grocery. Every night, we get a list of items to be sold on moving vehicles with their prices. You are supposed to keep the exact amount of money for the items you are willing to purchase. We are taking every safety measure. And the musical nights are helping us big time,” said Raj Bansal, a film distributor, who also resides in the locality.

Title: Migrant workers get free ride home after screening
Content:
Migrant workers board a lorry on way to their native places

Kanpur: District magistrate Brahmadeo Ram Tiwari on Sunday visited Jhakarkati inter-state bus terminus and asked UPSRTC authorities not to charge fare from migrant labourers. He announced that buses coming from other districts carrying migrant labourers would get free diesel.

During the lockdown period, movment of migrant labourers has become a cause of concern for the district administration. The district magistrate and SSP Anant Deo both visited the bus station and reviewed the situation. The DM said that migrant labourers were being stopped at the district border where medical teams are examining them. Only after their medical examination they were being allowed to move to their destinations. Chitrakoot has provided around 100 buses to ferry the migrant labourers.

The health department is using an emergency medical kit to examine migrant labourers most of whom are coming from Delhi and Ghaziabad.

Transport authorities have been asked to ensure that no fare was charged from migrant labourers on state roadways buses. If in some cases somebody has charged fare from them then it would be refunded, he added.

Earlier, chairing a meeting of district officers, state industry minister Satish Mahana asked them to check entry of migrant labourers at the district border and nobody should be allowed to move on without undergoing medical examination. A medical team deputed on the duty visited the bus station on Sunday afternoon and examined many migrant labourers.

Meanwhile, the district police has adopted strict measures to ensure enforcement of social distancing norm. The police ensured that vegetable market at O block in Kanpur South, Badshahi Naka mandi, Express Road vegetable market and Gol Chauraha fruit market near the medical college remained shut. At O block vegetable market police had to resort to canecharge people to disperse them as none was ready to follow social distancing norm. However, for the convenience of locals vendors were allowed to visit different localities.

Title: Three red sand boas and peacock rescued
Content:
Trichy: Forest department officials rescued three Indian sand boas or Red sand boa , (Eryx johnii) and an injured peacock from local people at Sethubavachatram of Thanjaur district on Sunday. The snakes, protected under scheduled IV of the Wildlife Protection Act 1972, were caught by fishermen in Thanjavur from shallow waters in the sea.

They informed the forest department in Thanjvaur and a team led by forest officer Iqbal rescued the snakes. All the three-snake having a length of about 2 to 3 foot weighed about 1 kg together. The snakes were released into the Sambaipattinam reserve forest by the officials. They also rescued a three-year-old peacock from the village. It had injured one of its legs, while wandering in the village.

The forest department treated its leg with the help of the animal husbandry department. TNN

Title: Deshmukh warns errant citizens of strict action
Content:
Pune: State home minister Anil Deshmukh on Sunday warned of stricter action by police against citizens not adhering to the lockdown regulations in the time of Covid-19.

“Almost 90% people are adhering to the rules by staying at home. But 10% of the population do not comply with the orders. The police have to take strict action against them,” he told TOI.

Deshmuk said over 2.5 lakh policemen were on duty across the state round-the-clock to ensure that the citizens followed the lockdown rules. He added that the state has sought assistance from the homeguards, wherever necessary, but categorically said the Army’s assistance has not yet been sought.

“We are not stopping people going out to get their essential items. But if a person is found roaming around unnecessarily, action will be taken against him or her,” Deshmukh said.

“A section of the citizens was not understanding the gravity of the situation. The should stay home. The state government has taken several measures to ensure that farm produce and grocery items are delivered at one’s doorstep,” he said.

Amid reports of migrant workers moving towards the state’s borders, the minister said all state and inter-district borders have been sealed. “The district administration has been asked to provide them with shelter and food. We will not allow any movement of people across the borders,” he said.

Title: Gas victims cry negligence at Kamla Nehru dialysis unit
Content:
