Bhopal: The condition of gas victim patients hastily "discharged" from the Bhopal Memorial Hospital & Research Centre (BMHRC) after the hospital was declared an isolation centre for COVID-19 patients on March 24 is not known, but kidney patients among survivors of Bhopal gas tragedy, who have now been asked to get dialysis done at Kamla Nehru Hospital, are sharing videos and audios to show how "shabbily" they were treated during dialysis at Kamla Nehru Hospital on Saturday.

One such patient Aqueel Ahmed, who has to undergo dialysis three times a week, said "There was just one technician to look after 11 of us who were put on dialysis in the first session Dialysis is a delicate process and requires attention till the patient is on the dialysis machine. How do you expect one technician to take care of 11 patients at one time particularly when nursing staff and ward boys in attendance were inexperienced and knew little about dialysis."

He apprehends that unlike BMHRC , which remains clean and hygienic, Kamla Nehru Hospital is "dirty" and “people like us, who have low immunity, may contract an infection anytime.”

Urvashi Pathak, who accompanies her mother Vidya Pathak for dialysis for the past 12 years, said, "There used to be two to three technicians at the time of dialysis of patients at BMHRC and even ward boys were highly trained but here if the machine started to beep in warning, the nursing staff and ward boys had no clue as to how to put it on mute. She also complained of unhygienic conditions in the ward, where dialysis was carried out.

When contacted for comments, director of Kamla Nehru Hospital, Dr M A Khurram said, “After 31 patients registered for dialysis at BMHRC were transferred to Kamla Nehru Hospital, the number. of patients for dialysis have doubled at our hospital. It will have its impact. They have sent us two dialysis machines, but when we asked for technicians they refused on the pretext that they may need them for COVID-19 patients."

Title: Union minister Prakash Javadekar sanctions Rs 1 crore to fight coronavirus in Pune
Content: PUNE: Union minister for environment, information and broadcasting Prakash Javadekar on Sunday sanctioned Rs 1 crore to deal with the Coronavirus outbreak in Pune He said the funds will be given from the Member of Parliament Local Area Development (MPLAD) Fund and utilised for augmenting the infrastructure of hospitals in Pune.“The funds are sanctioned for procurement of ventilators, monitors, ECG machines, defibrillator, suction machines, portable X-ray machine and fogger. It will cater to the needs of the hospitals,” said Javadekar.

Title: 4,200 duplicate hand sanitizer bottles seized in Anand
Content:
Vadodara/Anand: Two men in possession of 4 ,200 bottles of duplicate hand sanitizer worth Rs4.16 lakh were apprehended in Anand district on Sunday.

Pankaj Thakkar and Mihir Pankaj Thakkar were apprehended by sleuths of joint task force constituted by Anand district administration with Anand police.

The joint task force seized the 4,200 bottles of duplicate instant hand sanitizer liquid which was kept in 14 parcel boxes at a company’s office, a release issued by the administration said.

The parcels were labelled ‘top most hand sanitizer’ manufactured by a pharmaceutical company of Mahuva taluka of Saurashtra’s Bhavnagar district.

According to officials, the duo illegally sold the duplicate hand sanitizers to people and local medical shops. Due to spread of COVID-19, the demand for sanitizer has increased within a short period.

They said the accused were selling the sanitizer prepared with locally available material and manufactured and supplied without any prior permission from concerned departments.

Title: ‘Ration, veggies to be delivered door-to-door in Rajasthan’
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: In the wake of Covid-19 crisis in the state, food and civil supplies minister Ramesh Chand Meena on Sunday said essential items such as ration, dairy products, vegetables and medicines will be delivered door-to-door in all the districts. The district collectors will be in-charge of the door-to-door delivery of essential items.

He also said only authorised persons will be allowed to distribute essential items in curfew-imposed areas. Minister said that assistance of local stores, fair-price shops, e-commerce companies and big retail chains will be taken for door-to-door delivery of essential items in urban areas. "The district collectors will issue passes to the shopkeepers for movement of vehicles. They will sell essential items by going door-to-door with push carts, rickshaws and e-rickshaws along with a delivery boy. If any shopkeeper fails to arrange a delivery boy, the district administration will get the items delivered at the doorstep," he said. He also said e-bazaar platforms of information and technology department will also be used for it.

Title: Flip-flop on fuel pumps leaves locals high & dry
Content:
Calangute/Quepem: Locals in the Calangute-Candolim belt whose vehicles are running out of fuel are in a quandary, with petrol pumps either running dry or turning away customers who do not have a government pass which permits them to travel during the lockdown.

On Monday, a Candolim resident who had gone to the Nerul petrol pump for fuel was turned away. “Do you have the government pass?” the attendant asked him. When the customer replied in the negative, the attendant declined to give him fuel. The petrol pump had put barricades at the entrance with dozens of locals outside waiting hopefully for fuel.

On Sunday, another resident who rode to the petrol pump at Calangute on Chogm road found the pump closed. To make matters worse, his fuel also ran out as he was returning, and had to park his two-wheeler by the roadside and walk back home.

Meanwhile, Quepem deputy collector Rohit Kadam on Saturday ordered all fuel pumps within his jurisdiction to refuel vehicles belonging to government or local bodies and those holding valid transit passes, prohibiting private vehicles.

But when TOI contacted Kadam, he confirmed that he received instructions from higher authorities to withdraw the order. However, the lone petrol pump in the town was shut on Sunday, with the earlier notice still prominently displayed.

Title: Jhakarkati bus stn disinfected
Content:
Sanitisation drive being carried out at Jhakarkati bus station

Kanpur: The district authorities launched a major drive to disinfect inter-state Jhakarkati bus station in the wake of coronavirus outbreak.

According to the officials, it has also started displaying the advisories to inform the commuters about the symptoms, mode of transmission of coronavirus and Do's and Don'ts for the disease. A 24x7 helpline no:18001805159 has also been set up to deal with every query.

"We are taking precautionary measures at Jhakarkati bus station due to heavy influx of passengers. To deal with this situation, a major sanitization drive was carried out on Sunday to disinfect the premises," said Municipal Commissioner Akshay Tripathi.

Title: Chennai corporation skilled workers come to the rescue of residents
Content:
Greater Chennai Corporation

CHENNAI: The lockdown may have forced skilled workers such as plumbers and electricians to stay indoors, but the Greater Chennai Corporation is ensuring that electrical appliances at private residences run. It is sending workers at its disposal for repair work whenever a resident asks.

On Sunday morning, Vidya Reddy, a resident of EVK Sampath road in Vepery, sought assistance from the civic body to repair a motor pump at her residence and within 10 minutes a plumber was sent to her home by officials of the Royapuram zone.

"I have two elderly people who are in their nineties. On Saturday, the pump had stopped working. Our regular plumber resides in Velachery and though he was willing to come, he could not as the police are strict with movements. So I called up the numbers flashed by the corporation," said Reddy, appreciating the prompt response from the civic body.

The plumber worked for three hours and repaired the motor.

Royapuram zonal officer R Manoharan told TOI that they have skilled workers ready in all divisions and units to help residents. "We have a few workers to carry out our jobs and also we have contacts of those who do jobs for us from time to time. Since our workers carry ID cards, police will not stop them," Manoharan said.

According to Manoharan, some residents called up the zonal office or the helpline seeking assistance with buying medicines and the corporation staff were immediately pressed into service.

"The residents can pay the workers directly for their services and the rates are for the work carried out. We see to it that the residents are not overcharged," another official said.

The official said that while implementing rainwater harvesting schemes last year, the corporation had made available services of skilled workers to the residents.

Title: Firms providing essential services can contact PMPML
Content:
Pune: The Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) said private organizations providing essential services and in need of the transport utility’s services could contact them for the same. It was flexible towards providing them with buses by increasing the present daily fleet.

Employees of some hospitals, who have to come to duty each day considering the Covid-19 spread, have complained that they have to wait for a long time for buses. A senior PMPML official said daily schedule of the transport body had been prepared after consulting the authorities.

“At present, the PMPML is plying 87 buses across 51 routes. The service starts at 6am and continues till 10pm. A proper schedule has been prepared and it is made clear that the buses will be available at one-hour intervals. However, the PMPML is always flexible and can tweak the schedule according to the demand,” PMPML’s joint managing director Ajay Charthankar said.

Earlier, the PMPML authorities had said the number of buses running on a daily basis for essential services might be increased.

A senior official working at a hospital said many nurses had complained about having to wait for long for buses. “They have been allowed to report late to duty as it is known that they have to travel and public transportation is scarce. The staff is already overworked and the waiting time adds to the frustration,” the official said.

“We too are working under tough conditions. It is not possible to ensure all get buses on time,” a PMPML official said.

Charthankar said any private firm providing essential services and in need of buses for their staff were free to contact the PMPML. “They can call on the helpline numbers — 020-24545454, 020-24503211, 020-24503223. The details will be forwarded to the traffic department who will then take a decision,” the official said.

Title: NWR staff on the job to ensure smooth operations in Jaipur
Content:
JAIPUR: The operating staff of the North Western Railways (NWR) has never seen stations deserted like those during the lockdown. However, in order to ensure regular supply of essential commodities, the guards, station masters, locomotive pilots and signalling staff are working tirelessly.

M A Khan, station master, Dausa, and R K Yadav , station superintendent, Pali, were given a choice to sit back and relax at their homes. But they preferred to be on duty. Like them, several other railway employees across NWR have been working. Frequently surprised at the silence and absence of hullabaloo at the stations, they are quietly fighting the battle and making their contribution.

“I joined the railways in 1983 and have never seen a scenario like this. Since I am on the verge of retirement (he retires in August 2021), I was asked if I want to sit back home. I told the authorities that I am physically and mentally fit to handle my responsibility. Railways has been a lifeline of the country, thus, it is better we keep contributing in these hard times as goods trains are operational,” said Yadav.

Though the authorities had asked employees aged 55 years and above to take a break, many of them refused the option.

Title: NMC postpones testing co-passengers of positive patients from Khamla
Content: NAGPUR: The detection of a Covid-19 positive patient from another locality has necessitated the need for an immediate containment drive there. The Nagpur Municipal Corporation NMC ), however, has postponed the diagnosis of 12 passengers who were in bogies of the trains in which the Khamla businessman and manager (both of whom tested positive) travelled between Nagpur and New Delhi.The NMC had planned to do testing of all 12 passengers — who are residents of the city — and adjacent towns like Narkhed, Kamptee etc on Sunday at GMCH.“We are in regular contact with these 12 persons. They do not have any symptoms. In case any of them exhibits some symptoms, we will get them tested,” Dr Bhavna Sonkusre, NMC additional medical officer (health) told TOI.In all, 64 persons were in bogies of the two trains. The remaining 52 are from different districts of Vidarbha and other states. The NMC had alerted collectors and chief secretaries of respective districts and states.

Title: South Goa ropes in SHGs to cook for migrant labourers
Content:
Margao: The South Goa district administration has set up community kitchens at two places – one at Fatorda and the other at Dicarpale – to cater to the food needs of migrant labourers and homeless people who have been stranded at various places across the district.

South Goa district magistrate Ajit Roy told TOI on Sunday that arrangements have been made in every taluka to arrange for shelter and food to all those who have been stranded in the district, particularly the labourers from other states.

“Self help groups have been roped in to run the community kitchens. On Sunday, food was cooked for and supplied to around 2,500 people stranded in migrant labour camps across South Goa,” Roy said.

The largest number of migrant labourers is in Ponda taluka with approximately 900 people, followed by Salcete with around 600. Canacona and Dharbandora talukas each have 400 migrant labourers , while Vasco has 200, data obtained from the district administration revealed.

In view of the lockdown situation, migrant labourers as well as migrant roadside vendors have been left without their daily earnings, which was their sole source of livelihood. As they are unable to go back to their native places, their plight is deplorable. A group of street vendors camping at the SGPDA ground, Margao, who would sell their wares at temple and church fairs, had to go without food and water for two days until a good samaritan brought their plight to the notice of the district administration, which then made arrangements for their food and shelter.

The district administration, Roy said, also responded to distress calls made for food and essential commodities from various locations. “There were calls from people staying in large groups at some places where they were unable to get any food supplies. Also, there were calls from individual houses which had run out of food stocks and couldn’t purchase essential commodities. We made arrangements to supply food to all of them,” Roy said.

When pointed out that people have been unable to get their essentials at various places as grocery shops failed to open or were forced to close down by police after people crowded the shops, Roy said, “All shops are open and it is up to these shops to do home delivery of the goods. People are free to go to the shops and purchase the items or opt for home delivery service.”

“Police have been instructed not to force any shop to shut down. The shops have to be kept open. There has not been a single case where shops have been ordered to shut down,” Roy said.

Title: Click bhopalfightscorona, register as a volunteer
Content:
Bhopal: District administration has appealed to residents of Bhopal to register themselves as volunteers to fight the Coronovirus threat.

A website www.bhopalfightscorona.com with a tagline COVID-19: Social distancing is the best remedy has been launched.

Persons, who want to register themselves as volunteers to help the district administration fight the Coronavirus pandemic, may visit the website and register themselves as volunteers. Information about COVID-19, precautions to prevent spread of Coronavirus and helpline nos. are also there on the website.

People may also take a pledge on the website to observe social distancing rules and may also extend financial help to the district administration to meet the crisis. So far, 514 persons have taken pledge to observe social distancing norms and 61 have registered themselves as volunteers.

Title: 37 Saudi-return pilgrims booked for hiding travel history
Content: PILIBHIT: Following a written complaint by the chief medical officer ( CMO ), the Amaria police on Sunday evening lodged FIR against 37 Saudi-return pilgrims for erasing the home quarantine stamp on their hands and hiding their travel history to the authorities. Among them, two people are being treated for coronavirus According to CMO Seema Agarwal , the pilgrims had landed at Mumbai airport on March 18, following which they reached Bareilly by train and then to Pilibhit by bus on March 19. The pilgrims are residents of Pilibhit.The CMO said despite being told at the airport to report about their travel history to Pilibhit authorities, all the pilgrims refused to follow the protocol.“The matter came to light when two of the pilgrims, a 73-year-old woman and her 33-year-old son, developed flu-like symptoms and tested positive for novel coronavirus on March 22. Both mother and son are being treated in the district hospital,” Agarwal said.“By concealing the information of their Saudi pilgrimage from the health and medical department, they have endangered the lives of many people. This is the reason why legal action has been taken against them,” she added.Station house officer of Amaria police station, Udai Veer Singh said all the pilgrims have been booked under sections 269 (unlawfully or negligently doing any act which is likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life), 270 (malignantly does any act which is likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life) and 271 (disobedience to quarantine rules) of the Indian Penal Code Even though the election commission had allowed the use of indelible ink to stamp the hands of those who are kept under home quarantine, the commission had clarified that the ink would last for only three days on hands. Whereas, if applied on fingernail, which is done during voting, it lasts several weeks.

Title: Coronavirus in Bareilly: 34-yr-old man from Bareilly who worksat Noida firm tests positive for Covid-19
Content:
BAREILLY: A 34-year-old man who is a native of Bareilly’s Subhash Nagar locality tested positive for novel coronavirus (Covid-19) on Sunday. This is the first Covid-19 positive case in Bareilly. The man works at a Noida-based private company where his colleagues were earlier tested positive.

Health officials said the man returned to Bareilly on March 22 and he learnt on Thursday through WhatsApp that a few of his colleagues were found to be infected. As he had mild flu-like symptoms, he went to district hospital and gave his sample for test on Friday. The man was later admitted to the district hospital’s isolation ward on Friday and is currently under treatment.

Chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Vineet Shukla said, “After the patient returned to Bareilly on March 22, the patient was in close contact with six of his family members. They have been shifted to quarantine facility and their samples were collected for further tests. Medical reports of the man’s kin are now awaited. Besides, two other relatives were in close contact with him and they too have been quarantined.”

The CMO added, “Though the lockdown was in place when the man arrived in Bareilly, we are tracing people who came in contact with him and the places where he had visited before being admitted to an isolation ward on Friday.”

Dr Vageesh Vaish, who collected the man’s sample and is treating him, told TOI on Sunday, “The general condition of the patient is stable now. His breathing difficulties, cough and fever are better.”

Officials said there is active surveillance of people living within one kilometre radius of the man’s house. “We have trained accredited social health activists (ASHA) and auxiliary nursing midwives (ANM) workers. They will visit every house situated within a kilometre radius of the man’s house. They will ask people living here if they have any symptoms, did they come in contact with the patient or any other person who returned home from abroad or other state. If anyone in the area shows symptoms, he or she will be quarantined and sample will be collected,” CMO Shukla said.

A district administration team has pasted a poster in front of the Covid-19 positive man’s house that “no one should enter the place as it is under quarantine from March 29 to April 13”.

Title: 2,500 pilgrims stranded in Ajmer seek admin help
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Over 2,500 pilgrims from across the country stranded in the Dargah area of Ajmer are pleading to the authorities for their return.

Since the curfew was clamped in the area following a Covid-19 positive case, those who are helping them with food and water are finding it difficult to feed them.

Rafiq Qadri, a volunteer who is providing food to over 1,400 pilgrims, said it’s been a week that they are providing food due to generous donations from people. “It will be really difficult to run the food programme for long. After some days, we have to focus on the local poor families and with limited resources, we won’t be able to feed both the sections,” said Qadri.

These pilgrims came to Ajmer a few days before the lockdown and got stuck due to cancellation of trains and buses. Out of them, 300 are from Hyderabad and 300 are from Maharashtra , Gujarat, Karnataka and Kerala .

“I have come with 40 members including children and women. Without proper arrangement, we cannot travel. I have appealed to our CM K Chandrashekar Rao to help us return to our state,” said Hafiz Ur Rehman , a devotee from Hyderabad.

Dargah Nazim Shakil Ahmed has asked the CMs of the states to make arrangements for them to be airlifted.

Title: Beware, cyber cheats may cash in on virus fear
Content:
Indore: Covid-19 has now given a new avenue for cybercriminals, who are trying to cash in on the fear that people have regarding the pandemic.

Several fraudulent websites and e-commerce platforms have mushroomed on the internet, promising to sell medicines that could either prevent or cure Covid-19. Not only this, fraudsters are using this opportunity to dupe people by promising to send vegetable and grocery items at their doorsteps.

Renuka Bundela, 40, a resident of Dhar district faced problems while donating funds to the website created by the PM. “I am glad that I checked before donating Rs 10,000 of my hard-earned money. Someone had created a fake link similar to the one where people are donating money for PM funds,” said Bundela.

She said that the fake link was ‘PM care’ and had the name of the accused in the registered name column. However, the real one was PM cares with registered name also PM cares.

Cyber cell SP Jitendra Singh said that such things are often not seen by the users and in the current scenario when almost everyone is working from home and using online means for all the transactions, it is must to be aware and safe.

“Cybercriminals are also taking advantage of the current situation. Non technical staff while working from home should take care of the confidentiality of valuable transactions and sensitive financial documents,” he said.

SP added that almost all the crimes like UPI fraud, frauds on e-commerce websites and insurance frauds have picked pace in the past few weeks. Online predators are active and are taking advantage of the increasing amount of time that people spend online due to new measures taken by government to stop the spread of the virus.

SP said that the attackers are also using Covid-19-themed malware, social engineering and phishing messages that include links leading to malicious sites or have attached Microsoft Office documents with malicious macros designed to download and execute malware on a victim’s system.

Some of these messages appear to come from the World Health Organization or US Center for Disease Control, exploiting individuals’ obvious need to know more about the pandemic.

Title: Look before you spit, warn S Kol citizens
Content: Kolkata: Spit Kills. KMC , Act Now — this is the slogan for an online petition seeking ban against spitting in the open and stringent action against the offenders. The campaign, using the image of the famous Philadelphia street car with a poster reading “spitting spreads death”, asks Kolkatans to join the fight against the coronavirus menace.Addressed to the Kolkata mayor, the petition has already more than 140 signatories. “We want to make it 200 and then approach the authorities concerned to start cracking down on the people spitting in public . An ordinance could be promulgated to amend the existing laws,” said writer-activist and Ballygunge Garden resident Aditi Roy Ghatak, who initiated the campaign on Saturday.The petitioners want hectic campaigns by KMC so that markets, street tea stalls, public vehicles, local trains, bus stops could be saturated with anti-spitting posters, followed by police action and hefty fine to be imposed on violators. Banani Kakkar of PUBLIC (People United for Better Living in Calcutta), said, “The campaign to stop spitting in public could produce excellent collateral damage in reverse as one of the best by-products of the Covid-19 pandemic.”Her husband and fellow green activist Pradip Kakkar said, “Spitting has always been considered an unhygienic public behaviour because it could spread infectious diseases such as tuberculosis. So, offenders should not only be spot-fined but identified as agents of spreading the disease, even after coronavirus menace is over.” Banani added, “Let’s not let up on it. This is the time to act.” The petition reads: “The coronavirus pandemic has once again focused on the spread of communicable disease through public spitting. Many countries have taken serious measures to ban spitting and penalize the offenders. It’s high time for KMC to take measures that will make people aware of the health hazards posed by spitting. The poster from the 1918 Philadelphia anti-spitting campaign tells it all, referring to the ‘spitting spreads death’ parade 102 years ago amid the influenza pandemic that killed 20,000 Philadelphians.”Ghatak said that the civic body should seek powers within the existing Acts and prescribe regulations to address the spitting act and amend the Epidemic Disease Act 1897 for ensuring safety from not only the current pandemic but also from TB, hepatitis, viral meningitis and other diseases that are spread through saliva.

Title: In Moradabad, women police open community kitchen; Pilibhit SP unveils ‘koi bhi bhukha na rahe’ plan
Content:
Bareilly/Pilibhit: In an exemplary gesture, women police personnel at the women’s police station in Moradabad have turned the station house into a community kitchen and have been feeding hundreds of poor people who are facing a tough time due to the lockdown. In a similar vein, Pilibhit superintendent of police Abhishek Dixit on Sunday launched a ‘koi bhi bhukha na rahe’ plan, including stray cattle and street dogs, besides the poor people.

Women’s police station in charge inspector Jyoti Singh said when entire police department was taking different measures to ensure food to the needy and the poor, they also decided to start preparing food for the people in need. Their effort even won the plaudits of inspector general (Moradabad range) Ramit Sharma. “All police personnel are doing exceptional job by going beyond their duty. They will be felicitated once the pandemic situation is controlled,” said the IG.

When inspector Singh shared the idea of starting a community kitchen at the station house, her colleagues sub-inspector Poonam Rathi and constables Mahima, Kamlesh Kumari, Ruby, Nisha, Bheem Priya, Geeta and Rajvari took no time in joining hands and took up theresponsibility for preparing food.

“Till afternoon, we made more than 150 packets of poori and subzi (vegetable) ready for the distribution. We will continue the kitchen until the things get normal,” said Rathi.

In Pilibhit, the SP ordered the Assam road police outpost of Sungarhi police station to open a “police kitchen” to feed the stranded labourers on way to their home via Pilibhit.

“Officer in charge of Assam road police outpost Achal Kumar has been assigned a special duty of handling the kitchen. As the police post is situated at the crossing that connects the roads leading to three adjoining districts, nearly 835 migrant labourers returning home through Pilibhit were offered food, masks and sanitiser. To the best of our capability, we even arranged vehicles for most of them for their onward journey,” said Dixit.

Dixit also fed street dogs and stray cattle at different places in Pilibhit city on Saturday night.Besides these, the SP also made arrangements for packets of cooked food to be distributed among needy and hungry people.

According to the SP, in the past 24 hours, nearly 870 labourers — 835 persons belonged to Bareilly, Shahjahanpur and Kheri districts while the remaining 35 to Pilibhit — returned to their native place via Pilibhit on foot from several districts of Uttarakhand, including Pithoragarh, Champawat and Udham Singh Nagar.

“The labourers coming to Pilibhit have been quarantined for 14 days, while lists of labourers have been sent to district authorities of the other three districts so that they could make arrangement for quarantining the returning labourers,” he explained.

Title: SGCCI takes to webinar to connect with industry players
Content:
Surat: At a time when the trade shows , seminars and interactive talks have been suspended due to the COVID-19 lockdown, the Southern Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SGCCI) is making the optimum use of the digital platform to connect with the trade and industry players through free webinars in Surat and south Gujarat region.

In the last two days, the SGCCI has successfully held four webinars on various subjects ranging from Corona Effects: Expectations from Banking; Role of voluntary organisations in the present times; Opportunities and challenges in corona times and Unlimited power within you.

Talking with TOI, president of SGCCI, Ketan Desai, “Few of our members who are experts in information technology (IT) suggested webinar to reach out to stakeholders. I immediately took up the challenge and we hosted our first webinar two days back — Corona effect: Expectations from banking.”

Desai added, “The webinar we had could only be accessed by 100 participants and would shutdown after 40 minutes. However, we decided to purchase a licensed version from the reputed webinar provider where we can connect with more than 500 participants at a time with unlimited access. We have lined up many seminars and interactive sessions through webinars in the coming days.”

Mrunal Shukla, member of SGCCI who is looking after the webinar events said, “The webinar events hosted by the chamber has seen participation of more than 1,000 participants in four different seminars.”

Vice-president of SGCCI, Dinesh Navadiya said, “Even though there is a lockdown, the SGCCI is working through the virtual platform. We are organising meetings with our staff on daily basis through the webinar.”

Title: Curfew clamped in Ajmer a day after first positive case
Content: AJMER: Ajmer city witnessed curfew after two decades, not because of any communal violence but to stop the spread of coronavirus . About 5,500 police personnel , home guards and other reserve forces have been deputed in the district out of which 2,000 are deployed at the four police station areas of Dargah, Clock Tower, Ganj and Kotwali, where curfew has been imposed.In 1999, following a dispute between two shopkeepers in Dargah Bazaar, a curfew was imposed in Dargah area and surrounding regions.Fear of infection has forced Ajmer residents to lock themselves in their houses. Roads were deserted in Sisakhan, Bade Peer, Dargah Bazaar, Khadim Mohalla, Naya Bazaar and even Station Road.Ration was provided to the residents and milk was available from early morning.Suresh Motiyani, a resident of Cinema Road, said, they are not afraid of police but were concerned about a coronavirus positive case which surfaced at Kharikoi region, which is close to his house.Ameeda Bano, a resident of Diggi Chowk , said, after knowing about the positive patient in Kharikoi, she instructed her children to not venture anywhere near window.Meanwhile, 1,500 medical staff including teachers on Sunday went door-to-door for screening the residents of Kharikoi and nearby regions.According to the medical department, till Sunday, 79 samples were taken out of which 71 came negative, one positive and seven are awaiting result.The municipal corporation started fogging in the region with two types of vehicles and cleaned the lanes and drainage in the area.In all, about 3,200 medical personnel are working in the district.Regions like Kaserganj, Padao, Cinema Road, Madar Gate, Chudi Bazaar, Purani Mandi , Naya Bazaar, Agra Gate, Dhan Mandi, Dargah Bazaar, Phuwara Chowk and surrounding areas are under lockdown and police is deployed after every 100 metres with barricades.

Title: Wife, kid of Covid +ve man test negative
Content: Kanpur: The wife , 20-day-old infant and other family members of a coronavirus-affected man, tested negative for the deadly disease, informed the district health authorities.District pandemic scientist Dr Deo Singh told TOI, “The woman's husband returned from Hong Kong and visited his residence near Navrang cinema on Birhana road in Kanpur on March 5. He also visited his in-laws’ place in Harjinder Nagar, Lal Bangla during his stay. His wife delivered a child on March 8. Thereafter, he left for Hong Kong on March 15. He then tested positive for Covid-19 in Hong Kong on March 24,”“On being informed, the health authorities visited his house and his in-laws’ house in Kanpur, and conducted medical tests on them. They all tested negative,” he added.

Title: City airport handles 6 tonne medical cargo over the last three days
Content: Pune: The Pune airport has handled six tonnes cargo, mainly consisting medical equipment, during the last three days, the authorities said. At the moment, the airport is not witnessing any commercial flight movement. “Even with no commercial flights, the airport has been busy. Three flights carrying only cargo items have operated through Pune until now. While one aircraft went from Pune to Bengaluru, there was another aircraft that landed in Pune from Mumbai and then went onto Raipur in Chhattisgarh. The items that are being transported mainly include medical equipment and some electronic items apart from edibles like soybeans,” an airport official said. — Joy Sengupta

Title: Pune: Pet owner flees, 2 dogs live but pug passes away
Content:
The rescued golden retriever and labrador

PUNE: RESQ Charitable Trust rescued two dogs — a labrador and a golden retriever — and buried a pug on Sunday after being notified that their owner had fled from his house in Wagholi in early March.

Neha Panchamiya, managing committee member of Pune District SPCA and founder and president of RESQ Charitable Trust told TOI, “Covid-19 did not do this, but unspeakable human negligence did. The RESQ team received a call on Sunday morning about three dogs abandoned in a house in a society in Wagholi. The person who reported the incident told us that no one had been in the house for many days. I informed my seniors at the Pune District SPCA, the member secretary and district collector Naval Kishore Ram, who put me in touch with the superintendent of police, who gave us permission to enter and rescue the animals,” said Panchamiya.

The man had fled following the Covid-19 spread in Pune, said officials. When officials entered the house they found that the pug had died of starvation and dehydration, while the other two pets were severely emaciated.

Officials said the stranded labrador had a water jar stuck around its neck when it was found. They suspect the dog must have nosed into the jar in search of water.

Panchamiya said suitable action would be taken against the owner of these animals once s/he returns.

The labrador and the golden retriever have been medically examined for dehydration, tick fever and other underlying illnesses. They have been bathed, cleaned and fed and are currently safe at the RESQ Centre in Bavdhan.

SPCA’s message to public

You cannot contract Covid-19 from animals. If you notice abandoned animals in someone’s house without anyone coming to feed/clean them even once a day, please inform the Pune District SPCA (www.districtspca.com) or RESQ on 9890999111.

Title: Give me ‘hot samosa with 'chutney', man tells helpline set up to serve needy in UP
Content:
RAMPUR: The helpline set up by the district administration in UP’s Rampur to attend to the calls of those in need of food during the ongoing lockdown got another unusual call on Sunday. A man asked for hot ‘somasas’ and sauce to be delivered at his home. It was not for the first time that such an unusual demand was made over the helpline number meant to serve the needy during the ongoing lockdown.

A day earlier, a caller wanted pizza to be delivered at his home.

Perturbed by such calls, Rampur district magistrate (DM) Aunjaneya Kumar Singh decided to “shame” such people in public. The caller from Rampur’s Swar tehsil was caught and made to clean drain and sweep the road on Sunday evening in his area.

“We are receiving several calls on our helpline number in which people are asking for pizza and 'samosas'. So, now we have started ‘publicly shaming’ such people to discourage others who are making fun of this pandemic.”

According to officials, several people who don’t even fall in the BPL category, are calling up the helpline asking for cooked food. The DM also tweeted photos of people who made such calls recently.

“I have tweeted the pictures of those who had already received the ration from the authorities and now are demanding prepared food. One such person in Swar was made to clean a drain and sweep the road of his locality as punishment,” the DM said.

“Cooked food is being delivered to the needy families and to senior citizens. One pregnant government teacher called the helpline and asked for the food, and she got it immediately,” he added.

Title: 62-yr-old dies in Bhiwadi, family under home isolation
Content: ALWAR: A 62-year-old man died in Bhiwadi ’s Khanpur village on Sunday. The district administration fears that he could be a suspected case of Covid-19. The authorities did not test his swab samples apparently because of lack of equipment.The family of the man, who was unwell for quite some time, has been put under home isolation and his residence has been sanitised. He was cremated on Sunday with five persons in attendance.Officials claimed that on March 18, an MBBS student who had returned from Russia had met the deceased following which his condition further deteriorated. Tijara SDM Tejaram said, “The deceased was paralysed for quite some time and on March 18, a student who had returned from Russia, spent around three hours with him. After that, his condition worsened and he developed respiratory disorder. It could be a suspected case of Covid-19 due to which we are taking all necessary precautions . His house will also be isolated along with family members till we confirm whether he was infected or not.”

Title: Lockdown: Nearly 1,000 carts to supply veggies, fruits in Bareilly
Content:
BAREILLY: Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) is set to press into service around 1,000 carts across all 80 wards for uninterrupted supply of vegetables and fruits to city residents at their doorsteps.

According to corporation officials, efforts are on to deploy at least 1,000 vegetable and fruit carts from prominent vegetable markets such as Delapir, Kotwali, Quila, and others for the purpose. The carts will be moving through various localities, ensuring that people buy vegetables and fruits at their doorsteps and don’t go to the market.

Speaking to TOI, Bareilly municipal commissioner Abhishek Anand said, “The district administration and the civic body are working jointly to provide residents vegetables and fruits at their doorsteps by pressing around 1,000 carts into service across the city. We are in talks with sellers at markets such as Delapir, Shyamganj, Quila and Kotwali to provide the service until the lockdown is lifted. Several vendors have already started providing service in a few localities.”

“The move is being taken to curb the movement of people outside, as residents are thronging vegetable markets during the morning hours daily. This needs to be controlled, as it defeats the very purpose of the lockdown. Even as the guidelines for social distancing have been issued, many people are not following it, which can be risky,” added Anand.

BMC officials said the service would be available to people from 9 am onwards.

The civic body authorities have been taking several measures to provide residents the required household products at their doorsteps. Nearly 300 big and small grocery stores have been identified by the nagar nigam across the city to deliver groceries at the doorsteps.

Title: Telangana government ramps up steps to fight back virus
Content: HYDERABAD: Health department is gearing up to put in place safety measures for medical staff and their family members as they are vulnerable. Preparations are underway to firm up a roster system to maintain self-imposed quarantine for five days on rotation basis. Doctors, staff nurses, paramedics and outsource staff have to maintain the self-imposed quarantine for five days after working for an equal number of days.According to instructions issued (a copy available with TOI) to all teaching hospitals, government medical colleges and speciality hospitals under the Directorate of Medical Education (DME), one-third staff have to maintain self-imposed quarantine for five days. After the quarantine period, they have to duly report otherwise their quarantine period would not be considered as “ on duty” and strict action would be taken against them. Currently, the hospital administration is preparing lists of personnel to be in quarantine.The instructions also clarified that doctors should not carry out any private practice and mingle with the general public during the quarantine period. Health of the staff in quarantine would be monitored. If they display any symptoms, they would not be sent home. Also, transport facility would be made available to the medical staff to go the hospitals. The government is also taking measures to provide accommodation on the hospital premises or rented accommodation in nearby areas.A clarity on these measures would emerge in a few days.Meanwhile, a few post-graduate medical students said they were finding it difficult to get accommodation in nearby hospitals. “It is problem for those staying in private residences and we hope to find a solution soon,” a PG doctor said on the condition of anonymity.

Title: Lockdown could have long-lasting impact on fishing industry in Mangaluru
Content:
Representative image

MANGALURU: The forced fishing holiday due to the 21-day lockdown will have a long-lasting impact on the fishing industry which is already dented by lesser catch this year.

With investments already made, extension of the lockdown could end the fishing season . Fishermen fear they will be unable to resume operations this season if the lockdown extended as the industry largely depends on labourers from other states. The region has witnessed a steady influx of migrant labourers from Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Odisha and Bihar and they may not return immediately.

Umesh Karkera Kulai, boat owner and honorary president, Purse Seine Boat Owners Fishermen Association, said, “When compared to the previous year, there is 30% catch reduction this year. Currently, about 3,000 trawlers and purse seine boats have been anchored at the Old Port. Even if the lockdown period ends, fishing activity will depend on the return of labourers,” he said.

Harish Kumar, deputy director (in-charge), fisheries department, said over 40,000 people in Dakshina Kannada are affected due to the lockdown. This includes labourers, boat owners, ice plant workers, marketing, fisherwomen and workers involved in works like net mending and transportation, he said.

Kumar said a report on the impact of the lockdown will be submitted to the government.

The fisheries sector provides livelihood to a large section of economically backward people in the state and contributes to the nutritional security, employment generation and foreign exchange earnings. According to the Marine Fisheries Census, 2010, Karnataka supports a coastal populace of 1,67,429 comprising 30,713 fishermen families.

The marine fishing sector in the state has been turbulent during the last decade due factors such as declining catch, imbalance in economic returns between the sectors and high production targeted innovations in fishing practices.

An opportunity to study the impact

Experts feel that the lockdown will help in the reduction of fishing stress.

Dr Prathibha Rohit, scientist-in-charge, ICAR-Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute, Mangaluru Research Centre, said marine fisheries and ancillary activities contribute immensely to socio-economic development. “This unexpected but necessary closure of fishing activities will therefore impact several sectors. This provides an excellent opportunity to study the impact of total closure on fishery as well as on the primary, secondary and tertiary sectors. This will also provide better insight to develop appropriate management measures in the future. Though transportation and sales of fishes is included under essential and perishable commodities, the landing and auctioning of fishes is not considered safe at this point of time,” she added.

The closure would also highlight the need for better hygiene at fish landing centres. Large gatherings in harbours are not allowed and the supply chains are badly affected, said Dr Prathibha.

Title: Coaches to serve as mobile isolation centres in Ajmer
Content:
Representative image

AJMER: The railway carriage industry in Ajmer is preparing coaches to serve as isolation facilities, wherein in every coach 14 coronavirus patients can be isolated. As many as 20 such coaches will be prepared soon.

Railways has taken the initiative to develop infrastructure to cope with Covid-19 pandemic. Though the district administration has seized many private hospitals and hotels to convert them into isolation centres, yet railways has decided to develop mobile isolation centres in the form of coaches.

The orthopaedic department of JLN Hospital has been converted into an isolation centre. Looking at the number of suspects, the doctors are assuming more facilities will be required. There will be 24-hour power supply in these coaches, bathrooms, curtains and separate space for doctors and medical staff to monitor every patient. There will also be a facility of mobile and laptop charging.

Title: Tiffin centres turn saviour, feed city’s hungry students
Content:
Bhopal: Despite shortage of groceries in the markets, tiffin service centres across the state capital are doing their best to supply food and ensure their customers do not go to bed on empty stomachs.

Having to procure rice, flour and vegetables at a much higher price during the ongoing lockdown, it is noteworthy that most tiffin service centres are still not charging extra from the customers and bearing the extra costs from their own pockets and braving the difficulties on their shoulders.

“From March 22 to 24, there was an extreme shortage of flour, rice and lentils in the markets as people began to hoard food items in case of an emergency. In those two days, I had to apologise to my customers for not being able to provide them with food. But, now the situation is comparatively better and though groceries have become more expensive than usual, we are doing all that we can to make sure the supply of tiffin goes unhindered. I also got passes made so that cops don’t bother my tiffin boys”, said Deepak Lodhi, who runs a tiffin service centre near the Bittan Market.

Rajesh Kumar Navalia, who runs a tiffin centre at Saket Nagar area told TOI that most of his customers are students and many have left due to the coronavirus pandemic and he is now only supplying food to a few who stayed behind, without any extra charges.

“There are hardly four students left now, so I am giving them tiffin twice a day. They live in my own locality, so it’s not really that difficult to hand them their food. I have a stock that will last for another two weeks, but since vegetables don’t last long, we have to go out to procure them on a regular basis. Since the number of students has decreased, even though groceries are more expensive these days, it’s not really affecting the budget as of now, said Navalia.

Rachna Singh, who runs a tiffin centre in Old Bhopal said, “As students and most of out-of-town employees have left the city due to the coronavirus scare, we are left with only a handful of customers. I prepare the food at home and since we have no staff to deliver the tiffin because of the lockdown, my husband is delivering them for the time being. It is extremely difficult to manage, but we can’t leave the students hungry, they hardly have any money left. I hope the situation comes under control soon”.

Title: Two roads in Sal closed for traffic
Content: Bicholim: After receiving complaints from residents about vehicular movement on two roads in Sal , which connects Goa and Maharashtra’s Dodamarg, the Bicholim administration has sealed these roads.The administration had earlier sealed the Goa-Maharashtra border at Dodamarg after the 21-day lockdown was declared to curb the spread of coronavirus . However, it was found that people from Maharashtra and Goa started using the two alternative roads that pass through Sal village.Villagers brought this to the notice of Bicholim mamlatdar Pravinjay Pandit, who then, along with Bicholim PI Sanjay Dalvi, PSI Prasad Falani and others, sealed both the roads.

Title: Five more test positive for Covid-19 in Rajasthan, five recovered
Content: JAIPUR: Five more persons — three in Ajmer, one each in Bhilwara and Jhunjhunu — tested positive for Covid-19 in the state on Sunday, taking the total count to 59. Five others who were undergoing treatment in Bhilwara tested negative.One of the five who tested positive is a 21-year-old Jhunjhunu youth who had arrived from Philippines on March 18. A 53-year-old woman, who had undergone angioplasty at a private hospital in Bhilwara, the epicentre of the virus outbreak in Rajasthan, also tested positive. Besides, the father, mother and brother of a 23-year-old person from Ajmer who tested positive were also found infected.The Ajmer youth, who sells products from Punjab, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh in tourist places, was brought to JLN Hospital with fever, cough and running nose on Friday. Now, his 47-year-old father, 40-year-old mother and 20-year-old brother have been diagnosed with Covid-19. His 17-year-old sister, however, tested negative. The youth had visited 13 districts of Punjab and Haryana to sell handmade clothes in Ambala, Bhatinda, Chandigarh, Ludhiana, Jalandhar, Amritsar, Rohtak, Panipat and other towns before returning to Ajmer on March 22.“Five new cases were detected on Sunday, three in Ajmer, one in Bhilwara and Jhunjhunu each,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health So far, 25 cases have been reported from Bhilwara connected with the private hospital. The 53-year-old woman is the third patient from the hospital to have tested positive. She had undergone angioplasty there. The other two — one a chronic kidney patient who had also suffered a stroke and another who had suffered cardiac arrest — had been diagnosed with Covid-19 recently and died on March 26. At the hospital, 18 doctors, nurses and other staff have already tested positive so far, while three patients and their four relatives too have been found to be infected.“The woman was admitted before the first Covid-19 case was reported from the hospital. After the first case, the health department launched a search for all those patients who had been admitted to find out if they have been infected with the virus. During screening, we found three such patients. Two of them died on Thursday and the 53-year-old was found infected with the virus on Sunday,” said a health department official.Jhunjhunu reported its seventh case when the 21-year-old person, who reached the district on March 18, was diagnosed positive on Sunday. He had gone to Philippines and reached Delhi airport on March 18. He came to Jhunjhunu by a taxi on the same day. Health department officials said that he remained at home quarantine till March 22. Health authorities shifted him from home to a private university for quarantine. On March 26, he complained of fever and cough. His samples were sent to Sawai Man Singh Hospital in Jaipur on March 27 and the positive report was issued on Sunday.Meanwhile, five patients who are undergoing treatment in Bhilwara tested negative. “Five patients have tested negative,” said Dr Arun Gaur, medical superintendent, MG Government Hospital.Bhilwara Medical College principal and controller Dr Rajan Nanda said, “The government has provided all facilities which we needed for treating Covid-19 patients. We have a sufficient number of personnel protection equipment and other items such as masks.”A team from Sawai Man Singh Medical College was sent to Bhilwara when the first cases of Covid-19 was reported. Dr Narendra Khippal , senior professor, (respiratory disease) SMS Hospital said, “We have helped the doctors in Bhilwara for preparing protocol for screening, testing and treating suspected Covid-19 persons and patients.”The doctors in Bhilwara were in touch with SMS Hospital and other hospitals in various parts of the country which had succeeded in treating patients. They also followed treatment protocol prepared by AIIMS, Delhi.So far, seven patients from Bhilwara, including two in SMS Hospital, have tested negative for the disease. In the state, nine patients in SMS Hospital, five in Bhilwara and two in Jodhpur have been tested negative after being treated. A total of 16 Covid-19 patients have tested negative for the virus, after being treated in the state.

Title: CM: May mark homes of those under isolation
Content:
Panaji: Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Saturday said the government is trying to put a mechanism in place so that people can identify those who have been home quarantined in their respective neighbourhoods.

“We are thinking of stamping or marking the houses of persons who have been home-quarantined, but a final decision has not been taken,” he said. “We are not allowing anyone to enter Goa, but are concerned about those quarantined.”

The chief minister further said that only first-generation persons who come in direct contact with Covid-19 patients are quarantined as they were more vulnerable than second-generation people. He also said Goa will be in the ‘safe zone’ if no more positive cases are reported until April 14.

Title: Sales down, Gokul to convert milk into powder
Content: Kolhapur: The 21-day lockdown amid the coronavirus outbreak has affected the Kolhapur Zilla Dudh Utpadak Sangh’s ( Gokul ) daily sale of milk following which the dairy has decided to convert the available stock into milk powder Ravindra Apate, Gokul chairman, said, “The daily collection of milk from Kolhapur district is around 11.50 lakh to 12 lakh litre and our sale has gone down by around 3 lakh litre. There is no reduction in collection of milk and we have continued our supply to Pune, Mumbai in Maharashtra and to neighbouring states like Karnataka and Goa.”Apate said though the collection remains to be the same, consumption of milk has reduced to a great extent. “We are facing problems in Pune and Mumbai where sale has been reduced by more than 2 lakh litre. The nationwide shutdown has affected the sale as Amruttulya (a tea chain) have shut their shops and they are among our major customers,” he said.“People are not coming out of their homes and most of the retail shops where our milk was being sold have been shut down due to lockdown. This has also resulted in reduction of milk sale ,” he added.Apate said they have found a way to deal with the crisis and reduce losses. “We have a milk processing unit that converts milk into powder. At present the daily capacity of the unit is to convert 5 lakh litre into powder. We are left with a stock of around 3 lakh litre every day which will be processed and converted to milk powder. Once the lockdown is over, we will consider of transporting the milk powder to market. Our aim is that the milk producing farmers should not incur any loss due to the lockdown. Though the milk sale has been reduced, we will not stop collecting milk from the farmers. Some dairies have declared to procure only 75% of the total milk they used to buy, but Gokul is with the farmers and committed for their welfare,” he said.“All the dairies associated with Gokul and the farmers are following the strict norms issued by the district administration. They follow the discipline and maintain social distancing while delivering milk to the dairies. The administration has helped us by issuing passes for the drivers and milk collectors,” he added.Apate said the district administration has requested them to process the milk of other dairies as well. “We will soon take milk of other dairies for converting it into powder by charging nominal rates,” he said.

Title: Bareilly Municipal Corporation sanitises one-km radius
Content:
BAREILLY: After a positive case of Covid-19 was reported from Subhash Nagar on Sunday, the Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) has swung into action and sanitised one km radius of the area.

Bareilly municipal commissioner Abhishek Anand said, “Civic bodies, as per the state guidelines, have been directed to carry out frequent sanitisation work in their respective jurisdictions and use one percent hypochlorite solution to disinfect the place, especially if any positive coronavirus case is reported. After learning about the positive case, sanitation department teams were sent immediately.”

The municipal commissioner added, “Almost all the roads were covered under the exercise while shops, markets and religious places were washed to prevent any infection setting in. The area will be frequently sanitised now.”

Title: No electric meter reading for three months, pay bill online: UPPCL
Content: BAREILLY: The Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) has decided not to read electric meters for three months starting April 1 amid coronaviru lockdown.According to Madhyanchal Vidyut Vitran Nigam Limited (MVVNL) officials, directions have been issued to all power distribution companies in this regard, as visiting places and handing over power bills can be contagious and poses a risk to both power consumers and corporation employees. This is being done to contain the spread of coronavirus Speaking to TOI, MVVNL chief engineer Tariq Mateen said, “Though the Government of India has issued a guideline, asking not to shut the power billing centres, power consumers are requested to make the payments of their bills online. With the corona lockdown in place, we are trying to ensure the safety of corporation employees as well as the public, and thus, the process of reading meters has been stopped, because it requires corporation employees to visit a number of houses. Under the prevailing circumstances, it is not safe for the people to come in contact with each other. Thus, in an effort to contain the spread of coronavirus, it has been decided not to conduct meter reading for three months starting from April 1.”MVVNL sub-divisional officer (SDO) Gaurav Sharma told TOI, “We are informing people about the move through the media. Besides, a handful of people who have been visiting different power department offices are also being sensitised. Since meter readers will not be visiting the consumers’ houses, they are requested to generate bill themselves by logging on to www.uppclonline.com . Since DISCOMS have been asked not to shut the billing centres, the power department will generate bills based on the consumers’ average consumption by tracking their previous records, and the bills will be given to those who are visiting the billing centres.”

Title: Citizens reach out to thirsty cops manning roads
Content:
Colva: Yet again the apathy of Goa police towards its personnel has surfaced, this time during the situation created by the coronavirus health scare. The thousands of policemen manning the roads have been left to fend for themselves in the heat with the authorities not even making any arrangement for something as basic as water.

Speaking to TOI on condition of anonymity, some police personnel posted in Salcete said that it is the public who are coming to their rescue providing them with water and refreshment

A large number of police have been positioned at strategic locations since March 25 to curb movement of public to enforce lockdown.

Besides, police are also tasked with the responsibility of ensuring that social distancing is being followed at stores.

Sources said that the department has organised two shifts, from 8am to 2pm and from 2pm to 8pm. The first batch gets to go home for lunch during its break. However, some personnel said it is not possible for some of them to report back even after two hours as they live far away. “We can’t even carry packed lunch as it will not keep for long in the heat,” one policeman said. They work thirteen-hour shifts and these days they do not know when they can go home as they are charted for a longer period.

They said with all the tea stalls or eateries closed they have to go without food or depend on whatever the public provides. Interestingly, at different police locations, sufficient number of water bottles, fruit juices and fruits were seen. Police said that the public sees them standing in the sun and buys stuff for them.

Title: Rajasthan vows to take care of workers
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Heavy rush of migrants who hail from Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh was seen at Transport Nagar on Sunday when the state government through Rajasthan State Roadways Corporation (RSRTC) and private operators picked and dropped labourers up to Uttar Pradesh border.

In the evening, after the order of the Union home ministry to seal the state borders, the state government appealed the labourers to stay wherever they are and promised to take care of their food and other necessities.

A large numbers of labourers used the RSRTC and private buses at the Transport Nagar and Ghat Ki Guni area where police transport officials and others were seen facilitating the migrant workers.

“At least 150 buses were sent up to Bharatpur for the migrant labourers from Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh. All these buses were sanitized and passengers were disinfected before they boarded the bus,” said a senior officer of RSRTC at Transport Nagar.

Meanwhile, in the evening after Union home ministry’s directions of sealing the state borders, the state government urged migrant workers not to move out of Rajasthan and stay wherever they are.

“We will arrange for their food and other things. I would appeal them not to move and risk their lives. We have made various packages to provide them food, wages and medical aid. Also, the labourers who have come to Rajasthan from other states would be quarantined for 14 days,” said Rajiv Swaroop, additional chief secretary (Home).

He assured that state government will also ensure that all these labourers should not be deprived of their wages. “Any labourer who comes across any pay cut or any harassment can contact police and other government officials,” he added.

When contacted, he said, “We will follow the directions of the Union government and will ensure to give every facility to the migrant labourers who are living in Rajasthan.”

Meanwhile, the state authorities said all those who boarded the buses till the evening have entered into their states.

However, state transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas was not impressed with the Union home minisry’s directive. “As far as I am concerned, I will not let anyone to die on road by walking without food and water and covering unusual distance,” he said.

Title: Ahead of harvest season, farmers stare at loses due to lockdown
Content: NAINITAL: As the harvest season for the Rabi crops nears, farmers across the state are worried that in face of the crisis caused by the novel coronavirus and the lockdown imposed across the country, they will have to bear severe losses.Speaking to TOI, several farmers termed migration of workers out of the state as a problem for farmers in many areas, while others saw the closure of mandis and disturbance of the supply chain as a major threat. “I have crops ready to be harvested in a week in almost four acres. But the availability of labour is going to be a serious issue . Even if I have to employ a threshing machine , we will need several labourers to cut the crops which is going to be very difficult in the coming days,” said Ramzani, a farmer from Udham Singh Nagar district These fresh problems come after the already devastating months of February and March when untimely rains and hailstorms damaged several acres of wheat fields. “The hailstorms in the past two months have already damaged much of the crops but whatever remains now is also under threat if we do not get the labour to harvest it,” Ramzani added.Meanwhile, another farmer from Jhabreda area of Roorkee said that the problem for him is the breakdown and confusion around the supply chain. “We will start harvesting in eight to ten days. The unavailability of labour is an issue because there is a total lockdown in the state and we are not sure if the administration will let people assemble for the harvest. We are also unsure how we will take the total produce to the market,” he said.Government officials meanwhile said that the farmers will be helped to get labourers and also to get the harvested crops to the market. “We will approach the farmers and work out a mechanism to get the crops to markets. Since the major crop to be harvested is wheat, it can be stored for the time being. And as far as labourers is concerned, we will also speak to the local officials and work out a plan on the issue as well,” said a senior government official on condition of anonymity.

Title: Good news first: Two Covid patients cured, discharged
Content: Ahmedabad/ Surat: Amid corona gloom one from Surat and another from Ahmedabad , getting discharged on Sunday after recovering from Covid-19 infection which has put the country in a lockdown.Surat-based 21-year-old woman, who was one of state’s first Covid patients, was hospitalized on March 16. She has travel history to London.Dr Ashish Naik, Surat’s deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), told TOI, “Her third sample also tested negative on Sunday. She has recovered fully after 14 days of care and management.”In Ahmedabad, a 34-year-old city-based entrepreneur also walked out of the hospital hale and hearty after her two samples tested negative post 10 days of hospitalization.“.. 24 hours, Two tests: -Ve & -Ve. I'm coming home, I'm coming home; Tell the world I'm coming home. See you on the other side. You have been beyond wonderful,” the happy woman told the world on her social media post.Life had gone topsy-turvy some 11 days ago for this entrepreneur when her dream trip to Finland ended up in Covid nightmare. In her own admission, she ended up with the viral infection despite going great lengths – including changing her flight route – to escape the virus.“If I have to summarize my experience, I would say, ‘Keep Calm and Trust your Doctor.’ In my case, the symptoms started manifesting about a week after my return. But I was aware about my travel history and when I started feeling the problem in breathing, I immediately sought medical help,” said the survivor, adding that it’s not a linear progression and symptoms surely scares a person.Talking about her time at the SVP Hospital, she said that she was well cared for. “While I could not meet my family members, I was allowed to use my phone and I made most of it, calling my friends and family and keeping updated. I was among the nine patients recovering from the Covid-19 infection and I pray for their quick recovery,” she said.She did get nervous when her first report came negative as she described the following 24 hours as anxious in anticipation.Both the survivors would have to spend 14 days in home quarantine. None of their contacts are tested positive.

Title: Don’t argue with police, says minister
Content:
Pune: Divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar on Sunday urged citizens to not argue with the police trying to implement the lockdown order to contain the spread of coronavirus.

He said, “The police machinery are working round-the-clock to ensure that citizens follow the mandate and stay at home, as per the Centre’s guidelines, to prevent the spread of Covid-19.”

Mhaisekar said the number of coronavirus cases in the division has gone up to 64, with 24 cases in Pune city, 12 in PCMC, 2 in Satara, 25 in Sangli and 1 in Kolhapur. Of the 1,283 samples sent to the city-based National Institute of Virology, results of 1,191 samples have already reached.

Till date, as many as 15 people affected with the virus have been discharged from Naidu and YCM hospitals. The divisional commissioner said 64 farmer groups were providing supply to 13,516 vegetable vendors. He added that there was enough foodgrain in stock.

Title: 84 test negative in Kota, 18 put in isolation
Content: At least 84 people have been tested negative for coronavirus in Kota so far. Another 18 people suspected to be infected with coronavirus have been admitted to the isolation ward at Kota’s Maharao Bhim Singh (MBS) Hospital . Meanwhile, three Rapid Response Teams (RRT), medical teams and special administrative group are working round-the-clock to trace, screen and isolate the suspects.“The reports of 84 people have come out negative. No positive case has been reported in Kota so far,” said Dr C P Meena , in-charge of corona isolation ward in MBS Hospital. “Besides, 18 other persons suspected to be infected with the virus have been admitted in the isolation ward and their sample reports are awaited,” he added. “Out of the 18, three youths were admitted in isolation ward on Saturday night and Sunday noon,” he said.

Title: 68 bureaucrats to lead corona fight
Content: NEW DELHI: The government has formed ten empowered groups and a strategic task force, together comprising around 68 bureaucrats, as it seeks to move comprehensively and with speed to contain the Covid-19 pandemic.Each of the ten empowered groups has been assigned specific tasks spanning medical emergency management to ensuring isolation beds, quarantine facilities, availability of essential equipments such as personal protective equipment, masks, gloves and ventilators and upgrading human resources and capacity building. One group will specifically look at public grievances.“The idea is to have a comprehensive approach to deal with this unprecedented incident. The teams will look into different aspects and try to assess the impact from various perspectives. All the teams will work in a concerted way,” a senior official told TOI.While the ten empowered groups will be headed by secretaries from different ministries and government departments and look at specific issues related to Covid-19 management, the task force comprises of six members and will look at strategic issues related to the lockdown.The task force includes Dr V K Paul, member health in Niti Aayog; two secretaries from the home ministry, and three officials from the prime minister’s office .The task force will report directly to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and is empowered to take decisions, the official said.“We are dealing with an unprecedented situation. A flood or earthquake affects some parts of the country but this has affected the entire country,” health ministry joint secretary Lav Agarwal said.The Centre has been insisting on stringent implementation of the lockdown and isolation measures to break the chain of transmission of Covid-19 and avoid a situation where the virus spreads to a larger community making it difficult for authorities to trace the link.While cases are increasing rapidly in last one week, the government has maintained that there is still no evidence of community transmission in India.Amid concerns that India may see a further surge in case load, the government and health agencies said a strict implementation of lockdown measures can avoid such a situation.“If adherence to the lockdown is 100% then this (the cases) can be close to peak but we need to be aware that it is important to follow government guidelines and protocols for isolation, quarantine and social distancing,” Dr R R Gangakhedkar, head- epidemiology and communicable diseases at the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) said.

Title: Doctors decry govt’s policy of ‘booze with prescription’
Content: Kochi: Closure of liquor outlets in the state following the lockdown has kickstarted a debate as withdrawal symptoms and even suicides reportedly due to unavailability of liquor, has become an additional burden on the state struggling to fight Covid-19 . The government’s decision to give alcohol on prescription of doctors also has kicked up a storm, with various doctors’ bodies terming it unethical.Kerala Government Medical Officer’s Association (KGMOA) expressed concern over the government’s decision on Saturday. “Withdrawal symptom is an issue and it needs to be addressed. It can cause epilepsy, suicidal tendency, abnormal behaviour, etc., but making doctors prescribe alcohol for it is not the solution. We have treatment and medicines for the same and we will prescribe that. Besides, if doctors start to give certificates then there would be long queues at hospital at a very wrong time,” said Dr Joseph Chacko of KGMOA.Dr C J John, senior consultant psychiatrist with Medical Trust Hospital, Ernakulam, said that those facing withdrawal symptoms should get treatment as early as possible. “Doctors can’t prescribe alcohol, if at all, we could certify that a person has withdrawal symptoms. But whether to give him alcohol or how much to give him is entirely the policy makers’ decision,” said Dr John.Speaking off the record, doctors, however, said that if the government thinks that supplying alcohol to temporarily avoid issues like withdrawal symptoms and to avoid flow of spurious liquor, it would be a fair policy but doctors cannot be asked to write prescriptions for that.Indian Psychiatric Society- Kerala State wrote to the chief minister with a five-point suggestion on dealing with the withdrawal symptoms. The measures suggested by them included, making available medications like lorazepam, diazepam, thiamine, IV fluids and basic lab facilities to check liver function test, RBS and electrolytes and short online training programs for doctors and nurses.Indian Medical Association, Kerala state branch, also wrote to the CM urging the government to reconsider its decision.

Title: Returnees cry foul over Q-norm rules
Content: Hyderabad: Despite being asymptomatic after the mandatory 14-day quarantine period, several foreign returnees have complained that officials are considering the day they inspected the house of an individual as Day 1 instead of the date of arrival in the city. So, many end up in a month’s quarantine.A woman, who arrived from Qatar on March 19, said GHMC officials visited her house on March 28 and asked her to be in home quarantine until April 14.“I have not developed any symptoms since the time of arrival and was supposed to remain in home quarantine until April 2. However, the officials asked me to remain in quarantine until April 14,” she said.Another resident, who is in home quarantine since March 13, said her isolation might end only on April 8. “ The officials who visited my residence had very little knowledge of English and Hindi and I know very little Telugu. They came on Day 10 of my quarantine, but counted it as Day 1,” another resident said.Officials clarified that unless an individual develops symptoms, it was not necessary to remain in home quarantine after the mandatory 14-day period. “The date of arrival should be considered as Day 1, not the day of inspection. If a mistake has happened at our end, we will correct it. Individuals facing this problem can contact us and the error will be rectified,” said GHMC zonal commissioner, Serilingampally, N Ravi Kiran . TNN

Title: 6 booked for violating home quarantine
Content:
Kolhapur: The city police on Sunday booked another six people for violating the 14-day home quarantine norm.

According to police, three cases have been registered with Shahapur police station, 2 with Shivajinagar police station and one at Radhanagari police station.

“In all these cases, the suspects either have a travel history or they came in contact with people having travel history. They were asked not to leave their homes and their hands were stamped. Despite this they were found loitering in the market area and on major roads in the jurisdiction of respective police stations. They were detained after police from respective police stations got information about their movement,” a senior police officer said.

Police have booked them under sections 188 (Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 291 (Continuance of nuisance after injunction to discontinue), 269 (Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) and 270 (Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) of the Indian Penal Code.

Meanwhile, police also continued their drive against motorists coming on road without any reason and have seized as many as 202 two-wheelers from across the district on Sunday. “The drive will continue till the lockdown is lifted,” said police.

Title: Lack of stock halts service in Quepem
Content: Quepem: Quepem Municipal Council’s (QMC) door-to-door delivery of household essentials came to a halt on Saturday after attending to more than 600 residents. QMC chairperson Dayesh Naik said that fresh stock will arrive on Monday and supplies will be delivered on the basis of orders. The council has now decided to pack a bag of all goods at a fixed rate of Rs 600.TNN

Title: Bhopal: Curfew Wali Mata Mandir locked, but open for prayers
Content:
People stopping and offering prayers amid the lockdown,

BHOPAL: In times of Corona curfew, Bhopal’s ‘Curfew Wali Mata Mandir’ continues to provide succour though its gates stay locked. People stop by for a few seconds, keeping one eye open for the cops posted in the vicinity, murmur a prayer and hurry on.
