The idol of ‘Curfew Mata’ was established 38 years ago in Peer Gate area during a month-long curfew following riots. Hence the name. It was open even during Bhopal gas tragedy, but is now shut for the first time in memory.

The temple is locked but there’s no stopping the devout. On Sunday, the usual crowd of devotees was replaced by half a dozen policemen, tasked with enforcing curfew in letter and spirit – and with a stick, if need be.

People drove or pedalled by, closing eyes in reverence and sending up a silent prayer, before hurrying on lest the cops begin ‘enforcing’. But here, the cops are lenient, too. Who would stop a prayer in these times?

Those who paused a while longer got a gentle reminder from police to “leave it to Mata and move on”.

“It’s part of my daily routine to pray at the temple, so I continue doing it. The temple is closed to visitors, and we know it’s good this way, seeing the Coronavirus crisis, but something draws me here. I don’t get peace of mind until I see the temple and pay my respects. I’m thankful that I can do this, no matter how briefly,” said devotee Vishal Namdeo, nodding in gratefulness to the cops.

One of the policemen deployed there said there is a steady trickle of devotees, but they all pray for a few seconds and move on. “They come here as if the very sight of the temple reassures them,” he said, adding that only the priest goes inside every morning and evening through a backdoor for the rituals these days.

The temple was established during trying times in the city. Seventy-three-year-old Ramesh Saini, president of the 13-member committee that runs the temple, recalls the day it was set up.

“I was around 35 years old when the temple was built in 1982. It was during Navratri that year that an idol of goddess Durga was established and immersed after nine days. But locals established an idol there and the administration took it away, leading to a dispute. Curfew was imposed but soon people from nearby districts started flocking to the temple though there were arrests every day,” said Saini.

His father Babulal Mali, a Congress leader, was among the founding members of the temple, Saini said.

“Arjun Singh was the chief minister then, and Vijay Singh the Bhopal collector. Seeing the public sentiment, the administration asked us to establish the idol during the curfew. A puja was done at 5am and the idol was established. This gave the temple its name,” said Saini.

The temple has never seen such a time, he said, not even during the Bhopal gas tragedy. “There was no curfew after the tragedy, but roads were deserted for a long time. We still kept the temple open for entire nights so that anyone who needs help can come to us,” he said.

In the past 38 years, curfew was imposed once or twice but the temple never had to shut. “These are extraordinary times, and require extraordinary measures. On March 28, the administration ordered us to shut the temple completely,” said Saini.

“The goddess is watching over us. This is a trying time. It, too, will pass with Mata’s grace,” he said.

Title: Village school goes digital in Anand
Content:
A teacher explains maths digitally to the students under lockdown

Vadodara/ Anand: Like all other educational institutions, this school in Anand district too is closed because of the 21 days lockdown. While the state has already announced mass promotion of students from Class I to IX, 200-odd students enrolled with this government primary school are taking their lessons at their homes.

Teachers of Gopalpura primary school are taking their classes through WhatsApp groups. This, they say, is a voluntary initiative to ensure that kids don’t forget what they have learnt in their classrooms. And this initiative has found support from Anand district administration which has started promoting it as a model to educate children when they are away from their schools.

“Initially, this WhatsApp group was meant to share general information about the school schedule, programmes and other communication with parents,” said Shalin Dabhi, principal of Gopalpura primary school. “But after March 25, every teacher selects a topic – be it simple dictation, multiplication, subtraction or tables of subjects like mathematics or alphabets of language subjects. The teacher then prepares videos which are posted on the group and students are asked to follow them up at their home with the help of parents,” she said.

The school has nine teachers, of which six are involved in preparing this home-to-do digital syllabus. The school located nearly 3 km from milk city Anand has extra benefit as the kids are already tech-savvy.

For a population of just 3,000, the government school is equipped with five smart classes apart from computer lab with broadband connection thanks to support from NRI donors. Like Gopalpura, eight teachers of Jahangirpura primary school near Hadgood village are also involved in this digital education drive.

“We have 254 students in our school. The WhatsApp group formed has 200 members but many of them are wards of same parents or live in the neighbourhood. They share the content posted by our teachers. It also helps in long term as although students will get promoted, they can be made ready for the next class,” said principal Mitesh Mecklin.

Anand district primary education officer (DPEO) Nivedita Chaudhary told TOI that there is no directive from the state government to this primary schools or teachers. “These teachers have taken this initiative just to ensure that the wards don’t get cut off from their school,” she said.

Title: Authorities struggle to check home-quarantined deviants
Content:
Panaji: There’s a fresh headache for authorities in the form of people who are in home quarantine but not following it in toto. Sources said that this deviance increases the risk of transmitting the disease should they test positive. Of the two who tested positive on Sunday, one is the brother of one of last week’s positive cases.

Authorities have noticed several incidents of persons defying home quarantine, particularly those with travel history. Over 700 persons are in home quarantine . Goa has five confirmed cases of Covid-19.

A senior official confirmed that they are facing problems with people in home quarantine. They have been instructed that those caught defying quarantine should be lodged in facility quarantine.

“We recently found that a person who was home-quarantined was manning a counter at his shop in the village a few days ago. He has been warned since,” an official said.

Another senior official said it has been emphasised to authorities that those defying home quarantine have to be dealt with strictly. “Even after warnings, if they do not listen, they need to be lodged in the facility quarantine with a clear warning that if they mingle with others in quarantine, they she will be locked inside a room,” he said.

Sources say it is not physically possible to check on each person in quarantine. The official said that in Sankhali itself, there are 388 persons plus 26 travellers in home quarantine.

“Though calls are made to them every day, there is no way for us to know if any of them had stepped out unless someone brings it to our notice,” he said.

Goa has resorted to stamping persons who are in home quarantine. “We need to be strict with them if we want to keep the count of Covid-19 low,” an official said. It has been suggested that the quarantine period of 14 days be extended to 28 days, at least for persons having a travel history.

“From the day of entry of virus to symptoms, it takes a maximum of 14 days. A 28-day quarantine is advisable,” a GMC doctor said.

Title: 300 inmates of Agra district jail get interim bail
Content:
Agra/Pilibhit: Over 300 inmates of district jail in Agra have been granted interim bail. According to Shashikant Mishra, superintendent of district jail, “The inmates, who were serving jail term for less than seven years, or had completed 14 years or were above 60 years, were given eight weeks interim bail considering the coronavirus scare.”

However, the inmates are yet to be released.

Similar efforts were made in all district jails of UP after apex court order.

While in Pilibhit, the district jail authorities have sent a list of 15 convicts to state administration for approval of parole who had been sentenced to less than 7 year imprisonment. In addition, 13 under trial prisoners were granted interim bail for eight weeks on Sunday on filing of their personal bonds.

Title: Army personnel who returned from Rajasthan is Uttarakhand’s 7th Covid-19 positiveve case
Content: DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand reported its 7th Covid-19 positive case on Sunday. The patient, an Army personnel, was admitted to Military Hospital in the city after he returned from Rajasthan on March 10 and showed symptoms of the novel-cornavirus. However, on Sunday, his reports confirmed he was Covid-19-positive.Director general (health) Dr Amita Upreti told TOI, “The man, who is aged 47, had returned from Rajasthan on March 10. He showed coronavirus-like symptoms on March 24 and was admitted to Military Hospital on March 26. His swab samples were sent for test on March 27 and reports came positive on Sunday.”She added that the health department on Sunday received reports of 27 samples and of these,26 were negative.An official said that orders have been issued to quarantine all army staffers who came in contact with the man including doctors in the hsopital as well as others who met him in the last 20 days.He added that the personnel is associated with a batallion in Chakrata area and also hails from the same place.“He was asymptomatic at the time of his arrival from Rajasthan. Hence, we cannot rule out the possibility that he got the infection in Uttarakhand. Also, he met his family and many others in the 16 days of his stay outside the hospital. Hence, we will now have to identify each person he came in contact with and quarantine them,” the official said.Meanwhile, the second Covid-19 test reports of the first Indian Forest Service (IFS) trainee officer who was admitted to Doon Hospital on March 15 came out positive again on Sunday.The state has so far quarantined 1,730 people who had travelled from outside India and 31 of them have been kept in isolation wards in hospitals.

Title: Hyderabad: Supplies ease, prices soften after a soar
Content: HYDERABAD: At a time when poultry prices are soaring in the city, vegetable rates have now reduced after the supply chain bottlenecks started to ease in the last one week.Last week, the surge in purchases and shortage of supply resulted in a hike in vegetable prices across the city, with some vendors charging as high as Rs 100 for 1 kg of tomatoes. However, due to arrival of fresh vegetables in the last one week, prices have inched back to normalcy with rates dropping by almost 50%.For example, the Erragadda market received only 1,057 quintals of vegetables on March 23 as against 2,207 quintals on March 28. Similarly, Falaknuma market received 307 quintals of vegetables on March 23 as against 565 quintals on March 28, and Kukatpally market received 183 quintals on March 23 as against 606 quintals received on March 29.“We have recently received fresh produce due to which the prices have been reduced. Panic buying has also stopped with households having stocked up already to adjust to the lockdown routine,” said Seenu, a rythu bazaar vendor from Sainikpuri.With supply line hindrances removed, the prices of vegetables came down significantly. Tomatoes which cost Rs 50-100 per kg a week are now available for purchase at Rs 18-30 per kg. Prices also dropped for other vegetables such as ladyfinger, cauliflower, cabbage among others.Though the demand-supply gap still exists in grocery items, it has been reduced considerably by mobile rythu bazaars and online grocery stores making a comeback.“Now, the local vendors are again visiting our doorsteps and supplying groceries. I was happy to see that the local vendors too are offering sanitizers and taking precautionary measures,” said Varsha Narra, a housewife.

Title: Boy dies after slipping from terrace while flying kite in Bareilly
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

BAREILLY: A 16-year-old boy slipped and fell from a terrace while flying kite at Sarai locality under Gunnaur police station limits in Sambhal on Saturday evening.

Police said Waseem was rushed to a private doctor who referred him to higher facility. He had sustained severe head injuries. His family took him to another hospital where he passed away during treatment.

On Sunday, SHO Praveen Singh Solanki said that amid complete lockdown, people are asked to stay indoors but it had been quite difficult to keep children busy.

“Children are often involved in flying kites and other activities . We are continuously asking them not to do anything which can cause harm but there are some who doesn’t want to listen,” he added.

Title: ‘Travel permits only in rare cases’
Content:
Margao: The South Goa district administration has been adopting stringent measures to ensure bare minimum vehicle movement within the state during the lockdown.

South Goa district magistrate Ajit Roy on Sunday told TOI that while there has been a complete ban on movement of vehicles from across the state’s borders, permissions are being granted for vehicles to travel within the state within specified destinations only in “rarest of rare cases.”

For travel permits within the state, Roy said, “We have to see the type of emergency situation and permission is given on a case to case basis for emergencies, only in rarest of rare cases.”

Only movement of vehicles engaged in services classified by state authorities as “essential services” is permitted during the lockdown, while travel permits are granted to others by the district administration only for meeting medical emergencies or other exigencies, sources in the district administration said.

Title: ‘CM playing politics with volunteering’
Content:
Saligao: Social activists from Mapusa are irked over chief minister Pramod Sawant’s decision to allow only elected representative to act as volunteers to undertake delivery of essentials to people during the 21-day lockdown.

Accusing him of denying civilians the right to volunteer, they said the CM should not bring politics into play at such a time. The fight against the deadly coronavirus (Covid-19) should be fought unitedly, without any politics, they said.

Siolim-based Rajan Ghate said Sawant should realise that he is the CM of the state and not of BJP members alone. “We have been working for the people. Sawant should consider our demand as we are used to volunteering our services,” he said.

Many activists had already submitted their applications for volunteering on March 25 when the government suddenly came up with the idea of appointing only MLAs, panchayat members and councilors as volunteers.

Another activist, Shekar Naik, said his application has been lying pending with the authorities. “I cannot understand how just these elected representatives will be sufficient to cater to the needs of so many households,” he said.

“There is a lot of ongoing politics going in the appointment of volunteers. The rejection of our applications is proof of this,” Mapusa-based activist, Pravin Asolkar said.

Title: Uttarakhand government retracts on easing intra-state traffic movement on March 31
Content:
DEHRADUN: A day after announcing to ease intra-state traffic movement for 13 hours on March 31, Uttarakhand government retracted its decision on Sunday. This comes after the Centre issued fresh guidelines stating that all migrants, who have moved out to reach their homes states/towns, should be kept in a government facility and should be quarantined for a minimum of 14 days.

Announcing the latest decision to not ease lockdown for intra-state traffic movement, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat said, “We will have a better chance of conquering coronavirus if we follow the guidelines strictly. Hence, we are withdrawing the announcement of easing down traffic movement on March 31. I apologise to the state residents if they are finding it difficult to cope up with the lockdown situation but strict measures are required to get rid of Covid-19.”

After reports of several people being stranded in districts across the state, Uttarakhand government, on Saturday, had announced that it will ease the intra-state traffic movement for 13 hours on March 31. The stranded people were to be allowed the use of private taxis and Uttarakhand Transport Corporation buses to reach homes.

However, according to the guidelines issued by the Union ministry of home affairs on March 29, the states and Union territories must make temporary arrangements for stranded people, migrant workers, and those in need. The directive adds that all employers (industrial, private, commercial, or any other sector) shall make payments of wages to their workers without any deductions.

The MHA also issued an advisory to people who have rented out their homes to migrant workers asking them to spare one month rent payment. The guidelines add that any landlord, who is found to be forcing a student tenant to vacate the house during lockdown, shall be liable for action.

Title: PM Modi interacts with, praises Agra family of Covid-19 survivors
Content: AGRA: Prime Minister Narendra Modi interacted with novel coronavirus survivor Ashok Kapoor, a shoe exporter from Agra who along with his entire family, including wife, two son, daughter-in-law and grandson was infected after he visited Italy in January.Interacting with Kapoor in his Mann Ki Baat on Sunday, PM Modi said, “Without panicking, by taking the right decision at the right time, by contacting doctors in time and by observing all the precautions, we can defeat this pandemic.”Sharing his experience in a short interaction, Ashok Kapoor told PM Modi that his two sons and son-in-law who live in Delhi had caught the virus in Italy and infected other family members upon returning. PM told the 73-year-old and his family members to spread awareness about anti-coronavirus measures in Agra and use social media for the purpose.Talking to TOI, shoe export’s son Amit Kapoor said, “We were overwhelmed to get a call from PM Narendra Modi where he enquired about our wellbeing and the entire experience of our fight against Covid-19. We feel motivated to spread awareness about precautions against the disease and help those in need during the country-wide lockdown.”Talking to Ashok Kapoor, PM Modi said, “I have called you up because your entire family got entangled in the crisis. I will definitely want to know about your problems. How you defeated the infection? What happened at the hospital?”Responding to PM Modi, Kapoor said, “I have two sons who went to Italy to attend a shoe fair. We have a shoe manufacturing unit here. Our son-in-law, who lives in Delhi, also returned from Italy, with them. He had some health issues and went to Ram Manohar Lohia hospital in Delhi where he tested positive for Covid-19 and was shifted to Safdarjung hospital in Delhi.”He said, “We received a call from there that our two sons must also be tested. Hence, my two sons went to Agra district hospital for a test. The doctors at the district hospital asked them to bring the family along for a test, so we all went there. The next day, six members of my family members – my two sons, wife, myself, daughter-in-law and grandson – were declared positive and asked to come to Delhi.”He further said, “We were not frightened. We thought it was good that the infection was detected. We went to Delhi’s Safdurjung hospital in two ambulances provided by the Agra district hospital free of charge. We are greatly thankful to the doctors and district administration of Agra who extended their full cooperation”.“The ambulance left us at Safdarjung hospital where doctors were already there to help us. We were shifted to the designated ward where each of us was given a separate room. They were nice rooms and we stayed there for 14 days. We received excellent cooperation from doctors and the staff. They all used to come dressed in similar uniforms, so it was difficult to differentiate between a doctor, nurse and a ward boy. We obeyed whatever instructions they gave and we did not face even the slightest of trouble.”In response, PM Modi said, “Your confidence is also commendable. Your family faced such a grave crisis. Even your 16-year-old grandson was infected.”Ashok said that his grandson had to appear for the ICSE examination, but he asked him to forego it.To this, PM said, “Your experience came in handy for the family. You kept up their morale.”“All the family members were supporting one another. Though we could not meet, we remained in touch through telephone. Doctors provided us optimum care and we are grateful to them and to the staff nurses,” Ashok concluded.PM Modi said, “My best wishes to you and your family. Please spread awareness in your own way in Agra. You can feed whoever is hungry, care for the poor and can spread awareness among people to follow the rules. You can tell them about the plight of your family and how can they prevent that by following rules. If everyone follows the rules, country can be saved”.

Title: People dial SOS as Covid-19 lockdown draws wildlife out of forests
Content: AGRA: Calls to rescue wild animals spotted roaming about empty locked down streets in urban areas have increased over the past few days. This was confirmed by an NGO, Wildlife SOS. It said its teams have received numerous calls and rescued several monkeys, snakes and birds from Agra and Mathura cities.According to a spokesperson of the NGO, they have saved four injured monkeys and a Coppersmith Barbet that were found injured in Khandari Colony , a Wolf snake that was found stuck between a door in Sikandara and another that was found inside a house in Runakta. One cobra was also rescued from a storage room of a house in Shamshabad, while one rat snake was rescued from a doctor’s house in Dayalbagh Keeping with health and safety guidelines, all rescue staff has access to gloves, face masks, alcohol- based hand sanitisers and other necessary equipment to stay safe, said the NGO spokesperson.“There is no stopping or resting when it comes to conservation and our rescuers are quite aware of that. They are dedicated and willing to put their lives at risk to help an injured animal and the community in their time of need,” said director, conservation projects, Wildlife SOS, Baiju Raj MV.Co-founder and CEO of Wildlife SOS Kartick Satyanarayan, said, “We are trying our best to ensure no rescue calls goes unanswered and are extremely glad for the cooperation of the dstrict administrationa of Agra and Mathura, the Uttar Pradesh forest department and police in are carrying out rescues at this time.”In his nationwide speech, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said, “People should be compassionate towards animals as they too have been impacted during this lockdown. Animals are finding it difficult to seek out food and water sources during this difficult time.”

Title: AMU refuses to send students back home
Content:
Aligarh Muslim University

AGRA: With the government of India issuing directions to states for a complete clampdown on movement of people across borders, Vice chancellor of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) has turned down the request of students demanding transportation arrangements to send them back to their home towns.

Confirming this, spokesperson of the varsity, Shafey Kidwai, said that the VC has clearly told the students to stay put in their hostels and directed the provosts to provide counselling to them.

Earlier in the day, hundreds of students of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU), hailing from UP, Bihar and Jammu & Kashmir had urged the administration to immediately make arrangements to send them back to their home states, as they couldn’t continue staying here under the prevailing circumstances.

Though, the varsity officials initially started the process and approached the district authorities for the same, but gave up after central government’s directions to seal the district and state borders. The VC asked the provost to persuade the 4,500 students in hostels to stay put.

Unhappy with the VC’a decision a kashmiri girl student, Samreen Manzoor , who is pursuing post graduation in Sociology, said “Uncertainty of the lockdown, living far from their families and being virtually confined to small hostel rooms has led to depression and loneliness amongst many students,”

Another research scholars, residing in the campus’s hostel, Nuzhat Akhtar , a resident of Kashmir’s Baramulla, told TOI that she just wants to get out from here. “I don’t care. I have lost all patience. I’m scared and want to be with my parents”, she said. Admitting that her fears stem from various news reports on TV and social media, she said, "we are entering in the third stage and we don’t know what’s going to happen to us,” she said, adding that their lives had become “hell” by being confined to a room.

Title: Screening of workers coming to Rajasthan from other states
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: At least 1.25 lakh migrant labourers who arrived in the state from Gujarat and Maharastra were screened by medical and health department teams on Sunday. Both the departments have been empowered the district collectors, chief medical and health officers (CMHOs) of Dungarpur, Banswara, Udaipur, Jalore, Sirohi and Ajmer to ensure proper screening of these workers who are returning to their respective villages in Rajasthan.

Various camps having doctors and para-medical staff have been put near the bus stand and other areas which are close to the bordering states such as Gujarat, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh , Punjab and Haryana.

“Our screening is on since Thursday. But from Saturday, when the numbers started increasing, extra teams have been deployed in various districts to ensure proper screening,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (medical and health), on Sunday. He added that Asha Sahyogni (health workers) have also been assigned the task to have a door-to-door survey in various villages and hamlets to find if any migrant worker has arrived from other states recently especially Maharashtra and Gujarat. Medical and health department has also asked to rope in private hospitals, clinics for screening of the migrant labourers. “We are more concerned in the districts including Jalore, Sirohi, Dungarpur, Banswara and Udaipur from where a sizeable population works not only as migrant labourers but also do various other jobs. Whereever these people are spotted, they are being screened,” said a senior officer .

Title: Overcharging, hoarding of essential items concern Uttarakhand officials
Content:
DEHRADUN/UTTARKASHI/HARIDWAR/UDHAM SINGH NAGAR/NAINITAL: With the lockdown completing almost a week, reports of overcharging by traders and hoarding of essential commodities are coming from all across the state.

“The Covid-19 lockdown has triggered panic among people and as a consequence, traders are stocking essential commodities and shopkeepers are charging extra for home deliveries and other supplies. It is upon the local administration to check such incidents,” Mahesh Bhandari , president of Doon residents’ welfare front, told TOI.

Bhandari, who is also the in-charge of 70 RWAs, is actively urging residents to not hoard daily essentials.

On Sunday, six shopkeepers were penalised by Dehradun district administration for overcharging. Taking cognisance of such incidents, Dehradun district magistrate Ashish Kumar Srivastava has now mandated a rate list in every shop to avoid overpricing.

In Uttarkashi, soaring prices of vegetables and food grains are burning a hole in the pockets of locals during the ongoing lockdown. “Traders in bigger cities have started hoarding essential commodities. Besides, local farmers are no longer selling their produce and are saving it for their consumption fearing a crisis in the days to come. All this has led to sky-rocketing of prices,” said Dwarika Semwal, a social activist.

Gopal Matuda, Uttarkashi supply officer told TOI,”We have set up teams which conduct routine inspections in different areas to check overcharging and hoarding. We have also asked shopkeepers to put up price list in their shops to maintain transparency. We want to assure people that there is no shortage of basic commodities in the district."

Haridwar residents are also facing similar issues. The local administration has issued a rate list for fruits and vegetables but a price list for other food items, including flour, rice and wheat, is still awaited.

Yogesh Pandey, a resident of Ranipur area, told TOI, “Shopkeepers are over charging us for daily essentials. A bag of 10 kg flour is being sold at Rs 300-Rs 350 much more than the normall rates.”

Such incidents are also being reported from Udham Singh Nagar . “Ration shops have long queues and shopkeepers are charging exorbitantly. Even after action by officials, many continue to charge Rs 5-Rs 10 extra for almost every commodity,” said Pramod Singh, a resident of Kichha area of US Nagar.

In Nainital, however, people are complaining not so much of overcharging but of low supplies. “We are dealing with short supply of food items and protective gears like masks and sanitisers. But the prices have remained largely the same,” said Naresh Sah, a resident of the lake town.

To deal with this shortage in supplies, Nainital administration has set up a team to check black marketing of commodities.

Title: Fears recede, but chicken price rises to Rs 190/kg in Telangana
Content: HYDERABAD: With myths surrounding the consumption of chicken and spread of coronavirus subsiding, prices of poultry have been seeing a sharp rise over the past few days.Chicken prices, which had fallen to Rs 50 per kg until mid-March, rose to Rs 190 per kg on Sunday. With people realising that chicken consumption does not cause coronavirus and chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao ’s issuing a statement busting myths, the demand for poultry products has risen. Market rates of chicken on March 25, 26, 27 and 28 stood at Rs 135, Rs 152, Rs 168 and Rs 177 per kg, respectively.“The demand for chicken and eggs rose after people saw that others who were consuming chicken did not fall ill. The CM’s statement also helped the industry,” said Errabelli Pradeep Kumar Rao, president, Telangana Poultry Federation A butcher at a meat store on Road No 7, Banjara Hills said that customers coming to his store also helped put an end to the rumours. “Several commuters bought chicken after noticing people buying meat at my store,” said Mohammed Mazher, a staffer at TenderCuts, a meat store in Banjara Hills.Meanwhile, Chakradhar Rao, president, Indian Poultry Equipment Manufacturer’s Association, stressed that the government should not restrict the movement of vehicles transporting bird feed amid the lockdown. “Prices of poultry products also dipped as birds were being killed and distributed for free due to lack of bird feed in market. Only if poultry feed reaches farmers the industry will survive,” said Rao.

Title: Coronavirus in Telangana: 70 coronavirus cases in Telangana, 11 recover
Content: HYDERABAD: The number of coronavirus positive cases went up to 70 in Telangana with three more persons testing positive on Sunday.Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao, while giving out figures, said that 11 persons in hospital quarantine, have also recovered and tested negative during fresh tests.KCR said the 11 patients will be discharged on Monday after following all protocols to ensure that there is no scope of coronavirus spreading from these patients again.The chief minister said that 58 people are under quarantine treatment, including a 76-year-old person, who tested positive for coronavirus and is also suffering from various other ailments.“If the state does not get any new Covid-19 positive case after April 7, Telangana will be free from coronavirus. Let’s hope and pray that we becomes a Covid-19 free-Telangana,” CM said.

Title: Mangaluru: Uncertainty rife in dairy industry
Content: MANGALURU: The dairy sector in Karnataka is headed for a Covid-19-induced meltdown. Faced with the problem of disposing of around 8-10 lakh litres of unsold milk daily, the Karnataka Milk Federation (KMF), that manages the affairs of 14 milk unions, is also hit by labour and transport issues , and fast dwindling stocks of raw materials needed to keep the milk industry running on a daily basis.KMF procures an average 68-70 lakh litres of milk daily, and sells around 40 lakh litres either as milk, curd or packaged milk. The remaining 30 lakh litres is converted into more than 100 milk products such as ice-cream, peda, ghee and butter. Due to the lockdown, barring ghee and butter, there is no market for the rest of its bouquet of products, resulting in stocking up of unconverted milk.Through its five milk powder units at Channarayapatna, Dempo Dairy, Dharwad, Mother Dairy and another unit in Kanakapura, KMF converts around 15 lakh litres of milk into around 200-200 tonnes of milk powder. The Covid-19 crisis also scuttled KMF’s plans to commission a state-of-the-art milk powder production plant at Ramanagar, that would have the capacity to produce around 100MT of milk powder daily. Trial runs are on at the facility.A senior functionary at KMF said on condition of anonymity that the Ramanagar plant could have helped the federation face the present crisis. The experts who came to install the plant were from France and Italy, that are bearing the brunt of the Covid-19 pandemic, and returned to their countries. “We are in touch with them, and are trying to operationalise this plant,” he said.The Ramanagar plant would have helped KMF convert an additional 4-5 lakh litres of milk to milk powder. Presently, KMF is left with 8-10 lakh litres of excess milk. With milk sales to neighbouring states drying up, disposal of excess milk is a huge problem, he said. A labour-intensive industry, 15,000 workers are needed to run operations, but KMC is operating with only 60% of its workforce, he said, adding KMF is waiting for the government to take a call on its future.

Title: Funerals timings hinge on availability of grave diggers
Content:
Panaji: Funeral services which otherwise draw a crowd of relatives, friends, neighbours and acquaintances, now allow just a handful of family members. In keeping with the new Church guidelines there is no mass, just the final rites directly at the cemetery.

But with the regular grave diggers refusing to step out of their homes, getting someone to dig graves is becoming increasingly difficult. A majority of these workers are migrants.

Saturday and Sunday, saw three burial services in Siolim. There was no Mass – as is traditionally held for the soul of the deceased prior to the burial. Akin Fernandes has been helping St Anthony’s Church in Siolim to get workers to dig graves. They charge Rs 2,000 for each grave, and the burial has to be scheduled as per their convenience. “On Saturday, after I managed to locate two migrants who agreed to dig two graves, they came to the cemetery on their own bikes. But today (Sunday) I had to arrange for their transport as they said they got beaten up by the cops while returning.”

The priest, who usually always goes to the residence of the deceased and prays before the body is moved to the church, did not go. Instead, the bodies were brought directly to the cemetery and lowered into the grave. The priest then performed the last rites in the presence of close family members and a few friends. Almost everyone present was wearing masks. All dispersed quickly, without condoling the grieving family members.

“We kept the church closed. The family was cooperative. I told them I will celebrate mass myself and offer it for his soul,” a priest from a church in Bardez said.

At a funeral in South Goa where only a dozen people were present, they were asked to sit away from each other, on different benches during the Mass and were asked to wash their hands with disinfectant before entering the Church. “There was no choir and we priests did the readings ourselves as a precautionary measure,” the priest told TOI.

Title: Slum-dwellers in Cantt struggle to make ends meet amid lockdown
Content:
Secunderabad: As the lockdown has brought daily life to a standstill, residents of over a 100 slums in Secunderabad Cantonment areas are struggling to make ends meet. Most of the 5,000 families staying in the eight civilian wards in the Cantonment areas are daily-wage earners, domestic helpers, construction and sanitation workers.

Resident Welfare Associations (RWAs) of nearly 300 colonies have been told by their employers to stay home. “I used to earn of Rs 2,000 to Rs 3,000 per month, now who will take care of us?” said K Nagamma (38), a domestic helper and resident of Indiramma Nagar in Rasoolpura.

Durgaiah (28), a daily wager, said the SCB staff and local ward members have failed to help him during the crisis. “The state government had announced it will supply rice, oil and dal through fair price shops, but in the Cantonment, the officials concerned are not implementing this. I have five family members to feed,” he said.

Several families in slums also said SCB officials were only making announcements on preventive measures rather than providing them essential items.

Title: Manek’s masks keep Barodians stay safe
Content:
Workers at Chaitanya Manek’s

Vadodara: Ahead of the new academic calendar, Chaitanya Manek stocks up on cotton material for school uniforms. This year too he did the same, but the coronavirus pandemic decided to play spoilsport and schools and colleges closed down jeopardizing his business plans.

But for someone who earns just Rs20,000 a month by sewing clothes in his shop in Sama area, Manek thought of putting the stock of material to good use — make face masks when there was acute scarcity in the market. However, unlike many, his pursestrings were not opened by necessity, but by his heart. And so, lion-hearted Manek, not thinking about the loss he was incurring, decided to give back to the society by distributing these face masks for free.

Manek, who has been making school uniforms over last couple of years, told TOI: “Ahead of the new academic year, I always buy cotton cloth in bulk so that I can make school uniforms and deliver them in time. When the coronavirus scare started spreading some weeks ago, I thought it would subside soon. We began making uniforms. But about a week ago, I realised that the threat is real and closer home.”

“The health authorities were suggesting that people should wear face masks, but I learnt that their isn’t enough masks available in the market. That is when I decided to contribute from my side,” the 40-year-old SSC pass said.

From uniforms to masks was a giant leap and so Manek searched online on how to sew them, also talked to some people on the requirements. “And I began making cotton face masks of specific shape and size and also trained all the six workers in my unit how to sew them perfectly on machines. We are now making about 400 masks every day,” Manek said.

What’s the crowning glory to this venture is that he distributes them for free to the needy so that he too fights the spread of the deadly virus, in his own way.

When asked what prompted him to do so, Manek replied: “People are battling the deadly virus out there — police, health officials and government officials — all are doing everything to save people’s lives. This is my way of contributing to the society. I can’t be thinking about money now!”

After stitching in bulk, Manek hands over the masks to the police department for free distribution. He too distributes them to whoever approaches him.

And that’s not all.

Manek, who has two more mouths to feed at home, that of his son and wife, was ready to pay his employees their monthly salaries. However, inspired by his noble cause, the workers refused to accept the wages as they too wanted to be part of his missionary zeal!

Title: Surat cops use social media to nab violators
Content:
Police received this pic on Facebook page

Surat: Altogether 28 people were arrested by police on Sunday for violating lockdown orders. These offenders were tracked by the police through social media platforms after the police started receiving complaints on its Twitter and Facebook pages.

The police registered offences of violation of order against the people who were mostly seen assembling in groups at the same spot, pictures of which were sent to the cops on the social media sites.

Out of few photos shared on its FB page, police attended to 15 complaints from different areas in which people were seen hanging out or playing cards in groups.

Police control room van visited the spots and after verification registered cases in areas under Puna, Amroli and Katargam police stations.

Meanwhile, based on drone camera footage cops also registered at least 25 cases against those found assembling at a point in the city. Different police stations in the city have started operating drones to monitor their areas.

A team of crime branch police officers keeps changing its location within the city to monitor through three drone cameras.

"Police are keeping a close watch on all parts of city to enforce lockdown adopting various technologies. People should understand and cooperate and stay indoors because police will take strictest possible actions if anyone is found violating the orders," said R B Brahmbhatt, city police commissioner.

Police registered total 77 cases of violation of orders issued under public notification and detained 475 vehicles in the city. Since the lockdown was enforced, cops have registered 295 offences of violation of public notification and detained 2380 vehicles.

Title: More needs to be done to improve sanitation: Old City residents
Content:
Charminar: Sanitation efforts in the Old City areas have left locals dissatisfied especially since the outbreak of coronavirus. Residents have asked the state government to look into the matter and improve sanitation standards immediately. They said that while all possible steps were being taken to ensure people stayed in their homes, not much was being done to keep areas surrounding their homes clean. Touching upon sanitisation measures being taken up at certain places in the city, Syed Naser Ahmed from Jahanuma told TOI that effective sanitisation and fogging needed to be done within the localities.

“We have been asked to break the chain of Covid-19 by staying at home. We are doing our utmost best and following the government instructions. However, when you pass through the streets, there is garbage everywhere which poses a health risk to residents. While sanitisation has been taken up in some areas, more needs to be done throughout the entire city to ensure a healthier atmosphere for all,” Syed Naser said The residents also complained of a prevalent mosquito menace in their area.—Omer bin Taher

Title: Travel pass norms tweaked, med urgency prime yardstick
Content:
Cops are now allowing travel passes only in cases of medical emergency or death of kin

Bhopal: Once again, the order to issue travel passes to people, who want to go to their native places, has been changed. Now, only those people, who either want to go out for medical emergency, or in case of death of a close family member or those in essential services, will be allowed to go out of the district.

Since the lockdown order was issued for Covid-19, students and professionals hailing from outstations and residing here, had to face a lot of problems.

Many such people started flocking to police stations to get travel passes to go to their respective home towns. Initially, police issued them travel passes, but the very next day, an order was issued and only district administration officials were allowed to issue passes. Then again, an order was issued that passes will be issued by the local police station where the person needing the pass resides.

Police officials too were perplexed due to the orders being changed repeatedly. Now, cops maintain that the outstation students, who were left in the city, will have to stay in their hostels.

Speaking on the issue, Piplani SHO, Chain Singh Raghuwanshi, said that Piplani police issued around 1,100 passes and 80 per cent of them were issued to students, who mostly belong to Bihar and UP.

SHO MP Nagar, Manish Rai, said that most of the students left for their native places before the restriction order. Around 10-15 hostels still have some students, but they have been told that now they will have to stay here till the lockdown ends. Some hostel owners were asking students to leave or arrange for their meals themselves.

Police have warned such hostel owners to supply food and essential services to students lodged in their hostels or they will be booked under relevant sections and the hostel facility will be acquired by the government until the lockdown ends. SHO of Ashoka Garden, Sudesh Tiwari, said that Ashoka Garden police station has issued around 3,500 travel passes and around 40 per cent were issued to students.

SHO Ayodhya Nagar, Mahendra Kulhara, said that most hostellers in his jurisdiction have already left for their respective places.

ASP Zone-2, Sanjay Sahu, said that now the districts have been sealed and students have been advised to stay in their hostels and that all hostel managers have been informed to arrange food and essentials for the students.
