Title: SCR not to levy demurrage, wharfage charges till April 14
Content:
Hyderabad: The South Central Railway (SCR) has decided not to levy any charges for stacking, detention and ground usage of goods and parcel freight traffic up to April 14 amid the Covid-19 lockdown.

Operating over 270 freight trains in the last six days, SCR has transported fertilizers, coal to thermal power plants and food grains across the country, said officials.

“We have decided to cut down the rates of wharfage (fee charged on goods for not removing them from the railway after the expiry of the free time for such removal) and demurrage (charges levied for detaining rolling stock after the expiry of free time) for goods and parcels,” chief public relations officer of SCR, Ch Rakesh said.

“Furthermore, the free time for loading and unloading the trains and for removal of the consignments from the railways has been doubled,” he added.

SCR has been running freight train services to transport essential commodities since March 22 and the zone has registered freight loading of 10.17 million tonnes (MTs), averaging to around 1.70 MTs every day.

“Meanwhile, we are ensuring that a doctor is available for the rail staff on call. The working places, including offices and shed premises along with the rest houses are continuously sanitized and disinfected to provide a safe environments,” Ch Rakesh said.

Title: Do you send soldiers on war front without guns, say doctors fighting Covid-19
Content: DEHRADUN: Doctors, nurses and medical personnel from across the country have taken to social media to raise the issue of sub-standard personal protection equipment (PPE) kits being supplied to them in their fight against coronavirus . On Saturday, an irate doctor, Dr Debopam Chatterjee from the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Rishikesh exemplified the concerns of scores of medical professionals who are at the forefront of the fight against Covid-19. Posting pictures on Facebook about the kind of equipment provided to doctors and medical personnel at the Kolkata Medical College and Hospital — a dedicated hospital to treat Covid-19 patients — and comparing it to ‘raincoats,’ he wrote, “Healthcare providers should be rather asked to sign their death certificates prior to going on this suicide mission...we are ready to serve but not without protection!!”Not just Dr Chatterjee, medicos from across the country are protesting on the kind of protective gear that they are getting. What is fuelling these protests are rapidly emerging cases of doctors getting infected with the virus.Of the over100 patients in Mumbai, four are doctors who treated Covid-19 cases. In Delhi, a doctor of a mohalla clinic was found corona-positive. His wife and daughter have subsequently been infected as well. Doctors from Kerala as well as Lucknow have caught the virus infection too.The protests against lack of equipment have been simmering across the country. After Meerut reported its first Covid-19 case on March 27, nurses and paramedical staff of Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical College refused to treat patients in the absence of PPE kits. They were provided the kits a day later on March 28 when the city reported four Covid-19 cases in a single day.In UP’s Baghpat, there were similar protests by nurses and paramedics who alleged that instead of PPE kits, they had been given gear used in HIV protection which would not be as effective against Covid-19.That even premier hospitals still don’t have the protective equipment needed to fight the disease came to light recently when a letter from the chief medical superintendent (CMS) of King George Medical University, Lucknow, written to its V-C, went viral in which the CMS had proposed to deduct a day's salary of teachers, resident doctors and non-teaching staff to buy masks for health workers deputed for the treatment of suspected and confirmed Covid-19 cases. The proposal was later withdrawn.Terming the issue of safety of medical staff which is engaged in the fight against Covid-19 as one of paramount importance, the members of Progressive Medicos and Scientists Forum of India had a few days ago written to the Prime Minister to provide doctors with adequate protective gear like masks, gowns, head covers etc. A similar request was made by United Resident and Doctor’s Association of India which sought “urgent intervention” of the PM on the issue.The concern of doctors as they work every day in hospitals putting their own safety at risk is best exemplified by a doctor from Patna. Speaking to TOI, Dr Ravi Ranjan Kumar Raman, president of junior doctors’ association at Nalanda Medical College and Hospital in Patna, said, “My family, parents and sister cry every day I leave for work. They ask me not to go to the hospital but I can’t skip my responsibilities. Somewhere in my heart, I know that even if I die, it won’t affect the system. But my question is, do you send soldiers on the warfront without guns? Then why are you sending doctors to fight this war without proper kits?”

Title: Venturing out? 119 booked so far
Content:
Bhopal: City police on Sunday registered 10 cases against people violating lockdown order. On Saturday, 15 cases were registered against those violating the order. The accused were booked under section 188, 269 and 270 of IPC. Since March 22, after the lockdown order was issued by district collector, 119 cases have been registered against violators.

During the day on Sunday three cases were registered against people for roaming out of their house without any valid reason. Govindpura police booked two bus operators for allegedly leaving passengers at ISBT despite taking fare from them to drop them at Jabalpur and other districts. Police said that the bus operators boarded passengers from Ratlam for going to Jabalpur and other districts but left them at ISBT and fled. Police took details of buses from entry points and CCTV cameras on the way and registered cases against them. Two shopkeepers including a tea stall and a pan kiosk owner were booked for violating the order.

ASP Crime Branch Nishchal Jharia, who has been assigned to keep a check on police check points on city outskirts said that people, who work as labourers in Indore and other cities and are returning to their home towns by walking, have been constantly coming at these check points. They seem so depressed and tired that cops counsel them and provide them food and necessary things. They are being sent to their native place. He raised concern stating that now that the new order has been issued and district boundaries will be sealed, police and administration will have to find solution of this issue.

Title: Rise reported in alcohol withdrawal syndrome cases
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

KOCHI: With the lockdown proceeding with stringent restrictions , the number of alcohol withdrawal syndrome cases is on the rise in the state.

The Vimukthi cell under the excise department received 407 calls from all 14 districts at the tollfree helpline number 14405 over the last three days. Over 85% of these cases were of severe nature, including symptoms of violence and suicide tendencies. All these cases were referred to respective nearby government hospitals, where separate wings have been opened to treat patients with the withdrawal symptoms. The excise department and its Vimukthi cell are struggling to tackle the cases and are planning to extend the present 18-hour service to 24 hours with the help of more psychologists.

“The cases are increasing every day and the calls are made by the patients’ relatives. On Saturday, we got 201 calls and 194 were referred to hospitals. On Sunday, 201 cases were reported and a group of five Vimukthi counsellors are attending the calls and advising relatives of the patients. Several cases are being referred to respective nearby taluk hospitals or primary health centres. If transportation facilities are unavailable due to lockdown, people can contact their respective excise office. They will ensure the transportation,” said Vinu Vijayan, sociologist, excise department.

Officials said that most calls were of people with Delirium Tremens (DTs), which is a rapid onset of confusion usually caused by withdrawal from alcohol. When it occurs, physical effects may include shaking, shivering, irregular heart rate, and sweating. “People may also see or hear things that others don’t (hallucination). One call we received was of a patient hallucinating about liqour bottles hidden in his house and kept on searching for it throughout the night. It may finally lead to a very high body temperature or seizures. These people have high suicide tendencies. The only solution is immediate medical attention,” said Saranya S R, a Vimukthi counsellor.

Meanwhile, some excise officials raised concerns about the government’s plan to provide alcohol to patients with withdrawal symptoms based on the doctor’s prescription.

Title: T plans survey of migrant workers to extend help
Content: Hyderabad: Telangana chief secretary Somesh Kumar has directed the labour department to conduct a survey across the state for identifying migrant labours engaged in the unorganised sector and not registered with the labour department. Around 3.35 lakh migrants have been identified until now.The move comes in light of exodus attempt by many migrant workers after a 21-day nationwide lockdown was announced. “The state government issued directions to all the district collectorates to coordinate with labour department for conducting a survey to identify the number of migrants and their location of stay, if any, and their problems. The exercise started on Saturday,” senior officials in Labour department told TOI.The state labour department has received numerous complaints in the past few days, with a majority of them seeking police permissions at check posts, which will help people return to their native states. Interestingly, most of the complainants were from migrants of Odisha.“Odisha workers are generally known to be more aware of their rights when compared to workers from other states, working in Telangana. All the complaints which we got till now is that they want to return to their native places and they seek labour department’s help. We already informed that it is not possible,’’ sources said.The survey document prepared by the officials mentions that officials will be collecting information like problems (stranded/no work/no stay/no food/medical facility) to know why they wanted to return to their native place, requirements (food/dry ration/stay/ water/medical assistance), number of men, women and children in each family, their native state.The purpose of the survey is to identify the total number of migrants both in the organized and unorganized sectors.

Title: Pandemic hits Cantt board’s property tax collection hard
Content:
Secunderabad: The coronavirus outbreak and the 21-day lockdown has hit the property tax collection by Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB).The board had planned to generate around Rs 100 crore revenue from property tax, but has only managed to collect around Rs 50 crore through online payment.

The last date for payment of 2019-20 property tax, which is one of the major sources of revenue for the board, was initially March 31. At a recent board meeting, SCB chief executive officer SVR Chandra Sekhar said that the deadline will not be extended further and property owners will have to pay the tax online.

There are around 50,000 properties, including residential and commercial, in Cantonment areas.

Tax inspectors say that due to the fear of contracting te infection, property owners are not paying the tax at the board office. “Some people are not opening the door, saying that they would pay it online,” said a tax inspector.

Meanwhile, several property owners and ward members have urged the board to extend the deadline by atleast a month. However, SCB members said that only the CEO can take a call on the matter.

Title: Rajasthan promises food, shelter to migrant workers
Content:
Representative image

Following the Centre’s order to seal state borders to stop the movement of migrants , Rajasthan ’s ACS (home) Rajeeva Swarup sent out a video on Sunday in which he appealed to the migrant workers and those planning to travel to other states to stay where they are.

“I appeal to everyone to stay where you are and the state government will take care of you. I also want to say that all state borders will be sealed tonight so you will not be able to enter other states,” he said in the video. Swarup also said that all migrants will be in quarantine for two weeks. He said that no contractor can fire a labourer and would pay them in full. In case someone is abandoned or homeless, the state government will ensure that they don’t go hungry. In the video, Swarup appealed to the locals that they should also be vigilant if someone in their neighbourhood has come from outside the state so that they can be screened for the virus.

Title: Hyderabad doctors go for video call consultation, hospitals follow suit
Content: HYDERABAD: Dozens of doctors in the city have started attending to their patients through video calls and audio calls due to the ongoing Covid-19 crisis.A few doctors have also opened up their clinics to offer free consultations Many doctors also said that they are constantly in touch with the medical supply staff to find out where particular medicines can be bought, based on the proximity to the patient's location and are then relaying this information to patients. In addition to this, many hospitals for also extending tele-medicine services.In a majority of cases, these are free consultations extended to existing patients and the opinions as well as prescription of medicines is given via WhatsApp or text message. Few doctors are also providing paid consultations, for cases that need in-depth examination.“I am continuing consultations for my post-operation patients but also advising and prescribing medicines on WhatsApp to patients complaining of fever, abdominal pain, anal issues etc. If there is no improvement, I redirect them to hospitals and if it looks like a respiratory infection, I ask them to go to government notified hospitals,” said Dr Sanjeev Singh Yadav, general surgeon and secretary Indian Medical Association (IMA) Telangana.In special cases , where the prescribed drugs are not available over the counter, doctors are scanning and sending prescriptions.“I have 20-25 consultations per day, which are done either on video or audio calls. I mention on the prescriptions that this is a tele-consultation. The prescriptions are scanned and sent on Whatsapp. The only problem is that not all pharmacies have psychiatric medicines and it become difficult for patients to acess them,” said Dr Virinchi Sharma, consultant psychiatrist.He takes up around 10 paid consultations per day, and answers over 15-20 queries free of cost.

Title: South Central Railway: Full refund for railway tickets till April 14
Content:
Representative Image

HYDERABAD: Passengers who cancelled their tickets before the announcement of the cancellation of trains by Indian Railways between March 21 and April 14 will be given a full refund .

“No cancellation fee will be charged and the full amount will be refunded. This is applicable to both online tickets and the tickets bought over passenger reservation system(PRS) counters,” reads an official release from South Central Railway ( SCR ).

According to SCR officials, passengers can get a refund up to three months from the date of the journey for the PRS tickets purchased through counters. In the light of COVID-19, passenger train services in SCR zone including premium trains, express trains, passenger trains, suburban trains, are cancelled till April 14.

Title: Exodus, a 1,500 km trek from Mumbai to Aligarh via Rajasthan
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: From Mumbai to Aligarh via Vadodara, Ahmedabad, Jaipur and Mathura , a group of 22 ice-cream sellers has embarked on a journey of nearly 1,500km covering four states. On Sunday afternoon, they reached Jaipur’s Transport Nagar hungry and tired. After a short break, they were back on their feet. Home was still another 300km away.

Hundreds of migrant workers along with their families from Gujarat and Maharashtra have been tirelessly walking for the last couple of days to reach their villages in Mathura, Agra, Aligarh and other places in Uttar Pradesh .

While some managed to hitch a few rides here and there covering a few hundred kilometres, most of them have no clue if they would make it home in the next couple of days.

At Transport Nagar, hordes of people were seeking help from policemen to show them the directions which would take them home. Though Rajasthan government has arranged buses to drop them at the Uttar Pradesh border, the numbers of vehicles is hardly any match to the demand.

Most of these labourers have kids who are left with no option but to walk. Various NGOs have arranged food packets, but looking at the huge numbers, most have to keep walking hungry. A policeman deployed at Transport Nagar said more than 35,000 migrants crossed through the area on Saturday night.

Title: Covid-19 blanks out Telugu soaps, production halts
Content: Hyderabad: TV serial addicts in the Telugu states will soon miss their favourite shows as production of the new episodes came to a grinding halt from March 21.“Episodes are shot much in advance, so there are some more which will continue to be telecast but these will last probably for two or three days,” a television producer said. Meanwhile, Telugu TV channels are planning to telecast movies in the slots where otherwise serials would have been telecast.There are at least 70 fiction serials and another 20 non fiction serials that are not being telecast on various channels, according to Telugu Television Producers Council president A Prasada Rao. The serials are telecast for five hours during prime time which is 6 pm to 11 pm everyday in addition to at least three hours in the afternoon. There are nearly 7,000 people involved in Telugu TV serials production, including actors and technicians.“Once things settle down, the production will continue, if necessary at a faster pace,” said a producer K Ramesh Babu who is also the treasurer of the producers council. As of now, on a given day at least two episodes are shot for a serial.Some of the most popular TV serials which people have been addicted to include Karthika Deepam, Intinti Gruhalakshmi, Vadhinamma, Mounaragam, and Prema Enthamadhuram.Such is the popularity of TV serials in the Telugu states that their publicity has literally overtaken the publicity that is given for new film releases. Though pasting of posters on walls and public places is banned in Telangana , the publicity material is seen everywhere in Hyderabad. The paid-for publicity also happens in the form of bill boards and at bus stops.There, however, is a lot of criticism for TV serials as the episodes are said to be dragging and viewers being unhappy about it. In the space that will be vacated by TV serials, Telugu film audiences will be able to watch movies. In the Telugu states, remakes of serials from other languages like Tamil, Kannada and Bengali are common because of their storyline. However, there are no dubbed serials.

Title: Police seize vehicles of 150 motorists defying prohibitory orders
Content:
Nashik: City police took action against over 150 motorists , between Friday evening and Saturday morning, for venturing outside their homes without any valid reason during the lockdown and seized their vehicles.

A senior police officer said all the motorists have been booked under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code for disobedience to order duly promulgated by a public servant and their vehicles were taken to the police stations concerned.

Sajan Sonawane, senior PI of Bhadrakali police station, said, “The errant motorists will have to go to the local court and pay the fine following which they will be able to collect their vehicles.”

DCP Amol Tambe of Zone 1 said the action was initiated by police considering that people continued to neglect the continuous instructions that use of vehicles has been banned in the city and only those who have a medical emergency and those falling under the category of essential services are allowed to use their vehicles.

DCP Vijay Kharat of Zone II said, “In our zone we seized around 90 vehicles. The vehicles were seized from Ambad, Satpur, Indiranagar and Nashik Road areas. People are not heeding to the appeals made by police and the government. Hence, we have started seizing the vehicles.”

He added, “Once people realize that the police have started seizing vehicles, we hope that people will start observing the lockdown in the true sense.”

A constable said that police cannot be everywhere and people need to understand this. “A force of 3,000 police personnel is working in shifts to ensure the lockdown is a success. The decision has been taken in the interest of everyone, but some people do not understand the importance of it. If people continue to neglect the lockdown, the situation would become worse,” he said.

Meanwhile, on Saturday, police started making use of drones in Zone 1 and Zone II areas. On identifying the spots where people are gathering on the streets, the drones are flown to that spot for making announcements.

“The footage from the drone cameras will be used to take action against people under section 188 of the IPC,” he said.

The police plan to deploy six more drones for effective monitoring across the city.

Title: Have any ideas on tackling Covid? Just post it on this portal
Content:
Bhopal: The coronavirus pandemic is the only thing being discussed the world over for the past few weeks. Over 135 crore people in India, who are locked in their homes to maintain social distancing, are abuzz with ideas to control the deadly disease.

While not all ideas may be useful, all would not be useless either. A Gwalior-based techie has created a platform to give voice to the people of the country on the Corona issue. Kapil Gupta, a 2012 batch engineer, created republicindia.in wherein people can give their suggestions to fight corona that would directly reach to government of India and to all chief ministers of the country.

In the past 72 hours, at least 10,000 suggestions have been put forth on the platform from different parts of the country. Once a is posted on the portal, within seconds, it goes to the Union health ministry and to chief ministers of all states in the country.

The portal is trending on top on Google and whenever a person types to give suggestion to any government, it opens first, even above the government sites.

“The suggestion to use vacant rail coaches as isolation wards since there is a shortage of isolation wards in the country was also sent to the government from this platform. It was sent by a youth, Swapnil Dattatray kadu Swapnil from Songaon in Maharashtra, mentioning that since there are toilets, bed and electricity in train coaches and trains are not running in lockdown, doctors can easily use the coaches to attend to patients,” said Gupta.

The suggestion was sent on March 26 and was just one among over 10,000 suggestions sent in the past three days, but we do not claim that government accepted any of them, as the government did not write back to us acknowledging the suggestions, Gupta said. He added: “We do not accept any promotion or advertisement on the platform and the purpose is solely to give a platform to the masses to pour in their suggestion to the state governments as well as Union government.”

Title: Frustrated at not getting liquor, two more commit suicide in Kerala
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

THRISSUR/ALAPPUZHA: Apparently frustrated at not being able to get liquor due to the ongoing lockdown , two men ended their lives in the state on Sunday.

Suneesh (32) from Kodungaloor allegedly jumped into a river nearby, police said. “Suneesh was showing withdrawal symptoms. A complaint in this regard says that he left home late in the night and jumped into the river. His body was recovered from Irinjalakuda,” said police.

Meanwhile, Noufal (34), allegedly drank after-shave lotion after he struggled with withdrawal symptoms for two days, the police said. Noufal died in hospital where he was admitted to by relatives. “A statement given by his family said that he drank the after-shave lotion after he found it difficult to get liquor,” said Vallikunnam police.

Title: Online bail system launched, but prisoners remain in jail
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Glitches in the online bail application system have ensured that prisoners whose release was ordered by the judiciary to decongest jails during the lockdown continue to languish in captivity.

As soon as the lockdown was announced, the state judiciary permitted release on own bail of hundreds of accused in prison for petty offences.

However, people charged with offences carrying up to seven years of imprisonment could not be released. To help them, an online system was introduced through which accused eligible for bail could apply before the orders were communicated to their advocates through e-mail.

Two officers under the respective principal district sessions judge were deputed for each district. Advocates were instructed to file the bail application through the notified email addresses in the prescribed manner. A couple of phone numbers for each district were also notified for the lawyers to mention.

The problem was that the online system didn’t work in some cases and in others the deputed officers didn’t respond to mails or even phone calls. Advocate V Kannadasan said, “I mailed a bail application for a client accused of subjecting his wife to cruelty. But I didn’t receive any acknowledgement or response from the Tiruvallur sessions court. Then I tried to contact the mobile numbers provided. One was switched off while calls to the other went unanswered. I don’t know who else to contact since the courts are also in lockdown,” he added.

“When bail is a right for every accused person, denying such right would amount to a double jeopardy for people who are already in jail. While the main aim of such an arrangement is to decongest jails, such glitches would not serve the purpose exposing the prisoners to the outbreak. The issue becomes more serious considering the sanitation conditions in the prisons,” Kannadasan said.

Adding that the courts promised that such applications would be processed in 24 hours, Kannadasan suggested that the process be processed through the state legal services authority for efficient delivery.

Advocate Duraikannan, who practises in Chenna,i said he had applied bail for an accused arrested in a TNPSC exam scam. “My application mail was responded to immediately. But I don’t know what happened after that. I don’t know the status of my application.”

Title: Hyderabad Coronavirus News: Young sarpanch shows way in fighting virus
Content:
A 23-year-old young woman sarpanch of Madanapuram village in Nalgonda district has been taking rounds of her v... Read More

HYDERABAD: A 23-year-old young woman sarpanch of Madanapuram village in Nalgonda district has been taking rounds of her village to ensure that people stay home during the 21-day lockdown.

During the first few days of the lockdown, Akhila Yadav , a BSc graduate and sarpanch of the village stood outside her village holding a stick to stop people from entering it without a valid reason. “Earlier, people were not taking the lockdown seriously, I saw people from other villages travelling here for no valid reason. So I sat at the entrance of the village and put up barricades. I would ask them the reason for roaming outside and entering the village if they have a genuine reason, they were allowed to enter. Or else I would ask them to go back,” said Akhila.

She would stand at the entrance from morning till afternoon. After a break, she would again stand there, till the curfew hour. After the restrictions on people’s movement were tightened, she removed the barricades, but the sarpanch has been regularly taking rounds of the village to ensure people stay home during the lockdown period.

“This is the time we have to take precautions to save ourselves and loved ones from the pandemic. I know I can’t protect everyone, but this the least I can do for the safety of my village. If one person gets the infection, the whole village can be affected,” she said, adding, “If I find a new vehicle or new faces in the village I enquire about the reason for their visit, especially if someone comes from the city.”

She has also been asking villagers to take an alternative road while venturing out to buy essentials. The young sarpanch has also been going door-to-door to educate villagers on ways to protect themselves and symptoms of Covid-19. “It is important they know about the symptoms. There are around 1,600 people in the village, and we have distributed around 2,000 masks here. But there is a shortage of hand sanitisers,” she said.

The sarpanch worked for 10 months in Hyderabad in 2018, before returning to her village and getting elected as sarpanch.

Title: Youths from northeast allege discrimination in Mysuru supermarket
Content:
Representative image

MYSURU: Two youths from a northeastern state on Sunday alleged that they faced racial discrimination when they visited a More supermarket outlet in Chamundipuram to purchase grocery .

The incident took place on Saturday evening. Based on their social media posts and CCTV footage, the jurisdictional Krishnaraja police on Sunday registered a case against the three staff of the mall under Section 153 (1)( b)188,341 of the IPC.

However, the staff of the mall denied allegations and informed police that it was the public who asked the two youths not to allow the duo into the store as they looked like foreigners.

The incident came to light when one of the victims posted about the incident on his social media page. In his post, the youth , who is studying in a college in Mysuru informed that the incident happened when he went to the supermarket in Chamundipuram with his friend on Saturday evening for buying grocery. According to the post, the duo stood in the queue for 25 minutes maintaining social distance according to the norm. But when it was their turn to enter the market, they were stopped by the staff posted at the entrance. “Though we requested them to allow us as we didn’t have any symptoms of flu, they didn’t oblige. When we asked the reason, they said: ‘because you are not from India.”

Though the two youths were offended, they showed them their Aadhaar cards to prove their nationality. They told the people that they were from northeast India, studying in a college in the city. But nobody was willing to listen to them. The students said they argued for 10 minutes and went back without buying goods. The youth wrote in his post that it saddened them that they had to prove that they are Indians.

The student uploaded the video of the incident and accused the staff of racism. As the video went viral, city police acted swiftly. Police commissioner Dr Chandragupta informed that after a video showing discrimination against Nagaland students was noticed, an FIR was lodged in Krishnaraja police station and the manager and staff of the supermarket outlet have been questioned. “We urge people and shop owners and staff to desist from indulging in such act and behave responsibly in this time of crisis,” he stated.

Supermarket issues clarification

As the video went viral, strong reactions poured in against the staff of More supermarket, where the incident took place. The store said it will conduct an investigation into the incident. In a tweet, the authorities of More stated: More Retail does not accept discrimination of any kind in its stores. Our stores are open to all citizens of the country. A probe will be conducted into this incident. We adhere to all the norms of the state and central authorities and also request all the customers to follow the same.

Union sports minister Kiren Rijiju also reacted to the incident. In a tweet, he stated that this is unacceptable. Union home ministry has already issued a clear advisory to all the states and union territories to prevent any discrimination against the people of northeast. Please inform local police wherever this incident has occurred as soon as possible, he tweeted.

Mysuru deputy commissioner Abhiram G Sankar said the case has been taken up seriously. He warned of action against those who indulge in such acts.

Title: GHMC takes up disinfection drive, screening at Khairatabad
Content:
Hyderabad: As many as 350 families underwent screening for fever at the CIB Quarters in Khairatabad and were advised to home quarantine themselves for 14 days. The screening was done following the death of a Covid-19 patient, who was a resident of the area.

Disinfectants were also sprayed in and around the CIB quarters on Sunday and sanitisation activity was taken up in Indira Nagar, located near the quarters.

“Eight vehicles have been pressed into service to spray disinfectants in the locality. Sodium Hypochlorite was sprayed on pavement, railings, gates and all other places that people tend to access,” said Hyderabad mayor Bonthu Rammohan, who monitored the activity.

“Even commercial establishments such as shops and places of worship in that area were sanitised,” said an Enforcement Vigilance and Disaster Management official. GHMC officials said that residents in the locality were also briefed on preventive measures to keep themselves safe.

“The patient’s family was quarantined soon after he was tested positive. His neighbours have been asked to follow home quarantine guidelines and call GHMC officials for assistance,” said an official. “Unlike foreign returnees, we cannot completely restrict the movement of all people in that locality,” he added.

A source in GHMC said that the patient who passed away did not move around much as he was 74 years old. The area was also inspected by Khairtabad MLA Danam Nagender, GHMC zonal commissioner of Khairathabad, P Pravinya and the police .

Title: Man cycles to shrines despite lockdown
Content:
City-based Ram Chandran, who has been cycling to religious shrines across India and Nepal, is continuing his travels despite the lockdown in the country.

He was cycling on National Highway 44 in Ambala on Friday when volunteers helping migrant workers stopped and offered him food and gave him hand sanitizers and masks, mistaking him for a migrant returning home.

Ram Chandran, however, told the group of volunteers that he was on a quest to visit 250 temples in India and had taken leave for two-and-a-half months for his trip. “I started my journey from Jagannath Temple in Puri and from there I went to Kali Temple in Kolkata, then to Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu, Nepal. From there, I went to Haridwar and then to Jawalaji in Himachal Pradesh. Then I went to Vaishno Devi and Golden Temple,” said the man who has spent a month and 27 days cycling alone.

“ I am travelling on the belief of Sri Ram and God and so far, in this journey, my bicycle has not got punctured even once. due to curfew, I have been stopped at many places,” Chandran said and added that he was cycling to Hyderabad now.

Title: Kerala minister seeks report on suicides after lockdown of liquor vends
Content:
THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With more suicides being reported after the lockdown of liquor outlets , excise minister T P Ramakrishnan asks excise commissioner to submit a report on how to overcome the present crisis faced by alcoholics in the state. Till date, five deaths have been reported in the state because of the non-availability of alcohol.

Ramakrishnan is learnt to have asked the excise commissioner to submit the report by Tuesday. He will discuss the issue with chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Tuesday itself to find a solution. As per government statistics, there are six lakh people in the state who consume alcohol regularly, and among them at least 15,000 people are considered alcoholics.

The sudden closure of liquor outlets have created a major crisis for these people and has resulted in the suicide of some. Hence, the government has decided to explore alternative ways to avoid such suicides.

The government is considering an option of providing alcohol to those showing withdrawal symptoms and facing severe crisis.

tnn

Title: SCB ward members spread awareness on precautionary measures to fight coronavirus
Content: Secunderabad: Ministers, MLAs, civic body corporators and Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) ward members are spreading awareness on combating the spread of coronavirus among residents of cantonment areas.On Saturday, ward member J Maheshwar Reddy visited residential areas in Bapuji Nagar, Soujanya Colony, Kamsali Bazar and the weekly vegetable market at Peddathokatta and distributed masks to the vendors. Another ward member S Keshava Reddy went on rounds in his ward in an autorickshaw making public announcements on the precautionary measures to be taken in order to fight the spread of the virus.Playing a key role in the effort, a ward member, J Maheswar Reddy, even served food to police personnel with the help of residents, besides serving free meals to the homeless and orphans.Meanwhile, the SCB’s health and sanitation wing is making arrangements to mark blocks with bleaching powder in front of all grocery shops and milk booths to help customers follow social distancing.The sanitisation staff is also spraying disinfectants at bus stops in Gunrock Enclave, Sitaramnagar and various other cantonment areas, sanitising buildings, residential areas, school premises, libraries, parks and markets. “Action plans have been prepared as per the directions of Director General Defence Estates (DGDE). Measures have also been taken to ensure uninterrupted water supply as well as streetlights,” according to a senior SCB official.

Title: To keep food supply on, farmers seek bailout in Telangana
Content: HYDERABAD: Farmers are facing hardships due to 21-day nationwide lockdown, said Consortium of Indian Farmers Association (CIFA) on Saturday, in a letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief ministers of all states.CIFA demanded that government issue a moratorium on loan repayments and interest waiver on crop loans. Farmers are facing problems due to closure of shops, non-availability of pesticides and fertilisers and labour shortage due to barricading of villages.CIFA general secretary Bojja Dasaradharami Reddy told TOI, “During the lockdown, it is extremely important to ensure that food supplies are maintained, and the population does not become vulnerable to the risk of secondary infections due to malnutrition on account of short supply of food.”“We suggest an immediate removal of all village barricades. Most farms require farm labour from neighbouring villages and the barricades prevent the free movement of labour which is effecting the farm operations, such as picking of chillies, vegetables, horticulture crops and other crops which are currently ready for harvest,” Reddy said.If prompt action is not taken to address this issue, it is likely that there will be a huge loss of crops on account of the produce not being harvested. The barricades have hindered access to towns in case of health emergencies. The barricades have been installed by local communities either on their own or on instructions of local panchayat authorities or local law enforcement personnel,” Reddy added.CIFA demand a message be sent that barricading of villages is not permitted unless as a containment strategy on the instructions of the local health authorities in case of a spike in Covid-19 cases.“The instructions currently issued, while permitting farm operations, are silent with regards to the issue of supply of pesticides and fertilisers to farms. The fertiliser and pesticide shops are being closed by the local law enforcement only to be opened as soon as the police leave. It is necessary to provide clear instruction to the law enforcement authorities so that they do not close down the fertiliser and pesticide shops,” said Dasaradharami Reddy.CIFA suggested that in order to limit the physical movement of people, the government should make arrangements to deliver the stock from the shop to the farmers on a fixed fee basis based on the delivery distance so as to prevent large scale movement of farmers to the nearby towns. “There is a difficulty in marketing perishable goods such as vegetables due to non-availability of transport. While some states such as Andhra Pradesh and Telangana have already announced that the produce will be purchased from the villages directly, a comprehensive policy is required to be framed and a system put in place so that the crops do not get damaged waiting for the arrival of the government agencies to procure perishable agri produce and other agri produce at fair prices. The policy may also provide for a redressal mechanism to promptly address any issues which may be faced by the farmers in selling their produce,” he added.CIFA alleged that farmers are facing a lot of harassment from the local law enforcement personal while transporting labour from the neighbouring villages.“In recent times, there has been a massive increase in the number of auto rickshaws in rural areas, as they provide last mile connectivity in the most interior villages apart from forming the backbone of labour transport. However, since the lockdown, law enforcement have not been permitting the autos to ply between villages and rightly so, as it is difficult to maintain social distancing norms in an auto . However, there is every need to address the issue of labour shortage and it is suggested that the road transport authorities may operate special buses in rural areas in order to facilitate safe movement of labour to farms,” he said.In light of the Covid-19 pandemic, it is imperative that the government declare a moratorium on the loans disbursed to the farm sector for one crop season similar to the moratorium declared on working capital loans taken by companies, Reddy said.“It is further requested that the government provide interest free loans for the next crop season in order to facilitate easy access to capital and prevent loan sharks from taking undue advantage of the farmers. Apart from the above, it is requested that the government provide an insurance cover of Rs 50 lakh to each farmer and farm labourer currently risking their life in order to feed the country and treat them on par with our health care professionals,” Reddy concluded.

Title: Stay put, we’ll help you, Madhya Pradesh CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan reaches out to migrant workers
Content: BHOPAL: Desperate to stall reverse migration, Madhya Pradesh chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan on Sunday made an emotional appeal to labourers to stay put wherever they are and assured that they will get ration and everything else they need.Chouhan also said that all PDS ration will now be distributed without ration cards in the state. “Those from MP, who are living outside for work, need not leave in this hour of crisis . I have discussed with the chief ministers of six states to provide all possible help to you and make special arrangement for relief to the labour class,” Chouhan said during a Facebook live session with the public.Sources said that Chouhan has directed officials to collect details of workers stranded outside the state during the lockdown and deliver assistance. “Workers who have been staying at home during the lockdown will get their wages through their employers or else the government will take strict action against them. Those who are staying in rented house and aren’t able to pay rent need not pay dues during the lockdown period. The government will take action against house owners if workers are pressurised to vacate the house or pay rent,” the CM said.“There is no need to produce ration card at the PDS shop to get essential commodities. This is a crisis and everyone who is in peril or suffering due to lockdown will get immediate help from the government,” said Chouhan.The CM lauded all relief workers and medical staff for their service to society during the coronavirus outbreak. “I am thankful to all security and police forces, medical staff, media and municipal employees who are dedicating their life to fighting the crisis as corona warriors. I appeal to the public to stay at home and maintain social distance to fight the outbreak. We will also ensure proper supply of food material, medicines, vegetables and other essential goods to needy people for the entire lockdown period,” he said.

Title: Dist has 2nd highest number of people under home isolation
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The district now has the second highest number of persons under home isolation next to Palakkad with nearly 12,000 persons being brought under surveillance in the past four days alone. The capital had the highest number under home isolation till Saturday with 18,094 persons and by Sunday the number further rose slightly to 18,145. The sharp rise in number of persons who had to be brought under surveillance was mainly owing to reconsolidation of passenger data.Two days ago, cabinet secretary Rajiv Gauba had asked states to strengthen surveillance of international air travellers who entered the country between January 18 and March 23 since there was a gap between those being monitored for Covid 19 and 15 lakh arrivals during this period in the country. The cabinet secretary had pointed out that such a gap could threaten the efforts at containment.The district administration and health team received information from airport authority and bureau of immigration on passengers with passport address based in Thiruvananthapuram. The verification process revealed that many persons had landed in Kochi, Mangalapuram and Trichi and travelled by other means to Thiruvananthapuram. The details of these persons were missing in the surveillance list of district administration. Seat numbers were also checked to further confirm and now over 10,000 new persons were included in the surveillance list.Even on March 25, less than 7,000 persons were under home isolation in the district. Between March 26 and 28, the number rose from 7,968 to cross 18,000. This is expected to put additional pressure on ward-level surveillance teams. At present, 8,230 squads are being deployed in the district for home based surveillance and 15,081 volunteers have been directed to regularly check on people under home isolation. As on Saturday, 9,590 houses were visited by the ward-level teams, said minister for tourism and devaswom Kadakampally Surendran.With numbers crossing 18,000, the district administration is using a combination of severe penalty measures, manpower and technology to keep a daily tab on persons under home quarantine. The district collector had voiced his concerns over home isolation being compromised, even when the number was just 284. The administration initially stuck with an advisory and hoped people would obey that.The district administration was later forced to go for the harsh step; invoking section 51(b) of the Disaster Management Act which says that if anyone refuses to comply with the direction given by or on behalf of centre or state government or district authority or state/national executive committee, they shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year or with fine or with both. Further if such refusal to comply with directions results in loss of lives or imminent danger, the imprisonment will extend for a period of two years.Recently, stickers were pasted on houses where people are under quarantine mainly to avoid visits by relatives and friends. Although some households were not enthused about the move, the administration has gone ahead with the plan.

Title: YouTube becomes Lucknow University’s new classroom
Content:
YouTube channels launched by all 43 departments of the Lucknow University are turning out to be a boon for stu... Read More

LUCKNOW: YouTube channels launched by all 43 departments of the Lucknow University are turning out to be a boon for students during lockdown due to coronavirus outbreak.

At least 22 departments are getting good response from students. LU authorities have also directed departments to create WhatsApp groups where students may post their queries and get replies from faculty members.

A video on ‘rock folds’ uploaded by Prof KK Agarwal of geology department has received highest 570 hits with students requesting him to upload more lectures . Ayush Singh, a student of BSc, said: “ Prof Agarwal’s video has helped us get an experience of a field visit.”

Another video on optics, put up by a faculty member at physics department Navina Wadwani, has received 235 hits in just two days. “I felt as if I was in the class itself while watching the lecture,” said Ankita, a student.

Videos uploaded by departments like education, journalism & mass communication, linguistics and political science have got around 100 views.

A video uploaded by Shravan Kumar of education department on ‘how to use blackboard’ was liked by students for the use of animation, poems and caricatures.

Avantika, a student of BA, said, “The best thing about online lectures is that I can pause and again listen to it in case I am not clear.”

LU vice-chancellor Prof Alok Kumar Rai said, “Faculty members have uploaded e-study material on the university’s website, too.”

Title: City police feed the hungry
Content:
Coimbatore: Police commissioner Sumit Sharan has formed five dedicated teams to supply food to the migrant labourers stranded in the city.

“The teams collect food from the city corporation and the district administration. We supplied 2,000 breakfast and meal packets on Sunday,” Sharan said.

After an Uttar Pradesh-based social media user tweeted about the plight of three truck drivers from UP, who were stranded in Coimbatore city, a team rushed to their help with food packets. “People can contact the city police through our Twitter handle for assistance. Cops are always ready to help round-the-clock,” said Sharan.

A police team led by Selvapuram inspector T Sivakumar, who found some destitute people living on the streets, gave them a haircut before giving them food.

Deputy inspector general of police G Karthikeyan inspected the security arrangements at the Kaniyur check post on the Coimbatore-Tirupur border on Sunday.

“Goods carriers transporting essential commodities and those who have obtained permission letters from the district administration are allowed to cross the borders. We have been booking people who venture out deliberately and seizing their vehicles,” Karthikeyan, who was accompanied by superintendent of police Sujit Kumar and Tirupur district superintendent of police Disha Mittal, said.TNN

Deputy inspector general of police G Karthikeyan inspected the security arrangements at the Kaniyur check post on the Coimbatore-Tirupur border on Sunday.

“Goods carriers transporting essential commodities and those who have obtained permission letters from the district administration are allowed to cross the borders. We have been booking people who venture out deliberately and seizing their vehicles,” Karthikeyan, who was accompanied by superintendent of police Sujit Kumar and Tirupur district superintendent of police Disha Mittal, said.TNN

Title: ‘Lockdown without planning is cruelty’
Content:
Hyderabad: AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi has branded the 21-day nationwide lockdown as cruelty.

“State governments of UP, WB & Bihar are doing nothing to aid these stranded migrants. You cannot “play it by the ear” with people’s lives. A lockdown without thinking about the welfare of India’s vast majority is plain cruelty,” tweeted Owaisi. Reacting to migration of workers from Delhi, he questioned if Telanagana chief minister K Chandrashekar Rao should help the migrant workers with transport facilities. He also alleged that state governments of Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Bihar not providing aid to stranded migrants. TNN

Title: Kabasura kudineer given to South veli street residents
Content:
Madurai: A city-based friends group has been distributing kabasura kudineer to residents in and around South Veli Street for the past eight days. The decoction helps humans build immunity to fight various health problems and it is much in demand since the Covid-19 outbreak.

Around 15 volunteers of Dr APJ Nanbargal Anbukuzhu have been distributing the decoction by visiting houses covering around 500 people a day. So far, they have reached out to at least 4,000 people in various streets such as Sappani Kovil Street, Pookara Street, Meenakshi Theatre Lane, Kaja Street and Ondimuthu Maestry Street.

Secretary of the group C Vinothkumar said that they have been using 80 litres of water a day and 25 packets of kabasura kudineer powder, each weighing 250g. They have been purchasing it from a wholesale dealer in the city. People demand it to be served every alternative day, but they make sure that at least four days of gap between servings, since they have large area to cover.

People are well aware of the siddha-based medicine, however, many did not know where to procure it and how to prepare decoction. Preparation procedure is being explained to those who are require it, Vinoth Kumar said.

Title: Residents start to throw social distancing norms to the wind
Content:
Coimbatore: Days after chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami projected them as exemplary figures on Twitter for maintaining social distancing at markets, the city residents on Sunday made it look like they were completely ignorant of the big fight to contain Covid-19 as they crowded the markets like any other normal day to stock up vegetables, meat and other essentials.

One doesn’t know for sure whether the government’s recent move of reopening major markets across the state and relaxing rules to ensure adequate supply of essentials has sent the wrong message to the residents.

In the city, major markets at RS Puram and Singanallur functioned as usual on Sunday. While police and city corporation officials had jointly marked slots for customers at a gap of every 1m in front of each shop to ensure social distancing, they were completely ignored by the residents in their hurry to buy vegetables.

The picture wasn’t any different at Ukkadam fish market, farmers’ market at Somanur, and meat shops across the district, where the public moved in close contact with each other.

While sellers, especially at individual shops, managed to ensure social distancing by their customers, doing so was a difficult task for their counterparts at markets.

A shopkeeper said, “People have been purchasing vegetables out of panic and in their struggle to stock up items before they were sold out, they violated the social distancing norms. They were getting at us whenever we asked them not to crowd the shop.”

Disappointed at the city residents’ behaviour, a government official said the district administration has been creating awareness on the measures to prevent Covid-19 infection and the importance on maintaining social distancing. “They had also drawn slots in front of shops to ensure minimum distance between the customers. What more should the district administration do to make the public abide by the rules,” the official wondered.

On Saturday too, a large crowd had gathered on RG Street to buy essentials. However, the city police had then managed to control them by drawing up slots in front of shops. On Sunday, they could do little to manage the crowd.

Despite several attempts, police department officials were not available for a comment.

Title: KWA sets up drinking water kiosks for cops
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala Water Authority has installed drinking water kiosks for police at five locations in the city. KWA chief engineer G Sreekumar said drinking water kiosks have been set up so that police personnel could directly consume from it.Currently, 20-litre cans have been installed at Sastamangalam, Vellayambalam, Statue, Palayam and PMG by the south division of KWA and has stuck their contact numbers on it. “In case the water gets over, police can contact us and we will refill it,” said a KWA official. The south division has so far purchased 10 cans and is planning to procure more.“There was a suggestion from the chief minister to provide drinking water to police as there is total shutdown. So we arranged the kiosks,” said an official adding that more could be installed if there is such demand from the police department.Due to the shortage of hand sanitizers, the KWA is also planning to produce it for its own staff, who are working even at the time of lockdown. “We have got permission from the excise department, which will handover around 50 litres of spirit for the purpose. We hope that around 60 litres of sanitizers could be made and distributed among our staff. The KWA staff has increased their duty time from usual 8 hours to 24 hours to keep other staff on reserve,” a KWA official said.Though KWA has been exempted from lockdown, several contract staff of KWA face objection from police when they commute. “The contract staff, being temporary employees, do not have KWA’s ID cards. We had met various officials and informed the issue. However, the employees are still getting blocked. I had to make over 20 calls to various police officials to bring a contract staff from Pravachambalam to the city,” said a KWA staff.Though lockdown has put everyone is a crisis situation, it has come as a blessing in disguise for KWA as there is more availability of water due to closure of government offices, hotels and other shops. “We are getting lesser calls regarding water supply disruption. Water shortage exists in certain areas. However, overall situation has improved,” KWA officials said.

Title: Lucknow: Fight against virus still on, mosquitoes begin to sting too
Content: LUCKNOW: Mosquito menace in the state’s capital is on the rise. The number of complaints related to fogging registered at Lucknow Municipal Corporation helpline have spiked by over 100% in eight days in comparison to earlier this month.The civic body received around 131 complaints since March 18 till Friday for conducting fogging as compared to 54 complaints between March 1 and March 17.Areas from where most complaints were received are Vikasnagar (34) , Niralangar (17), Aliganj (21), Lalbagh (19), Kaiserbagh (8) Yahiyaganj (11) and Rakabganj (21).“Drains in my locality are choked with garbage serving as breeding grounds. We had complained to LMC on Thursday, but no help has come even after 24 hours, “ said Ishita Mukherjee, a resident of Aliganj Sector-K.“We can protect ourselves from coronavirus by locking ourselves in our homes but rising mosquitoe menace is increasing risk of vector-borne diseases, “ said Deepak Mishra in Rakabganj.Aniket Asthana, a resident of Jankipuram Sector-H, said, “If windows are left open, mosquitoes storm into the house, making it difficult to sit at one place. This year, they seem to have become resistant to repellents as nothing is working from coils to vapourisers. Only traditional mosquito nets are doing the job.”LMC officials claim the civic body has already conducted drives to spray anti-larva in all eight zones of the city in January and February. LMC environment engineer Pankaj Bhusan said, “We have 21 fogging machine mounted trucks and 60 cycles. All of them are fogging daily in various areas of all 100 wards.”

Title: Man ends life in Hassan
Content: HASSAN: A 58-year-old man committed suicide in Channarayapatna taluk in Hassan district on Sunday morning. The victim had reportedly returned Hassan from Mumbai to celebrate Ugadi with his parents. He was examined for Covid-19 infection, and tested negative for the same. However, he was asked to stay quarantined at home for two weeks. The victim is survived by his wife and two children, all of whom are in Mumbai.He had arrived by himself to his native village in Channarayapatna, travelling from Mumbai by road. On Sunday morning, he was found hanging at the back of his parents’ home.Hassan district health officer Dr Sathish said that, on learning about the victim having come to the village from Mumbai, officers in the department had subjected him to a medical test. “The result of the test was returned as negative, and he was directed to stay in quarantine for a fortnight. But he was suffering from many other ailments, and we suspect this might have driven him to take the extreme step,” Dr Sathish said.

Title: Liquor ‘prescription’ lands doctor in dock
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

THRISSUR: An ayurveda doctor ’s liquor ‘prescription’ for a patient has gone viral in the backdrop of the reported move of the state government to provide liquor to people based on the prescriptions of doctors. However, within hours, the doctor clarified that he had sent a picture of the ‘prescription’ on a lighter vein to a couple of friends and did not expect it to reach the public domain.

Meanwhile, the Kerala Prohibition Council had filed a police complaint against the doctor.

Dr M D Renjit, who runs the Anjaly Ayurvedic Wellness Centre at North Paravur, had prescribed his ‘patient’ Purushothaman (48) ‘M C VSOP Brandy’ to be taken in 60ml thrice in the evening with roasted peanut.

Dr Renjit now says that he had sent the ‘jocular prescription’ in an old letter-pad to three or four friends on WhatsApp and added that the ‘patient’ was fictitious. He added that one of his friends might have forwarded the ‘prescription’ to others, thus making it viral. “I sincerely apologize for the mistake I had committed,” he said.

Renjit said he has already written to the bodies like Ayurveda Medical Association of India (AMAI), clarifying his stance.

He said that he was also planning to approach the police against those who had shared his ‘private message’ without his permission.

Title: Hyderabad techie develops app to help achieve social distancing during grocery runs
Content: HYDERABAD: With Union and state governments stressing on the need for social distancing to tackle the coronavirus pandemic, a city-based techie has now developed an app to enable social distancing.The web-based application developed by Vijayanand Reddy, will help citizens practise social distancing at grocery stores, vegetable markets and super bazaars. Using the app, people can book a slot at particular stores in the city this will help prevent overcrowding thereby helping people maintain the required distance from each other while making purchases.The 38-year-old techie who owns a fin-tech startup had checked the feasibility of the app by implementing it at his apartment complex in Kukatpally. “ We have about 2,500 flats and 8,000 people residing in our apartment complex. We also have an in- house medical shop and a super bazaar. Residents of the apartment have already stated booking slots for the super bazaar and there has been a substantial reduction in the length of queues,” Reddy said.The system works in such a way that super bazars or shops will have to integrate with the app to enable booking of slots. Once users book a slot, they will receive an SMS with an allotted timing. There are two types of type slots available - a five-minute express time slot and a 15-minute time slot. The five-minute is meant to buy basic provisions such as milk, eggs and bread. Users can book the 15- minutes to pick up all other grocery items. The SMS will cost the users 15 paisa per message.“ At our apartment complex, we also have a security guard stationed at the super bazaar so that people maintain social distance while shopping, during their designated time slots, ” Reddy added. Currently, the app is being provided for free to those interested in testing it. “ An apartment in Bengaluru has come forward to test this model. We will also be providing a demonstration of the application to other super bazars. “The app will avoid crowding of grocery stores and reduce the chance of contracting the virus while waiting in queues,” said KV Chandra, a resident of Kukatpally.

Title: Selfie contest to rev up lockdown days
Content:
Coimbatore: The city corporation has announced a selfie contest for the residents to encourage them to stay at home during the lockdown.

The city corporation, through its Twitter and Instagram handles, has asked the public to post their selfie that was taken while doing some fun activities at home and challenge five others, by tagging them.

A civic body source said, “The purpose of the contest is to imbibe the thought of social distancing in the minds of people and encourage them to continue to stay at home. As most of the residents are used to going out on regular basis, it will be very hard for them to break their daily schedule. So, we have taken this initiative to keep them occupied.”

Pointing out that their main focus was now on disinfecting public places, the source said they were also concerned about the people who were spending their time alone at home.

While the initiative hasn’t found much takers, the source said they have been thinking of ways to make it popular among the residents.

Title: Want food for us first before we distribute it to others: Anganwadi workers to Uttarakhand government
Content:
DEHRADUN: The frontline workers of women and child development (WCD) department of Uttarakhand have expressed inability to distribute ration among the elderly, children or disabled people during the ongoing lockdown.

They claimed that they haven’t been paid for four months but are still being made to do extra work.

“State WCD minister Rekha Arya has asked us to distribute ration amid the novel-coronavirus threat. The state government needs us most right now to ensure that ration reaches the needy at the earliest but they are not giving us our dues. Forget appreciation, we haven’t even received our monthly honorarium of Rs 7,500 for the past few months,” said an anganwadi worker.

Gangotri Bhandari from Pabo block of Pauri Garhwal has in fact put up a video message urging the CM to first resolve the issues of anganwadi workers before forcing them to go on the field during this time.

In the video, Bhandarisays, “I lost my husband in December 2019. I have a daughter and we have no money to even buy food as we haven’t got honorarium after November. I would like to ask the CM how is it possible for me to leave my daughter alone at home at this time. What if I contract the virus? Who will take care of my daughter? We need food for ourselves first before we distribute it to others.”

Echoing similar sentiments, Soni from Ghansali area of Tehri Garhwal expressed concerns regarding honorarium payment and safety kit for the workers during ration distribution.

Soni, who is working as an anganwadi worker since 2011, said, “I have three young daughters to feed and I am the only earning member in my house. We haven’t received honorarium for the past four months. I want money to feed my family first, only then we will be able to do our duty with diligence."

She added, “There is almost negligible ration available at the anganwadi centres for distributing to all the beneficiaries. This also needs to be made available by the government.”

Title: No stigma attached to Covid-19: T patient to PM
Content: Hyderabad: In his latest episode of ‘ Mann Ki Baat ’ on Sunday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi spoke to two Covid-19 survivors, including Ram Gampa Teja, an IT professional from Hyderabad, who told the PM that quarantine was not a punishment and there was no stigma attached to the disease.Teja told PM Modi he was scared after he tested positive for coronavirus but felt reassured because of the doctors and hospital staff.“I work in the IT sector and had gone to Dubai for an official meeting. I got fever as soon as I returned and after five to six days the doctors conducted a test and I was found positive,” Teja said, while sharing his experience during the radio telecast.“Although I was scared in the beginning, the doctors and nurses at Gandhi Hospital took good care of me and gave me the strength and assurance to overcome the situation,” said Teja, whose parents living in Mahendra hills faced social boycott for days.When PM asked Teja about the response from his family, he said that he was relieved after they tested negative. “I was really worried for them but I heaved a sigh of relief after it was found that no other family member has got infected,” he said.Teja further stressed the fact that quarantine is not a punishment. “Being in quarantine is for our own good. Quarantine is not a prison. People should know that there is no stigma attached to it,” he added.The PM also requested Teja to share his experience on social media. “ It will help remove fear from people’s minds and make them aware of the necessary precautions to protect themselves,” he said.Modi also spoke with Ashok Kapoor, a resident of Agra, who along with his five family members, recovered from Covid-19.

Title: They are forced to leave their yield to rot
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: It is an irony; on one side authorities scramble to get supplies to keep community kitchens running while the farmers at Vellayani who have painstakingly grown red amaranthus for the past few weeks now cut the plants and dump it to rot in plantain fields. The 21-day lockdown has left the toil of these farmers in vain as they are not finding any takers for their produce.Only two to three loads are getting transported now instead of 15 loads that used to be transported earlier. Their regular trade market extends from Balaramapuram to Karunagappally. Also demand from the Chalai market is also less owing to lockdown. Due to strict traffic regulations by police, trucks aren’t coming to pick the amaranthus.Around Rs 45,000 is invested by the farmers to cultivate in an acre of land .Usually they get Rs 70,000 to Rs 90,000 as returns. Only 25 days are needed for amaranthus to grow up. Because of this short duration, more farmers take up amaranthus farming. The same is the situation of farmers at Punchakkari, Pandaarakkari, Vavvaamoola and Kalliyoor, who are cultivating other vegetables.The plantain species namely Chingan and Padathi, which were cultivated during festival season face low demand. Due to the cancelled festivals, they get only Rs 25 instead of Rs 75 per kilogram.Manikandan, a farmer, said that they cultivated amaranthus with a lot of hope, but due to the lock down announcement, their plans were rattled. So many amaranthus plants are left to rot due to the absence of transportation and customers. But we are ready to obey the instructions of government even in the time of loss. And we are hoping for some help from authorities regarding this.Pick up van driver Binu said that lockdown and transporting restrictions by police is creating difficulty to take vegetable loads. Getting transportation pass from police station on a daily basis is a very difficult process.The local government bodies entrusted with community kitchen management have been finding it difficult to source materials owing to lockdown, which has hindered the movement of trucks from neighbouring states.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Doctor, 10-month-old son, mother, maid test positive for coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 29-year-old doctor, who had treated two Covid-19 patients from Thailand at the Perundurai Government Hospital in Erode, tested positive for the disease here on Sunday.

The doctor has infected her 10-month-old son, 58-year-old mother and a 51-year-old maid, a district administration official said. “Perhaps, she is the first doctor to have contracted the disease from patients in the state. With this, the number of Covid-19 patients here has gone up to six. The four patients are being treated in the isolation wards of the ESIC hospital. Their vitals are stable,” he said.

The doctor had joined duty on March 23 at the Podanur Railway Hospital after she was transferred from the Erode Railway Hospital. As she felt feverish, she took leave on the same day. She was admitted to the ESIC hospital on March 25 after she started showing the symptoms of the infection. Her throat and nasal swabs as well as those of her family members were sent to the King Institute of Preventive Medicine and Research in Chennai. Shortly, the railway closed both the railways hospital she had worked as a precautionary measure.

“Her husband and the other child have tested negative. But their swabs have been sent for reconfirmation,” the official told TOI.

Meanwhile, four people who had travelled from New Delhi to Erode tested positive for the virus on Sunday and are undergoing treatment in the IRT Perundurai Medical College. With this, the number of Covid-19 patients in Erode has gone up to nine.

Health department officials are trying to track down 51 people - 28 from Mettupalayam and the rest from Anaimalai, Pollachi and Coimbatore city – who had attended a religious function along with the Thailand nationals in New Delhi for two days from March 22, said the official. “We tracked down 43 people and collected swabs for testing. They were admitted to the isolation wards of the government hospitals in Mettupalayam, Pollachi and Coimbatore.”

Two people who had returned from the Maldives had to struggle after doctors at the ESIC hospital in Coimbatore prescribed home quarantine on Saturday. “The duo had visited a private hospital in the city as one of them had cough. The hospital sent them to the ESIC hospital in an ambulance. Doctors there ruled out symptoms of Covid-19 and asked them to leave on their own,” a source said.

The duo managed to convince the driver of a goods carrier to give them a ride back home with the help of cops.

Title: Citizens get creative with birthday celebrations in lockdown
Content:
Nagpur: Ever heard of a cake made of chips and savoury snacks or seen people celebrating their birthdays with a protecting mask on? Thats the new reality in the era of long lockdown. Nagpurians confined to their homes are celebrating their birthdays in the unique ways. Some have decorated their houses with glittery happy birthday wall hangings, while others enjoyed their ‘Quarantine birthday’ with delicious home-cooked meal, making it a memorable one.

Giving some insights into her celebration, Pallavi Bais, a psychology student, stated she cut a cake made of chips and snacks, “I had a fun virtual birthday as I was busy attending video call of my loved ones. My friends a made a cake with ingredients lying around such as chips, kurkure and other stuff. It was special in its own way,” she said.

Gaurav Medha, a banker, celebrated his birthday on March 25 and feels it was an unusual yet happy experience of being at home for the entire day. “It was indeed a different birthday and I will always remember it for years to come. We did not have any cake or outside food, but celebrated it at home with my family. I just cut some bread symbolically instead of a cake,” he said.

Citizens also invoked their inner chefs and baked their own cakes on their birthday, as they are avoiding outside food and delivery was closed too. Rakhi Ghode celebrated her 46th birthday on March 21 with her family and made her own cake. “It was a different experience altogether. Yet I was happy as I baked my own cake, decorated it and celebrations were doubled as my son who usually stays outstation joined me,” she said.

Sampada Shinde, an architecture student, celebrated her birthday on March 26 with nicely done decorations and also posted pictures of herself wearing a mask. “My brother and mom ordered a cake online, and it was home delivered. They decorated my room with whatever was present at home. I spent the whole day with my family. Otherwise, each year I go out with friends and party. We played carom, watched a movie and had own sweet time at home,” she said.

Self-isolation gave an opportunity to Rinkesh Gorasiya, an entrepreneur, to celebrate his birthday with his family after seven years on March 27. He cut a home-baked cake at midnight and calls it the best birthday ever, “This birthday was special to me as I celebrated it after seven years with my family. I cut the cake which to my surprise was baked at home. We played UNO, and the room was filled with laughter. My most special birthday, better than any fancy party,” he said.

Adding to this, Rahul Dhok who celebrated his mother’s 57th birthday on March 26, said, “We tried very hard to get a cake from a bakery as we had already cancelled big celebration plan. My friend who stays nearby joined for a small get together at home. My mom was happy. It was a very different,” he said.

Talking about her lockdown birthday on March 27, Dhanashree Mathulkar, a banker, said, “No cake was cut as no shop was open. I went to office and came back home. My mother made me sweet halwa and I stayed at home with my family.”

Title: Industries shut, residents get 5MLD more water
Content:
Chennai: Industrial units in the city are in lockdown and the five million litres of water a day (MLD) meant for them is being used to supply residents in various areas.

A senior Metrowater official said the per capita consumption of water in the city, with most people staying indoors, is likely to have increased by 15% since the lockdown kicked in at 6pm on Tuesday last. The 100 litres of water a consumed on average by an individual may have gone up to 120 litres per head, he said.

After April 14, when the lockdown is scheduled to end, Metrowater will analyse water consumption across the city to arrive at a rough estimation, the official explained.

Since the shutting down of the desalination plant at Nemmeli on the outskirts of the city to replace a moving filter, or travelling band screen, Metrowater has managed to continue the regular water supply by drawing water from Veeranam lake in Cuddalore district.

Generally, water from this lake is used only during the peak dry period. As on Sunday, the lake had a storage of 1,100mcft (million cubic feet) against the full capacity of 1,465. After the repairs at the Nemmeli desalination plant are completed, drawal of water from the Veeranam lake will be stopped, said the official.

A couple of months ago, Metrowater made a proposal to increase piped water supply to city residents from the existing 650MLD to 750MLD before dropping it.

The reservoirs at Poondi, Chembarambakkam, Red Hills and Cholavaram have a combined storage of 6,400mcft currently. This combined with water from Veeranam lake, a few abandoned quarries, Metrowater’s own sources and agricultural wells in Tamaraipakkam in Tiruvallur district, can help cope with the situation over the next two months, which is the crucial period, the official said, adding that all steps are being taken to ensure there is no repeat of the situation in the summer of 2019.

Title: Lucknow: Schools, coaching units log into online classes
Content:
A number of video calling applications are being used by teachers

LUCKNOW: For Ayushi Singh, a class IX student of a school in Indiranagar, lockdown does not mean a break from classroom studies or from tests by her coaching institute. In the morning she attends online lectures on the school’s YouTube channel and in the evening she connects with her coaching institute using a cloud app.

“For our parents it’s work from home and for me it’s study from home. I am back to the same schedule of six hours studies everyday,” said Ayushi.
