Around a lakh school students (class V and above) and those who have opted for coaching institutes are attending online classes using web-based video conferencing or with the help of various applications .

“There is a free application named Zoom which is being used by every coaching institute. With the help of this application, students are recording sessions. For school students it gives an option to collaborate on projects and share or annotate on one another’s screens, all from one easy-to-use platform,” said Santosh Tiwari, the owner of a coaching institute .

Another coaching institute at Kapoorthala is using a chatting application for conducting classes.

“We have fixed a time for every student and we take classes via video-calling in which multiple students can be connected. The study material is also circulated on the group and it is followed by question-answer sessions,” said owner of a prominent coaching institute in Kapoorthala Shishir Kapoor. A number of schools have started classes through video-conferencing applications.

“More than 50 schools are using various android applications, cloud-based applications and other internet services for teaching,” said president of Unaided Private Schools Association Anil Agarwal.

Title: Small farmers to remain indoors as tea production resumes in Ooty
Content:
Udhagamandalam: Small tea growers’ associations in the Nilgiris on Sunday strongly objected to the state government’s move to resume tea manufacturing in the district, when the nation was in lockdown mode to fight Covid-19.

All the tea manufacturing factories - be it bought leaf factories, industrial cooperative tea factories (Indco), corporate tea factories and Tamil Nadu Tea Development Corporation (Tantea) - had shut their operations as soon as lockdown was announced in the country.

However, a corporate player, Chamraj tea estate, had on Friday approached the district administration, seeking permission to resume tea production, citing guidelines issued by the central government for the lockdown. They also urged the district administration to clear the air regarding their operation in consultation with the state government, which said tea manufacturing activities could be undertaken.

Following this, collector J Innocent Divya had on Saturday said tea manufacturing and production activities could be undertaken in the district, subject to general restrictions and other safety measures.

B Dharuman, president, Nellikolu Trust, a body of Nilgiris small tea farmers, said, “When the people in the hills are abiding by the lockdown rules, this kind of clarification by the government only confuses the small tea farmers. We understand the seriousness of Covid-19 and we prefer to remain indoors, irrespective the government’s stance.”

While the managing director of Indcoserve, an apex body of 15 cooperative tea factories in the district, have instructed the cooperative tea factories to resume operations, B Kumaran, vice-chairman, Tea Board of India, on Sunday wrote to the official to stall tea manufacturing activities at the cooperative tea factories, citing practical difficulties involved in following precautionary measures while at work.

There are 22,000 small tea farmers who are attached to the Indco tea factories.

Kumaran said, “The stance of the government, in my view, is not correct as manufacturing of tea subject to general restrictions and other safety measures such as social distancing is impractical given the present situation.”

Pointing out that 40 lakh kg made-tea was yet to be auctioned, he said, “What is the point in resuming tea manufacturing activities in this time of crisis? Government can resume the auction that hadn’t taken place in the past two weeks for supply of tea to the market.”

He said tea production should be stalled in the Nilgiris at least until April 14 in view of Covid-19 outbreak.

Meanwhile, Manjai V Mohan, a representative of small tea farmers in the district, has written to chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami, seeking a compensation package of Rs5000 for the small tea farmers in the Nilgiris. He said, “The cooperative tea factories would start functioning from Monday. However, supply of green leaf tea will not be available as farmers will continue to stay at home.”

There are around 165 tea manufacturing factories, including 15 cooperative tea factories and as many corporate companies, in the Nilgiris, where more than 50,000 small tea growers cultivate tea on more than one lakh acres.

In addition, Tantea owns around 9,500 acres in the hill retreat, mainly in Gudalur and Coonoor taluks. Sri Lankan repatriates are mostly engaged in works in the tea gardens of Tantea.

Title: IUML leader booked over daughter’s wedding ceremony
Content:
Kozhikode: The city police booked Noorbina Rasheed , women leader of Indian Union Muslim League ( IUML ), her husband and son on Sunday on the charges of violating government guidelines regarding home quarantine and weddings during the lockdown period. The Chevayoor police booked the case following a complaint by officials with the Kozhikode city corporation .

According to police, Noorbina’s son Subin Rasheed was booked for violating guidelines regarding home quarantine, whereas Noorbina and her husband were booked for conducting the wedding ceremony of their daughter with the participation of more than 50 people.

Subin, according to police, was under home quarantine as he had returned to Kozhikode from the US. It was on March 14 that Subin had reached Kozhikode.

Despite direction to undergo home quarantine, the man took part in the wedding of his sister at his residence on March 21. “We have booked him under Section 269 of IPC (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) and Section 118 E of Kerala Police Act (penalty for causing grave violation of public order or danger),” a police officer of Chevayoor station said.

Police also charged Noorbina and her husband for organizing the wedding of her daughter and for allowing the presence of their son, who was under quarantine at the ceremony. As prohibitory order is in place in Kozhikode, not more than 10 people can participate in a wedding or other ceremony at a time. The maximum number of people who can attend a wedding ceremony at different time should also not exceed 50.

A few days ago, the police had booked former mayor and CPM leader A K Premajam as she tried to obstruct a group of health workers who questioned the violation of home quarantine by her son. Premajam’s son and family were in home quarantine as they had returned to Kozhikode from Australia.

Title: Nashik’s grapes rot as exports to EU and local sales grind to halt
Content: Nashik/Mumbai: Export of Nashik’s famous grapes to European countries is the latest casualty of the Covid-19 pandemic. Even sale of the fruit within the country has trickled due to the lockdown.Farmers from Nashik— the state’s grape capital—are facing labour shortage and issues with transportation as private transporters are reluctant to ply citing police harassment.The situation today is in sharp contrast to the previous season when Nashik exported 1.4 lakh tonne of grapes—an all-time record. The grape season lasts for five months beginning December. Their previous all-time high was 1.3 lakh tonne during the 2016-17 season.According to the Grape Exporters’ Association of India (GEAI), 30% of the produce meant for exports is yet to be harvested. “The vineyards are full of good quality produce but the farmers have no option but to let them rot as there is no demand and no labour to harvest them. Also, there is no way the produce can be carried to the market ,” said Abhijeet Zambhare, a farmer.“Apart from exports, we are also unable to send grapes to various domestic markets as workers are not available to load the trucks. Moreover, farmers are not getting workers to pluck the grapes either,” said Jagannath Khapre, president, GEAI.Maharashtra Rajya Draksha Bagayatdar Sangh (MRDBS), an association of grape growers, has said that around three lakh acres are under grape cultivation in Maharashtra, with two lakh acres in Nashik alone. Vineyards on 90,000 acres are yet to be harvested, including around 50,000 acres in Nashik.“We have not been getting containers for the past few days to export grapes via JNPT. We are not getting packaging material as outlets are closed due to the national lockdown,” said Manik Patil, a senior association member. State agriculture minister Dada Bhuse met grape farmers and exporters on Thursday and assured them containers and packaging material would be made available to them.

Title: BU to offer masks with viral deactivation properties soon
Content:
Coimbatore: Researchers at the Bharathiar University in the city have come up with a prototype of a mask that has viral deactivation properties. According to them, the nanofiber-based three-layered mask, which contains active compounds of some medicinal plants, would be of great use to both healthcare workers and general public to fight Covid-19.

The researchers said they have been working on the mask since February. It all began with them drawing up a list of medicinal plants, which were prescribed by the ministry of ayurveda, yoga and naturopathy, unani, siddha and homoeopathy (Ayush) for prevention and as prophylactic for Covid-19, to be used in the mask.

Last week, papers on their research were published in two journals - Science of the Total Environment, and European Review for Medical and Pharmacological Sciences.

University vice-chancellor P Kaliraj said they have shared the information with the state government and were looking for their support. He said they were also planning to tie up with industries in Coimbatore for large scale manufacturing of the mask “We hope to take the product to the market within two to three months.”

V Balachandar, assistant professor of the university’s department of human genetics and molecular biology, said the active compounds of medicinal plants that were prescribed by the ministry of ayush were incorporated in cotton nanofibers that were used in the mask. “The compounds extracted from the plants would deactivate the virus,” said Balachandar, also coordinator of the research team.

While mentioning that plants such as andrographis paniculata, sphaeranthus indicus, clitoria ternatea and hyoscyamus niger were having anti-viral properties, they said in the research papers, “(They are) renowned for their antiviral and pulmonary protective potentials. Active compounds from these plants can be incorporated into respiratory masks to furnish them with inherent antiviral properties. This will provide the wearer with an extra mode of protection, in addition to the physical barrier.”

However, the team hasn’t named the exact medicinal plants, the active compounds of which they would use in the masks.

Balachandar said they wanted to develop the mask that won’t allow the virus to survive on its surface for long. “The survival rate of virus on its surface will be minimal. We are also looking at making the pore size of the mask small so that the virus would be filtered out.”

Pointing out that developing a vaccine for Covid-19 would take quite a while, he said, “We hope these cost-effective masks would be of help. In the absence of vaccination, protective masks can be worn to prevent transmission of airborne pathogenic aerosols and control diseases. Also, medicinal plants infused in the mask would be a protective measure.”

The university vice-chancellor said they have appraised higher education minister K P Anbalagan, health minister Dr C Vijayabaskar and health secretary Beela Rajesh IAS about their research. “We are also looking at industrial collaboration for large scale production of masks,” Kaliraj said.

Title: Bengaluru: Cops register two cases related to false information on social media
Content: BENGALURU: Cybercrime police wings of Kolar and Ramanagara districts have registered a criminal case each for alleged spreading/forwarding/reposting of false information related to Covid-19 on social media.A 45-year-old businessman in Kolar filed a complaint against unknown miscreants for allegedly spreading false information about his daughter, who returned from Germany on March 5.“My daughter has undergone all types of medical examinations and is in home quarantine. She showed no symptoms of Covid-19. But some miscreants spread false news on WhatsApp claiming my daughter is suffering from Covid-19 and this is false,” the complainant told police.Kolar CEN police have taken up the case. Police said several people contacted the businessman and his family over phone to enquire about the rumours.The second caseIn another incident, a 28-year-old farmer filed a criminal case against a Facebook user for allegedly spreading false information on his FB wall that a family from Kanakapura had tested positive for Covid-19 .Ramanagara police have registered a case based on the complaint filed by the farmer. He alleged that some miscreants unnecessarily created fear among the general public in Ramanagara district by posting a blurred image of a Kanakapura family and claiming that it had tested positive for the virus.The complainant checked with newspapers as well as with health department officials and learnt that the claim made on Facebook was wrong.Ramanagara police registered a case of under IPC section 305 against the unidentified FB user for indulging in public mischief.

Title: Kerala: Won’t prescribe alcohol, say doctors
Content:
THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Doctors have termed the government’s decision to allow liquor to be provided on prescriptions , as a most unfortunate and unscientific step. The state branch of Indian Medical Association ( IMA ) and Kerala Government Medical Officers Association ( KGMOA ) have both hit out at the government over its move to make arrangements for regulated availability of alcohol in the state for those suffering from withdrawal symptoms.

Various associations of doctors have alleged that it was an unscientific decision and hence the government should reconsider it. The IMA members made it clear that no doctors in the state will give a prescription allowing the patient to take alcohol as a medicine.

Title: Thanks to prompt collection, waste worries not piling up
Content:
Bengaluru: Having anticipated waste woes during the lockdown, residents of several localities in Bengaluru are relieved at garbage being disposed of promptly.

“BBMP workers are ensuring waste is collected regularly during the lockdown. The responsibility of proper segregation lies on us,” said Niveditha Sunkad, member of Rajarajeshwari Nagar-I care, a resident welfare association.

Hemanth Kumar Agrawal, a member of Domlur Resident Welfare Association, said waste collectors need to be rewarded as they are risking their health to keep others’ safe. “The auto-tippers are visiting us every day and picking up waste. However, people are still not segregating waste properly,” lamented Kumar.

Shiva Prakash, a member of the Junnasandra RWA, said BBMP had been picking waste from their locality on alternate days earlier but is doing it every day now. “BBMP’s solid waste management staffers have turned a new leaf and are collecting garbage without any prodding,” he added.

The Palike has not let the lockdown affect its work. The attendance has remained 80%, officials said. “We want to ensure garbage is collected on a daily basis and residents are not troubled by overflowing bins,” said Nagaraj Kalappa, a waste collection worker. “Our families may be worried for us, but if we don’t collect waste, people will throw it on the streets and this can create a bigger problem,” he added.

Lockdown a challenge

D Randeep, special commissioner, said the lockdown was indeed a challenge. “Pourakarmikas did not have transportation for a short period and were forced to travel in private vehicles. But we gave them an allowance of Rs 100 per day to ensure the expenditure did not drill a hole in their pockets,” he said.

“The situation has improved now as BMTC has decided to extend help to ferry pourakarmikas,” he added. BBMP has ensured some flexibility, wherein a pourakarmika can work for only half a day, from 6.30am-10.30am.

Pourakarmikas and other waste collection workers were largely dependent on hotels and Indira Canteens for breakfast but they too have been shut down, regretted a senior BBMP official.

Title: State halts farm loan waiver scheme
Content: The state government has temporarily halted implementation of the farm loan waiver scheme as the staff working on the ground has been diverted for coronavirus measures. Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar said this past week this is being done as farmers too cannot travel to these centres due to the lockdown and are also wary of giving their biometric impressions.

Title: Two Nagaland youths allege racial bias in Mysuru's supermarket; 4 staffers held
Content:
Representative Image

MYSURU: Two youths from Nagaland alleged they faced racial discrimination when they visited a supermarket in Mysuru’s Chamundipuram to purchase grocery on Saturday.

Based on their social media posts and CCTV footage, police on Sunday arrested four employees of More store on charges of racial discrimination against the two students and denial of food items. Police commissioner Chandragupta said an FIR was lodged at Krishnaraja police station and the manager and staff of the supermarket were questioned.

The arrested are Manjunath, customer service associate, Naveen from IT maintenance division, Avinash, manager of the outlet, and Revanna.

However, the mall staff denied the allegations and told police it was the public who asked them not to allow the duo into the store as they looked like foreigners.

The incident came to light when one of the Naga youths — a college student in Mysuru — posted about it on his social media page. He said the incident happened when he went to the supermarket with his friend on Saturday evening to buy grocery. According to the post, the duo stood in the queue for 25 minutes, maintaining social distance. But when it was their turn to enter the store, they were stopped by the staff at the entrance. “Though we requested them to allow us as we didn’t have any symptoms of flu, they didn’t oblige. When we asked the reason, they said, ‘you are not from India.’”

Though the two youths were offended, they showed them their Aadhaar cards to prove their nationality. They said they were from Nagaland, studying in a college in Mysuru. But nobody was willing to listen to them, the post claimed. The students said they argued for 10 minutes and went back without buying goods. One of them uploaded the video of the incident and accused the staff of racism.

Police commissioner Chandragupta said: “We urge people and shop owners to behave responsibly during such crises.”

Supermarket to probe incident

The supermarket said it will conduct a probe into the incident. “More Retail does not accept discrimination of any kind in its stores. Our stores are open to all citizens of the country. A probe will be conducted into this incident...,” read a statement.

Reacting to the incident, Union sports minister Kiren Rijiju tweeted that this was unacceptable and the Union home ministry has already issued a clear advisory to all states and Union Territories to prevent any discrimination against people from northeast.

Title: Lucknow: Supply chain streamlines a bit but many buyers return empty-handed
Content: LUCKNOW: The supply chain mechanism of essential commodities streamlined a bit on the fifth day of the lockdown on Sunday, but people in several localities complained that local grocers are sending them back empty-handed saying that items like flour, rice, pulses and branded food are out of stock.District magistrate (DM) Abhishek Prakash said efforts are being made to strengthen supply chain further. “Over 9,200 households were supplied ration, fruits and vegetables through home delivery by private service providers on Sunday,” he said.Around 62 outlets of 13 retail and online supermarkets have been permitted home delivery in the city.Officers on Sunday inspected godowns of a app-based supermarket, 10 wholesalers and 75 grocery retailers to check availability of stocks. “We have directed wholesale traders to ensure proper supply to retailers facing shortage of essential items on priority basis,” Prakash said. On complaints that the app-based supermarkets are giving date of delivery after 10-15 days because of backlog, he said “We have asked them to include 50% old orders and 50% new in the total delivery they do daily.”The DM further said that total 1,500 people were supplied medicines through home delivery by 91 pharma suppliers authorised by the administration.“Telephone lines of supermarkets remained busy all day and local groceries said they are out of stock,” said Abhigyan Singh, a Gomtinagar resident, who visited several stores for 45-kg flour after he could not connect supermarkets on phone.Shashi Singh of Aliganj said “If you need anything urgently, local grocer is the only option, but they too show us empty shelves,” he added.Supermarket managers said that lines are busy because of a steady stream of calls. “We try to cater to maximum possible houses daily,” said a manager.

Title: Staff, residents, nurses oppose GMCH as Covid-19 hospital
Content: Nagpur: The state government’s plan to convert the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) into an exclusive Covid-19 treatment centre received a major setback on Sunday when resident doctors, nurses, health workers and sanitary work force of the hospital together opposed this plan.Three separate delegations of resident doctors, health and sanitary workers, and nurses called on GMCH dean Dr Sajal Mitra on Saturday and demanded not to convert GMCH into a Covid-19 hospital. All three organizations have their own reasons to oppose the plan.First and foremost, the students are worried about their academics. GMCH houses more than 2,000 students of UG, PG and super speciality courses. All stakeholders are also worried about the lack of proper resources like protection equipment and masks in enough quantity to do the job properly.“We are ready to fight against Covid-19 and mostly resident doctors are taking the responsibility of treating patients in isolation wards. But converting the entire hospital into Covid-19 centre is not at all a good idea,” reads a statement issued by Maharashtra Resident Doctors Association (MARD) in GMCH. According to MARD, poor patients being treated at GMCH will have to go to private hospitals in case GMCH is reserved only for Covid-19 patients. Students are also worried about the future of their academics.Nurses are also worried about patients and their own academics. “GMCH is India’s most prominent medical colleges and many courses related to nursing are conducted here. Nurses trained in GMCH are working all over India. Converting the hospital into Covid-19 centre will be a setback for us,” the statement issued by Sahayohita Mhaisagawali, president of Maharashtra State Nursing Association, reads.Association of Health Workers has also raised issue of poor patients. “Patients coming from across Central India get free treatment at GMCH. Trauma care centre, super speciality hospital and neonatal care unit will suffer in case the premises are sealed for Covid-19 treatment,” said Trisharan Sahare, president of the Health Workers Association attached to INTUC. They have also claimed that GMCH is centrally located in Nagpur and it may spread infection in city if many patients of Covid-19 are accommodated here.GMCH dean Dr Sajal Mitra said that the state government will take a final decision on setting up the Covid-19 centre only after consultation with medical education department.Meanwhile, the Directorate of Medical Education and Research (DMER), on Saturday, issued a resolution that government can now accommodate registered private practitioners to treat Covid-19 patients. Deans of government medical colleges have been given powers to avail services of private practitioners in the district if required in an emergency. A formal permission of DMER will be necessary for this.GMCH NAGPURGMCH is the biggest medical college campus in AsiaTotal area of campus was 190 acre when it was built in 1947Present capacity of hospital is 1,750 patientsHospital treats patients from Maharashtra as well as neighbouring statesHospital has inflow of a more than 3,000 patients daily at its OPDWith UG, PG and super speciality courses, hospital has more than 2,000 studentsAll academic activities will suffer if hospital gets converted into Covid-19 centre

Title: Teachers busy marking ‘all pass’ for students from Class I to IX
Content:
Coimbatore: With the state government deciding to promote all students from class I to IX amid the Covid-19 outbreak, government schoolteachers, who are working from home due to the lockdown, are busy consolidating marks of the first two terms, entering them in consolidated sheets and declaring them ‘all pass’.

The directorate of school education has instructed CEOs that after schools reopen, this should be entered in the promotion registers.

T Arulanandam, a schoolteacher and the state auditor of the Tamil Nadu High and Higher Secondary School Graduate Teachers Association (TNHHSSGTA), said they used to aggregate marks of the first two terms and take an average. “We would enter them in consolidated sheets before entering them online in the educational management information system (EMIS) portal. However, with all the students declared promoted, we are now entering the marks and marking all of them pass. Though it’s an all pass, we have to enter that for all students. If there are 800 students, we have to mention the result as promoted for all of them,” he told TOI.

The teachers are also doing the pending work related to the academic year, says P K Ilamaran, president of the Tamil Nadu Teachers Association. “We have been verifying students’ half-yearly marks and have been entering their results. Once there is an announcement, we would upload them online,” he said.

The teachers have also called for promoting Class X students. “As the academic year is almost over, it would not be appropriate to ask Class X students to return to their old portions. Instead of a board exam, the government should come up with some kind of entrance exam to let students choose the group they want in Class XI,” he said.

Title: Hyderabad Lockdown: Hit by lockdown, auto drivers seek governement’s help in Hyderabad
Content: HYDERABAD: Auto rickshaw drivers in the city, who are struggling to make ends meet amid the lockdown to prevent the spread of Covid-19 , sought help from the state government.Most of the auto drivers buy food with the money they make each day and have no savings to fall back on. They said their families have been struggling for food and other basic amenities due to the unprecedented 21-day lockdown.“Our first concern is how to feed our families, not the virus. We usually earn about Rs 500 to Rs 600 per day which we use to buy food, save up for rent and pay other bills. With the government announcing the lockdown, we have no other means of income or savings to fall back on. We will starve to death if this continues for a longer period,” said Mohammad Rameez, an auto driver. “I request the government to help us overcome these tough times,” Rameez added. Rameez and his family are from Warangal and have been residing in Hyderabad from the past 2 years.Similarly, another auto driver, M Ramnath said, “I do not have any money left to finance my auto or to even buy groceries. I am the only earning member of my family and I do not even have a white ration card to avail benefits of the government. I request the government to help us survive these tough times.”Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao on March 22 announced that one month’s ration and 12 kg of rice will be given to each of the 87.59 lakh white ration cardholders in the state. While the relief from the state is yet to arrive at many places, unions say that many auto drivers who depend on their daily earnings to feed their families do not have white ration cards.“This unprecedented 21-day lockdown is forcing a lot of auto drivers to struggle for even the basic needs. While those who have white ration cards will receive the ration in a few days, those who do not have the cards will be the ones who will suffer the most,” said Satti Reddy, a member of Telangana Auto Drivers Joint Action Committee.“None of them were prepared for this lockdown and are struggling to feed their families. We request the government to consider our plea and help the auto drivers,” said Reddy.

Title: Railways sets up foot-operated hand-wash kiosk for staff
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: There have been frequent reminders for the staff attached to Thiruvananthapuram Central railway Station to wash hands in the times of Covid-19 . But the hand-wash kiosk at the coaching depot extensively used by workers to clean themselves has a threat attached to it: Virus spread through transmission as several hands touch the same tap daily.The mechanical staff of accident relief train then came up with a solution — a contactless hand-wash kiosk that can be operated using foot. The idea was mooted by Shirish Kumar Sinha, divisional railway manager, Thiruvananthapuram division.There are two foot pedals provided at the kiosk. One is for dispensing water and another for sanitizer. When one steps on the pedal, the handle provided on the top of the sanitizer moves and it dispenses a certain amount of liquid. Similarly, the tap for water is controlled by another pedal.After a video of the machine was shared in social media, railway minister Piyush Goyal tweeted the same with a comment: ‘Railways combats coronavirus : In an innovative move, a contactless hand-wash system has been developed by Indian Railways at Thiruvananthapuram railway station. Watch railways staff keeping #SafeHands in this novel way!”.“Now, we don’t have the infrastructure and manpower to make more such machines. If people approach us, we are ready to guide them to make it,” said a railway spokesperson.

Title: Horticorp makes special arrangements
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Horticorp, under the state agriculture department , has made special arrangements for procurement and distribution of fruits and vegetables during the lockdown period. Agriculture minister V S Sunilkumar said horticorp would procure fruits and vegetables from local producers through special arrangements. The produces thus collected would be distributed over the counter of 100 horticorp outlets and 200 franchisees. The same would be also delivered to community kitchens and institutions run by the social justice department.

The minister said that the government has decided to deliver fruits and vegetables against orders from residents’ associations in Thiruvananthapuram district. Online facility has also been launched for door delivery of the items in select areas in Thiruvananthapuram and Ernakulam districts. Orders for procurement of 20 tonne of pineapple from Vazhakkulam and five tonne of mango from Palakkad Muthalamada have been given of late. tnn

Title: Another health worker tests Covid-19 positive in Kerala
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: One more person involved in Covid-19 prevention activities tested positive in the state on Sunday. Earlier, a nurse with Kottayam Medical College Hospital had tested positive.As many as 20 new cases were reported, taking the total number of cases reported in the state to 202. Of this, 20 people have been discharged while one person died on Saturday. At present, 181 patients are admitted at different hospitals of the state.Of the persons who tested positive on Sunday, 18 had travelled from different foreign countries. The health worker was with a government hospital in Ernakulam.Eight cases were reported in Kannur, seven in Kasaragod and one each in Thiruvananthapuram, Ernakulam, Palakkad, Thrissur and Malappuram. Kasaragod district has the highest number of positive cases reported, with 80. The one positive case reported in Thiruvananthapuram is learned to have no travel history. Authorities are looking at the possibility of direct contact with an infected person.Meanwhile, health authorities are yet to trace the source of the infection in the case of the Congress leader who tested positive in Idukki. In Kollam, the district administration released a list of 101 people in the high-risk category who had come in direct contact with the positive case reported in the district.At present, 1,41,211 persons are under observation in the state, of which 593 are admitted in designated hospitals. In Pathanamthitta, four persons tested negative in repeated tests and are being readied for discharge.Since the new cases were persons who had come from abroad, the health department is sticking to its line that there is no community spread in the state. Even though more cases were reported from Kasaragod, authorities are of the view that all the cases are either those travelling from abroad or direct contacts.Till date, 6,690 samples have been sent for testing, of which 5,518 have returned negative. On Sunday, 105 people were admitted to various hospitals with suspected symptoms.After Kasaragod with 80 positive cases, Kannur has 38 cases and Ernakulam 14 positive cases. The other districts with Covid-19 cases are: Thiruvananthapuram (8), Kollam (1), Pathanamthitta (5), Alappuzha (1), Kottayam (3), Idukki (2), Thrissur (5), Palakkad (5), Malappuram (9), Kozhikode (9), Wayand (1).Palakkad has the most number of people under observation, at 18,837, followed by Thiruvananthapuram (18,145) and Kollam (17,040).

Title: Lucknow: Students stuck in metros; parents seek government’s help
Content:
Various students and parents have taken to social media to ask authorities for help in travelling to Lucknow i... Read More

LUCKNOW: Thousands of parents, whose children are studying in Delhi, Mumbai, Bengaluru and other metros and are unable to return to the city due to the lockdown, are passing sleepless nights these days.

Harish and Anju Srivastava, residents of Alambagh , are worried for their son pursuing graduation from Bengaluru. With all state borders closed and no mode of transportation is available, they are haplessly waiting for the government to ensure safe return of their son.

“My son had taken a room in college hostel. But all colleges have been closed due to lockdown. Now he is sharing a PG accommodation with one of his classmates. He was supposed to return Lucknow on April 5 after his semester examination. Video calls are the only option for us to stay in touch with him,” said Srivastava.

Sandhya Paul, another local, has posted on a Facebook group a query asking her FB friends to tell her whether her two sons can drive back to the city from Gurgaon. “I am requesting you to please help me out. My sons are stuck in Gurgaon. Can they come to Lucknow in their car?,” wrote Paul. However, many of the group followers have advised her to stay put till the lockdown ends on April 15.

Suman and Uttam Marwah are counting restless days as their daughter is stuck in Delhi. While parents are worried for their kids, children living away from their families are also trying to return. Avantika Bhatt, a student in Delhi, said she called up helpline numbers issued by the government for people from Uttar Pradesh stuck in Delhi, but to no avail.

Lucknow resident studying in DelhiVasvi Verma took to Twitter to share her ordeal and tagged Delhi CM in her twitter thread.

Title: Artist to donate paintings to Prime Minister’s relief fund
Content:
Coimbatore: A city-based artist is planning to donate five of his oil paintings to Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Covid-19 relief fund.

P Nandakumar, who works as an art teacher in a city school, said he was inspired when the PM said that it was people’s will to contribute that mattered and not the actual amount they contributed. “If I sell my paintings myself, I can get a few tens of thousands. But if the PM does it for the cause, it can fetch much more. So, I have decided to donate five of my best oil paintings to the PM’s Covid-19 relief fund,” he said.

Nandakumar has tweeted this, tagging the PM’s Twitter handle.

In December 2018, when cyclone Gaja hit the coastal districts, Nandakumar sold six of his paintings to raise Rs 95,000. He used the money to buy rice and blankets for the people in villages near Vedaranyam.

Title: Roorkee jail admin to release 71 inmates
Content: ROORKEE: In view of the novel coronavirus outbreak, the Roorkee jail administration has decided to release 71 inmates. The move comes after the Supreme Court on March 23 ordered to release all jail inmates (with less than 7 years imprisonment) on interim bail and paroles to make jails decongested.“Around 60 undertrials and 11 prisoners will be released for six months. The undertrials will furnish a personal bond of Rs 1 lakh whereas parole arrangement will be followed in the case of prisoners,” said PK Dwivedi, jail superintendent of Roorkee jail.He added that the district administration will send these people to their respective homes under police security.

Title: Over 1,800 arrested in Uttarakhand for defying lockdown
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: A total of 1 ,866 persons have been arrested across Uttarakhand for violating the lockdown imposed by the central government on March 24 to contain the spread of the coronavirus.

The Union government had announced a nationwide 21-day lockdown on Tuesday. In the following five days, Uttarakhand Police registered 329 FIRs under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), seized 1,795 vehicles and challaned as many as 6,727 for running on roads despite the lockdown. In the process, police have collected a penalty fee to the tune of over Rs 29 lakh.

Speaking to TOI, director general (DG) law and order Ashok Kumar , said, “Police are strictly enforcing the lockdown in the state and people violating it are being punished.”

Notably, the state has been divided in 102 zones and 500 sectors for effective implementation of the lockdown order. Apart from that, 6,000 police personnel and additional 20 companies of Provincial Armed Constabulary (PAC) have been deployed in Uttarakhand.

Title: Curfew Mata Mandir shuts its gates, but hears prayers
Content:
BHOPAL: In times of corona curfew, Bhopal’s “Curfew Wali Mata Mandir” continues to provide succour though its gates stay locked. People stop by for a few seconds, keeping one eye open for the cops posted in the vicinity, murmur a prayer and hurry on.

The idol of “Curfew Mata” was established 38 years ago in Peer Gate area during a month-long curfew following riots, hence the name. It was open even during the 1984 Bhopal gas tragedy, but is now shut for the first time in memory, reports Amarjeet Singh.

The temple is locked but there’s no stopping the devout. On Sunday, the usual crowd of devotees was replaced by half a dozen policemen, tasked with enforcing curfew in letter and spirit — and with a stick, if need be.

People drove or pedalled by, closing eyes in reverence and sending up a silent prayer, before hurrying on lest the cops begin "enforcing". But here, the cops are lenient, too. Who would stop a prayer in these times?

Those who paused a while longer got a gentle reminder from police to “leave it to Mata and move on”.

“It’s part of my daily routine to pray at the temple, so I continue doing it. The temple is closed to visitors, and we know it’s good this way, seeing the coronavirus crisis, but something draws me here. I don’t get peace of mind until I see the temple and pay my respects. I’m thankful that I can do this, no matter how briefly,” said devotee Vishal Namdeo , nodding in gratefulness to the cops.

One of the policemen deployed there said there is a steady trickle of devotees, but they all pray for a few seconds and move on. “They come here as if the very sight of the temple reassures them,” he said, adding that only the priest goes inside every morning and evening through a backdoor for the rituals these days.

The temple was established during trying times in the city. Ramesh Saini , 73, president of the 13-member committee that runs the temple, recalls the day it was set up.

“I was around 35 years old when the temple was built in 1982. It was during Navratri that year that an idol of Goddess Durga was established and immersed after nine days. But locals established an idol there and the administration took it away, leading to a dispute. A curfew was imposed but soon people from nearby districts started flocking to the temple though there were arrests every day,” said Saini.

His father Babulal Mali , a Congress functionary, was among the founding members of the temple, Saini said.

“Arjun Singh was the chief minister then, and Vijay Singh the Bhopal collector. Seeing the public sentiment, the administration asked us to establish the idol during the curfew. A puja was done at 5am and the idol was established. This gave the temple its name," said Saini.

The temple has never seen such a time, he said, not even during the Bhopal gas tragedy. "There was no curfew after the tragedy, but the roads were deserted for a long time. We still kept the temple open for entire nights so that anyone who needed help could come to us,” he said.

In the past 38 years, curfew was imposed once or twice but the temple never had to shut. “These are extraordinary times, and require extraordinary measures. On March 28, the administration ordered us to shut the temple completely,” said Saini.

“The goddess is watching over us. This is a trying time. It, too, will pass with Mata’s grace,” he said.

Title: Time to address the need of deaf and mute
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: When volunteers of Prathidhwani , a socio-cultural organisation in Technopark , launched a helpdesk to address various issues faced by IT professionals at the time of lockdown, little did they know that they were offering a much-awaited support to a techie in real need. Technopark-based IT professional Sanu P Chukkiri, 33, who is deaf and mute, was looking for an option to buy essential items at the time of lockdown.When he informed Prathidhwani members through a whatsapp chat about his requirement and difficulties, Prathidhwani volunteers soon delivered the provisions to him.TOI communicated with Sanu with the support of sign language interpreter Suji Nair, also his colleague, through a video call. Sanu said that he was afraid to go out as he saw visuals in television about police beating people. “I was confused whether it was okay to go out for buying provisions. I went on Saturday to buy necessary items, but soon returned after managing to purchase a few items. When I saw Prathidhwani help desk, I sent them a message and they helped to buy the remaining provisions,” he said.Vineeth Chandran, secretary of Prathidhwani, said they realised about concerns of deaf persons only when they received Sanu’s message. “After Sanu posted about our support in a group, around 4-5 others with hearing impairment contacted us. One person wanted us to help him contact the helpline number as his internet connectivity was getting disrupted while working from home. Problem with several help desk is that only option for call is available. Issues of persons with hearing impairment should be addressed during crisis like these,” he said.Sanu’s family comprises his parents, wife and a child. Except his daughter, all are deaf and mute. “I can communicate through my friend who knows sign language. Others might not have such access. They will find it extremely difficult at the time of lockdown,” he said adding that he was relieved as his parents have enough stock of medicines now.Sanu said he views Covid-19-related information on American sign language websites and certain channels which uses sign language.Suji said while some people with hearing impairment could communicate using sign language, others could only write to communicate. “Both are time consuming and ineffective when they go to a new environment,” she said.

Title: Minister asks teachers to keep students in good spirits
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: General education minister C Raveendranath called for the service of school teachers for ensuring the effective social distancing by students and their parents during the lockdown . The minister said all teachers should take it up as their own responsibility that people connected with them and their students keep themselves inside their homes. "It would be nice if teachers contact students over phone and give them the courage and resilience to pass through the lockdown period.

“They can give students guidance on how the students can spend their time effectively while being at home. Teachers should give special focus to those students whose examinations are currently put on hold.

“If every teacher can infuse confidence in the minds of students and their parents, it would be a great emotional support for a large number of families'', the minister said. tnn

Title: No extension of financial year due to lockdown
Content:
Lucknow: The state government will not extend the closure of financial year 2019-20 beyond March 31 and said there would be no shortage of funds due to corona lockdown.

Speaking to TOI, additional chief secretary finance, Sanjiv Mittal said there would be no extension of the current financial year and the new FY 21 will start from April 1.

The state government will ensure there is no paucity of funds despite lockdown and end the financial year 2019-2020, as state treasury and the department concerned would get h funds from April 1 without any delay.

Mittal also clarified that if departments have not been able to exhaust the funds of last financial year, the same would be returned to the state government which would transfer them in their accounts on April 1. There would be no impact on ongoing plans, programmes and projects of state government, said Mittal, adding that the state assembly and cabinet have already passed the state’s budget of Rs 5.12 lakh crore, so there would be no problem at all.

Mittal is also chairman of the committee formed by the chief minister to draft a revival plan for state economy after assessing the impact of the lockdown and would submit its report by April.Some members of the committee feel that the closure of factories, firms, decline in consumption of petrol and no property registration in the lockdown duration will impact the state economy.

Title: K’taka’s border blockade hits movement of goods
Content:
deadlock: The blockage of main road via Coorg and Makkoottam has raised concern about scarcity of essential co... Read More

Kannur: The decision of the Karnataka government to block the main road via Coorg and Makkoottam that connects Kannur with Karnataka, in the name of the lockdown has affected the flow of goods to the state, which has caused concern about scarcity of essential commodities and vegetables .

Though chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan intervened in the matter and the issue was discussed at the chief-secretary level, the road is still blocked after the Karnataka authorities heaped soil on the road near Makkoottam in the Kerala-Karnataka border and elsewhere. He had also written a letter to the Prime Minister on March 27, but in vain.

The stand of Karnataka authorities is that there are alternative routes, said Sunny Joseph, MLA. “When this road is blocked, the trucks have to travel an additional distance of over 100km via Gundlupet and Wayanad to reach Kannur and this would lead to the escalation of price,” he said. If the government failed to address the issue immediately, the scenario would worsen, he added.

Though the Karnataka authorities had promised to open the road via Kutta, it has not been opened till Sunday evening, said Iritty tahsildar K K Divakaran .

“Though the road via Kutta is over 75km longer than Virajpet road, it is shorter than the Gundlupet-Wayanad route, but even now there is no clarity as to when it would be opened,” he said. But the Coorg-Makkoottam road is the most important one which should be opened, he said.

Kannur MP K Sudhakaran also intervened in the issue and talked to the chief secretary and state police chief of Karnataka on Saturday.

Many trucks have got struck in the border and the Union cabinet secretary had strictly said in a video conference with the senior officials of all states recently that the trucks should be permitted to cross the borders, he said. The act of Karnataka is objectionable and this has started creating problems for the people of both the states, said CPM district secretary MV Jayarajan in a statement.

Title: Matri Sadan seers end fast
Content: HARIDWAR: Matri Sadan seers Swami Shivanand Saraswati and Sadhvi Padmavati ended their fast on Sunday after fasting for 20 and 106 days respectively to protect the Ganga. The seers said the decision to end fast was taken after followers of the Haridwar-based ashram repeatedly urged the head of organisation Swami Saraswati through written communication to end the fast owing to coronavirus pandemic.

Title: Drug peddlers use ambulance to smuggle smack, held in Dehradun
Content:
Representative image

RUDRAPUR: Four drug smugglers were held on Sunday by city police for transporting contraband in an ambulance. The police also recovered 25 grams of smack from their possession. The accused have been identified as Bhowali residents — Mukesh Kumar , Imran Ali, and Shubham Kumar — and Haldwani resident Shiv Kumar. They wwere using an ambulance to get past lockdown restrictions so that their vehicle isn’t stopped by cops, said officials.

Bhuwan Chand Joshi, senior sub-inspector (SSI), said a police team was inspecting vehicles near Bigwara Mandi when an ambulance coming from Kichha stopped at some distance. "The police personnel approached the ambulance and found four people dressed up like a driver, a patient, a doctor and an attendant in it. It turned out all of them were drug peddlers and were bringing the contraband from Baheri city of Uttar Pradesh to sell it in Rudrapur. The vehicle was impounded and the accused have been booked under Narcotics Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act,” said SSI Joshi

Title: No ‘community spread’ in UP, each case has a foreign history: Officials
Content:
Lucknow: Amid fears that Covid-19 cases may record exponential growth after extensive reverse migration to UP, health officials on Sunday said there has been no community spread of coronavirus so far in the state.

“The global pandemic has not spread to the community in UP…. I repeat coronavirus has not recorded a community spread in the state,” said principal secretary health and family welfare, Amit Mohan Prasad, adding, “Every single case in UP can be traced back to a foreign history.” Global health agencies have listed three stages of Covid-19 transmission; Stage-I in which a country receives imported cases, Stage-II when positive cases pass on the infection to locals, but the source of all cases in known, and Stage-III.

Stage-III is community transmission, when the source of infection is not known for majority of infected population and new positive cases can no longer be traced to diagnosed cases. It is marked by scores of deaths and exponential growth in the number of affected persons as in case of ChinaItaly, France and America.

Prasad also said that only two places in UP can be called clusters — Noida and Meerut — where more than one reported case can be linked to a common source.

“Infection containment activities are being carried out extensively in the two districts. In addition, a special officer has been appointed in Noida to oversee the situation,” Prasad said. It is notable that around 20 confirmed cases in Noida and Ghaziabad are being linked to a common source, while in Meerut one person could have spread the infection to four others besides putting 50 more people at risk.

“Not even one patient in UP has needed intensive care facilities till now,” Prasad said. Sources however informed that though UP is not in ‘community spread’ level, containment strategies have taken requirements for stage-III in mind.

“It is for this that UP was readying over 14,000 isolation beds. It has already launched a three-level containment plan in which treatment facilities from CHC to special tertiary care Covid hospitals will be provided. Training of staff is underway and now private sector is also being engaged widely,” said an officer.

Title: Two held for dumping carcasses
Content:
Vadodara: Before coronavirus hit Gujarat, poultry farm owners were already in trouble as they were forced to sell chickens at lower prices. Lockdown has exacerbated their problem as they are unable to find labourers to keep their farms clean.

On Saturday, two poultry farm owners of Dabhoi in Vadodara district were arrested for dumping dead chickens in open and failing to maintain cleanliness leading to stench in the entire locality.

Residents of Saguvada village complained to village talati Vanrajsinh Parmar that 2,000 chickens died at the poultry farm of Abdul Golawala and Mohammed Golawala and that the brothers had dumped them in the open. “I was quite shocked on learning this so I rushed to the village on Saturday. The information turned out to be false as only about six chickens had died,” said Parmar. He added that they had dumped the dead chickens in the open and also not cleaned the sheds due to which there was stench in the locality.

“There were bird droppings everywhere in the sheds and it needed immediate cleaning. We are already facing coronavirus scare and can’t afford another infection,” Parmar added. When the two brothers were asked about the untidy farm, they told Parmar due to lockdown all labourers have gone back to their native places and that they cannot clean it alone. Parmar informed Dabhoi police and got Abdul and Mohammed arrested.

“We have registered an offence under IPC sections 278 (making atmosphere noxious to health) and 269 (committing negligent act likely to spread infection or disease dangerous to life) since in the past too they were warned by the talati to keep their farm clean,” said a police official.

Not just Golawala brothers, but several other poultry farm owners are facing labour issues. “All our labourers are from Madhya Pradesh and due to lockdown, they have all gone back and things have come to a standstill here,” said a poultry farm owner.

Title: Telangana: 23-year-old trainee pilot rides 550km, rams bike into divider
Content:
Representative Image

HYDERABAD: A 23-year old trainee pilot who works at Begumpet airport sustained injuries in a road accident in the early hours of Sunday near Chatanpalli bridge under Shadnagar on Sunday. The victim had travelled 550 km overnight even as there is a countrywide lockdown amid Covid-19 outbreak.

The victim was on a bike and rammed into the road divider at around 4.45am, while travelling from Madanapalle, Chittoor. “Taking up such a journey on highways full of heavy vehicles is suicidal as the rider can crash due to sleeplessness and fatigue. Also, the lack of driving skills among some two-wheeler riders make them vulnerable as they can’t manoeuvre between the heavy vehicles and steep curves,” said a Cyberabad traffic police officer. The victim sustained multiple injuries and was rushed to a private hospital. A case was registered in Shadnagar.

Title: Traders to felicitate those who set up veg gardens
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Traders of Palayam have taken up the vegetable cultivation challenge suggested by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan. The Vyapari Vyavasayi Samiti (Palayam) is planning to felicitate residents’ associations and individuals who set up vegetable gardens during the three-week lockdown period.As many are finding it tough to get seeds needed for farming, the Samiti has suggested people to use seeds from vegetables used for cooking. It also asked people living in apartments to used rice bags instead of grow bags for planting saplings.By the end of the lockdown, the families can send pictures of their vegetable garden to the samiti’s email ID vvspalayamac@gmail.com. The mail should contain name, address and phone number.C S Ratheesh, secretary of Palayam area committee of the samiti, said that the challenge was planned to relive stress of people who are confined within their houses during the lockdown period. “The chief minister suggested it as a measure to reduce our stress. It also helps to develop the habit of growing our own vegetables. We don’t know when this lockdown is going to end. In order to reduce stress, people can engage in farming. By the end of the lockdown period, they can send pictures with details to us. Our state-level leaders will visit selected houses and given them our token of appreciation,” he said.Ratheesh said that individuals and residents’ associations in areas such as Palayam, Thampanoor, Statue, Vellayamabalam, Thycaud, Sastamangalam, Vattiyoorkavu etc. can be part of the challenge.The Samiti feels that with initiatives like this, society could become more self-reliant on our food.

Title: Volunteers guard endangered sea turtles in time of Covid-19
Content: KOZHIKODE: Even amidst lockdown in Kasaragod , which has emerged as a Covid-19 hotspot , volunteers of Neythal have another life-saving work at hand. The non-government organisation engaged in turtle conservation for the past two decades has been safeguarding an endangered Olive Ridley turtle nest with 133 eggs, which is expected to hatch on April 1, apart from tending to two injured sea turtles , including a critically endangered Hawksbill turtle Neythal president K Praveen Kumar, along with other volunteers, have been taking turns to safeguard the nests ever since the eggs were collected from the Thaikkadappurama beach near Neeleshwaram on February 21. And yes, they have been following social distancing norms in the process.“We have been observing the lockdown guidelines issued by authorities. At the same time, we cannot abandon the turtle eggs, kept in the hatchery. I have been monitoring the nest daily to ensure they are safe. We have been making the visits to the hatchery in the early mornings so that there are no people around. Today, I fixed a small cardboard around the spot, where the eggs are buried so that the hatchlings won’t scatter away,” Praveen said, adding that volunteers have been taking extra precautions as a person in the adjacent locality was tested positive Covid-19.Though Neythal had tried in situ protection of turtle nests, this nesting season at places where the eggs were laid, it has not been a success, as all the eggs in one nest did not hatch after sand got accumulated over it. Also, only a limited number of hatchlings survived in the other nest, which had around 80 eggs, following which they decided to shift the eggs from the third nest to the Neythal hatchery.Praveen and team are tending to two injured turtles as well, including a critically endangered Hawksbill turtle kept in tanks in the turtle conservation centre.“Getting fish to feed the turtles was a problem due to the lockdown. But police have given permission for one person to go to market to buy fish and we have stocked fish to feed the turtles. While the injured Olive Ridley turtle has lost one flipper and cannot be returned back to the sea, the Hawksbill turtle has been recovering from the injury sustained after getting trapped in an abandoned fishing net,” he added.Though the current turtle nesting season has been in its fag end, Neythal volunteers have been monitoring the beach for newly-laid turtle nests as female turtles return to the same beach from where they first hatched for nesting.Ever since its inception almost two decades back, Neythal has released around 25,000 turtle hatchlings back to the sea in Kasaragod.

Title: Denied entry into home state, more than 3,000 UP workers lodged in Rudrapur shelter homes
Content:
Representative image

RUDRAPUR: After a 21-day nationwide lockdown call by Prime Minister Narendra Modi on March 24, migrant workers from neighbouring Uttar Pradesh (UP) decided to march all the way to their native villages from different districts of Uttarakhand. But when these workers, more than 3,000 in number, finally trudged up to the UP border late on Saturday night, they were not allowed entry into their home state by the UP Police officials stationed at the check posts.

An administrative official from Uttarakhand told TOI that UP Police told themthat they don’t have any direction for allowing entry to these workers.

“We were stopped by the UP Police at the UP border in Pulbhatta town. They asked us to go back. With no money and no food, where were we supposed to go,” questions Subhash Yadav , a migrant worker from Uttar Pradesh’s Pilibhit district .

“The Union ministry of home affairs has directed states to facilitate movement of migrant workers so that they reach their hometowns safely but UP officials are denying entry to people of their own state," said Sushil Gava , a social worker and activist.

Taking cognisance of the plight of these workers, Rudrapur sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) Mukta Mishra said that food and lodging for these workers had been arranged in a government college in Fazalpur Mehraula village and in Radha Swami Satsang facility on Kichha Road. “We will hold talks with UP officials and ask them to allow these workers entry into their home state. Meanwhile, the health department is screening these workers,” said SDM Mishra.

Notably, on March 28, the UP government had arranged 1,000 buses to take all the migrant workers from Delhi and drop them to their respective hometowns.

Title: Modi on Pune Doctor: Sassoon doctor says Covid-19 battle is winnable on Mann Ki Baat
Content:
Rohidas Borse

PUNE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi spoke to Pune-based physician Rohidas Borse about how doctors and paramedics rendering crucial service during his Mann Ki Baat radio programme on Sunday.

Borse is a professor of medicine at the state-run B J Medical College and Sassoon General Hospital and is at the forefront in treating infected persons at Naidu hospital.

He told the PM about youths being worst-hit by the Covid-19 infection, adding that even the most infected persons have had only mild symptoms.

“I told the PM that we are going to win the war against the novel coronavirus. Social distancing and lockdown are the effective weapons in this war,” Borse told TOI.

“When the PM asked me what protocol recovered patients follow, I told him that every recovered person is advised to stay in home quarantine for another 14 days,” Borse said.

Modi talked to Borse on Friday evening and the radio show was relayed on Sunday. “The PMO’s office said the PM would call on my cellphone at any time, so I was prepared,” Borse said.

Title: Join Covid-19 fight, CM Yogi exhorts BJP grassroots force
Content:
Lucknow: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath has roped in the vast army of BJP foot-soldiers to join the battle against Covid-19. On Sunday, he interacted with over 1.63 lakh BJP workers of the state through video-conferencing and exhorted them to be prepared to combat the pandemic.

The CM told the BJP district presidents about the state government's preparedness and sought their help in combating the menace. He said that all BJP workers should make the public aware of the Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Package worth Rs 1.7 lakh crore released for extending relief to the masses during the lockdown. Yogi called upon the workers to provide more and more essential facilities to the people in view of Covid-19 epidemic.

Later, UP BJP chief Swatantra Dev Singh said that the party organisation would help the state government in its bid to provide food and other essential items to people. Singh also announced donation of Rs 1crore from his local area development fund and a month's salary each in the PM relief fund and the CM relief fund.

Singh thanked the party workers in lending their support in the fight against coronavirus. He said that the support from the BJP workers would give the much needed support to the state government. Singh said that the BJP national chief has given a call to feed at least five crore people. “For this, the party organization would work at every level,” Singh said.

The UP BJP chief appealed to the BJP functionaries to feed at least five people daily. He also asked the BJP workers to provide details of people to the district administration. “In there is some problem, the party workers may contact district chiefs or the state-level party leaders,” he added.

Title: Four more test positive for Covid-19 infection in Pune
Content: PUNE: Four persons, including two men with no recent history of foreign travel or any proximity to infected persons or their close contacts, tested positive for the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection in the district on Sunday.The two men without any history of foreign travel are residents of Yerawada and Baramati. With this, the number of coronavirus cases has gone up to 38 in Pune district.The two others who tested positive on Sunday had returned from Dubai on March 9 and were quarantined at Naidu hospital. They developed symptoms of coronavirus two days ago. One of them is a 65-year-old man and the other one is his daughter (30). They are residents of Gultekdi.As many as seven people have been diagnosed with the contagion in Pune between March 20 and March 29, wherein the source of infection was not linked to international travel or a traceable contact to an infected person.“The 76-year-old man from Yerawada is undergoing treatment at a private hospital in Pune. The 40-year-old man from Baramati has developed viral pneumonia and is being treated at the intensive care unit (ICU) of Naidu hospital,” a civic health official said.The Yerawada resident was admitted to a private hospital with cardiac complaints and shortness of breath around 3am on March 28. “We sent his throat swab sample to the National Institute of Virology (NIV). It tested positive for Covid-19,” an official from the hospital said.“The senior citizen had on March 25 and March 27 visited a hospital close to his home, before he was brought to our hospital. He had no history of fever and travel in the last four weeks. His condition is stable,” the official.The Baramati resident had developed breathlessness, following which he was moved to Sassoon General Hospital on March 28. “He tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday and was shifted to the Naidu hospital. He has viral pneumonia and is in the intensive care unit,” a civic health official said.

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Pashan centre may be ideal for isolation
Content: PUNE: The authorities seem to have missed a sprawling property that could easily be added to the list of facilities, where people suspected to have contracted Covid-19, can be quarantined. The state government-proposed centre for training in mental health has been lying vacant in Pashan for more than three months.Built at the cost of Rs18 crore, the 7-acre building premises in Pashan can be effectively used to quarantine about 250 people suspected to have contracted the novel coronavirus infection.“We are aware of the property. The building can easily offer quarantine facility to over 250 suspected persons till they get tested for the contagion,” said spine surgeon Ajay Chandanwale, dean of Sassoon General Hospital and B J Medical College.The building is a proposed training centre under Maharashtra Institute of Mental Health (MIMH), on Sassoon Hospital premises. MIMH is a centre of excellence for the union government’s manpower development initiative in mental health under the National Mental Health Programme.Elaborating further, chief administrative officer of MIMH and psychiatrist Nitin Abhivant said, “The premises can be an ideal isolation facility for people needing institutional quarantine. There are four independent buildings and there is enough spacing among them so there won’t be any overcrowding situation. All rooms have cross ventilation. The buildings are ready and can be converted into a quarantine facility within a week.”The union government has provided the institute funds to the tune of Rs18 crore to build the training centre and run courses in mental health. The land on which the centre has been developed belongs to the MIMH.“The State Public Works Department has developed the building. Four buildings together can easily offer quarantine facilities to 250 to 300 people. Again, there are no housing societies around so quarantined individuals will not get exposed to the community at large until they get cured,” Abhivant said.

Title: Helpline for counselling of those in quarantine
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Indian Systems of Medicine, Kerala, has launched an Ayurveda helpline for counselling of people under quarantine and their family members.The help desk ‘Hello My Dear Doctor’ has been set up to help the people under quarantine and their relatives to overcome anxiety and trauma.Service of the Ayurveda help desk would be available for people in Thiruvananthapuram over the following mobile phone numbers 9447963481, 9495148480,9400523425 and 9142417621.A statement from Indian Systems of Medicine director Dr K S Priya said that mental issues are likely to last longer even after the isolation and medical emergency is over. “Along with preventive steps, one should also boost one’s own immunity to fight the virus. A person’s health depends on the physical as well as psychological well being, With the outbreak of Covid-19 , psychological issues faces by people too have increased and hence the decision to set up the help desk, she said.

Title: CM to natives of Uttar Pradesh: Stay put till lockdown is lifted
Content: LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Sunday appealed to UP natives stuck in other states to stay put till the lockdown was lifted.Yogi, however, asked the natives, most of whom are daily wagers, to contact the nodal officers appointed by the UP government if they needed any help. “People should follow the lockdown and not step out of homes and walk all the way to their homes in UP,” the CM said. He assured that the government would address the problems being faced by them. “People should not put their lives at risk by not following the process of social distancing,” the CM said, while announcing that the state government was in the process of setting up sanitized temporary shelter homes for migrants.On Sunday, the CM also visited the Mohaan Road toll plaza in the city — which is the entry/exit point for Lucknow-Agra expressway — and reviewed the arrangements to quarantine the hordes of migrants returning to UP from other states. Yogi directed the officials to get the health checkup of migrants done, quarantine them and admit those found infected with corona virus to hospitals. The CM even met some of the migrants and sought feedback about the arrangements done by the state government.

Title: Coronavirus: Video calls to monitor quarantined residents in Pune
Content: PUNE: The Pune police will use the video-calling facility on smartphones to keep tabs on the 1,200-plus home-quarantined people in the city.This initiative is aimed at helping police eliminating contact with the potentially infected and also save time. As many as 152 teams have been formed to monitor 1,276 people under home quarantine “We are stressing on minimal public contact for police personnel,” joint commissioner of Pune police Ravindra Shisve told TOI.“Policemen at different checkpoints have also started using selfie sticks to scan QR code-enabled permits issued to motorists for emergency commutes,” Shisve added.From Monday, police will also deploy drone-mounted cameras to monitor the situation on the roads and vehicular movement, he said.Each police station has formed teams to check on home quarantined people on a daily basis, following instances across the state of people breaking home quarantine.A senior police officer said those under home quaratantine must designate a specific spot in their house to receive the video calls from the police, who will use screenshots of the calls to keep records.The calls will be made at random in a bid to ensure the home quarantined toe the line.“It is the duty of the constables from the monitoring team to check if the quarantined person is standing right at the designated spot during the call. In case any discrepancy, the team will visit the house to check on the quarantined individual,” he said.Also, police have collected phone numbers of the neighbours of the home quarantined persons and told them too to keep an eye on their movement. “The neighbours can contact police if they see the home quarantine moving outside their residence,” police said.On Sunday, masks, sanitizers and selfie sticks were distributed to police personnel manning checkpoints across the city.

Title: Coronavirus: Pune civic body prepares software to step up vigilance process
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The civic body has started tracking the home quarantined people with a specially developed software to check the spread of Covid-19.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC), in association with a private software firm, has developed the software that will track people with the help of GPS. The latitude and longitude of these citizens’ houses will be used to check if they are properly following the quarantine regulations.

Around 2,200 home quarantined people, who have international travel history, will be tracked with this cellphone-based software. “Mobile links were send to the citizens on Saturday,” a PMC official said, adding that it was activated from Sunday.

The civic officials said the home-quarantined citizens would have to download the application and their monitoring would be done by the PMC’s information technology (IT) department.

The GPS on the cellphone handset would be used to track the home-quarantined people or the travellers. An SMS text sent to them has the link to download the application. The PMC has collected the data of people in home quarantine. The data includes the people’s phone numbers, residence addresses, their longitude and latitude and the GPS coordinates.

“If a person leaves home, we get an update on our software. His or her movement will be tracked through it. These movements are expected to show the locations within the house,” Rahul Jagtap, head of the PMC’s IT department, told TOI on Sunday.

PMC officials said a backup of the phones would also be taken by calling frequently the people staying at home. Both offline information and online data would be matched to see if the patient was in isolation or not. “In some cases, civic officials may give a surprise visit to the residence of a home-quarantined persons to check if he or she is at home. The details about people not following the norms would be sent to the authorities. Legal action will be taken against the violators. Criminal offence may be filed against them,” a senior PMC official said.

Title: 70-yr-old dies as K’taka police denies entry to ambulance
Content: Kannur: With the Karnataka government taking the stand that no vehicle from Kerala would be permitted entry into the state, yet another patient lost her life on Kerala-Karnataka border near Thalapady on Sunday. This is the second such case in the last two days.The latest victim is Pathunji , a 70-year-old woman from Karnataka , who was staying with her granddaughter at Udyavar village in Manjeshwar Block near Kerala-Karnataka border, as she was unable to go back due to lock down.On Saturday evening Pathunji, a native of Bantwal in Dakshina Kannada near Kerala border, developed health complications and was taken in an ambulance to Mangaluru. According to the ambulance driver, Aslam Kunjathur, who is also a social worker, took her in his ambulance around 5:45 pm, but the Karnataka police at the border in Thalapady denied entry. She was brought back to her home where she died in the early hours of Sunday.“Her granddaughter was alone at home and she was unable to take her to a hospital in Kerala in that condition as all their relatives are in Karnataka, and hence she was taken back home as requested by her,” said the driver.He tried explaining to the police that she was a Karnataka native who got held up in Kerala due to the lockdown but they were not ready to listen, which finally took a life, said Kunjathur, adding that such instances have become quite common at the border now.On March 26, Abdul Hameed, an asthma patient from Thuminadu near Thalapady, had lost his life after the Karnataka police refused entry to the ambulance to go to a Mangaluru hospital. On March 27, the wife of a guest labourer from Bihar delivered her baby in an ambulance after Karnataka police denied her entry into the state.This has become quite common now and the Karnataka police term Kerala as ‘corona manufacturing factory’, said Manjeshwar block panchayath president AKM Ashraf.“Even after the intervention of chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, the Karnataka authorities are adamant and this might become worse in the coming days if some strong measures are not taken,” he said.The residents of Kasaragod depend on Mangaluru for many things including healthcare and hence the Karnataka government should immediately find a solution to the issue, and the border should be opened for patients being taken to hospitals, said revenue minister E Chandrasekharan.Man under home quarantine in Kannur dies of cardiac arrestKannur: A 65-year-old man from Kannariparamba, near Cheleri in Kannur district, who was under home quarantine since his arrival from Sharjah in UAE, earlier this month, died on Saturday.According to police, the deceased, Abdulkhader, had no symptoms of Covid-19 but was under mandatory home isolation since March 21 as suggested by the airport officials. Before he reached home, all the family members were shifted to another house and he was staying alone.Relatives who brought him food on Saturday night felt suspicious when he did not respond, following which they broke open the house and found him unconscious. Though he was rushed to a district hospital, he was declared brought dead.Abdulkhader suffered from heart ailment and was under medication, said health authorities. As per preliminary examination, he died of cardiac arrest.However, since he was under observation, the specimen has been collected for Covid-19 test and it has been sent to Kozhikode. If the result is positive, inquest and autopsy would be held, otherwise the body would be handed over to family for normal burial, said police. The body has been kept at Kannur Govt Medical College, Pariyaram.

Title: Schools, colleges take the online route for conducting classes
Content:
Students have also been told they may video call teachers at any time to clarify queries

Vijayawada: A number of educational institutions in the state are switching over to online classes to utilise the 21-day lockdown period. From addressing queries to assigning homework, institutes are using technology to ensure students stay in touch with coursework.

Online participative learning has received a positive response among students appearing for class X board examinations this year. With board examinations getting deferred twice within the span of a month and uncertainty over the exam schedule amidst the lockdown, students are resorting to online classes and counselling sessions from teachers.
