Speaking to TOI, Gitam University VC Prof K Siva Ramakrishna said they have been offering online classes through the supercomputer-powered Centre for Advanced Solutions.

“The students are informed beforehand about the schedule of the online classes. We want to make sure that the students do not fall back in their academics or the curriculum and are switching over to digital learning tools during the lockdown period. Moreover, we can stream the lessons to our students across the country,” said Prof Ramakrishna.

M Vijay Kumar, a physical sciences teacher at a private school in Vijayawada said that a personal computer or laptop with an internet connection, or even a smartphone is sufficient for virtual learning. “Besides offering online classes/video materials, we can even assess the performance of the students through the same platforms by conducting online tests. We are also getting accommodated to the situation during the lockdown as well as embracing digital learning tools,” said Kumar.

R Naveen, a class X student, said students have also been told they may video call teachers at any time to clarify queries.

Title: In isolation, he spoke to himself and had books for company
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: He read ‘Deivathinte chaaranmar’ by Joseph Annakutty Jose three times, sipped on watermelon juice, occasionally read poetry of Vallathol and spoke to himself when he felt low during the days of his treatment at Medical College isolation ward.The 32-year-old Vellanad based physiotherapist, who was the first to be tested positive for Covid-19 in the capital, is back to home quarantine after being discharged from the hospital two days ago.“I made requests for books and watermelon juice and they granted all the requests. I read the book three times because there was no other way to while away the time. When I felt low and depressed, I spoke to myself and sometimes I paced up and down in the room,” he said.This man had won the praise of district collector for showing high levels of awareness and social responsibility right from the time he arrived at the airport.He had kept his contacts minimal and avoided any kind of transmission. When he was told that he was ready to be discharged, he was relieved. He was moved out at night in an ambulance. He didn’t speak to anyone, tried to peer out of the window and saw empty streets all around.He has been confined to single room for nearly three weeks; first at hospital and then at home. His wife, who is a nurse, has been his biggest support. The doctors and nurses who treated him at Medical College kept telling him to remain positive.“They told me that I should not be worried about the disease and that it can be cured. The major concern was that it could spread really fast. I listened to their words carefully and tried to stay positive. There were times when I felt I would lose it, but I kept talking to myself,” he said. At his home, he stays in a single room without a television and internet. His father gives him food and he talks to his kids and wife who are in Idukki.“I will be under isolation for a few more days. I had known about this lockdown when I was in hospital and I don’t know when I would get to meet my family. But one thing I have learnt from this experience is that you have to be patient to deal with this disease,” he says.Apart from the first two days when he felt chills, he was comfortable for the remaining days of his recovery. He has now been directed to stay under isolation till April 4 and then contact the designated medical officer.

Title: Hyderabad: Police constable on patrol attacked, manhunt on
Content:
Representative Image

HYDERABAD: A police constable who was on patrol duty as part of Covid-19 lockdown bandobust at Sanathnagar was allegedly assaulted by a group of youngsters on Saturday night. Due to the assault, the constable suffered a fracture and police launched a manhunt to nab the offenders.

Around 7 pm on Saturday, a team of Sanathnagar police, comprising sub-inspector (SI) Venkateshwarulu and three constables, went to Allapur for patrolling. The team members split and went into different lanes to check whether people were moving in the streets. Constable Naveen Kumar, who went to Masjid Galli, noticed a group of youngsters in the lane and asked them to disperse.

“The youngsters picked up an argument with the constable, who was alone. The youth confronted him, arguing that they will continue to stand together near their houses and obstructed him,” Sanathanagar police said. During the argument, two men hit the constable with sticks and eight others punched him with their fists,” Sanathnagar SI D Paidi Naidu said.

Due to the assault, the constable suffered a fracture in his left leg and sustained internal injuries. Based on the complaint lodged by Naveen Kumar, Sanathnagar police registered a case under sections 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to a public servant while discharging his duty), 188 (Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 269 (Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), 148 (rioting) r/w 149 of the IPC and Section 3 of the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897.

“The constable is out of danger. We have put up a picket at Allapur and a manhunt has been launched to nab the accused, including Irfan and Syed Fazil. All the accused were workers in small business establishments,” the SI said.

Title: Pune Municipal Corporation eyes CSR funds to boost health infrastructure
Content: PUNE: The civic body has decided to reach out to corporates and the eminent people of society to improve the city’s civic health infrastructure The Pune Municipal Corporation is trying to rope in corporate social responsibility (CSR) funds to better equip the civic hospitals with medical machines and instruments, and other basic facilities.The PMC recently approved funds of Rs2 crore for dealing with the Covid-19 pandemic in terms of health infrastructure.Donations for electronic and entertainment gadgets like television sets, computers and laptops would also be welcomed, a civic official said.“The standards of the civic hospitals can be improved with help of CSR funds and individual contributions. It will enable the PMC to give facilities at par with private hospitals. A special cell for coordinating such aid has been formed,” PMC commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad said. Hospital beds, ventilators, fans, water tanks and other materials can also be provided, an official said.

Title: Delhi Corona Update: 59% of those surveyed can’t get essentials
Content: NEW DELHI: As many as 59% of people were unable to get essential goods such as milk, pulses, wheat, rice, sugar etc through e-commerce platforms on March 27-28, while 40% were unable to get these items when they visited local retail stores on those days. These are the findings of a survey conducted by social media firm LocalCircles.This was the fourth such consumer survey carried out in the last week to ascertain if the demand was being met by the existing supply.Conducted on March 27-28, the survey received 17,000+ responses. The numbers showed a marginal improvement from March 25-26 when 61% of those who ordered essential goods online did not get them and 43% of those who went to local retail stores failed.The survey stated, “The key challenge reported by consumers is that many local retail stores are still closed and not delivering because their owners and managers have still not received curfew passes. In addition, it has been reported that the stores are missing a good percentage of their workforce as many have gone back to their hometowns/villages”.It added that lack of clear instructions to police and officials had also led to restrictions on movement of vehicles and people engaged in carrying essential goods.

Title: Vijayawada cops rush pregnant woman to hospital
Content:
Representative Image

VIJAYAWADA: Police arranged transport for two women in two separate incidents as lockdown measures have made commuting a near impossible affair.

Police helped a pregnant woman having labour pains to reach hospital. The family members could not find any vehicle due to lockdown. Finally they approached Bhavanipuram police for help and inspector D K N Mohan Reddy shifted her to hospital in his vehicle.

According to Mohan Reddy, the doctors had given probable date of delivery on April 10. However, on Saturday night she developed some complications and experienced pain. As her husband who works in an optical shop went to Guntur and was held up there with lockdown, she called her mother who lives in the same neighbourhood.

On Sunday morning, the mother tried to get an auto but could not as the autos were not plying and those who came out refused to take her due to lockdown. Their efforts to get an ambulance dialing 108 did not succeed.

Finally the neighbours urged them to call the police station for help.

In another incident, the Krishna district SP M Ravindranath Babu helped an elderly woman suffering from elephantiasis who was stuck at Pedana reach her home in Guntur by arranging an autorickshaw for her transport.

Title: With no way out of city, parcels pile up
Content:
Chennai: There are mounds of parcels waiting to be shipped off, but there are no means to dispatch them. This is the situation in Chennai Central and the city’s postal head office on Anna Salai. Despite the nationwide lockdown to fight Covid-19, 40,000-odd employees in 12,000 post offices in the state are being forced to show up at work and man deserted counters.

The employees continue to use biometric attendance to punch in despite an advisory against it from the Centre, and those delivering posts door-to-door in the city haven’t been given masks, gloves or sanitisers.

Every day, post offices in TN deliver an average of one lakh posts to every nook and corner of the state. Since the lockdown began on Tuesday last, thousands of parcels including important legal notices, financial statements and registered posts, lie undispatched. With limited number of mail vans, a majority of the posts were dispatched to concerned states/districts through trains and buses. Now that road transportation and rail services are cut off, what’s the point of making their lives miserable by keeping post offices open, ask employees. They have requested the chief postmaster general for complete closure of the facilities fearing this could endanger their lives.

Even before the national lockdown was formally announced, private couriers had cut back on services and stopped accepting bookings, leaving post offices as the last resort for the public.

On Tuesday (March 24), all bookings in Chennai were stocked and sent to the major Rail Mail Service (RMS) points — Chennai Central and Egmore railway stations. With no trains leaving, that night, parcels at Egmore were moved to Ekkatuthangal post office so they can be dispatched to the southern districts through the last truck leaving. But on Sunday, the parcels at Central were yet to be cleared.

After a week’s wait, around 2,000 consignments were likely to be dispatched through special trains to Mumbai, Kolkata and Delhi sectors on Monday morning, said a postal department source. These are mostly magazines, invitations, pamphlets and in other words ‘not-so-urgent’ items, said the source.

“But the 7,000 items at Anna Road head office in Chennai were registered posts which contained legal notices, financial statements, personal communications and other important items that couldn’t be dispatched. It’s bad that the post offices are still open despite this,” the source added.

How can it be ‘essential’ services when the needs aren’t fulfilled, ask employees. “What is the benefit in providing such facilities in the name of essential services when booked articles have no further disposal except for lying idle, either in the post office or hubs gathering dust,” asked N J Uthayakumaran, Chennai circle secretary of National Association of Postal Employees (Nape). Such hoarding can lead to important parcels like medicines and equipment getting buried in the mounds as employees will not know what’s inside them, he added.

“For cash withdrawals, there are ATMs in every street corner and in all post offices. So there is no need for employees to be physically present in the offices,” Uthayakumaran said in his letter to the chief postmaster general, urging for the post offices to be shut.

Title: Ensure 24x7 supply to hosps, discoms told
Content:
Power demand in the state fell by around 25% the week after the lockdown was imposed

Vijayawada: Minister of energy, environment and forests Balineni Srinivas Reddy in a review meeting with officials of the energy department on Sunday asked power utilities to prioritise supply to hospitals and the healthcare sector.

He instructed senior officials to be ready with teams to address supply outages, especially in hospitals. With domestic demand set to rise with increasing temperatures, the minister directed power utilities to ensure round-the-clock supply to all households in the state.

Power demand in the state fell by around 25% the week after the 21-day lockdown was imposed, the energy department has said.

With negligible demand from industry and commercial establishments, power demand fell from 200 million units (MU) in the week prior to the lockdown to 150 MU during the first week of the lockdown.

The state government has also placed power utilities on high alert to ensure uninterrupted supply to the domestic sector as well as agriculture as several crops are at the pre-harvesting stage.

Following the fall in demand, power generating stations with a capacity of 3,370 MW under AP Genco have been shut down. This includes five units in Rayalaseema Thermal Power Plant (RTPP), four units at Dr Narla Tatarao Thermal Power Plant Station (Dr NTPPS), one unit in SDSTPS, one unit in Kudigi and a 40 MW plant in Valluru.

Title: Well-crafted messages on Covid-19 by Pune police get more listeners
Content:
The police use the PA system to tell people about coronavirus

PUNE: Audios and videos seem to communicate better what monologues cannot. The Pune police have come up with a novel way to ensure that their instructions to people on securing a complete lockdown till April 14, are followed diligently. The police started extensive use of the public address system for sensitising people. They have now switched to audios and videos in simple language to tell people about coronavirus. They have sought help from singers, writers and others to prepare audios and videos in Hindi and English. Deputy commissioner of police (zone I) Swapna Gore told TOI, “When people come out on roads, we have to sensitise them. It is difficult to manage the core city areas particularly the heavily congested lanes and bylanes. The PA system was used by the beat marshals and policemen on CR mobiles after the lockdown was announced. We have now prepared audios and videos in Marathi appealing to the public to follow the government’s directives. We are also playing the audios on the PA system installed on autorickshaws. People are listening more attentively to the messages.” Senior inspector Ashok Kadam from the Warje-Malwadi police said, “We have started playing Marathi audio messages at six places including Ramnagar and Gokulnagar-Pathar slums and outside housing societies to prevent elderly people and others from coming out. The audios also contain details about what is section 144 of the CrPC and the various orders issued and what are the emergency helpline numbers. The audios and videos have also been circulated on various WhatsApp groups launched by the citizens’ group for creating massive awareness,”he added. Senior inspector Bramhanand Naikawdi from Swargate police said, “Vehicle users are stopped on Solapur and Satara highways, Tilak Road and other places and made to listen to the five-minute audio on social distancing. The audios contain initiatives bypolice on coronavirus. We ask them questions on what they understood and then allow them to go.” Marketing professional Vinod Mehta said, “The announcements on the PA system on coronavirus are too formal and not appealing because people get stressed when the same message is recited. The playing of recorded messages in an innovative style on the PA system is more appealing and effective in sensitising the public in the slums.”

Title: Govt doubles ration quota for next 3 months
Content:
Amaravati: In a major relief to the poor, the state government has decided to double the free ration supply for three months. A family of four, which is presently getting 20 kgs of rice a month, would now get 40 kg for three months and the entire supply will be free. But instead of giving the entire 40 kgs of rice at one go, the government would distribute ration twice a month that would facilitate rice cardholders to easily carry the stock home. This means that each cardholder would get ration six times in the next three months. After the April quota of ration distribution, which started on Sunday, there would be another five free ration distribution till the end of June.

“Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has already announced that April quota of ration will be given free of cost and directed officials to double the quota for three months keeping in view the lockdown conditions,” civil supplies commissioner Kona Sasidhar told TOI.

He explained that the decision to give three-month ration in six equal parts has been taken keeping in view several factors. “While it is easy for the people to carry 20kg/30kg depending on the number of family members at home, it also resolves the issues of transportation of goods till the depot,” said Sasidhar. He said that the government would also distribute one kg dal per month free of cost.

He said the distribution of rice and dal has begun across the state early on Sunday as they had successfully sent the stocks to the depots by Saturday in spite of several troubles in cargo movement. He, however, pointed out that availability of ‘hamalis’ or porters in the godowns has emerged as a big issue, as many workers are unable to reach the godowns due to the lockdown restrictions.

Meanwhile, long queues were seen at all ration shops across the state on Sunday. With the civil supplies department issuing detailed guidelines for distribution of rice and dal, the officials visited each and every shop to ensure that social distancing was maintained during the distribution.

They also ensured that cardholders cleaned their hands before collecting the ration. The dealers were also directed to wear face masks as part of containment measures. About 1.4 crore cardholders would benefit from the measure.

Title: Delhi Coronavirus Cases: 23 new cases, most in a day
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi recorded 23 new cases of Covid-19 on Sunday, the highest in a single day. No other state or union territory in the country has so far recorded these many cases in one day. The number of total novel coronavirus cases in the national capital has now reached 72, and two patients have died.The upsurge in number of patients is a worrying sign, officials said. “In the last two days, 32 new cases have been confirmed,” said an official.Of the 23 new cases, the state health authorities told TOI that 13 have travel history, four persons are contacts of positive cases and the status of six others who are natives of other states is unknown.The government said 64 Covid-19 positive patients were admitted in various public and private hospitals in Delhi as on Sunday. The reports of 369 persons who are suspected cases of Covid-19 are awaited.“We have started a Covid-19 crisis support and counselling centre at Institute of Human Behaviour and Allied Sciences. It is operational from 8 am to 8 pm on all seven days. People can also speak to the doctors via video conferencing facility using Skype,” said a Delhi government official.It has been seen that many high risk individuals, such as elderly and those suffering from comorbidities, tend to become anxious in a pandemic situation. They need psychological support, say epidemiologists.The Centre is also running a helpline for counselling in collaboration with the experts from Nimhans.Meanwhile, surveillance of all possible contacts of persons found positive is being followed aggressively. “We urge people to share their travel information proactively and report symptoms similar to that of Covid-19,” public health specialists in Delhi government said.Of late, the state government has started testing even people with no travel history or known contact with a Covid-19 positive case to assess whether the disease has spread at the community level.

Title: Tyre puncture, sit-ups... cops get innovative with people
Content:
Vijayawada: The police and revenue officials are adopting innovative methods to restrict people from coming out and violating lockdown rules, especially after cops are being criticised for beating up people. The inspector of Vinukonda, Ch Chinna Mallaiah deflated the tyres of bikes on the road.

The police said that the some people weren’t heeding repeated requests from the police and revenue officials and breaking the lockdown rules. At many places, policemen lost their cool and caned people roaming on the roads, which attracted sharp criticism against cops for beating people.

In order to avoid criticism and at the same time to enforce deterrence, the police have been adopting alternative methods.

In Bapatla, the police made lockdown violators do sit-ups. At Gannavaram in Krishna district, officials took a similar step as punitive action to restrict people’s movement during the lockdown period.

But on the other hand, another video cropped up in social media on Saturday in which the cops were seen beating up some persons in a village of Anantapur district. The cops were seen abusing them in filthy language apart from beating them. The victims are supposedly village volunteers.

Last week, tension prevailed in Hanuman Junction in Krishna district after the police lathi-charged and thrashed journalists on duties.

Another video showed police charging against people who stood outside their homes and beating up a woman and a man at Tadepalli in Guntur district. Some of the videos also included people showing their injury marks.

Title: Many come out of homes to give succour
Content: NEW DELHI: Sometimes, the worst crisis brings out the best in people. As hordes of migrant workers from Delhi, Haryana and Rajasthan hit the roads, walking towards their villages in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar braving hunger and the elements, people living along national highways came out of their homes to provide them succour.The aid came in the form of food, water and, at some places, shamianas for a brief halt before they resumed their march.The afternoon heat on Sunday didn’t seem to bother Mohammad Akram, who was busy distributing packets containing vegetable pulao and water pouches to migrant workers and their families walking on Delhi-Meerut Expressway. Akram, who lives in Dundahera, was accompanied by a few of his neighbours. “Only the poor understand the pain of the poor. These people are like our brothers and sisters and it is our duty to help them,” he said.At Lal Kuan bus stand in Ghaziabad, people from nearby villages had come with food and water. With a mask firmly in place, Ashish Yadav, a resident of Dasna, was offering puri and aloo subzi to them. His neighbour Lalit ‘Fauji’ was busy keeping the queue in order and also ensuring no one was left out, particularly women and children. “The best way to serve God is to feed the hungry,” Yadav said.Tarun Yadav, a resident of Chipiyana village, had brought a cart laden with food packets. On the other side of the road, Kamil Chowdhury, a resident of Indergarhi, was seen giving tea in the morning to the commuters.Many social organisations also took the lead in providing food to the workers. Near Anand Vihar ISBT, the staff of Nirman Vihar’s Khanna Eye Centre brought food packets and water. IRS Society in Abhay Khand-II, Indirapuram, had also arranged for food packets, which were distributed by cops from Indirapuram and Ghazipur police stations.

Title: Migrants clash with cops over lockdown
Content:
Surat: A group of more than 1 ,000 migrants clashed with the police in Vadod area of Pandesara in the city late on Sunday night. The group of labourers was demanding permission to go to their native places while the police teams were enforcing lockdown and asked these people to stay put in their homes. In Pandesara majority of the labourers are from Uttar Pradesh and Bihar and were alleging that they are not getting regular food supply and not being allowed to go to their native places either.

During the clash, the crowd of angry migrants also pelted stones and damaged a few police vehicles. To control the riotous crowd, police lobbed teargas shells and also fired in the air. Police force comprising more than 250 policemen, state reserve police (SRP) battalion personnel and cops from special operation group, prevention of crime branch and detection of crime branch rushed to the spot to control the situation.

"The residents were demanding permission to let them go while police were requesting them to stay at their homes. The situation turned tense and the crowd attacked police. The unruly situation was immediately brought under control by the police using maximum force to ensure peace in the area," said city police commissioner, R B Brahmbhatt.

Police teams started patrolling in the area and have also started investigating to find out if the labourers were instigated by some community leaders.

Senior police officials have expressed concerns in the past couple of days about the rising demand of migrant labourers to be allowed to go back to their native places.

Apart from ensuring lockdown in the city areas police are facing the biggest challenge in controlling the movement of these migrant labourers, who are trying various options to reach home across the borders.



In Video: Covid-19: Migrants clash with cops over lockdown in Vadod, Surat

Title: Corona-induced stress? Tech can help
Content:
Amaravati: The George Institute of India has carried out a research study in West Godavari district using technology-enabled solutions to screen and manage mental health and found insightful results. The research findings were published in the recent issue of Journal of Medical Internet Research (JMIR).

The findings gain in significance as a nation-wide lockdown being declared, one of the groups to be worst hit are people with mental health issues. Given that patients are being triaged at this crucial time and transport has been suspended, many might fail to access psychiatrists and psychologist. Moreover, the outbreak of coronavirus has added to people’s anxiety.

Titled “Technology-enabled Systematic Medical Appraisal Referral and Treatment (SMART) Mental Health services in rural India”, the study corroborates the fact that technology-enabled mental health services can help mitigate the risks posed by the corona scare. “Technology was used as an enabler to deliver mental health services for screening, diagnosing and managing common mental disorders (CMD) such as stress, depression and suicidal risk in 12 intervention villages in West Godavari district,” Pallab Maulik, deputy director, and director of research at the George Institute of India told TOI. “The findings are encouraging and with some training, mental health workforce can be expanded to tackle challenges posed by situations such as the coronavirus scare in the coming weeks and months,” he said.

This is important in the light of the fact that both during the current COVID-19 crisis and following that, one is likely to see an increase of stress, depression, and anxiety. While the immediate need is to address the respiratory infections, an unaddressed need is management of stress in both the community and among health workers, said research experts.

Title: Delhi: Stay where you are, says Arvind Kejriwal, and repeats his plea on tenants
Content: NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday once again urged house-owners in the capital not to turn out tenants if they failed to pay their rent. He said the government would now start registering cases on such complaints. He assured the house-owners that the AAP government would compensate them if the tenants failed to pay the rent even after a relaxation of one to two months.Kejriwal’s announcement came after the exodus of migrants working as daily wagers in the capital peaked on Saturday with thousands of them reaching Anand Vihar ISBT in search of some means of transport to take them to their hometowns in Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand and Bihar. Some leaders of opposition parties and the governments of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar had questioned Kejriwal on Saturday on allowing the migrants to return to their native places despite the complete lockdown.“Please stay wherever you are — that is the lockdown mantra. If you continue to go back to your native places, this country will fail in the fight against coronavirus,” the chief minister said at a press conference on Sunday. “We have seen what has happened in some of the developed countries like US and Italy. Thankfully, India has not reached that stage yet. But going into a crowd will invite the risk of infection,” he added.He said that even if just two-three people among thousands of those who reached Anand Vihar ISBT on Saturday were infected by coronavirus, thousands of others will get infected. “A lot of villages are not affected by the pandemic for now. You will expose your family and villages to the risk of Covid-19 ,” said the CM.In an appeal issued earlier on Sunday, Kejriwal said the AAP government had made arrangements in schools for migrants to stay and was even getting stadiums vacated in case the need arose. He said the AAP government was providing cooked food to over four lakh people apart from dry ration that was one-and-a-half times of their entitlement to almost 72 lakh beneficiaries under the public distribution system.Concerned that the city’s poor would not have anything to eat in case a complete lockdown was imposed in the Capital, Kerjiwal had announced a slew of measures on March 21 – a day before the janata curfew — including providing free lunch and dinner to anyone who was willing to eat at the city’s 220-odd night shelters, distribution of enhanced quantity of dry ration to 18 lakh-odd card holders and double the amount of pension to about eight lakh beneficiaries.With the announcement of a complete lockdown for 21 days earlier this week, Kejriwal also announced distribution of food packets at 325 schools and later increased it to 568.The CM urged house-owners on March 21 not to force their tenants to pay rent for a couple of months and repeated it in all his subsequent public announcements and press conferences.A senior Delhi government official said that ministers, MLAs, municipal councillors and others had also been meeting the house-owners and the migrant population, urging the latter to stay back in Delhi. “Our civil defence volunteers have also been making frequent announcements that it was dangerous to go back to their villages and Delhi government is making all possible arrangements for them and taking care of food and other requirements,” the official said.

Title: Amt man tests +ve in UP, civic body seals locality
Content: Nagpur/Amravati: A 50-year-old crockery vendor from Amravati, who had gone to his son-in-law’s place in Bulandshahar district (UP), was tested positive for Covid-19 during his screening at Meerut. The man is now admitted in isolation ward of Lala Lajpatrai Memorial Medical College in Meerut.On getting this information, the Amravati Municipal Corporation (AMC) has started door-to-door contamination drive in the locality where he resides.AMC commissioner Prashant Rode said that the staff is creating a containment zone of 0.75km around the patient’s house and a buffer zone of 1.5km.“We have formed ten teams to comb every house in the locality to trace suspects if any. AMC has banned movement of people in 1 km radius of the patient’s house and home quarantined all his family members,” said Rode.The civic body has pressed two autorickshaws into service to create awareness in the locality. The AMC is preparing a list of man’s relatives and who he met while he was in Amravati. All of them are set to be screened.The man had gone to Meerut last week when passenger train movement was on. He had started his journey by Amravati-Jabalpur express and later changed trains.Amravati division received a major relief on Friday when all three positive patients admitted in Yavatmal GMCH were recovered and discharged. The division had no positive patient on Saturday. But this relief was short-lived. A 45-year-old man from Buldhana who died of pneumonia in district hospital on Saturday was tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday. So, the administration in Buldhana, Amravati and Yavatmal had to remain on toes.The health department in Buldhana started active surveillance of the city on Sunday. In Yavatmal, district guardian minister Sanjay Rathod announced that a 500-bed isolation ward dedicated to Covid-19 patients will be created in the GMCH premises soon.In Nagpur division, surveillance and testing of suspects is under way in Chandrapur, Wardha and Gondia. One positive patient admitted in Gondia GMCH is doing well now. The IGGMCH Lab tested 10 samples of his family members and close friends on Saturday and all tested negative.The Gondia patient, a 23-year-old youth, is an asymptomatic carrier. In Chandrapur, seven people were tested on Saturday and all of them were negative.In Wardha district, 12 samples from Wardha, 5 from Sevagram, 8 from Sawangi, and three from Hinganghat have tested negative. Seven samples were sent from Bhandara so far and all of them tested negative.

Title: Govt efforts on to supply adequate med products
Content:
Visakhapatnam: To ensure uninterrupted supply of medical oxygen, healthcare products and facilities, petroleum products and other necessities, the Petroleum and Explosives Safety Organisation (PESO) under the department for promotion of industry and internal trade, has taken initiatives to cope with the nationwide lockdown.

Instructions have been issued by PESO to all it’s offices to ensure urgent grant of licences for storage and transport of medical oxygen. Instructions have also been given to principal secretaries of all states requesting them to allow uninterrupted transportation and manufacturing of medical oxygen and nitrous oxide, a release by the commerce ministry said.

B Ravi Kumar, deputy controller of explosives (Visakhapatnam), said, “Since coronavirus is a respiratory problem, ventilators are high in demand. We are ensuring that medical oxygen, nitrous oxygen and other medical care facilities to hospitals in the state are provided. All manufacturers, bulk storage and supply licence holders, cylinder filling and supply licence holders shall take precautions and steps to ensure uninterrupted supply of medical oxygen, nitrous oxide and other health care facilities covered under this department.”

Title: States rush to give migrants food, and some hope
Content:
Delhi Government workers distribute food during a nationwide lockdown, imposed in the wake of coronavirus pand... Read More

As states rushed to seal their borders on Sunday to stem the avalanche of migrant workers on a long march home from different directions, the enormity of the Covid-19 fight grew to include another daunting task — of medically screening and providing food, transport, shelter and a sliver of hope to those already halfway down roads to the hinterland.

Jaipur was swamped with hungry and weary migrant workers and their families who had set out from parts of Gujarat and Maharashtra after the lockdown started at midnight last Tuesday. Most of them had walked and occasionally hitched rides on goods vehicles in the hope of reaching their villages in Mathura, Agra, Aligarh and other districts of UP. At Transport Nagar in Jaipur, cops were kept busy since Saturday night by hordes of migrants asking for directions. The state government arranged for buses to take these people home, but there were far too many of them to be accommodated. Those who couldn’t board a bus decided to continue walking. Food packets provided by NGOs quickly ran out. “Since Saturday night, 35,000 migrant workers have passed by,” said a policeman.

At least 1.25 lakh migrant labourers who arrived in the state from Gujarat and Maharastra were screened by the teams of medical and health department on Sunday. For migrants returning to Rajasthan from other states, medical screening centres have been set up in Dungarpur, Banswara, Udaipur, Jalore, Sirohi and Ajmer. “Screening has is been on since Thursday. With numbers increasing on Saturday, extra teams have been deployed in various districts to ensure proper screening," additional chief secretary (health) Rohit Kumar Singh said.

In MP, the influx of migrant labour from Delhi-Ghaziabad intensified on Sunday. Those headed from the north have to reach Morena after crossing the Chambal river from Dholpur in neighbouring Rajasthan. More than 3,000 people had reached the MP-Rajasthan border in Morena till 5pm. Hundreds more are on the way.

"They are being stopped at three checkpoints in Morena. Their numbers are going up. We have teams of doctors screening them for Covid-19 on the border before they are allowed to move further," Morena collector Priyanka Das said.

After being fed, these migrants are being provided transport for the onward journey to their respective villages.

Hundreds from the Saharia tribe are also moving back to Sheopur from Rajasthan. Inward migration is already proving to be a problem in Barwani district. Thousands from there migrate to Maharashtra, Gujarat and southern states in search of work. They are flooding back now.

Also, since the Agra-Mumbai highway passes through Barwani district, those headed for UP and Rajasthan are also streaming in. Two shelters have been set up on the MP- Maharashtra border.

In UP, the Agra district administration requested the Army to help take stranded migrants to their destination. a day after a delivery boy of a Delhi restaurant died after walking 200km from the capital to Agra. Besides 10 Army trucks, over 300 state buses operated on different routes. Another 100 buses took migrants from Bareilly to various places.

From Lucknow, 721 buses ferried 60,000 people to different parts of the state. CM Yogi Adityanath visited the Mohan toll plaza in the morning to take stock of the arrangements made for migrant workers. Aligarh DM CB Singh said around 3 lakh migrant workers had so far been ferried on buses to different districts of UP and neighbouring states.

The Bihar government has decided to keep migrant workers returning from different states in camps being set up in the border districts. Everyone returning by road will have to spend at least 14 days in a camp. Additional chief secretary (home) Amir Subhani said the state was contemplating fixing a deadline by which people returning from other states would be allowed in. However, as reported by PTI, those marching towards their native villages in Bihar and elsewhere are not being welcomed back home and instead are reported to the police, who are handing them over to medical authorities for tests and subsequent measures. Some villages in Bihar have gone into lockdown, refusing entry of people from neighbouring areas.

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar has already expressed reservations about Delhi and UP’s decision to send stranded daily-wage workers to the state. Siwan native Bhagat Kumar Gond and nine others reached their villages on Sunday, travelling nearly 500km from Kanpur on so-called "jugaad" vehicles. Rajkumar Prasad and seven others who worked in a shoe factory in Kanpur returned walking through highways for more than two days. Kundan Kumar, from Vijay Nagar in Ghaziabad, said he and 70 others boarded a truck to reach Aurangabad in Bihar. "Each one of us paid Rs 1,000 to be taken till the Bihar border," he said.

In Karnataka , CM BS Yediyurappa said after an all-party meeting on Sunday that the government was arranging shelter and medical screening for those stranded on the state borders. Around 1,000 migrant Kannadiga workers are now stuck along the state's borders with Goa and Maharashtra. After the state government set up a helpline for migrant workers on Saturday, it logged 2,833 calls in 12 hours.

Kerala's Kottayam district saw migrant workers from UP, Bihar, Bengal and Odisha hit the streets of Paippad town demanding food, water and transport to return to their respective states. District collector PK Sudheer Babu said food had been arranged for these workers till April 15.

A group of migrant workers headed for north India from Andhra Pradesh in a container vehicle was stopped while passing through Telangana 's Gadwal Jogulamba district. Another group on their way to Maharashtra from Hyderabad was stopped at Patancherru. They have been provided food and shelter, officials said.

In Odisha, which shares borders with AP, Bengal, Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand, the HC on Sunday directed the state government to make arrangements in the border districts to medically screen migrant workers returning in droves and give them food and shelter.

Title: Railway employees want more masks and sanitisers on trains
Content:
File Photo

HYDERABAD: Railway employees of freight trains in SCR have complained of lack of masks and sanitisers on trains.

“Officials and workers in signal and telecommunications, engineering departments and gatemen work on tracks and we deal with them on a daily basis. There is a significant shortage of masks, gloves and hand sanitisers,” an employee told TOI.

Track machine employees have also urged the authorities to stop their work as they were being asked to work in groups with nary a care for social distancing. Locomotive pilots have also demanded the sanitization of freight train cabins.

Locomotive pilots also highlighted the shortage of sanitisers. “The locomotives, of which we take charge at various crew changing points, need to be sanitised,” an assistant locomotive pilot of a goods train said.

Meanwhile, to negate any possibility of contracting infections, the mandatory breathalyser has been done away with for crew operating freight trains, an SCR official release said. “To implement the measure and ensure no compromise on safety, locomotive inspectors have been deputed to keep a stringent check. Likewise, manual signing of attendance registers in lieu of biometric verification has also been arranged,” said chief public relations officer of SCR, Ch Rakesh.

“The breathalyser is next to the Crew Management System (CMS) machine in the same kiosk in most places. Both the machines get used multiple times in an hour. We have taken steps to avoid any spread of infection through them,” he added. In a letter dated March 27, the Railway Board stated that crew members with history of alcoholism will not be allowed the relaxation. They will be required to provide a declaration stating they are not under influence of alcohol.

Title: 780 migrant workers given food, shelter in Wardha
Content:
aaaaaaaaa

Nagpur: The Wardha district administration, along with some non-governmental organizations ( NGOs ), has swung into action to check mass exodus of migrant workers from other states.

The administration is looking after lodging facilities for the migrants while the NGOs are providing food and grocery items.

The district and state borders have been sealed following the 21-day countrywide lockdown. Still several labourers are leaving for their states on foot. They mostly belong Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Rajasthan.

Several small groups of labourers were tracked down by the Wardha administration, police and NGOs. Between Saturday and Sunday, the administration has rescued around 780 workers.

Wardha sub-divisional officer Suresh Bagale told TOI that lodging and food was arranged for around 780 migrants with the help of NGOs. “These workers were brought from different locations. They were convinced to stay back until the situation improves. They belong to different states and were leaving the district on foot in small groups. Several camps have been put up on premises of some companies, dharamshalas and at a library. They are being provided all the necessary items,” he said.

Bagale also claimed that around 370 labourers were working with two companies appointed for construction of Samruddhi Mahamarg. “We helped them get their one month salary which was on hold due to the lockdown. Health officers conducted their medical check-up at different locations,” Bagale said.

Dr Sachin Pawde, president of NGO Vaidakiya Jan Jagruti Manch, told TOI that several NGOs are providing the migrant workers bags containing grocery items. Till now around 60 bags have been distributed. “The NGOs are also working to provide these packets to other daily wage labourers who cannot afford to buy food due to lockdown,” he said.

“Labourers from not only Wardha city but from nearby villages like Selu are also being brought to these rescue camps. We are also spraying sodium hypochlorite disinfectant at these locations. Till now, all the migrants are fine and only some of them have complained about mild cough and cold for which medicines have been provided,” Bagale said.

Title: Lockdown violators have their vehicles seized in Hubballi
Content: HUBBALLI: Police here have started seizing the vehicles of those venturing out without pressing reasons.Deputy commissioner of police (law and order) P Krishnakant said 144 vehicles, including cars, were seized on Saturday and the drive continued on Sunday. “Police will be compelled to book cases if they find anyone loitering on the streets ,” he said.“It is a clear message to those who roam unnecessarily on the roads and violate the lockdown orders that police would not hesitate to book case against them. People should understand the gravity of the situation. We have to break the chain of novel coronavirus and it can be achieved by remaining indoors and maintaining social distancing ,” said Krishnakant.Despite repeated requests and caning by police, bike-borne people continue to be spotted on the roads in violation of the Covid-10 lockdown. Police have intensified surveillance following reports that people are venturing out even in the evening.On Sunday, police personnel met senior citizens to learn about their problems and offered help to them. Krishnakant said police would visit to help senior citizens every day.In the Old Hubballi area, police requested people who thronged the market in the morning to maintain social distancing.

Title: ‘In the village, my family won’t go hungry’
Content: NEW DELHI/GHAZIABAD: “I can go without food for days but no mother can see her children crying with hunger,” 25-year-old Lakshmi said at Ghaziabad’s Lal Kuan bus stand on Sunday while feeding puri-sabji to her three-year old son and two-year-old daughter — their second meal since the family left its rented home in north Delhi on Saturday. They were waiting for a bus to reach Unnao in Uttar Pradesh.Sarvesh Kumar (32), Lakshmi’s husband, is a beldar at a construction site but has been out of work since last sunday’s janata curfew, which was announced as a step to fight the novel coronavirus outbreak.“I haven’t earned anything for a week. I was left with no money and the ration at home wouldn’t have lasted long,” Kumar said. “Relatives and neighbours at our village near Unnao will not at least let my family go hungry. In a big city like Delhi, such brotherhood is missing,” he added.Lakshmi said her children’s hunger bothered her more than the fear of the infection. “Some people in our area were saying we might get free ration but I didn’t want to take a chance. Who knows how long this curfew will continue.”The family first reached Anand Vihar ISBT on Saturday, like scores of other migrant workers, and were then transported to Lal Kuan.Vidya Ram (38) was, however, stuck at Delhi’s Anand Vihar ISBT even on Sunday afternoon. “I have been waiting for a bus to my village near Gorakhpur since Saturday. I was near the Kaushambi bus depot with many others when we were asked to board a private bus at the crack of dawn. A little ahead, it took a U turn and reached the ISBT gate. The driver said he couldn’t take us any further,” he said.His friend Satya Prakash (35) is also from the same village and both are daily wage labourers. “We were staying back despite being out of work but our families are worried and insisted that we come home. So we started walking,” he said.Aren’t they worried that they may become carriers of the virus and infect their families? “My wife has told me that those coming back will have to stay at our village school for 20 days and police are ensuring no one reaches their home directly,” Prakash said.Though the exodus thinned considerably on Sunday, many could still be seen walking on national highways 24, 34 and 9 to reach their villages despite heavy clampdown by both Delhi and UP police.

Title: Waltair div to refund Rs 3cr in tickets
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The Railways on Sunday announced it would refund all passenger tickets with journey dates between March 21 and April 14. The Waltair division of East Coast Railway will have to refund around Rs 3 crore, of which the share of Visakhapatnam railway station will be around Rs 2 crore.

Speaking to TOI, a senior railway official said, “nearly 35,000 to 40,000 passengers daily go from Visakhapatnam station to various destinations. Nearly Rs 2 crore of the refund amount should be sent to passengers here at Visakhapatnam station.”

For tickets booked and cancelled prior to March 27, a ticket deposit receipt has to be filled by the passenger with journey details. The application can be made till June 21. Tickets cancelled after March 27 will get a full refund.

The division has previously refunded tickets on account of trains cancelled due to cyclones in 2014 and 2018.

Title: Forest dept to contribute nearly Rs3cr to CM fund
Content:
Nagpur: All forest department officials and employees have decided to contribute a day’s and two-day salary to the Chief Minister Relief Fund (CMRF) in view of the Covid-19 pandemic.

There are over 16,000 employees and officials with the forest department. Their contribution is expected to be nearly Rs3 crore, including 1,200 employees of the Forest Development Corporation of Maharashtra (FDCM), a state-owned company.

“In the hour of crisis, it is our responsibility to strengthen the hands of the government to fight against Covid-19,” said SC Gairola, PCCF (head of forest force).

The Indian Forest Service Association, Maharashtra, has resolved to contribute one-day salary of March 2020 by each of its member to the CM Relief Fund. The IFA secretary Sanjeev Gaur has authorized PCCF to take appropriate decision.

KV Bolke and NR Gawande, both president and secretary respectively of the Forest Rangers Association (FRA), Maharashtra, in a release said owing coronavirus crisis leading to lockdown, the country’s economy is passing through a critical phase.

“The massive efforts taken by the state and central government need huge funds to fight the crisis. Hence, we have decided to donate two-day salary of March to CM Relief Fund,” said Gawande.

The Maharashtra State Gazetted Forest Officers Association, Nagpur, too has decided to donate a day’s salary of March. President Subhash Dongre has appealed to all gazetted officers to contribute generously.

Ajay Patil, BJP leader and central president of the Maharashtra State Forest Guards & Promoted Foresters Union, besides Maharashtra State Van Majoor and Forest Employees Union has appealed to all the employees to contribute to CM Relief Fund to fight the coronavirus.

Pradeep Shende of Maharashtra State Forest & Social Forestry Employees Union said all employees affiliated to the union have decided to contribute a day’s salary.

Title: Bizmen loosen purse strings, boost relief efforts of corpns
Content: NEW DELHI: Until a few days ago, the cash-strapped municipal corporations were in a fix over providing food to the needy, but their concerns have been addressed with many good Samaritan firms and organisations extending support.To help the three corporations in their fight against novel coronavirus , businesses are loosening their purse strings by donating masks, protective equipment, foodgrains and even cooked food.South Delhi Municipal Corporation spokesperson Radha Krishan said, “We have been daily distributing 8,000 food packets in Najafgarh, 7,000 in south and 3,000 each in central and west zones with the help of Iskcon.”Mayor Sunita Kangra said over 43,000 employees have decided to contribute their salary of one day for funding preventive measures to contain the spread of the virus. “The amount, Rs 3.5 crore, will be transferred to the PM relief fund and SDMC’s corona fund,” she added.East Delhi Municipal Corporation commissioner Dilraj Kaur said that all employees of the municipal corporation had also decided to contribute one days’ salary to the PM relief fund.SDMC has also opened a dedicated bank account for the contributions. “SBI account number 39238693858 with IFSC code SBIN0000631 at Chandni Chowk branch can be used for such contributions,” Krishan said.North Delhi Municipal Corporation said help has come from multiple quarters. “Shri Ratanlal Foundation has donated foodgrains — one tempo each of rice and dal, 1,000kg sugar, 500kg salt, turmeric and red chillis. The foodgrains were dispatched to the resident commissioner of Bihar in coordination with DUSIB,” an official said.ICICI bank donated 2,000 N-95 masks to the north body. Ajay Goenka, a resident of Rana Pratap Bagh, provided 500 hand sanitiser bottles and 3,000 masks, while Govind Aggarwal from Unity Group donated 5,000 masks and 4,000 gloves. Abhishek Gupta from Clean India Ventures helped with 3,000 masks and sanitisers. A senior official said the corporation has received funding promises, apart from space for Covid-19-related work ranging from funding protective gear and help to set up isolation wards.A circular issued by Union ministry of corporate affairs on March 22 might be the one of the reasons behind the corporate funding. “Funds spent on measures to tackle Covid-19 will be counted towards corporate social responsibility activity,”the circular read.

Title: Gujarat: 34 booked for gathering to offer namaz in Rajpipla
Content:
A drone camera spotted the gathering at a madrassa on Sunday

VADODARA: Thirty-four men were booked in Rajpipla town of Narmada district on Sunday for assembling to offer namaaz at a local madrassa.

All of them had gathered in a small room near the market area at about 2pm and were spotted in the drone being used by police to catch those violating prohibitory orders in the ditrict, said the cops.

Police said they will also start the process to arrest them in groups of three.

According to the police, prohibitory orders are in place and people have been asked not to gather at one spot due to lockdown.

“We began using the drone from Sunday in town areas. When the drone captured the images of so many men gathering near the madrassa, our team reached the spot and booked them for violating prohibitory orders,” said A M Gamit, PSI, Rajpipla police station.

“Inside the madrassa, 34 persons led by the maulvi, were offering namaz. All of them were detained and a complaint of flouting police notification was registered against them. We haven’t arrested them in groups yet due to health department advisory,” Gamit told TOI.

Rajpipla police said that it has warned all the locals to not come out on roads without any valid reasons and more so, in groups.

“If anyone flouts the notification, we will file FIR against the person,” Gamit added.

Title: Sardesai praises Rane for efforts
Content:
Panaji: While applauding the initiatives taken by health minister Vishwajit Rane, Goa Forward Party (GFP) has in the same breath criticised chief minister Pramod Sawant for repeatedly overturning guidelines on social distancing and supply of essential groceries.

In a statement on Saturday, GFP president Vijai Sardesai said the panic across the state over short supply of essentials is a result of the fact that the government was “never prepared for such an enormous crisis” as BJP was more focused on the “inconsequential” zilla panchayat election.

“BJP, led by its president Sadanand Tanavade, has chosen to blame the opposition for this chaotic situation. This is a clear attempt to shift focus and shield their incompetent and indecisive chief minister who has been committing flip-flops,” Sardesai said. Stating that the effective enforcement of a lockdown does not mean starving people of their need for food and medicine, the former deputy chief minister said, “It becomes imperative that the government ensures steady and unhindered supply of essential commodities.”

Earlier, Sardesai lauded Rane for having stepped up to deal with the health emergency. “We suggest that sample tests be conducted in the neighborhood of the three people who tested positive for Covid-19, to determine the extent of community transmission, if any ,” he said.

Title: Be productive to stay calm: Psychiatrists
Content:
Representative Image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Covid-19 pandemic and 21-day lockdown are bound to take a toll on the psychological health of people, say experts. Given the prevailing conditions, lack of socialising, with routine life and economy thrown off gear, people are bound to suffer from anxiety and stress. It could also worsen existing mental health issues such as depression.

Mental health experts advise staying productive to stay calm. Dr C Radhakanth, professor of psychiatry NRI Institute of Medical Sciences and consultant psychiatrist at Apollo Hospital, averred, “Under such a scenario, crisis management is important. Focus on the goals, behaviours and tasks, which have to be accomplished. Use the lockdown to get in touch with friends, family members, loved ones and well-wishers through phone and social media. It is an opportunity to introspect, re-assess and come up with new plans for the post-crisis period.”

Dr S Radharani, medical superintendent of Government Hospital for Mental Care said, “Both the disease and the lockdown are adding to anxiety, depression and apprehension. Restlessness grips as people cannot go outdoors and are socially isolated. Their routine life is disturbed, for some, it is work from home, for some others without this opportunity, anxiety and fear about salary remains. The high chances of an economic slowdown, business breakdown is also affecting people’s mind. Overworked and exposed to the virus risk, police are becoming aggressive and stressed. The unending information on social media, whether fact or rumour is adding to the panic and anxiety. In the coming months, post-traumatic stress disorder is bound is increase.”

Title: Poor families get food in Bicholim
Content:
Bicholim: The Bicholim mamlatdar’s office began distributing food to migrants located in the Bicholim industrial area and in the villages of Mulgao and Nanora from Saturday night.

Around 220 food packets were handed over to the families under the supervision of Bicholim mamlatdar Pravinjay Pandit. He later said the administration would start delivering groceries to them from Sunday which they could use to cook their own food.

Earlier on Saturday, Bicholim PI Sanjay Dalvi and talathi Ajit Gaonkar visited migrant-inhabited areas in Bicholim and heard the people’s grievances.

Meanwhile, villagers of Vathadev complained that have not yet been provided with home delivery service.

Title: China to begin importing marine products from Andhra Pradesh
Content:
KAKINADA: Deputy chief minister Pilli Subash Chandra Bose held a meet with aqua farmers and owners of processing units of Kakinada on Sunday. At the meet he announced that China has consented to import marine products from AP. The farmers and owners told the deputy CM that workers have stopped coming to the units even though they are being provided with masks, gloves, shoes and other safety equipment. To which he said the district collector will provide passes to workers after consulting with the administration.

He advised that workers be carried in small groups in buses and social distance be maintained.

Pinipe Viswaroop, minister for social welfare said that exports to other countries form only 30% of production and the remaining product should be exported to other districts and states. He asked the administration to provide licenses to vehicles.

East Godavari collector D Muralidhar Reddy said no other passengers will be allowed on vehicles earmarked for aqua transport and said that passes will be given to workers. He said if vehicles carrying aqua products are stopped at checkposts, managements can inform the control room at the collectorate.

Title: Arvind Kejriwal: Don’t fight with rivals, read Gita
Content: NEW DELHI: AAP convener Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday asked party volunteers and functionaries not to engage in any argument on social media with rival parties and individuals.The chief minister also urged all political parties to work together to fight novel coronavirus and not engage in politics.The appeal came a day after BJP party leaders blamed Delhi government for not handling the migrants’ issue properly and allowing them to walk and take buses for the neighbouring states despite a complete lockdown in the country. AAP’s Raghav Chaddha, the Rajendra Nagar MLA and DJB chairperson, also posted a tweet against Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath but later deleted it.Kejriwal said on Sunday, “I want to appeal to all political parties. This is not the time to do politics. Irrespective of whether you are from BJP, Congress or AAP, it’s time to work together for the nation.”Referring to the blame game and the bickering on the social media, he told party volunteers and members, “It is not the time to do all these things. Let people say what they want to. We will do whatever we can for the welfare of the people. You need to give a justification for your work only once, and then not engage with them in any further dispute.”The chief minister also advised people to read the Bhagwat Gita for the remaining days of the 21-day lockdown. “I and my wife are starting Gita paath. It has 18 chapters. Urge you all to do the same,” he said.

Title: Police chase away beggars, homeless awaiting food in Margao
Content:
Colva: While people looking to stock up on supplies were allowed to crowd grocery and vegetable shops without maintaining social distance, the homeless and poor in Margao, many of them hungry for several days, were not allowed to eat the food provided to them by good samaritans on Sunday.

For years, more than 200 beggars around the Margao Municipal Garden have been given a Sunday meal near the South Goa police head quarters. With the lockdown in force, the service has stopped. Some other individuals banded together to provide food for the poor this week, but were stopped by the police.

On Sunday afternoon, policemen were seen patrolling the area in a jeep and chasing homeless people away. One of them, Joaquim Mesquita said he has did not get his meal as those serving them fled when they saw the police jeep.

TOI came across the police personnel chasing away the beggars enjoying their lunch, and to a query as to what they expect the poor to do for food, a police writer who was driving the vehicle said that the beggars have to go Navelim, where they will be given food. A beggar said that they could not travel to Navelim as it was over 3km away, and no transport was available either. He said that he had pinned his hopes on getting his Sunday meal as he had not eaten in two days, but had to go hungry.

Title: Ex-Panaji MLA, mayor go head-to-head over groceries
Content:
Panaji: Former Panaji MLA Sidharth Kuncalienkar and Uday Madkaikar, mayor of the Corporation of the City of Panaji, which is presently under BJP Panaji MLA Atanasio Monserrate have been at each other’s throats on social media during the lockdown over CCP’s home delivery system.

CCP, the first in the state to announce a home delivery system of essentials to its residents, came under fire from Kuncalienkar, who accused the civic body of clandestinely diverting rations from government stores to private stores and selling it to public at exorbitant rates. Tagging the chief minister in a tweet, Kuncalienkar requested him and Monserrate to “investigate and punish people who are cheating Panaji & making money in these times of crisis”.

Kuncalienkar also uploaded a picture of a sugar packet from Goa Sahakar Bhandar and claimed CCP was selling it at Rs 57.5.

Meanwhile, on Facebook, Madkaikar challenged Kuncalienkar to prove his allegation or produce his informer.

Referring to Kuncalienkar as “Mr Twitter master”, he asked him to help people instead of sitting at home and engaging in cheap politics. . He shared a picture of Kuncalienkar relaxing on a chair and reading a book and accused him of resting at home and engaging in politics.

Madkaikar told TOI that Kuncalienkar has been accusing CCP from time to time. First of setting fire to the garbage centre behind Heera petrol pump, then of making money from the pay parking contract, and now of diverting supplies. “He has no bill for the sugar. He’s sitting at home while we are putting our lives in danger and helping people. It’s our duty,” Madkaikar said.

Kuncalienkar said there was mischief on the part of CCP that needed to be investigated. Asked why the party wasn’t working unitedly, Kuncalienkar said “Irrespective of political belief, we cannot support wrong. This needs to be investigated,” he told TOI.

Title: Covid-19 spl parcel train to pass through region on April 1
Content: Nagpur: The Indian Railways has geared up to meet the demand of essential commodities by increasing the number of parcel trains Parcel trains are vital for mass quick transportation of medicines, medical equipment, masks, food items, etc across the nation.Eight parcel trains are already operating on crucial routes since March 29. The railways have now decided to extend them on 20 more routes. One of the special trains will pass through Nagpur on April 1. Schedule of another parcel train between Kalyan-Santragachi is yet to be announced.The Covid-19 special will start from Kakaria (Gujarat) on March 31 and reach Nagpur on April 1 at 9pm via Jalgaon and Bhusawal. It will have stoppages at Gondia, Durg, Raipur, Bilaspur, Jharsuguda, Tata Nagar, Kharagpur and Sankrail (Kolkata).“Railways is offering its unhindered services of parcel trains for transportation of essential commodities and other goods required to meet the needs of citizens in the wake of Covid-19 ,” said Central Railway spokesperson SG Rao.Both Central Railway and SECR are working out their own plans for running these parcel trains. They are reaching out to prospective clients through various modes of communication, including advertisements.Industrial houses, companies, any interested groups, organizations and individuals can avail these services. Interested parties can approach the parcel offices for registration.In the meanwhile, the SECR has started quarantine facility of 11 beds at his civil defense hostel at Motibagh for suspected coronavirus patients.“Our control office is working round-the-clock to run freight trains and is also planning the empty rake balance of passenger trains, so that when passenger rain operations start link rakes are available at originating stations,” said SECR DCM Anurag Singh.As reported by TOI, the Central Railway, Nagpur, is converting entire rake of 24 coaches for keeping Covid-19 suspects and patients. The Railway Board on Saturday has also asked the zones to recruit para-medical staff on contract basis with a condition that it should not exceed the sanctioned strength of the cadre.As the Railway Board expects increase in the number of coronavirus cases, the divisions have also been asked to recruit either retired para-medical staff or make fresh appointments.Railway guards to donate 2 days salaryThe All India Guards Council (AIGC), a registered trade union representing guards of the Indian Railways, has decided to contribute Rs65 crore towards the PM-Cares Fund to fight Covid-19. Over 32,000 guards will donate their 2 days pay. The amount is to be recovered from the salary of April and May.“Despite discharging their duties in most baneful service conditions and the virus risk, the freight train guards also have come forward to contribute,” said SK Shukla, AIGC leader.

Title: Chicken, fish back in vogue as veggie prices touch sky
Content:
Vijayawada: People ignored social distancing norms at their peril while buying fish , chicken and other non-vegetarian items in the city on Sunday. Despite the lockdown, major markets selling non-vegetarian food remained open in the city on Sunday.

Chuttugunta, Patamata and other Sunday markets witnessed big crowds. The majority of sellers and buyers moved in the markets without wearing masks or using hand sanitisers.

The state government’s statements promoting poultry and aqua food might have led to the rush in markets. “A strong immune system is very important in the fight against coronavirus. Chicken and fish are cheaper protein providers and we prefer them,” said Goli Govardhan, a buyer at the Durgapuram market.

The public ignored the announcements made by VMC via public address system to maintain social distance at meat stalls. At a few markets, police were seen controlling the crowd.

VMC authorities had arranged hand sanitisers at multiple locations and educated the public about maintaining hygiene. The health wing of the VMC held inspections at a few meat markets in the city. They imposed fines on a few traders at Kothapeta fish market for unhygienic conditions prevailing at the shop.

VMC authorities said that they will implement a plan to regulate the crowd at Sunday markets.

Vijaywada Municipal Corporation (VMC) has set up 25 makeshift vegetable markets in the city and introduced door delivery of groceries.

Meanwhile, for the first time in recent times, chicken prices touched Rs 200 a kilogram in major cities of Andhra Pradesh on Sunday. Those in the business say the price is likely to rise further due to increased demand and shortage of supply.

With doctors advising protein-rich food to boost the immune system in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, and government dispelling rumours linking non-vegetarian food and coronavirus transmission there has been a surge in the demand.

The price of broiler chicken in Vijayawada touched a record high, since the coronavirus outbreak in the county, on Sunday, with prices rising to Rs 200 per kg. While country chicken (Natu Kodi) sold for Rs 650 per kg, said a retail vendor of Baaji Chicken Centre, Krishna Lanka.

“We expect the demand for chicken (broiler and country) at restaurants, which have been offering takeaway service, to go up in the coming days as people have realised that chicken is a protein-rich food, which can improve immunity,” said Sk Madina, a retail chicken vendor in Vijayawada. “Last Sunday, we managed to sell only 50 kgs of chicken, but this Sunday we sold over 150 kgs of broiler and 50 kgs of country chicken,” he added.

“Demand for the chicken has surged and we are happy. A majority of poultry farmers have cleared their stocks fearing losses. Hence, we are running short of live birds. It will take at least two months to boost production. The price of dressed chicken may touch Rs 300 per kg in the meantime,” said K Satish Reddy, a chicken vendor and member of Amaravati Poultry Traders’ Association.

“Be it because of panic buying or more awareness, people have been thronging meat shops, resulting in 100% price rise (from Rs 100 to Rs 200 a kg) within a few days. If the situation continues, we have to either be prepared to pay more or give up eating chicken, said A Tarun, a consumer. The price of eggs has also increased to Rs 5 from Rs 4 in the retail market.

Title: Lockdown: PESO to redress problems faced by industries
Content:
Madurai: In the wake of the nationwide lockdown to prevent the spread of COVID-19, Petroleum and Explosives Safety Organization (PESO) has extended the deadline for renewal of licences and has taken steps to redress the problems faced by petroleum, explosives, fireworks and industrial gas companies.

The deputy chief controller of explosives, Sivakasi, K Sundaresan said that PESO has taken steps to ensure uninterrupted supply of oxygen cylinders to hospitals and other health care facilities. He said that PESO headquarters has given instructions to all its offices to ensure grant of licences for storage and transport of medical oxygen urgently.

He said that principal secretaries (home) of all states have been requested to allow uninterrupted transportation and manufacturing of medical oxygen and nitrous oxide as per the order of ministry of human affairs dated March 24. He said that validity of licences for transportation of oxygen and other gases, which would expire on March 31 would be extended till June 30.

The validity of licences for storage, transportation, sale, use and manufacturing of explosives and fireworks, which will expire on March 31, has been extended up to September 30 and fee for late renewal of licence would not be charged.

Title: People flout social distancing norm across Rayalaseema
Content: Tirupati: Social distancing norms went for a toss, with people thronging fair price shops and chicken shops in large numbers, where they stood in close proximity to each other in long queues, across Rayalaseema districts on Sunday.In Chittoor district, distribution of ration at fair price shops began as early as 6 am on Sunday morning. According to Chittoor district collector Dr Narayana Bharat Gupta, 5 kgs rice and 1 kg Toor dal, was distributed to 1.64 lakh ration card holders, through 2900 fair price shops across the district on Sunday.“Following the state government’s order, the first phase of the distribution through fair price shops began on Sunday and will end on April 15, the second phase will begin on April 15 will go on till April 29 and the third phase will begin from April 29. All ration card holders are requested to strictly adhere to social distancing norms at the fair price shops,” the collector appealed.At Kadapa, deputy chief minister SB Amzath Basha launched ration distribution to people at 1,739 local fair price shops in the district. “Apart from providing free rice and toor dal, state government will also provide half a kg sugar at Rs 10 and 1kg wheat flour at Rs 17. People should strictly adhere to social distancing norms when they arrive at the fair price shops,” he said.In Anantapur district, where there are 11.69 lakh white ration card holders, officials procured 18,580 tonnes of rice and 584 tonnes of toor dal to distribute to the people.At almost all these fair price shops people stood in close proximity to one another in serpentine queues. The situation was similar at chicken shops across the Rayalaseema districts.In Anantapur district, where there are 11.69 lakh white ration card holders, officials procured 18,580 tonnes of rice and 584 tonnes of toor dal to distribute to the people

Title: Actor Paravai Muniamma passes away in Madurai
Content:
Madurai: Tamil folk singer and actress Paravai Muniamma, who was undergoing treatment for age-related ailments, passed away at the age of 83 at her house at Paravai here on Sunday. She was undergoing treatment at a private hospital in Madurai for the last few years. She is survived by three sons and three daughters.

Muniamma was a famous folk singer who had performed in several temple functions. She became famous after her performance in the movie Dhool in 2003, starring alongside Vikram and Jyothika. Her song ‘Madurai Veeranthaane’ from the movie was a huge hit following which she acted in over 80 movies including Kovil and Tamizh Padam.

In 2019, there were rumours that Paravai Muniamma had passed away, however, she posted a video on social media clarifying that she was alive. She was also conferred with the Kalaimamani Award by the state government in 2019. Former chief minister J Jayalalithaa had also granted financial aid to Muniamma.

Following her demise, people in her locality paid their respects at her residence.

Title: Gujarat: Fracture can’t break this cop’s zest to fight Covid-19
Content:
Veraval constable Bhupatsinh Parmar on duty at a checking point on Sunday, a day after the mishap

RAJKOT: His hand was fractured after he fell off his bike. He was advised rest for one and a half month. But as soon as yet another Covid-19 positive case came to light, Bhupatsinh Parmar, a constable with Veraval city police station of Gir Somnath district, resumed within 24 hours of the mishap.

"Taking a serious note of the current situation, I felt called upon to resume my duty. When a yet another case of Covid-19 positive patient came to my notice, I asked my senior officer to deploy me at a checkpost," Parmar told reporters.

Parmar, who serves as a driver of the police jeep, has been deployed at a checkpost at the entry point to Veraval city, as he cannot drive with a fractured hand.

"I requested Veraval city police inspector to allot me duty at some fixed point since I won't be able to drive for a month-and-a-half. Already, there are two positive case in Veraval and I thought I would be running away from my responsibility by staying at home in these challenging times," said Parmar.

Amit Vasava, assistant superintendent of police, Gir-Somnath, said, "Parmar's commitment to work in such testing times is commendable and we are proud of him. Despite being advised rest at home for a month-and-a-half, he has preferred joining duty just a day after the accident.”

Vasava added that police are working tirelessly to ensure a complete lockdown to defeat the coronavirus pandemic. “We appeal to people that they should take inspiration from Parmar and cooperate with us by staying at home," the ASP added.

Title: ‘Sanitation staff’s safety a priority’
Content:
Sanitation staff board the bus deployed for them in the city on Sunday

Vijayawada: In a move to protect the health and safety of sanitation workers in the city, the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) is focusing on improving amenities for ground-level sanitation staff .

The VMC has hired school buses from private schools and is providing free transport to sanitation staff as reaching work on time and reports of police action against persons out on the streets became a concern for sanitation workers since the lockdown was announced.

“Sanitation workers play a key role during this time of crisis. We have noticed that they are facing a problem in moving from one place to another. School buses were engaged to mobilise them. Similarly, the safety of the sanitation workers is our top priority and we have provided gloves, aprons, masks and other safety gear,” said VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh.

“We are also providing nutritious meals to sanitation workers from time to time,” the commissioner added.

Around 2,200 outsourced workers are involved in daily sanitation activities in the city. The VMC has also deployed additional staff as part of measures to break the chain of transmission of Covid-19.
