Sanitation workers have welcomed the initiatives of the civic body and have requested officials to rope in additional workers to reduce the work burden.

Title: Workers, crew screened at Pipavav Port
Content:
Amreli district health officials carry out health checkup on Sunday

Rajkot: Health check-up of labourers and officers working at APM Terminals’ Pipavav Port was carried out by Amreli district health department on Sunday.

"We sanitized all the vehicles at the port by spraying disinfectants on them. We also checked the health condition of all the crew members of different ships of various foreign countries anchored at the port," said an official from the Amreli district administration.

These steps were taken after Amreli Jilla Mazdur Sangh (Amreli district labour union) on Saturday asked the state government to close Pipavav Port in view of the nationwide lockdown in wake of COVID-19 pandemic.

"The movements of labourers, traders and other people at the port are posing a grave threat of COVID-19 infection to all at the port and those living in Rampara, Bherai, Kovaya, Rajula and Mahuva towns nearby.”

“Hence, we appeal to you to ensure a complete lockdown of the port," said a notice issued by the labour union sent to various government authorities.

In a statement, APM Terminals said the port has adopted standard crisis protocol at both the international and local levels as per the various relevant guidelines.

The entry of non-business critical visitors at the port is prohibited. However, business critical visits are permitted on prior approval.

Jakob Friis Sørensen, managing director, APM Terminals Pipavav said, “In these challenging times, our prime objective is to keep our employees and the community safe. We are closely monitoring the local situation and committed to ensure the safe operations whilst working towards mitigating any possible impact. We are working persistently to support our customer’s supply chain with minimum disruptions.”

Title: No food in Goa, no aid from UK embassy, Brit tourists rue their fate
Content:
Panaji: The chaotic lockdown in Goa, marked by volte-faces and chronic mismanagement, is now bringing the state government international shame. On Sunday, AC Milan goalkeeper Asmir Begovic sent out a public plea on Twitter, seeking help for a 67-year-old British national stuck in Goa. The woman, a mother of his close friend and agent, has been struggling to get her hands on even food and water, he said.

She isn’t the only one. There are a thousand-odd individuals from Britain alone stranded in the state. After Goa, along with the rest of India, was abruptly thrown into lockdown, stranded tourists were left with no time to prepare for what is turning into a humanitarian crisis, and stranded foreigners are now left with no way to return home.

In Agonda in South Goa, Jewel Travis, 35, is stuck with nothing more than home-made bread bought from a friendly neighbour. “Initially it was announced that it would be a one day lockdown, so many of us went and got ourselves a bag of crisps (chips) and something to drink. Six days later, our food has run out. We need food, bread, milk and eggs,” said Travis.

Their plight is shared by stranded Brits across India. In Dehradun, 260km from New Delhi, 39-year old Jude Wight Nayar is holed up with his 71-year old aunt, surviving on biscuits, bread and any food provided by locals.

The resident of Earlsfield has desperately been trying to get the British Embassy to repatriate him.

“My aunt, Anne Bailey, 71, is with me and she is stressed out and worried about her 95-year old mum back home,” said Nayar, who works with a supermarket store in the UK.

“Other European countries have come in and taken their citizens out, and if you think about it, UK has done nothing to evacuate us. I have to say that they have been very, very slow.”

An online petition to compel the UK government to organise repatriation flights for those stuck in India has received support from 33,000 people.

With food, medicines and money running out, British tourists stranded in India feel that the UK foreign office has been unresponsive. With a week gone by, the Britishers have watched as citizens from Russia, Germany, Czech Republic and France have been rescued by their respective countries.

At 3am on Sunday, a relief flight took 29 passengers back home to the Czech Republic from Goa International Airport. Thousands of UK citizens are thought to be stuck in India, with the last return flight taking off from Goa in the wee hours of Wednesday.

“We are in a complete lockdown with no shops open. How are we supposed to eat and survive?” asked Jessica Mialee.

“We continue to work urgently on a plan to get you home — more information coming soon. Please be assured that if you have received an autoreply, my team is looking at your email and will respond ASAP. Please look after yourselves,” said acting British High Commissioner to India, Jan Thompson, in a statement to the stranded Brits.

The number of confirmed cases of coronavirus in India has crossed 1,000, and many UK citizens are worried that as the number of positive cases rises, the UK may seal its borders.

Title: Mumbai: Housing societies cook extra for guards struggling to find food
Content:
Dabba service has stopped and accessing transport is difficult for guards

MUMBAI: With the lockdown restricting movement and making access to groceries especially difficulty for those still working out of home, housing societies across the city are cooking extra meals for their security staff who otherwise depend on a now unavailable dabba service or home-cooked meal.

A Vile Parle resident spoke about how her building has even provided accommodation for a watchman within the building so that he does not have to commute to work and every flat owner takes turns to provide him with three meals and chai. Another housing society in Thane and some in Kandivli, too, have devised a rota which assigns cooking duty to different residents on different days.

The meals are simple but hearty, comprising dal, chawal, sabzi and the occasional regional delicacy.

At Dosti Imperia, Manpada, residents are taking turns to cook for over 50 watchmen who work in the complex.

“Each building has 11 watchmen who work in two shifts. Since everyone is rationing their resources, we decided to each take turns and cook for one watchman during every meal instead of one person cooking for all of them. This way, it will be more sustainable for them and us,” said a resident.

At another building in Thane, a watchman who lives in the premises is unable to buy his meals like he usually did. Ever since, members are cooking for hm to ensure he does not go hungry.

Artist Sukesha Chandarana, resident of Shree Balasinor Coop Housing Society at Kandivli (West) which comprises 67 bungalows, said the move came immediately after the national lockdown was announced. “We had a committee meeting and some of us youngsters suggested to lock down the society and restrict people from coming in and going out. So we requested our seven watchmen to stay back in the building itself. They agreed and we provided them with accommodation in the society office. We also assured them of all four meals,” she said.

Chandarana said the women in the society have a group and they decided the schedule. “While one each would be in charge of breakfast and tea, all others would take turns to provide lunch and dinner. The food comprises normal ghar ka khaana—khichadi, sabzi ,” she said.

Photographer Jui Patravali of Arco Coop Housing Society, Vile Parle (East), said this was quickest decision the residents of the five-year-old building have made. “Everyone reached a consensus in five minutes,” said Patravali. The seven-storey building housing around 20 families has one watchman, Ajay, who is in his early 20s. “We wanted him to stay inside the building to protect him from the virus so he was provided accommodation. When he told us about his dabba service being stopped, there was a meeting and different dates were allotted to different households to provide him with all four meals,” she said. Patravali further said the food provided is the same as anyone in the particular household would eat. “Even senior citizens who live alone wanted to take part and so did those living on rent.”

Title: Centre: No bar on newspaper delivery chain
Content: New Delhi: The Centre on Sunday clarified that the newspaper delivery chain will continue to be allowed to operate during the 21-day lockdown as part of exemptions granted to the ‘print media’ even as it asked for strict implementation of restrictions on movement of people.Elaborating on the scope of exemptions granted by the home ministry in its guidelines dated March 24 and subsequent orders dated March 25 and 27, home secretary Ajay Bhalla informed state chief secretaries that the transportation of all goods, without distinction of essential and unessential, was permitted during the lockdown. Sources said this means that non-essential goods can be also transported seamlessly through state borders, even though their sale at point of retail and delivery cannot happen during the lockdown.In his letter to the chief secretaries, Bhalla said groceries be allowed to be sold as essential items during the lockdown included hygiene products like hand wash, soaps, disinfectants, body wash, shampoos, surface cleaners, detergents and tissue papers, toothpaste and oral care, sanitary pads and diapers, battery cells and chargers.Also, the entire supply chain of milk collection and distribution, including its packaging material was allowed, he added. Bhalla told the states that services of Indian Red Cross Society would be included in the exemption category relating to medical and healthcare services. Besides, the exception granted for ‘pension’ under Clause 2(g) of guidelines would cover pension and provident fund services under Employees Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO).“I would like to inform that the Central government has also allowed use of SDRF for homeless people, including migrant labourers, stranded due to lockdown measures, and sheltered in the relief camps and other places for providing them food etc..,” the Home Secretary said adding that district authorities and field agencies may be informed accordingly to avoid any ambiguity at the ground level.

Title: Covid-19 impact: Mango traders anticipate big fall in procurement
Content: Visakhapatnam: The Covid-19 pandemic has mango farmers in Visakhapatnam district worried. Lockdowns in a bid to control the spread of infection has brought all farm work to a standstill, besides affecting the fruit’s procurement and export chain.G Latcha Reddy, of Tuni wholesale market, the largest in the four districts of north-coastal AP, said for mango crop to be sold, it first has to reach the markets. “We fear that the clampdown could seriously affect mobility of agricultural labour, drastically affecting procurement capacity,” he said.The procurement process usually begins after Ugadi and continues till May. “This is when a large team of people are employed in orchards to pluck fruits. They usually live on the farms till the end of the season. With such restrictions in place, we will not find labour and transport,” he added. M Ayyappa, a wholesaler from Narsipatnam, said lakhs of daily wage workers find employment during the procurement process. “Losses for the rural economy will be monumental if the lockdown continues,” he said.

Title: Plea to extend financial year to June 30
Content:
Madurai: Following the nationwide lockdown to prevent the spread of COVID-19, members of the Tamil Nadu Food Grains Merchants Association has urged the central government to extend the period of the financial year till June 30.

The president of the association, S P Jeyapragasam said that the central and state governments are taking effective steps to prevent the spread of COVID-19. He said that all the industrial and commercial establishments are closed following the lockdown announced.

However, as an impact of the lockdown, the industries are unable to finalize the yearly accounts for the year 2019-20. He noted that there are practical problems like physical stock taking and lots of small and medium-level stakeholders do not have the facilities at their homes to finalize their accounts on March 31. tnn

Title: Kerala police help 1,500 TN labourers
Content:
Madurai: Around 1,500 to 2,000 migrant workers from Tamil Nadu who were stranded in Kochi, Kerala have got help from the Kochi city police and resident associations in the city. These labourers are among the nearly 12,000 migrant labourers from Bihar, West Bengal, Odisha and Assam who are left jobless due to the lockdown and are stuck and unable to return to their home towns.

On Sunday, A Sankar, a consumer activist from Tuticorin, noticed an audio message in a WhatsApp group with the contact number of labourer Shanthi from Pappapatti in Madurai who is stranded without food and is also finding it difficult to pay her house rent in Kochi due to the lockdown as she and her husband are left without jobs. They were among the many construction workers from the state who have been stranded in Kochi.

“I called her and said that we will not be able to bring her home, which is her main demand. I reached out to my Facebook friend K Karthick who is the Ernakulam district police superintendent. He said the place is not under his jurisdiction and also referred to G Poonguzhali the deputy commissioner of police of Kochi, who extended help to the stranded people,” said Sankar. Poonguzhali told TOI that there were 230 people from 55 Tamil families in the locality where Shanthi is stranded and that their city police team is helping out more than 1,500 such people from Tamil Nadu due to the lockdown. “The police are playing the role of the first responders,” she said.

Title: IISc equipment to make testing faster, cheaper
Content: Bengaluru: Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) has given Indian Institute of Science (IISc) the all clear to join the war against the global pandemic more aggressively by allowing its test equipment to be used by diagnostic centres accredited to National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories (NABL).The clearance means the number of Covid-19 detection tests in Karnataka will rise drastically, with test results being provided the same day. Besides being faster, tests will also become cheaper The World Health Organisation (WHO) rules state laboratories should be capable of conducting real time polymerase chain reaction (RT- PCR) that involves converting virus RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA). This requires skilled technicians with knowledge of molecular biology and a number of lab accessories along with approved testing-kits. However, India has a limited number of RT-PCR instruments and only large government and private diagnostic labs have access to them currently.“We have received approval from competent authorities to allow us to work on Covid-19. To begin with, we will help NABL-approved laboratories to use our equipment to conduct tests,” said Prof Umesh Varshney, chairman of biological sciences division, IISc.With the scale of infrastructure available at IISc, the number of Covid-19 tests conducted in a day can be ramped up by 1,000. It is expected to boost the government’s ongoing efforts to curb the spread of the virus.Currently, eight labs in the state conduct about 600 tests per day, which experts say is too little to judge the gravity of the pandemic. So far, the government has conducted about 3,000 tests of which about 82 have returned positive. Experts say more testing is needed.“We suspect there are many more infected people. The only way to get them under the scanner is to scale up the number of tests,” said Dr CN Manjunath, director, Jayadeva Institute of Cardiology and nodal officer for Covid-19 lab tests.Manjunath said the government’s efforts to procure indigenously developed reagents (chemical compounds required to conduct tests) and rapid test kits is among other initiatives aimed at ramping up tests. He said with these rapid kits, test results would be known in 15 minutes, while the conventional polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based tests take a much longer time.In another initiative, IISc’s instrumentation of applied physics division has proposed to develop mobile diagnostic laboratories capable of collecting and processing samples (BSL-2) and perform Covid-19 tests.“The turnaround time for 12 samples would be three hours. Also, it substantially reduces costs,” said Prof Sai Siva Gorti, associate professor at instrumentation and applied sciences division.

Title: No lockdown on equipment, workers for farming: Gujarat DGP
Content:
Gujarat DGP Shivanand Jha

AHMEDABAD: DGP Shivanand Jha said on Sunday that movement of farming equipment, famers and and farm labourers will be exempted from lockdown. He added that the exemption should not be misused and the requirements of social distancing remain applicable even when the farmers are working in their fields.

Jha also said that home delivery and takeaways from e-commerce portals have been allowed for essential items. However, strict vigil will be kept for implementing the lockdown through police and drone surveillance.

“I have instructed district SPs and police commissioners to visit places where lockdown is not being strictly implemented. I have instructed them to first make the violator understand the consequence of coming out of house, and then take legal action if they continue to argue. Teams of crime branch will also be posted in such areas,” Jha said.

The DGP informed reporters that for total lockdown in villages and rural areas they are in talks with local sarpanches and district administration. “It will soon be implemented,” Jha said.

Reiterating the advice of PM Narendra Modi, Jha said, “Stay in the house and stay safe”. He said that about 80 % of the police force is involved in implementation of the lockdown. In all, 70 thousand police and SRP awans and 30 thousand home guards are working o implement the lockdown,” said Jha.

Surveillance through drones and cyber cell is going on, said Jha. “Fourteen cases have been registered based on the photographs taken by drones and cyber cell has registered about 46 cases for spreading rumours on the social media. Vehicles have also been detained and people who have been home quarantined are also being checked for compliance,” Jha added.

Title: Delhi government mum on MHA action against officers
Content:
NEW DELHI: A day after the Union Ministry of Home Affairs placed two senior Delhi government officers under suspension while serving show-cause notices to two others for allegedly failing to enforce the Centre’s guidelines on containing the spread of Covid-19, the Kejriwal government remained silent on the development.

A source close to the CM’s office said the government had its “plate full” following the lockdown decision and wanted to “channelise energy” in providing relief to vulnerable people. The decision was taken by MHA and Delhi government was not even taken into confidence, he said.

“The Union home ministry is the cadre-controlling authority of bureaucrats in the capital and Delhi government has no role to play. It is the Centre’s prerogative to appoint or transfer IAS and DANICS officers in Delhi or take punitive action against them,” said an official on the condition of anonymity.

The officers who were suspended on Sunday evening with immediate effect are additional chief secretary (transport) Renu Sharma and principal secretary (finance) Rajeev Verma. Additional chief secretary (home) Satya Gopal and SDM (Seelampur) Ajay Arora have been show-caused.

Lieutenant governor Anil Baijal indicated during a meeting with Kerjwal on Sunday about the actions, the source said. Baijal himself wrote to the CM the same day expressing his displeasure over the way Delhi government handled the issue of migrant exodus and its failure to provide basic amenities to make them stay back.

Scores of workers started gathering at Anand Vihar ISBT on the Delhi-UP border in violation of the lockdown on Saturday. The decision to use DTC buses to ferry them to the UP border and ISBT has been at the centre of discussion.

Delhi government was accused by UP for not doing enough to hold back migrants, a charge that has been denied. UP government subsequently made arrangements to transport people to hinterland destinations to clear the logjam.

Title: Covid positive’s kin, foreign-returned man get virus, state tally at 5
Content: Panaji: Two more persons tested positive for Covid-19 on Sunday taking the state’s tally to five. Last week, three persons with travel history were detected of having the virus.“Of the 56 samples sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, 55 reports were received today (Sunday). Two tested positive for Covid-19,” said Dr Jose D’Sa, director of health services.“Both are male patients, aged 37 and 19 years. One has a travel history of returning from Bahamas via New York to Goa. He was admitted to the isolation ward of GMC. The other is a close contact of a Covid-19 positive detected earlier and under isolation at sub-district hospital , Ponda,” said Dr D’Sa.Later, chief minister Pramod Sawant said one of the persons who tested positive was the brother of a patient who had earlier tested positive for the virus and was undergoing treatment along with two other positive afflicts.The patient’s family, including his brother and mother, were home-quarantined after he was tested positive immediately after return from Spain last week.Sawant said the other person, who had tested positive, had been quarantined after his return from Bahamas.“He did not come in contact with any of his family members. We have shifted eight of his relatives to the government quarantine facility,” he said.Sawant said the test reports of the family members of three Covid-19 persons have come negative, while the report of one of the family members would come on Monday.Meanwhile, two Covid-19 suspects, a 75-year-old man and a 68-year-old woman, who were undergoing treatment in the isolation ward of the Goa Medical College (GMC) died on Sunday. “Both tested negative for Covid-19,” a health official said.The man’s test had come negative, while health minister Vishwajit Rane had tweeted earlier in the day that the woman was suffering from respiratory distress and was diagnosed with COPD.“The woman tested negative for Covid-19,” Sawant said.Sawant said he virology set-up at GMC will become functional from Monday. South Goa district hospital will be used as a quarantine facility.“We are making all efforts to make it functional within a fortnight,” he said. The completion of the 500-bedded hospital has been delayed.

Title: Plea to reverse bifurcation of milk society: HC seeks govt response
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has sought response from the state government in a plea sought to reverse the bifurcation of Tirunelveli District Cooperative Milk Producers Union.

The petitioners – S Niraikulathan, U Natarajan, S Subbiah – stated that the daily average milk procurement from the societies to the union in both the districts stood at about 64,000 litres including 31,500 litres and 33,500 litres from Tirunelveli and Tuticorin districts respectively.

Based on a GO dated August 22, 2019, the Tirunelveli District Cooperative Milk Producers Union was bifurcated and Tuticorin District Cooperative Milk Producers Union was formed.

They noted that the GO was passed without considering the opinion of the stakeholders and without even passing any resolutions in the general body of the union. The bifurcation would cause heavy loss and hardship to the members of the societies besides the financial burden already being faced by the union. They stated that if the bifurcation is permitted, then it would affect the milk producer’s societies.

Hence, the petitioners sought to quash the GO and also sought to reverse the bifurcation of Tirunelveli District Cooperative Milk Producers Union.

When the petition was taken up for hearing recently, Justice C V Karthikeyan sought the response of the state government and adjourned the case for further hearing.

Title: Fire breaks out in softdrinks godown
Content:
Madurai: A fire, which broke out in a godown where soft drinks and balm were kept, gutted properties in Madurai city on Sunday.

Fire and rescue personnel doused the fire after two hours of fire-fighting. Preliminary inquiries suggested that electrical short-circuit could have trigged the fire.

The incident took place near Sarveshvarar Temple in Anna Nagar in the morning. Residents of the area noticed smoke emitting from the building and alerted local police and fire and rescue personnel.

Six fire tenders from nearby stations were pressed into action.

A fire officer said that the godown was not opened in the last few days due to restrictions in place. A large quantity of soft drinks and a particular balm brand was stored there. The godown belongs to Sivalinga Prakash, a native of Andhra Pradesh.Measures were taken to keep people away from the incident spot, the fire officer said.

Based on a complaint a case was registered with the Anna Nagar police station and a detailed inquiry was underway. tnn

Title: To beat ‘novel’ virus, Goans return to childhood favourites
Content:
Panaji: From Ruskin Bond and Enid Blyton to the old editions of the Indian children’s magazine Chandamama, Goans are turning to their childhood favourites for comfort and cheer in the time of the lockdown necessitated by the Covid-19 threat. While some have purchased cloud readers like Kindle to read e-books, with public libraries currently out of bounds; others had already picked up the books on their to-read list from bookstores ahead of the lockdown, in anticipation of the government move, said bookstore owners.

An assistant professor, Jyoti Kiran Pisipati, has a full-time job and a family to take care of on a regular day. But the lockdown, she said, has given her the opportunity to pick up and re-read her childhood favourites, something she always wished to do. “Reading has a calming effect on me. I am using my time at home reading new books, as well as my childhood favourites. I have old issues of Chandamama, right from the 1970s. It's so much fun reading them all over again. Next in line are Enid Blyton's ‘Malory Towers’, which I had read when I was in school,” said Jyoti, a resident of Taleigao.

She said that among the new books she had picked up to read ahead of the lockdown was Michelle Obama’s ‘Becoming’, which Jyoti calls a ‘light’ and ‘stress-free’ read.

“Now, with the lockdown, I have no access to public libraries or the library of the college where I teach. This was the main source from where I used to pick up my reading material. I recently purchased a Kindle and I am finding it very convenient to download books and read from,” said Jyoti.

The owner of Broadway Bookstore in St Inez, Khalil Ahmad, said there was a sudden surge in purchase of books from his stores just before the curfew.

“It looked like people were aware of the lockdown. Three to four days before curfew was announced, there was a sudden spike in footfalls. People purchased lot of books, mostly children's books and light reading, mainly fiction. Some foreigners who live in Goa bought books worth Rs 8,000 to 9,000 each, which is not something that we see on a regular day,” said Ahmad.

Chicalim-based artist Kaushalya Gadekar said she has a stock of Ruskin Bond books lined up for reading during the period of lockdown. But she is currently reading Bond’s autobiography ‘Lone Fox Dancing’, which she hopes will help her better understand all his children’s and other books she has previously read.

She said reading helps transport her into another world and forget reality, at least for a while.

A research scholar at the department of international relations at Goa University, Volvoi-resident Yugank Naik is reading through literature in regional languages to help him get a better grasp of Goa’s current political scenario.

“I am reading ‘Jaagaryaache Kukare’, a Konkani book by Dr Narayan Desai and ‘Sushegad’, a Marathi book by Raju Nayak. The perspective of a regional language book on political science is totally different from a book written on the subject by intellectuals in English. I am trying to relate what I am reading to the current political ongoings in the state,” said Yugank.

Title: Four power utility employees die of electrocution in 10 days
Content:
Aurangabad: The recent deaths of four power utility employees due to electrocution, four in 10 days, in the Aurangabad division have set alarm bells ringing.

Three of the staffers were associated with Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL), while one was working with Maharashtra State Electricity Transmission Company Limited (MSETCL).

In the latest incident that took place on Saturday, Pravin Bhalke, who was working with the MSEDCL on contract, was electrocuted while carrying out line-work in Jalna district on Saturday.

He was rushed to the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) in Aurangabad, but declared dead on arrival.

In another incident on the same day, Vijay Patil, working with MSEDCL Jalgaon, died while carrying out troubleshooting work. Earlier, on March 26, Alim Shaikh, another contractual employee with the MSEDCL, also died due to electrocution in Satara area of the city while carrying out repair work.

The first incident took place on March 11 when Namrata Kulsange, an employee associated with MSETCL, also met with similar fate at Padegaon. The female employee suffered 95% burn injuries and died at a private hospital on March 19.

MSEDCL Aurangabad zone chief engineer Suresh Ganeshkar said all contractors who have been supporting the contract-basis workforce have been asked to beef up safety measures.

“These are unfortunate deaths and inquiries have been ordered into every incident. Only the inquiry reports shed light on the exact circumstances in which the employees lost their lives,” he said.

MSETCL authorities could not be reached for comments. Sayyed Jahiroddin, leader of technical staffers within the state power utility, said the MSETCL and the contactors concerned must compensate for the deaths.

“The chain of fatal accidents involving staff of the state power utility within 10 days is worrisome. The top-brass must look into these deaths. If any lapse is observed in the safety measures, strict action must be taken against those who are guilty,” he said.

Title: Working odd hours, she ensures everyone gets their cuppa on time
Content: Bengaluru: Stray dogs that go bonkers at the slightest sound of a vehicle do not seem to mind a blue Honda Activa that moves towards an apartment complex on 16th Cross, Hoysala Nagar, East Bengaluru.Rather than bark, the strays wag their tails once Sathyavani Tulasiraman, 30, gets off the scooter and lugs a sack of 50 milk packets effortlessly into the lift. She goes up to the first floor. It’s 2.30am.Two hours later, Sathya as she is fondly called, is in front of the famed Anjaneya temple in the neighbourhood with her various trays of milk and curd. There is a nip in the air, but Sathya has a sweater on and a scarf covers her face. It’s her protective gear against the virus.These days, Sathya’s first customers trickle in only by 5.30am. “Business has fallen by 50%. Earlier, several shops used to buy milk, but now most of them are closed,” she says.But Sathya remains one of the lifelines of the locality. “Our only customers are residents. While we used to distribute around 3,000 litres of milk daily, it is only 1,000-1,500 litres now,” says Sathya.Sathya is among the thousands of Bengaluru’s lockdown heroes , who stretch every sinew to ensure essentials are delivered to residents’ doorstep to avoid violating social curbs.Sathya studied till II PU. She and her husband have been in the milk delivery business for over 12 years. “I joined him five months after we had our daughter. The only time I feel bad about my job is when my daughter asks us not to leave her asleep alone but to take her along with us,” she says.Sathya gets Rs1.5 per packet for home deliveries and 50ps for selling at the counter. “It’s hard times now. Plus, there is the fear of contracting the virus. I always keep my face covered and try and maintain a distance. Several apartments do not allow us to come inside. We leave the milk packets with the security,” she says“There are people who are kind and understanding. There is this doctor who paid me in advance. She also asks people not to crowd around and to keep a distance to ensure I’m protected. There are other customers who message me asking me to take care. Such small acts are heartwarming for what is otherwise considered a thankless job,” she says.

Title: East Delhi civic body launches sanitisation drive
Content:
An EDMC tanker disinfecting areas in east Delhi during lockdown

NEW DELHI: After the city administration found it tough to manage the migrant labourers who had gathered at Anand Vihar interstate bus terminal to go to their hometowns recently, the civic body is now struggling with two major challenges—clearing the garbage and sanitising the entire area.

A East Delhi Municipal Corporation (EDMC) official said that a mega sanitation and disinfection drive is under way for the past three days. “We are clearing the waste and disinfecting the public places along the route till UP border so that possibility of any further outbreak is minimised. Ten auto tippers have been deployed to shift the garbage to Ghazipur landfill site,” said the official.

“Thousands of leftover packets and wrappers had created a sanitation crisis in the area. Special vacuum machines are being used to ensure minimum human contact while clearing the garbage,” he said.

A dedicated team of employees was deployed to disinfect the foot overbridge. “Its railings were touched by thousands of people, and hence no risk of transmission could have been taken,” the EDMC official said.

“Two trucks with fumigation sprinklers are deployed on the bus terminal premises to cover both the sides of the road from the bus stop till Kaushambi side. Two disinfectant pumps and four "Jatayu" litter pickers have also been deployed,” he added.

Jatayu works on the vacuum sucking principle and reduces the contact of sanitation workers with the garbage. This also lessens the risk of contamination.

Title: 1st Covid-19 death in Vidarbha, 3 more positive in Nagpur
Content: NAGPUR: The first Covid-19 death in Vidarbha was reported on Sunday after swab samples of a 45-year-old Buldhana man, who passed away on Saturday, tested positive at Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH) lab.The Buldhana man was undergoing treatment at the district hospital there. This is the first Covid-19 death outside Mumbai and 8th in Maharashtra. The deceased was a diabetic and had no travel history even within the country in recent months. Now, authorities are tracing his contacts and have started door-to-door surveillance in Buldhana city.In Nagpur, three more positive cases were reported on Sunday, including the first patient from central Nagpur, taking the city’s tally to 14. Earlier cases detected were all from south-west Nagpur and north Nagpur areas. Divisional commissioner confirmed three new positive cases in the city.The central Nagpur patient, a 55-year-old man from a housing society near Gandhisagar, had travelled to New Delhi and some other places in North India in March and returned to city on March 15.The other two cases are of a 12-year-old girl and her paralysed uncle. The girl is daughter and paralysed man is elder brother, respectively, of the 33-year-old patient detected in Jaripatka on Saturday. They were all living in the same house.The Jaripatka man is assistant at the shop of a Khamla businessman who had tested positive on Thursday. The shop assistant’s daughter is also the youngest Covid-19 patient in the city.On Saturday, swabs of 15 close contacts of Jaripatka man were collected. The report of the man’s elderly father, wife, and younger daughter are negative. The elder son of his paralysed brother tested negative. Confirmation regarding other reports is awaited.In a big relief for the city, two maid who used to work at the house of Khamla businessman tested negative on Sunday. One of the maids is from Gautam Nagar , a slum adjacent to Khamla, and another from Jaitala village. This implies there is no community spread of Covid-19 in slum areas and outside Khamla.In another welcome development, wife of the first Covid-19 patient from the city, who was admitted at GMCH from last two weeks, was discharged on Sunday after complete recovery. With this, all four patients of the city, who were detected between March 11 and 13, have recovered and discharged.All others, including neighbours and close friends of positive patients from Khamla — businessman, his wife, mother, son, manager and his daughter — have tested negative. According to NMC authorities, 27 of them tested negative on Friday while 15 others on Saturday.Till late on Sunday evening, the NMC’s health department officials were tracing the close contacts of the latest three cases. These include the paralysed man’s wife and two sons. The test reports of his mother and younger son are awaited.The 12-year-old girl used to play with the younger son of the paralysed man. This is the only high risk identified from the two new cases from Jaripatka.The paralysed man was initially admitted to a hospital in Jaripatka and general ward of GMCH, as per NMC officials. People at high risk from these hospitals would be identified and tested on Monday.Officials are also tracing close contacts of the Central Nagpur’s patient. He along with his wife and daughter had travelled to Vrindavan in Uttar Pradesh on March 15. The man had picked his son from hostel on way back.As per the district information office, 71 suspects were identified by 3pm on Sunday.

Title: 1,500 prisoners to be released
Content:
Ahmedabad: In the fight against the novel coronavirus, the state government has decided to release around 1 ,500 prisoners from about 14,000 lodged in the 33 jails across the state.

Additional DGP Jails, K L N Rao said a high-power committee led by the Gujarat high court chief justice had proposed to the state government to release some of the prisoners to decrease the inmate density inside jail premises and reduce the threat of Covid-19 infection.

Rao said the proposal has been accepted by the government. “About 1,200 undertrials will be granted temporary bail and about 300 convicts will be granted parole or furlough up to 45 days, ” he said.

Title: Amreli police turn good Samaritans for poor
Content:
Rajkot: The poor , the pavement dwellers and the labourers stuck due to the lockdown in Amreli district don't have to sleep empty stomach, thanks to an initiative by the Amreli district police.

The officials of the Amreli police are reaching out to the poor living in remote villages of the district to provide them with meals on daily basis.

“These are people we need to take care of. If there is a person with learning difficulties nearby then we don’t forget to feed him or her,” said Nirlipt Rai, Amreli superintendent of police.

“Generally the poor get the leftover food from restaurants which now are closed due to the lockdown. They have nowhere to go. We are taking care of these people. We are also taking care of people with learning difficulties,” added Rai.

Title: Delhi: Need help with food, meds? Call the cops
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi Police has formed its own food delivery network comprising staff from PCR and the local police with support from RWAs.The markets and residents’ welfare associations have been asked by police to inform them in case someone needs food. An appeal has been made to citizens to contact the lockdown helpline — 011-23469526 — or the PCR if any aid is required.Once a distress call is received, police get in touch with the area RWA through the local beat officer for immediate assistance. A team from the local police station and the PCR is then dispatched to check on the caller.“We ask the caller if they have means to cook food or whether they require cooked items. Action is taken accordingly with the help of NGOs working with us,” said a police officer.On Sunday, police received such a call from 80-year-old Amrik Singh Bhandari, a resident of B-Block in Greater Kailash-I. He had nothing to eat at home. His son is out of station. Som Nath, SHO of GK police station, then reached the senior citizen’s house.Bhandari lives with his wife and a domestic help, but there were no groceries in the house. He asked police to accompany his help to buy essential items. “We got them grocery from a local shop, inquired about their health and instructed the beat officer and the RWA to look out for them,” said DCP (South) Atul Thakur.Police received another call from 78-year-old Ravinder Bhasin, who lives alone in an apartment in south Delhi. He had called police for grocery. He sent the list of items he required and a head constable delivered them.On Saturday, police received 1,156 calls on the 24x7 helpline out of which 100 were related to “no medicines” or “no food”.The food network has been established in all 15 districts at more than 250 locations, feeding nearly 1,32,000 every day.At most police stations, a list of senior citizens residing in their respective areas has been made. The policemen have been instructed to meet them and call them every alternate day to ensure everything is well or if they need anything.

Title: Madurai: Over 21,000 houses near Covid-19 patients’ house under scanner
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: As many as 21,300 houses located within a kilometre radius of the house of the family of three which tested positive for Covid-19 in Anna Nagar has come under the district administration’s scanner. “With their house as the epicentre we have started screening all the houses door-to-door to check for symptoms such as fever, cough or breathing difficulty,” district collector T G Vinay told TOI.

The collector said the mammoth task commenced on Sunday and will be carried out by field level personnel every day for 14 days. It may be recalled that a 54-year-old man from Anna Nagar had tested positive for Covid-19 and breathed his last at GRH on Wednesday. Consecutively, his wife and a son were also isolated after they tested positive.

The ‘containment zone’ has been divided into clusters of about 100 houses each. A field-level worker will inspect the houses door-to-door every day. As many as 176 anganwadi workers, domestic breeding checkers and volunteers from the Red Cross society have been entrusted with the task and will be functioning under the supervision of 28 supervisory officers,” the collector said.

Field workers will identify persons with the symptoms and report to their supervisors. These individuals will then be checked for additional complaints and a decision to shift them for isolation will be taken.

Meanwhile, a total of 283 direct contacts with the family of three have been identified and are also under the scanner. The collector has also permitted closure of the branches of seven banks that are functioning in Anna Nagar.

In Virudhunagar, the district administration has cordoned off houses in a three-kilometre radius from the house of the 60-year-old man from Rajapalayam who tested positive for Covid-19 on Saturday. On Sunday, he was shifted from GRH to a private hospital on the insistence of his family. Two others from a family in Anna Nagar who tested positive are in the isolation ward of the GRH. It is said that condition of all three persons is stable and the two from Madurai are only showing mild symptoms.

Title: Couple bludgeoned to death in Tankara village
Content:
Police are at the crime scene

Rajkot: A man and his wife were bludgeoned to death allegedly by their relatives in Otada village of Tankara taluka in Morbi district early Sunday morning.

Police said the bodies of Dashrath Vasava (27) and his wife Kari Vasava (25) were found from near a farm owned by Dilip Patel. The bodies bore severe injury marks on the heads.

The complaint in this regard was lodged by Patel. In his complaint, Patel accused Dashrath's sister, Vesati Mavi, her husband Patadia Mavi, and their sons — Ravi Mavi and Sumer Mavi — of killing the couple.

“Patel alleged that Sumer had an illicit relationship with Kari, due to which there used to be frequent fights between Kari and Vesati. Nursing a grudge against her, Vesati and the co-accused allegedly murdered Kari and Dashrath,” said L P Bagada, sub-inspector with Tankara police station.

Meanwhile, the police have launched a manhunt for the accused who are absconding ever since the case was registered.

Title: Class IX boys create app to track grocers
Content: Panaji: Ever since the lockdown began, procuring groceries had been the topmost worry for the people of Goa.Two Class IX students of Dr KB Hedgewar school at Cujira have stepped forward to help address this issue. Students Sohail Bhandari and Parth Sambary have developed an app ‘Goa Delivery’ in their school’s Atal Tinkering Lab , which provides area-wise list of stores delivering groceries and milk at people’s doorsteps. Bhandari said that in these trying times, when citizens are supposed to stay indoors, the app will help them considerably in getting their essentials without any inconvenience.“Stores carrying out home deliveries are segregated area-wise and has groceries, vegetables and milk suppliers besides pharmacies. The information would be updated at regular intervals so as to incorporate new and updated contacts for home delivery,” said Sambary. Citizens can access the app on www.goadelivery.glideapp.io/.“It is really a commendable effort by Sohail and Parth, who were assisted in their efforts by engineer Devansh Cholera. The duo was also guided by ex-students Hrishikesh Bhandari, Sanket Marathe and Yashwant Rivankar. All of them are part of the Atal Tinkering Lab of Dr Hedgewar School,” said the school headmaster Vilas Satarkar.The coronatracker developed at Hedgewar school’s Atal Tinkering Lab has more than 146k users and the number is growing. It provides real-time authentic, intuitive and simple to understand worldwide novel coronavirus statistics with Hyperlocalised Heatmap for India.The web-app also informs how far the user is from the nearest confirmed case.This tracker was launched on February 22 this year and was amongst the first few to be launched internationally. The coronatracker.in was developed at the lab by Shrey Keny, Niket Kamat Satoskar, Salil Naik, Nishat Tilve, Hrishikesh Bhandari and Sanket Marathe.“The tracker and the team has made Goa proud, as it has been developed by an all-Goan student team. The corona tracker has been endorsed by NITI Aayog and Atal Innovation Mission,” said Satarkar.Students of the Dr KB Hedgewar School have not stopped at that. Some are in the process of developing a 3D printed face shield for the use of the medical staff handling the coronavirus infected, Satarkar said.“Once approved for medical use, the product will be manufactured using the 3D printers at Hedgewar Atal Tinkering Lab,” he said.

Title: Woman held for attacking a religious preacher
Content:
Kolhapur: The Shahupuri police on Sunday arrested a woman for allegedly attacking a religious preacher with a sharp weapon on February 24.

The suspect has been identified as Smita Samuel Bedekar. According to police, the woman attacked the preacher after she was not allowed to start a food stall in the premises of the religious structure.

The preacher, Jagannath Akaram Hirve, was admitted to the ICU of a private hospital. However, he was later discharged.

He is the secretary of the church council, Kolhapur, and looks after the management of the assets and properties related to the church.

Police said that they are investigating the case in details.

Title: SDMC to turn primary schools into shelters
Content: NEW DELHI: South Delhi Municipal Corporation SDMC ) is offering its primary schools as shelters — with promises of bed, food and other basic amenities — to migrant labourers and their families, many of whom are clueless about how to survive during the 21-day lockdown and have been trying to walk back to their villages in Uttar Pradesh over the past two-three days.A civic official said the administrative zones located along the border areas had been asked to prepare a list of schools available for this purpose. “Hundred schools in Southwest district, including 50 in Najafgarh zone itself, are being converted into shelter homes. Several schools in Badarpur-Mithapur area along the Haryana-UP border are also on the list. The idea is to prevent any further crowding on the UP border,” he said.An administrative officer of the Najafgarh zone said executive magistrates would keep an eye on the management of these shelters. “All facilities are being sanitised with the help of sodium hypochlorite solution and provisions of hand sanitisation points are being made,” he said.Three executive magistrates each have been deputed for Dwarka, Kapashera and Najafgarh belts. “The Dwarka magistrate will look after schools in Dabri, Matiala, Sagarpur Old, Sector 4 and Naseerpur while the Kapashera officer will be in charge of Shyam Vihar phase I and Kapashera belts,” the officer said. Similar shelters will also be opened in Jafarpur, Mitraon and Khera schools.The corporation has also acted upon multiple complaints about poor quality of protective gear by workers involved in the overall isolation and sanitisation drive. “SDMC has procured 14,000 special nitrile gloves for its medical staff, domestic breeding checkers, field workers and sanitation workers. Each of the four zones will get 3,500 gloves,” said a spokesperson. Each glove will last 15 days and have to be washed with soap daily, he added.Jetting machines are also being deployed to sprinkle disinfecting mixtures in public areas. “Fifteen tankers are also continuously spraying disinfectants near food distribution centres, public areas and neighbouring areas of quarantined houses. The area councillors are monitoring the sanitisation drive,” the spokesperson said.

Title: States grapple with sea of stranded migrant workers
Content:
The lockdown has left thousands of migrant labourers from other states stranded in Tamil Nadu and vice versa. While some are getting help from their employers, local authorities and philanthropists help many after highlighting their plight through social media.

Around 1,500 to 2,000 migrant workers from Tamil Nadu who are stranded in Kochi, Kerala have got help from Kochi city police and resident associations in the city. “The police are playing the role of the first responders. Based on their need we are providing them with food or raw materials required for preparing food or setting up community kitchens,” deputy commissioner of police (law and order and traffic) G Poonguzhali told TOI.

These migrant labourers are among the nearly 12,000 migrant labourers from Bihar, West Bengal, Odisha and Assam who are jobless due to the lockdown and are stuck without food and money and unable to return to their home towns. “It is not a one-day activity. We will continue to help them in this model till the lockdown comes to an end,” the police officer said. Some got help after the issues were raised in the social media.

More than 50 migrant labourers of Vaisali in Bihar, who have been stranded at KVR Nagar in Karuvampalayam, Tirupur, got food following the intervention of Chief Minister Edappadi K Palaniswami. Former Bihar health minister Tej Pratap Yadav raised the issue on twitter, tagging the CM, who instructed Tirupur collector K Vijayakarthikeyan to help them the earliest. Revenue officials rushed to the place and provided food and water.

Hundred-and-thirty migrant labourers working in SKL Exports on the Palladam-Chettipalayam Road in Coimbatore district gathered in front of the company on Sunday staging a protest. They complained that their employer provided them variety rice thrice a day and demanded meals and roti, instead.

Palladam Tahsildar Sivasubramaniam and police rushed to the spot and held talks with them. “We spoke to the management and the issue was sorted out immediately,” the Tahsildar said. The district administration along with NGOs provided food to migrant workers from Odisha and Bihar who were stranded at Pongupalayam near Tirupur.

Twenty-four youths working in a tool manufacturing company in Pandharpur town, Solapur district, Maharashtra have been stranded in three rooms at their workplace. They sought intervention of the Tamil Nadu government to relocate them to a safer shelter. Talking to TOI over phone they said that they are staying in three congested rooms and are scared of contracting Covid-19 as it is impossible to practise social distancing.

“We share a common toilet,” S Sivakumaresan of Trichy said. They complained that they are forced to drink water meant for domestic purpose. “The local people at Pandharpur are intimidating us to vacate. The police are restricting us even if we go out for food,” says H Vimalraj of Chennai in a video. When contacted, a senior Trichy district administration official promised to take the issue with their counterparts in Maharashtra.

(Input from M K Ananth, A Subburaj and Deepak Karthik)

Title: Cane harvesters travelling from Islampur quarantined
Content:
Aurangabad: As many as 60 sugar cane harvesters and their contacts — residents of Majalgaon and Dharur in Beed — have been put in institutional quarantine after they returned from Islampur in Sangli on Saturday evening.

The development comes days after TOI highlighted how sugar cane harvesters are travelling without any precautions while returning from western Maharashtra where the number of Covid-19 cases there.

Beed district collector Rahul Rekhawar told TOI that the decision has been taken as a part of the precautionary measures to prevent coronavirus spread in the district.

“These are people who were found travelling from Sangli’s Islampur to Beed between 7 pm and 9 pm on Saturday. As soon as our teams were alerted, we picked the people up from their villages and placed them in quarantine at well-equipped government buildings on Saturday evening,” Rekhawar said.

He added that their safe accommodation, sanitation, health and food is taken care of for the next 14 days. While 31 of them are placed in two quarantine centres at Majalgaon, 29 are at a quarantine centre at Dharur. The district health department has screened them and none of them has any symptoms like a cough, cold or fever.

So far, there have not been any confirmed Covid-19 cases in Beed. However, the district has close to 4 lakh people who go to other places in search of work. Most of them work in sugar cane fields in western Maharashtra and Karnataka. According to district guardian minister and state minister for social justice Dhananjay Munde, around 1.5 lakh workers were still working in the fields or are on their way back. Following his intervention, it was decided that those returning are screened properly and are provided safe passage to their villages.

However, with the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Sangli district rising to 25, and 24 of the 25 being from Islampur, the Beed district administration is on a high alert. Subsequently, the move to quarantine them was taken.

The administration has sought the help of the journalists to keep it informed about the persons entering the district .

Title: Submission of GCET forms deferred
Content:
Panaji: The directorate of technical education (DTE) has indefinitely deferred its process of accepting forms for the upcoming Goa Common Entrance Test ( GCET ).

The move comes after the state extended the janata curfew to curb the spread of coronavirus. The forms were to be accepted at two centres - the DTE office in Porvorim and Ravindra Bhavan in Margao - from March 26 till April 1.

“As of now, the dates for the GCET of May 5 and 6 will remain unchanged. The dates to accept the forms for GCET will be announced later ,” an official said.

Title: Drone helps cops in fight against corona; 69 held
Content:
Rajkot: When the officials of University police station flew a drown over Ridhhi Siddhi Society near Raiya Chowkadi in Rajkot, they could spot 13 youths playing cricket in the society compound on Saturday night. Apart from these 13 accused, 46 people were arrested in Rajkot for the alleged violation of the lockdown order imposed by the Union government to combat the outbreak of coronavirus, in the past 24 hours. In Jamnagar district, 10 people were arrested for the similar offences.

“We arrested those found playing cricket with the help of a drone. We had flown a drone over Ridhhi Siddhi Society and found the accused playing cricket,” said M V Rabari, sub-inspector with the University police station.

Meanwhile in Jamnagar district, 10 people were arrested for allegedly venturing out from their homes and violating lockdown norms.

Title: Gujarat: Migrant labourers keep heading for home
Content:
At the main Chiloda and Odhav checkposts, many labourers were helped by police to board trucks heading to Raja... Read More

AHMEDABAD: The anxious exodus of migrant workers from Gujarat refuses to die down, despite the government trying hard to provide them shelter and food. For the first time in Ahmedabad, migrants walking back to their natives were booked for violating IPC Section 188 and Section 144 CrPC at three police stations in Ahmedabad. Two cases each were filed in Karanj and Paldi, and one person was booked in Naranpura.

At the main Chiloda and Odhav checkposts, many labourers were helped by police to board trucks heading to Rajasthan and MP.

The newly constructed EWS housing complex behind Rajpath Club is now empty as many of the 3,500 labourers who were housed in the 512 flats temporarily, insisted on returning to their residences in Ahmedabad.

“We arranged some 40 buses for these families and individuals and dropped them at their respective locations in the city. They have promised that they will not leave,” claims deputy municipal commissioner Mukesh Gadhvi.

But despite Gadhvi’s claims, TOI came across labourers headed back to their native states. Many labourers employed with companies located in industrial estates of Odhav, Vatva and Naroda too have begun leaving their workplaces .

Ravindra Kumar and Hridayesh Kshatriya were heading to Etawah in UP. “We have nothing to do here and our costs are mounting. There is so much uncertainty,” said Kumar.

Similarly, Ramprasad Kevat and Shivraj Dangi, who had come walking from Kalupur to Chiloda for almost 30 km were seen trying to hitch a ride to Jhansi in MP. Kevat said, “The contractors who engaged us for construction work at Kalupur railway station did not help us. We planned to head home straightaway as we were getting anxious.”

Vinod Bhil, a tribal who came walking 51km from Kadi taluka in Mehsana to Gandhinagar said , “I plan to go back to my home in Jhalod. Life is getting tough here and there is no work.”

Krishna Chaubey, a mason who was engaged in construction work at the Odhav fire station is now heading back to his native Gorakhpur in UP. He told TOI, “Eight years ago I lost my wife to an epidemic, and after that I had migrated to Ahmedabad after a severe bout of depression. Now Iam heading back home.”

Title: Sunday rush at fish, meat stalls throws lockdown out of gear
Content:
Madurai: Fish and meat markets in the city witnessed good crowd on Sunday flouting social distance norms even as the scare of Covid-19 is looming large every day. Police and local body authorities were caught off guard at the overwhelming crowd at the fish markets and meat stalls.

What police could do was to make announcement using a public-address system asking people not get into crowded markets further in vain. Hundreds of people kept crowding the Nelpettai market since early morning. It left the narrow street more crowded than a normal Sunday. People have forgotten everything and focused only on purchasing their favorite non-veg items. Traffic police in East Veli Street had a tough time handling vehicle movement and restricting parking.

A police office said, “People developed the habit of enjoying Sundays with family at home by cooking sumptuous food, but these days people are confined to home through the week. One can purchase non-veg items on any week day, but people are flocking to markets as it is the last day of non-veg sales.”

P Pachaiappan, a resident of Tallakulam, said that fresh non-veg items such as fish are available only on Sundays. He came to the market thinking that there would be few people due to the restrictions.

All fish stalls, meat stalls and markets were overcrowded on Sunday. A large number of people gathered at Southgate Fish market and vegetable market in South Marret Street, forcing the police to close the road for traffic movement. Commuters had to use alternative roads. Similarly, Thayir Market and Simmakkal were also crowded as people gathered in large number to purchase vegetables and fruits.

Sources at Madurai Corporation said that they are planning to close down vegetable markets at South Marret Street and Thayir Market, while retail sales at the Central vegetable market at Mattuthavani has already been closed.

Madurai collector T G Vinay and corporation commissioner S Visakan inspected the market later in the evening. Corporation commissioner said that efforts are under way to decongest the market by spreading out shops to various areas. Madurai district police have registered 384 cases for violating curfew restrictions and arrested 450 people. As many as 284 vehicles were impounded by them. On Saturday, around 180 cases were registered and 227 people were arrested. As many as 113 vehicles were impounded.

Title: Ahmedabad: Two head constables fight over lemons thrown in gallery
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Cross-complaints were registered at Danilimda police station against two head constables for quarrelling and threatening each other. In the first complaint, Gayatri Chudasama, wife of head constable Upendrasinh Chudasama of Danilimda police line, stated that someone threw lemons in their gallery to scare them.

In the second complaint, Radha Thori, wife of head constable Raman Thori, stated that Chudasama had been facing problem in parking his car and hence he started abusing them and threatened to beat them.

Gayatri has mentioned in her FIR that when her husband came home at about 1.30am, she came out and saw lemons in her gallery. At that time, she saw Radha standing in her gallery.

She stated that Radha went inside and then her husband Raman Thori came out and started abusing them. On the other hand Radha in her FIR made similar allegations against Chudasama.

Title: Three railway stations offer meals to migrants
Content: NEW DELHI: Northern Railway and the Railway Protection Force (RPF) have started a food distribution drive at three major railway stations in Delhi — New Delhi, Nizamuddin and Shakurbasti — with 4,000 meals distributed on Saturday and Sunday.A railway official said that the markings with proper spacing have been made on the ground for effective social distancing while queueing up. At present, food is only being distributed at these stations between 12 pm to 1 pm.“Those standing in a queue stand in marked spaces on the ground until their turn arrives. Sanitisers are being used as well and all RPF personnel deployed have masks too. We will continue to distribute 2,000 meals every day,” said S C Jain, divisional railway manager (DRM), Delhi division.An official said the food is being prepared in a hygienic base kitchen of the IRCTC and it is being distributed free of cost. “This is being done in order to feed the daily wage labourers and the homeless that are still in the city but may not have access to food. A lot of them who stay near railway stations can now get access to food. We are also spreading the word so people can reach here,” said a senior railway official. The official added that Anand Vihar railway station was also being considered as an addition to this scheme.In addition to freight trains, Northern Railways on Sunday said it had also started running parcel special trains that will be carrying small quantities of essential items like dairy products, medical equipment, medicines and groceries.

Title: Ex-Panaji MLA, mayor go head-to-head over groceries
Content:
Panaji: Former Panaji MLA Sidharth Kuncalienkar and Uday Madkaikar, mayor of the Corporation of the City of Panaji, which is presently under BJP Panaji MLA Atanasio Monserrate have been at each other’s throats on social media during the lockdown over CCP’s home delivery system.

CCP, the first in the state to announce a home delivery system of essentials to its residents, came under fire from Kuncalienkar, who accused the civic body of clandestinely diverting rations from government stores to private stores and selling it to public at exorbitant rates. Tagging the chief minister in a tweet, Kuncalienkar requested him and Monserrate to “investigate and punish people who are cheating Panaji & making money in these times of crisis”.

Kuncalienkar also uploaded a picture of a sugar packet from Goa Sahakar Bhandar and claimed CCP was selling it at Rs 57.5.

Meanwhile, on Facebook, Madkaikar challenged Kuncalienkar to prove his allegation or produce his informer.

Referring to Kuncalienkar as “Mr Twitter master”, he asked him to help people instead of sitting at home and engaging in cheap politics. . He shared a picture of Kuncalienkar relaxing on a chair and reading a book and accused him of resting at home and engaging in politics.

Madkaikar told TOI that Kuncalienkar has been accusing CCP from time to time. First of setting fire to the garbage centre behind Heera petrol pump, then of making money from the pay parking contract, and now of diverting supplies. “He has no bill for the sugar. He’s sitting at home while we are putting our lives in danger and helping people. It’s our duty,” Madkaikar said.

Kuncalienkar said there was mischief on the part of CCP that needed to be investigated. Asked why the party wasn’t working unitedly, Kuncalienkar said “Irrespective of political belief, we cannot support wrong. This needs to be investigated,” he told TOI.

Title: Man dies of Covid-19 in Buldhana sans travel, contact history
Content:
Nagpur: Panic gripped Buldhana town as soon as people came to know on Sunday that a 45-year-old man who died in the district hospital on Saturday had tested positive for Covid-19. The administration swung into action and process of contact tracing and active surveillance began immediately on Sunday. Entire Buldhana city has been taken under active surveillance.

The 45-year-old man from Buldhana, who died of pneumonia in District Hospital of Buldhana on Saturday, was detected positive for Covid-19 on Sunday. This is the first Covid-19 death out of Mumbai, and 8th death in Maharashtra. The man was a diabetic and has no history of travel even within the country in recent months.

“This patient was suffering from pneumonia. He was admitted in local private hospital in Buldhana from March 24 to 27. As his condition deteriorated on Saturday, he was brought to Buldhana District Hospital, where he died during treatment,” said Dr Riyaz Faruqui, Deputy Director of Health Services (DDHS), Akola division, under which Buldhana district falls.

As his symptoms were of Covid-19, doctors had immediately collected his swab samples after he was admitted in the isolation ward. The samples were sent to Nagpur IGGMCH Lab facility. The patient had died within two hours of treatment starting.

“In reports received on Sunday, the person tested positive for Covid-19. We have started active surveillance process. All his family members, contacts, and staff of the private hospital where he was being treated have been called for Covid-19 tests,” said Buldhana civil surgeon Dr Premchand Pandit.

The burial of the deceased was performed on Sunday afternoon and even after repeated instructions by health authorities, about 100 people attended the burial. Authorities have decided to conduct thermal screening of all of them. The private hospital where the man was admitted has been sealed, and all staff members and sanitary workers in this hospital have been asked to get themselves tested in the government hospital. All these contacts including family members will be screened.

A senior official of the health department said that the person could have been infected by an asymptomatic carrier of coronavirus. “The person may not have travelled himself, but due to his diabetic nature he was vulnerable to coronavirus. Any asymptomatic carrier could have infected him. This means, there are asymptomatic carriers in Buldhana. Only surveillance and contact tracing will clarify who they are,” said the official.

On March 14, a 71-year-old man had died in Buldhana of pneumonia and his samples had tested negative for Covid-19. But, there are many residents in Buldhana who had gone to Saudi Arabia on a religious trip. Some of them could be asymptomatic carriers. The deceased may have come into close contact with some of them. Being diabetic from several years, he was severely affected by the coronavirus.

NO TRAVEL HISTORY, NO APPARENT CONTACT

45-year-old man was diabetic

He had not travelled anywhere recently

Doctors believe he must have come into contact with some asymptomatic carrier of coronavirus

Being diabetic, he got infected easily and developed Covid-19

Several residents of Buldhana recently travelled to Saudi Arabia on a religious trip

Some of them could be asymptomatic carriers

Now, administration has taken entire Buldhana city into active surveillance

Contact tracing of deceased has started

Title: Struggling cotton industry braces for uncertain future
Content:
Aurangabad: The ongoing lockdown and the absence of a fresh stimulus package so far could severely impact the agricultural sector, and especially the cotton industry, farmers’ groups have warned.

There have been no restrictions on transport or sale of farms produce like fruits, vegetables, pulses . But farmers said they have been hit by losses because of the curbs on movement of buyers. Exports have been shut and many of the Agriculture Market Produce Committee markets have closed.

According to Kailash Tawar of the Shetkari Sanghatna, the farming community has suffered a severe blow. He also slammed the government for not declaring a stimulus package.

“The only announcement for farmers was the advance payment of Rs 2,000 under the PM-Kisan scheme. But this works out to only Rs 500 a month for farmers. Also, not all farmers are covered under the scheme,” he said. The Shetkari Sanghatna has demanded that the state pay a compensation of Rs 25,000 per hectare.

Cotton farmers have been particularly affected. Mahesh Daga, the MD of Cottonguru LLP, which works with 50,000 farmers across India to improve yield and quality, said because cotton is a non-essential commodity, farmers growing the crop are extremely worried.

“As much as 15% of cotton produce, which includes the harvested and the non-harvested crop from the last season, is currently stuck with farmers as they are not able to transport or sell it. Limited farming operations to meet the minimum support price were on until last week. But they too have stopped now,” Daga said.

As far as the forthcoming kharif season is concerned, the production of cotton — a cash crop — remains in limbo because the seed packaging operations have ground to a halt.

A key amendment in a state government circular from March 27 includes logistics and packaging of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides in the list of essential commodities.

. “Retail of seeds was allowed, but there was no provision to manufacture or package these seeds. After Cottonguru made a presentation before the agriculture commissioner, the government allowed these processes in the seed industry ,” Daga said.

The byproducts of cotton ginning are essential commodities with multiple uses.

Title: 31 fever clinics to start operating from today
Content:
Bengaluru: The Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) is set to open 31 fever clinics at its existing primary health centres (PHCs) on Monday.

Those suffering from symptoms such as fever, cold and cough can approach these clinics where doctors will decide whether they are suspected Covid-19 cases. This will enable Covid Rapid Response (CRR) teams to screen and triage suspected cases. Those with international travel history can access these clinics and get themselves tested, D Ravi Surpur, special commissioner, health, BBMP, said.

The clinics will have one doctor, staff nurse and security personnel and will function from 9am and 4:30pm.

Title: Very few vendors turn up at decentralised veg markets
Content:
Madurai: The effort taken by Madurai corporation to decentralize the central vegetable market at Mattuthavani by spreading it to nine places in the city for better crowd management in the wake of the Covid-19 scare, met with tepid response from vendors.

Hardly a few turned at the proposed places on Sunday despite a meeting involving representatives of vendors from central market chaired by corporation commissioner S Visakan at the corporation main building on Saturday. The shops were distributed as follows: 100 shops each for Melamadai Signal - Aavin Signal road in KK Nagar, Race Course stadium road, Mattuthavani-Surveyor Colony Road, 75 shops each at Armed Reserve Ground, Krishnan Temple ground in Iyyer Bungalow and 50 shops each at southern part of Teppakulam and Harveypatti, 25 shops at TB Road-Railway Colony compound wall and Fenner Junction-Muthaiah Temple in Kochadai.

There were only a few vendors at Teppakulam, around 10 at KK Nagar and less than five at Race Course stadium road. A large number of people who had thronged the markets to purchase vegetables for the upcoming week had to return empty-handed. The very little quantity of vegetables brought to these markets were sold off quickly.

“I came here after seeing news of decentralisation of central vegetable market in newspapers. But there are hardly any vegetables left to buy. Police deployment was made. There were markings too for each shop mentioning the numbers for the entire stretch, but vendors did not turn up. I am leaving without purchasing anything,” V Mariappan, a resident of Viraganoor said.

An official of Madurai corporation said the vendors did not turn up as they did not get adequate stock. They will start sales at these markets in a day or two. They have no choice since retail sale has been closed at the central market. They are considering closing down of Thayir market and South Marret Street markets too for better crowd management.

Title: Overseas students take GTU’s e-class
Content:
Ahmedabad: Gujarat Technological University (GTU) has received an overwhelming response from participants in India as well as abroad for its online lecture series, the varsity claimed in a media statement.

After the Centre announced the country-wide lockdown till April 14 due to the fast-spreading COVID-19 pandemic, the varsity started holding online lectures for all its affiliated colleges. Also, experts from the GTU Graduate School of Engineering, Pharmacy and Management conducted online lectures using various social media platforms.

Students from at least 10 Indian states and from countries including Kenya, South Africa and USparticipated in the lecture series. In all, about 750 participants have participated so far, according to the varsity.

Till now, about 70 lectures have been conducted by the GTU. Dr Sanjay Chauhan, a professor at the GTU’s pharmacy department, spoke about drug control and regulation which received a very good response, read the statement.

Earlier this week, the GTU decided to defer all summer exams, indefinitely. The varsity, which had earlier announced the exam schedule on March 7, announced to postpone all theory and practical summer 2020 examinations for all the courses as a precautionary measure against the COVID-19.

Title: Labourer slits fellow worker’s throat, held
Content:
Rajkot: A labourer was arrested on Saturday night for allegedly slitting the throat of a fellow worker in Shaktinagar labour colony in Nana Kapaya village of Mundra taluka in Kutch district on Saturday evening.

Police said the accused, identified as Karmapal Bhagat, had murdered Karma Urav (22).

"Bhagat allegedly had an affair with the sister of Urav, which Urav did not like. On the fateful evening when Urav went to take up the issue with Bhagat, an altercation broke out between them, following which Bhagat allegedly flashed out a knife and slit the throat of Urav," said D K Patel, inspector with Mundra police station.

Urav, who was also stabbed in his chest and back, died on the spot. The police arrested Bhagat from his cabin in the labour colony late on Saturday night.

Title: Ahmedabad: Highways sealed, migrants use unguarded minor roads
Content:
Migrant workers, especially those working in Surendranagar, Bhavnagar and Morbi districts, are using interior ... Read More

AHMEDABAD: The Ahmedabad district administration, which is attempting to stop the exodus of migrant workers, is faced with a new challenge. Migrant workers, especially those working in Surendranagar, Bhavnagar and Morbi districts, are using interior roads of villages to pass through, as the highways are manned by cops.

District collector K K Nirala said that while the highways connecting Ahmedabad district to other neighbouring districts are manned by police, migrant workers are using interior roads to pass through the district. “People working in Surendranagar, Bhavnagar and Morbi districts are using interior roads to pass through Ahmedabad district and reach their native places in other states and districts of Gujarat. They are travelling through fields and village roads. It is a challenge to track such persons, but this exodus will be brought under control within a day,” the collector said.

The administration has set up shelters in every taluka of the district. About 25 shelters have been set up in rural areas, while the AMC and collectorate have jointly set up shelters in Ahmedabad city as well. “The major influx of migrant workers is from the western side, and since cops are posted only along the main routes, we will accommodate them in shelter homes,” Nirala said.

Nirala said that the immediate aim is to stop workers wherever they are. “Once we can contain movement of workers along the interior routes, we will arrive at the number of people who have been halted in each district,” Nirala said. He added that since the workers are extremely well connected through mobile phones, they appear to be advising each other on routes that they can take to reach their native places.

Title: Kolkata Coronavirus Update: Test capacity set to double in a week
Content: KOLKATA: With two private hospitals — Apollo Gleneagles Hospital and Tata Medical Centre — receiving the nod to test samples of Covid-19 suspects, the city’s capacity to test samples is set to double in the next one week. While NICED, IPGMER and North Bengal and Midnapore Medical Colleges are already conducting tests, School of Tropical Medicine in Kolkata is set to start on Monday.
