“For the past three-four days, nobody has come to pick up garbage. Residents are leaving their waste, tied up in polybags , in front of their homes, and it’s been piling up,” said Vidya Deshpande , a member of DLF-3 RWA.

Other residents said they are extremely anxious about the matter as these aren’t normal times, since the country is battling with a pandemic. “There is a chance of the spread of vector-borne diseases if the garbage isn’t cleared soon,” a resident said.

Officials from DLF, the developer, said garbage collection was handed over to MCG and Ecogreen. “We are responsible for sewage and drainage work, and that we are taking care of. Also, the sweeping of roads had become a challenge as a few workers haven’t been reporting to work since the lockdown. We’ll resume it on Sunday,” a DLF official said.

Ecogreen officials said new drivers are being called, however, and services will be restored from Monday onwards.

Meanwhile, MCG said it will send its workers to clean the area till the time Ecogreen restores its services. “We’re facing this challenge because workers of the third party that was looking into waste collection have left,” an MCG official said.

“We’ve deployed our staff and vehicles to clean up the area. We’re also distributing food and preventive gear to the workers so that they don’t shy away from work or try to leave the city,” the official added.

Title: BS Yediyurappa: Karnataka CM BS Yediyurappa promises shelter for stranded workers
Content:
BS Yediyurappa, Karnataka chief minister (File Photo)

BENGALURU: Karnataka chief minister BS Yediyurappa on Sunday said the government would arrange shelter for those stranded at the state borders and provide facilities to conduct medical examination on them.

About 1,000 migrant Kannadiga labourers are stranded along the Goa and Maharashtra borders with Karnataka. During an all-party meeting on Covid-19 pandemic chaired by the CM, the opposition parties attacked the government for its failure to provide transportation to migrant labourers from Karnataka working in other states.

Citing the home ministry's directive that the stranded migrants should stay put, Yediyurappa said the government, instead of making arrangements to bring them back, would ensure required amenities for them till the coronavirus crisis defuses. "These are difficult times," the CM said.

A lucky few managed to reach home hours before the Centre issued the order. The Karnataka government arranged 70 buses to ferry 3,000 migrant labourers to their hometowns in Maharashtra and Rajasthan.

In Nangali of Kolar district, Andhra Pradesh sent 50 buses to pick up 1,400 stranded fishermen. The move came after it got the fishermen, who worked in Mangaluru and Udupi, medically examined and found them fit.

Title: MCG’s community centres turn into relief camps for migrants
Content:
Gurgaon: MCG has turned its 17 community centres into relief centres to provide water, food and shelter to the migrant labourers and underprivileged during the ongoing lockdown period.

An MCG official said, these community centres can accommodate nearly 3,000 people. “The priority will be given to the underprivileged, however, in cases where house owners or landlords have asked those under home quarantine to vacate can also take shelter in these relief centres,” the official said.

The Haryana Shahari Vikas Pradhikaran (HSVP) officials will visit these centres and submit daily report on the condition.

“We’ve made the facility available and some people stayed in around six community centres on Saturday. We’ve made arrangements for their stay and food and collaborated with Red Cross society,” said Jitender Yadav, administrator, HSVP told TOI.

These community centres are located in Carterpuri, Dundahera village, Sirhaul village, Sukhrali village, Basai, Dhanwapur village, Sector 15 Part-I & II, Sector 10A, Sector 31, Kherki Daula, Badshapur, Sector 38, Kanhai village, Sector 45, Chakkarpur and relief camp at Pachgaon.

Title: Patiala village of Covid-19 patient sealed, 14 of family test negative
Content: SHAMBHU (PATIALA): Patiala district administration sealed Ramnagar Sainiyan village on Sunday, a day after a 21-year-old man from there tested positive for coronavirus at Haryana’s Ambala city civil hospital.Health teams shifted 14 family members of the patient to Government Rajindra Hospital in Patiala and placed them in isolation. Their samples tested negative for coronavirus, said Patiala civil surgeon Dr Harish Malhotra Patiala deputy commissioner Kumar Amit and SSP Mandeep Singh Sidhu , along with other officials, visited the village in the morning.The patient, who returned to India from Nepal on March 20, was admitted to Ambala civil hospital on March 26. His family members have been kept in isolation as a precaution. Dr Malhotra said, “No family member had so far shown any symptoms of coronavirus.”The DC also interacted with the village sarpanch and locals, and asked them to approach health officials in case any local showed symptoms associated with Covid-19. The SSP said police teams had been deployed at all entry and exit points of the village and a round-the-clock vigil was being maintained to ensure individuals from other areas did not come in contact with the local population.Police laid barricades around the village.The civil surgeon said health teams under epidemiologist Dr Sumit Singh conducted a survey of the village and generated health charts of locals. Four health surveillance teams and two medical teams have also been deployed at the village. They are spraying sodium hypochloride to disinfect the village.An advisory has also been issued in adjoining villages.The patient had earlier complained of a stomach ache. He also had headache, loose motions and fever, and no respiratory problem at first. He works for a private firm in Chandigarh, but did not attend work due to the lockdown.

Title: Punjab ask DCs to give relaxation to substance abuse patients
Content: CHANDIGARH: To ensure continuity of medicine to substance abuse patients undergoing treatment at private and government de-addiction centres, the Punjab health department has issued instructions for relaxation in curfew amidst Covid-19 outbreak for these patients. The department has, however, so far not taken any call for patients of other psychiatric disorders, much to the chagrin of both doctors and patients.In a communication to deputy commissioners, director health services highlighted importance of substance abuse patients taking medicine without break. In the letter, Punjab’s director of health services stated that patients were facing difficulty in reaching outpatient opioid-assisted treatment (OOAT) clinics, government-run and private de-addiction centres. The department contended that chances of patients relapsing increases if they miss their daily dose of detoxification medicine and can be fatal as well.All deputy commissioners have been asked to give relaxation at their level to such under treatment addicts to visit centres to take medicine. They have been asked to direct centres in their jurisdiction to ensure that precautions are taken to avoid spread of coronavirus infection. In each centre, only one or two staff members equipped with protective mask and gloves will be deployed. Such centres have also been asked to ensure that there is no overcrowding and proper distance is maintained between patients and staff. At the time of registration of new patients, details of relatives coming from aboard will be sought.As per official record, over 3.66 lakh patients have so far been registered for treatment in 193 OOAT clinics, 35 government de-addiction centres and 106 private de-addiction centres and nine central jails.Association of Psychiatrists (AOP) Punjab lauded the decision of government to give relaxation to substance abuse patients, but demanded that the psychiatrists running OPDs should be allowed to treat their stable patients (non- drug dependants) of psychiatric disorders and epilepsy.AOP president Dr Rupinder Kapur rued doctors and their staff are not being allowed to reach their OPDs to dispense medication. Discontinuation of treatment has started to affect the patients, he said. “Many patients have started having withdrawal seizures, mood swings, sleeplessness and sadness all due to discontinuation of treatment,” Dr Kapur said.Sharing his experience, he said that there is lot of confusion. “SDM Phagwara refused to give me a permit while DC Kapurthala stated that doctors can attend to their patients. There is no clarity,” he said. He claimed that patients are being harassed, turned back and even beaten up by the police.Despite repeated attempts, Punjab director health services Dr Avneet Kaur was not available for comments.

Title: Punjab ropes in local units to manufacture life-saving equipment
Content: CHANDIGARH: In its preparations to check the spread of coronavirus , the Punjab government has roped in local manufacturers to supply life-saving equipment such as masks, gloves, other personal protective equipment (PPE) kits, and ventilators.Additional chief secretary Vini Mahajan said the state government had roped in local manufacturers in order to reduce dependence on outside vendors. Therefore, 10 lakh pieces of indigenously made hazmat suits had been ordered by the central government from JCT Mills in Punjab. Mahajan said to facilitate testing of these suits, the Punjab Police had taken samples through the lockdown to Delhi from where they were taken to the central testing laboratory at Coimbatore via a special flight.She added that samples of PPEs and N95 masks designed and made at six more Punjab industrial units had left for Coimbatore and Gwalior respectively, for testing. Two local entrepreneurs had come forward with proposals for making ventilators too.By March 31, the state will have another 25,000 N95 masks, in addition to the 52,500 already in stock, along with one lakh nitrile gloves, she said, adding that the state government already had stock of 26.32 lakh triple layer masks (TLM), another 12 lakh will be received by April 1.Punjab government has ordered one lakh PPE kits, out of which 7,640 have already been received. The state government also has a stock of 10,425 hand sanitisers and 17,000 viral transport media (VTM) kits, with 2,000 and 10,000 more, respectively, expected to be added to the inventory by April 1. The state government is also procuring ventilators for handling critical cases. Mahajan said that adequate equipment and medicines had already been made available to the government medical colleges at Amritsar and Patiala, besides the Gian Sagar Hospital.

Title: Way back home in times of Corona: Marchers take river route to escape road barriers
Content: SHAMBHU (PATIALA): The governments of Punjab and Haryana have sealed state borders to prevent any movement, but still several migrant labourers are crossing over from Punjab to Haryana, using the Ghaggar riverbed to cross over and skipping the road route to evade police barricades.Many of them have been walking from Amritsar and Jalandhar. Many of these marchers have been left with no money and they hardly have any backup to sustain a living.On Sunday, hundreds of migrants labourers were seen walking in rows through agricultural fields near Shambhu border and crossing over into Haryana after walking through the Ghaggar riverbed.While security personnel continued to man state borders, labourers, who were seen carrying a few bags of clothing and other essentials, entered Haryana through rough patches and agricultural fields. The Haryana government has set up shelter homes in Ambala to accommodate these marchers and prevent them from moving ahead. Ambala Sadar police station SHO Nikita said elaborate security arrangements had been made to seal state borders. “All marchers coming from Punjab are being given two options- go back or stay at shelter homes set up by the state government,” she said, adding that under no circumstances, movement of people would be allowed as it would be a violation of the protocol set in place to contain the spread of coronavirus.She said force had been mobilised to check incoming marchers through agricultural fields. “All who will reach Haryana will be rounded up and taken to shelter homes,” she said.While thousands of job;es marchers are thronging the national capital in an attempt to go back to their homes, workers left with no money in Punjab said they would prefer walking back home rather than heading for Delhi. They said there was no system in place for them to go back home.Pappu, a marcher near Shambhu, said they would try to take a lift from trucks when possible to reach home.The Patiala administration had on Saturday sent five buses to transport Kashmiri workers to Jammu and Kashmir. But, so far, no such provisions have been made for workers who came to Punjab in large numbers for employment in factories, agricultural fields and construction projects. An officer, who did not wish to be named, said sending back a large number of migrant labourers would put them at the risk of contracting coronavirus and it was not feasible during the lockdown as all transport services were suspended. He said focus was on smooth delivery of essential items at present.

Title: Haryana seals inter-state borders, provides buses from Delhi
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: As exodus of migrant laborers continued on Sunday, the Haryana government has provided 1,000 buses from various resources for their movement so that they could reach their destinations within the state safely. At the same time, the Haryana government has intensified the efforts to retain the labourers in the state for their utilisation in the coming harvesting season and other works undertaken by them.

According to information, the emergency staff of Haryana Roadways have been put on 1,000 buses drawn from Rohtak, Sonipat, Panipat, Jhajjar, Jind, Gurugram, Faridabad and Palwal depots of the state carrier. Besides this, the transport department has also arranged buses from those in contract carriage and private operators. All these buses were sent to Delhi.

In a related development, Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar and chief secretary Keshni Anand Arora reviewed the arrangements made for labourers who have been retained in the state or likely to stay back in Haryana.

During his videoconferencing with the deputy commissioners and superintendents of police on Sunday, the CM issued direction to seal the inter-state borders to stop the movement of labourers from Haryana.

He directed the officers to set up ‘shelter or relief camps’ and ensure that proper food and staying arrangements for the migrant labourers staying in such camps and if anyone still opposes staying, then strict action should be taken against him. He directed a nodal officer for every camp in each district should be appointed who will ensure lodging, food and medical facilities of the workers. Apart from this social distancing should be ensured in these camps.

The CM directed that special shelter or relief camps should be set up along the national highways for the migrant walking on foot so that they can stay in these camps and no one should be allowed to roam around on roads. Apart from this district-level call centers should also be set up.

Title: Himachal Pradesh starts process of releasing prisoners
Content:
Representative image

SHIMLA: On the directions of the Supreme Court, Himachal Pradesh government has started the process of releasing prisoners who are either convicted or undertrial. In a meeting held on Friday, the high-powered committee of the state decided that undertrials would be released for a maximum period of three months. They will be freed after furnishing a personal bail bond without surety to implement the social distancing policy of the state government to the satisfaction of jail superintendent concerned.

The district magistrate concerned will see to it that travel pass is provided to the prisoners, who will be released after proper medical check-up. The district magistrate and superintendent of police will make arrangements for their transport to their respective places.

The high-powered committee meeting was held in compliance with Supreme Court directions and was chaired by Justice Tarlok Singh Chauhan of Himachal Pradesh High Court , who is also the executive chairman of Himachal Pradesh State Legal Service Authority. Additional chief secretary (Home) Manoj Kumar and DGP (Prisons) Somesh Goyal, who are committee members, were also present.

The Committee said for the release of prisoners convicted with imprisonment of up to seven years, it has been decided that the competent authority will expedite applications of eligible convicts to maximise release on parole or furlough or grant of emergency furlough as per rules and procedure.

For the release of undertrials, the committee has fixed the criteria to consider cases including first time offenders, those who have been arrested or are facing trials for an offence punishable up to seven years or less; where the case is triable by magistrate; who are in custody for last three months or more and are residents of Himachal Pradesh.

It has been made clear by the committee that release of convicts or undertrials from outside the state and foreign nationals will not be considered in view of the nationwide lockdown.

Offences to be excluded from consideration include cases relating to Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, crime related to sexual offences committed against women, offences relating to rioting and waging war against the state, crimes relating to counterfeit currency, crimes against children relating to kidnapping, crimes relating to anti-corruption matters, crimes relating to commercial and economic offences, crimes relating to Gangsters Act; crimes against NDPS Act relating to the recovery of commercial quantity and less than commercial quantity but more than small quantity.

For the release of convicts under Section 432 of the Code of Criminal Procedures,1973, Committee has decided that competent authorities will expedite and prioritise matters of the convicts under their consideration as per law.

While deciding the procedures to be adopted, the Committee resolved that the jail superintendent concerned will scrutinise eligible convicts and undertrials as per above mentioned criteria and applications of convicts for parole and furlough will be expedited by adopting digital modes and online procedure. The Committee said interim bail applications may be moved through jail authorities with the help of District Legal Services Authorities to the courts concerned.

Applications may be filed online to prevent mass gathering in courts or government offices. The secretary, District Legal Services Authority will depute bail and remand counsel to assist the court in hearing such applications.

Title: Ludhiana health officials nod for converting existing wards, hospitals into ‘corona rooms’
Content: LUDHIANA: Health authorities of the district are preparing a proposal for converting different wards into isolation rooms in the next few days to tackle the increasing number of suspected patients of Covid-19. They are also contemplating converting the mother and child hospital on Chandigarh road into an Covid isolation ward to cater to patients from villages of the district.Senior health authorities had held a high-level meeting with all medical officers of the district for making all necessary arrangements and asked the local officials to start the process of identifying the building that would be turned into isolation wards in case there will more demand in a few days time.Sources in health department said for the last two days, the senior medical staff and higher authorities have been discussing the possibility of converting various wards of civil hospital into isolation rooms and now they have given the orders to local health officials to begin the process of preparing the list of required logistics.Moreover, health authorities of civil hospital have also raised the demand for personal protective equipment for local medical staff who is dealing with suspected patients, as they fear of being infected with the virus while giving treatment to suspected patients.A medical staff, on the condition of anonymity, said, “After seeing the increase in the suspected Covid-19 patients, health authorities have decided to make some wards into isolation room so that the deadly virus is not spread among the other patients who are getting their treatment in the hospital.”Senior medical officer of civil hospital, Dr Ravi Datta, confirmed that some wards in the old building of the civil hospital will soon be converted into isolation wards for dealing with the increasing number of corona patients.“We have also already prepared the proposal for converting the mother and child hospital into special corona hospital. We are equipped with required infrastructure to deal with any kind of emergency situation as we are continuously getting all necessary items on daily basis from higher authorities for better service to patients,” added Datta.According to the SMO, civil hospital has now rapid response teams trained to handle the suspected cases of coronavirus . “They will be taking samples from suspected people and send it for testing,” said the SMO.He also claimed that the hospital has now adequate numbers of personal protective equipment so that medical staff cvan attend to the patients without fear olf being infected.

Title: Man in Ludhiana impersonates cop, loots vendors
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: A man has looted residents of Daba, impersonating as a cop. The accused used to roam around in Daba and harass vegetable vendors, grocery shopkeepers, and fruit-sellers. He would threaten to lodge an FIR against them for selling goods during curfew. After threatening them, he would take away fruits, vegetables, and grocery from them.

On Saturday, when some residents objected to his act, the accused immediately escaped from the spot. Following this, on Sunday, Daba resident Sandeep Shukla lodged a complaint with the police.

He said, “The accused, posing as a cop, used to be seen around in our locality for the past couple of days. On Saturday, he also took away three LPG cylinders of a labourer, and thrashed him. Further, he also extorted Rs10,000 from other shopkeepers, and took away fruits from a fruit-seller. Thereafter, one resident — TS Kaka — objected to his act, and raised an alarm. When locality residents started gathering outside, the accused escaped from there.”

Shukla alleged, “The accused is a tout of the police. Residents have seen him at a police station several times. We have lodged a complaint with the police against him.”

Additional SHO at Daba police station, Upinder Singh , said, “The police have received a complaint, and investigation is on. We will arrest him after an inquiry.”

Title: These corona warriors work 16 hours a day to keep you safe
Content: LUDHIANA: At times, people argue with them, abuse them, call them heartless and even get into fisticuffs with them for not allowing to them to go out. Despite that, the poilice personnel are going about their duty, working for almost 16 hours a day.TOI met a few of ‘corona warriors’, some of whom were managing the law and order and some distributing ration and food to the needy residents.TOI met assistant commissioner of police (ACP), west, Sameer Verma in Jassiya area when he was distributing ration and cooked food to the needy ones.ACP Verma said, “We start our duty by 5am and work till 11pm to midnight. Of course, it is risky too, as we come in contact with everyone, from residents to vegetable vendors, milk suppliers and even suspects of coronavirus . I believe cops are more vulnerable to coronavirus. But we make sure that we take all precautions while performing our duty.”ACP said he takes extra precautions at home as he has elderly parents and very young daughters. “My elder daughter is 10 years old and the younger one is just three years old. When I go home after duty, I get extremely cautions while going near my family, especially my daughters. Both my daughters miss spending time with me, but duty comes first.”Assistant sub-inspector (ASI) Amarjeet Kumar from Raghunath police post, who was on duty at Ashapuri Chowk near Barewal road, said, “At times, people argue with us and even call us heartless when we don’t allow them to go. At times it feels bad that they don’t understand that we are working for their safety. We have got clear instructions from CP sir that we should not be rude to anyone. Those having genuine reason will be allowed to go and those roaming around without a reason will politely be convinced to go back home. We are following the same directions.”A traffic cop, deputed at Bharat Nagar chowk, ASI Baldev Singh , said, “I and my son both are in police force. He is constable Mandeep Singh and is deputed on Jagraon bridge. We work from 7am to 9pm whether it rains or is extremely sunny. We are not stressed or overworked, as this is the duty we have chosen. In this testing time, when everyone is vulnerable, I want to give my best to my duty.”But yes, he is human enough to miss the good old times when he could get home and play with her straight. “My granddaughter is only 10 months old. These days after duty, I don’t go straight to her, as much as I want to. If I have to go near her, I make sure to use all precautions.”Commissioner of police, Rakesh Agrawal, said, “We are definitely overworked and overburdened with variety of responsibilities, but we are not at all stressed. We consider ourselves fortunate that god had given us opportunity and strength to serve the humanity in these testing times. In fact we are enjoying our duty.”

Title: 50 untraced travellers go missing, officials say people fear social stigma
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Around 50 travellers are still untraced in Ludhiana, and the health officials said this is because people fear social ostracism. To tackle this, the city administration has set up a new helpline, 0161 4622276, where neighbours and family could inform the authorities if they identify anyone with symptoms or have had travel history but not isolated.

The commissioner of police (CP), Rakesh Agrawal said, so far the police have traced 5,296 people. According to him, 95 teams have been tasked with tracing the people coming from abroad, along with with officials of district administration and health department. “We have found 5,296 people so far and health department’s rapid response team has tested them for symptoms of Covid-19.”

Besides the police, more than 350 officials from Khanna and Jagraon are involved in this process of tracking them. Police officials received a list of people who returned to India from the deputy commissioner (DC) and have been tracking them down.

The DC shares the details with the police officials about the traveller and if the traveller is traced, then police officials are sent to verify the details. If not, it is reported to higher authorities of state administration.

The CP said, “When we do trace them, we question them whether they have flu-like symptoms. In any case, they are recommended home quarantine. There is no question of humiliation here, it is for the welfare of everyone.”

More than 6,000 people, who had travel history or were in contact with people travelled to red-listed countries, have been recommended home quarantine by health department.

“One of the major reasons that the officials aren’t being able to trace them is wrong address and phone number mentioned in the passport. Yet, our teams are active and searching for them. They will be traced soon via phone numbers. If they are outside Punjab , we will share the information with the other state authorities so that they can follow up,” added CP Agrawal.

Chief medical officer Dr Rajesh Bagga said the people are not coming forward in telling the travel history due to social stigma. However, neighbours of the travellers keep a track and help and share information.

“Travellers are hiding their travel history. Thus we have launched a new helpline number where neighbours or the family can report to the health department about them,” added Dr Bagga.

Title: 6 days on, Ludhiana’s 2 positive cases still await confirmation from Pune lab
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: It has been six days and the health officials are claiming that they are still awaiting confirmation of two from Ludhiana who have tested positive in their preliminary report.

The two who have tested positive include a 72-year-old from Jalandhar, who is admitted at Christian Medical College and Hospital (CMCH) and 55-year-old from Gurdev Nagar, who is admitted at Dayanand Medical College and Hospital (DMCH).

Meanwhile, of the 93 suspected cases, health department said 66 have tested negative. The results of 25 samples are still pending at Rajendra Hospital in Patiala .

The 55-year-old tested positive on March 24 and the health department has claimed that the samples have been sent to National Institute of Virology , Pune. But it has been six days and there is no response from civil surgeon Dr Rajesh Bagga.

On March 24, he claimed that the reports will be received in two days.

Deputy commissioner Pradeep Agrawal said, “The treatment will remain same whether the reports have been sent or not. She is undergoing treatment.”

Even after repeated attempts, Dr Bagga ignored the question and claimed, “I have not received the reports and you can question the Rajendra Hospital, Patiala whether they have forwarded the sample to Pune lab or not.”

The social media, meanwhile, is abuzz, with speculations over whether health department is hiding report or acting careless.

However, the media bulletin released by the state headquarters has already declared it a positive case.

Secretary of DMCH Prem Gupta said, “Samples have to be routed through health department. We would again resend the sample after 3-4 days. I have never questioned health department on this.”

Ward boy of DMCH in isolation ward

At DMCH, a ward boy is admitted in isolation ward after diagnosed with flu-like symptoms. Besides this another patient is also admitted in isolation ward.

Officials at DMCH said, “Ward boy has been quarantined. He has fever and we have sent the sample for test.”

At CMCH, eight patients are admitted in the isolation ward.

At civil hospital, Dr Baldeep Singh said, “We have discharged three patients who have tested negative and we have admitted five more suspected patients in isolation wards.”

Title: Crime file: 24 bottles of illicit liquor recovered
Content:
24 bottles of illicit liquor recovered

The Division number 8 police have recovered 24 bottles of illicit liquor form near Green Filed area. An unidentified man was commuting on his scooter PB10GU1645 with liquor. On seeing police, the accused escaped form there leaving scooter on spot. A case has been registered against him.

Two held for violating curfew

Jamalpur police have arrested Gurmeet Singh of village Ramgarh and Navjot Singh of village Jhabbewal for roaming around near Jandyali chowk , violating curfew orders. A case has been registered against them.

Title: MC secretary makes roads safe for residents
Content: LUDHIANA: The day the lockdown was announced, municipal corporation secretary Jasdev Singh Sekhon took to the roads to conduct a sanitisation drive.“I am outside so that residents can be at their houses without fear of any infection,” said Jasdev.When a businessman gave a vehicle equipped with a sanitisation machine to the MC, Jasdev took it around to clean-up the city. “So far, I have covered half of the city, including main and inner roads. Initially, I drove the vehicle for more than 32 hours without catching a wink,” he added.When the first Covid-19 case spread panic in the city, he did not bat an eyelid before sanitising her house in Gurdev Nagar.The hours-long work does not tire him. “I cannot sit back when my city needs my services. At times, my wife and children worry about me, but they never stop me from doing my bit,” he said.Crediting his team for helping him sanitise the city, he said, “My co-workers, including drivers, are supporting me in this endeavour. I appeal to citizens to stay at home and follow the government directives so that our efforts do not go down the drain I feel like we are the warriors fighting the battle against coronavirus .”In 2018, Sekhon was among 16 people honoured for their week-long tireless work in Suffian Chowk where a multi-storey building had collapsed after a fire in 2017.

Title: Ludhiana: Rising to the occasion and above communal lines
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Amid the coronavirus gloom, some Ludhianvis are scripting heart-warming tales that will make you smile and hope.

From shrines, groups to individuals, many have come together and ramped up their efforts to help those in need.

Gurdwara Dukhniwaran Sahib, Field Ganj, is organising community kitchen every day. The gurdwara management president, Pritpal Singh Pali, said, “The langar service was not discontinued even once despite the lockdown. It continues, albeit with a difference: the devotees are seated at a distance. Following the lockdown, we are receiving more people than before and they are served langar thrice a day. Besides, many people are taking food from here for distribution among the needy.”

Gurdwara Manji Sahib, Alamgir, too, has joined the altruist efforts. Apart from giving food packets to almost 10,000 people every day, the gurdwara team is also helping the administration serve the slum dwellers. The gurdwara manager, Resham Singh, said, “Our team tours Ludhiana and hands over food packets to the needy wherever they find them. There are many who need help at this time. Our endeavour is to reach out to them.”

The Muslim community, too, is helping the poor. They have distributed groceries to more than 200 families. “And now, we are making more packets of grocery to distribute among the needy. I appeal to the business community to donate for public help,” said Shahi Imam Maulana Habib Ur Rehman Sani .

Stories of communal harmony, too, are lighting up many lives.

“While we are distributing essential items to the underprivileged, Gurdwara Dukhniwaran Sahib is serving food to those living in Jama Masjid,” he added.

Sanglan Wala Shivala temple on Sunday gave wheat flour, rice and other essential things to more than 200 families. Neeraj Verma from the temple management said, “With the Central and the state governments working hard to stem coronavirus, the religious organizations, too, should come forward to perform their duties. If we will not help the needy at this time of crisis, then people will lose faith in God and not visit shrines.”

Gurdwara Bhaini Sahib has also upped its efforts to help humanity. Its volunteers are visting slums and other places to give food to more than 15,000 people every day.

Namdhari Sangat Sasrali Colony, too, has chipped in by providing food to at least 7,000 people daily.

Title: Non-essential factories in state get green signal to resume work
Content:
LUDHIANA: At a time when other northern states are feeling helpless and unable to find a solution to the problem of mass exodus of migrant workers back to their homes, the Punjab government on Sunday took a major decision and gave a go-ahead to factories producing non-essential goods to resume operations, subject to fulfilment of several conditions. Some of the conditions include free lodging, food, and medical facilities to workers by factory owners, and ensuring all measures, including social distancing, are followed by workers.

The decision comes in the wake of a hue and cry raised by several business associations, which had warned the government that if workers leave the state, they will never be able to re-open their factories, as almost 90% of the labour they employed is from other states, mainly Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, and West Bengal .

State industries minister Sundar Sham Arora said, “The problem of exodus of migrant labourers from Punjab is getting serious, and the movement of workers in such huge numbers is not just a cause of concern for Punjab’s industry alone, but also dangerous for workers.”

He added, “In the wake of the outbreak of Covid-19, workers are putting their lives at risk by moving out of developed cities like Ludhiana, and setting on a journey to their home states, that too on foot. So, in an effort to put an end to this humanitarian crisis, we have decided that factories in Punjab will be allowed to operate, subject to certain conditions, including providing in-house free lodging, and free medical check-up to their workers. Factories interested in operating must comply with all the parameters set up by the health department with regard to Covid-19, like social distancing, use of masks, and hospitalisation of persons showing symptoms of the virus.”

Arora further added, “Since lakhs of workers are employed in brick kilns spread in different districts of Punjab, we are also permitting brick kilns to resume partial operations, subject to fulfilment of all conditions, as laid down in the case of factories. However, I want to make it clear that kilns will not be allowed to do the firing process, but they can get workers to do other processes, like forming, cutting, and drying.”

Meanwhile, industrialists seem to be divided over the decision of the government, as some of them welcome it, while others are of the view that the conditions laid down by the government for permission to begin operations cannot be fulfilled by a majority of industries. Besides, there are other reasons too because of which this permission would be of no use.

According to CII Punjab chairman Rahul Ahuja, who played a crucial role in convincing the government to take this decision, “Thousands of migrant workers in Ludhiana alone have embarked on a journey by foot to their homes in Bihar, UP, and other states. The situation has taken place due to fear and confusion prevailing among them due to the lockdown. Some of them are leaving because they feel they will be safer if they return to their villages, while others are of the view that they will not be able to get any work now.”

He added, “We met the general manager of the District Industries Centre (DIC), through whom we got our proposal sent to the state government, and we are happy it has been accepted and implemented promptly. The factories which fulfil the requirements can obtain permission from the DIC’s office, and start their factories right away.”

Opposing the decision, Charanjit Singh Vishivkarma , former president of United Cycle and Parts Manufacturers Association (UCPMA), said, “This is not the proper time to open factories, as this decision should have been made in consultation with all industry associations, after discussing all the pros and cons. It should not be made by any individual, and this is not the right environment to run a factory.”

He added, “Even if we decide to start units, from where will we get our raw material? We do not even have any orders, nor do we have any means to supply the products to our dealers. Moreover, the markets where our products are sold are closed, then what is the purpose of running the factories and producing goods, even if we are able to.”

Title: Punjab starts releasing children in conflict with law for 21 days
Content: CHANDIGARH: In a step to protect children in conflict with law from the outbreak of Covid-19, the Punjab government has started releasing eligible children on 21 days “leave of absence” from its observation homes, special homes and place of safety. Three such juveniles were released on bail by Sangrur juvenile justice board (JJB), three by Kapurthala JJB and one by Ludhiana JJB on Friday.Punjab has three observations homes for boys at Ludhiana, Faridkot and Hoshiarpur , and one for girls at Amritsar. There is one special home and one place of safety for boys at Hoshiarpur.These places have 174 children in conflict with law, against the total capacity of 300. There are no girls in these homes as on date. Undertrial children are kept in observation homes, children above 18 years of age, who are convicted by JJB in special homes, and convicted children between the age of 16 and 18 years in places of safety.Director of social security and development of women and children department Gurpreet Kaur Sapra told TOI, “We have issued written directions to all district child protection officers regarding release of eligible children placed in observation homes and special homes. We are in regular touch with respective juvenile justice boards in taking up such cases.” She added that the department was maintaining a regular check also in terms of hygiene in all child care institutes to prevent children from getting coronavirus infection.Juvenile justice monitoring committee of the Punjab and Haryana high court, headed by Justice Jaswant Singh , had on Saturday issued directions to all the districts and sessions judges in Punjab, Haryana and Chandigarh that undertrial and convicted children for committing offences other than heinous crimes may be considered for a leave of absence for a period up to 21 days. Children in conflict of law who will not be considered for release include those convicted or undergoing inquiry for intermediate or large quantity recovery of drugs, rape, acid attack, snatching and use of force in which imprisonment is not less than 10 years, and under the Prevention of Children from Sexual Offences Act.Convicted or undertrial children who are foreign nationals, and those who are convicted or undergoing inquiry in more than two cases will not be considered for release either. Convicted or undertrial children belonging to other states will also not be considered for release since they shall not be able to travel to other states on account of lockdown and sealing of borders.

Title: Punjab CM allows industry to function to stop marchers
Content: CHANDIGARH: To stop casual workers from leaving for their homes in UP and Bihar in the wake of the curfew to contain coronavirus Punjab chief minister Capt Amarinder Singh has allowed industries and brick kilns to start operations if they can accommodate and provide food to workers inside their units.The state government is also in discussion with Radha Soami Satsang Beas to allow such workers to stay in its bhawans. The workers will be required for wheat harvesting in Punjab in another two weeks. This organisation has already offered its bhawans as quarantine facilities.The CM has asked the owners of industrial units and brick kilns to ensure social distancing is maintained and hygiene practised. The decision has been taken amid reports of lakhs of marchers getting stranded across the country and they gathering in large numbers at state borders.The Punjab labour department has also issued an advisory to employers and owners of private establishments like industries, factories, shops and commercial establishments not to terminate jobs, particularly those which are casual and contractual in nature. It has also been directed that employers should not deduct wages or salary of their employees.

Title: 1,000 apply online for curfew passes
Content:
Gurgaon: In just two days, over 1,000 residents have applied for curfew movement passes online. While on March 27, around 200 passes were issued, over 400 were issued on March 28 to residents seeking free movement during the lockdown period.

Officials said the reasons for rejection of applications included applicants not uploading supporting documents and absence of authorisation letters. Their were applicants requesting to move out to meet their families in some other state.

“We’re also receiving requests through helplines. We direct them to submit their application through the portal which is being monitored and handled by GMDA,” an official said.

Title: Bathinda man waives shops’ rent totaling Rs 2.75 lakh
Content: BATHINDA: While coronavirus is causing devastation around the world, some persons aiming to support the needy are adopting various ways, but a landlord of Bathinda, Tarsem Lal Garg , has done something different. He has waived the rent of all his 24 shops in Bathinda rented to various persons.The monthly rent of these shop in total is Rs. 2.75 lakh. He has announced to waive the rent till the situation normalises and will start charging the rent of shop when the shopkeepers start earning. Apart from it, Tarsem is also distributing ration among the underprivileged by spending from his own pocket.Tarsem said, “When the curfew was imposed to stop the spread of coronavirus and all shopkeepers were asked to down shutters, I understood the agony of my tenants. I have 24 shops in two markets around Post Office Bazaar. I have decided not to charge any rent from any tenant till the situation normalises and the shopkeepers start earning.”He further said, “I have requested the local municipal corporation authorities to collect ration packets and distribute these among needy persons.

Title: AWBI appeals to Punjab CM to ensure fodder, medicines for cattle in shelters
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Amid the anti-coronavirus curfew imposed in Punjab, where the state residents are struggling to meet their daily needs, there are also around 3.84 lakh speechless cows and stray cattle in 512 cattle pounds or cow shelters struggling for their survival.

Animal Welfare Board of India (AWBI) state officer in Punjab, Kimti Lal Bhagat , has urged the Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh to ensure that these animals do not die for want of fodder and essential medicines. He told TOI that since the curfew has been imposed in the state, various volunteers who used to donate fodder and medicines in these cattle pounds are also helpless in coming to the rescue of these speechless animals.

Bhagat has requested the chief minister to issue directions to all the deputy commissioners to provide the required fodder and medicines in all cattle pounds as well as cow shelters under their respective jurisdiction. Bhagat, former chairperson of Punjab Gau Sewa Commission , has apprised the chief minister that after imposition of curfew, these animals run the risk of starvation deaths as many cattle pounds facing shortage of fodder.

He added that as per the reports gathered from various cattle pounds across the state, he had come to know that there are a number of deaths of cattle in government cattle pound in Lalru. Some cows had died for want of medicines in cattle pounds of Tarn Taran, Amritsar , Moga and other districts, said Bhagat.

Title: Doctor tweets about having suspected Covid-19 symptoms
Content: AMRITSAR: A second-year postgraduate student of Government Medical College, Amritsar has tweeted about having suspected symptoms of coronavirus. Dr Parminder Kaur tweeted on Saturday, “As a second-year resident in GMC, Amritsar with symptoms of nCOVID-19 but no test is yet performed, my temperature is 102.3 F and have shortness of breath, if I get any worse my family will not get to meet me at all if one foot unfortunate happens kindly help.”She tagged Punjab chief minister Captain Amarinder Singh in her tweet. Talking to TOI on Sunday, Dr Parminder said she was feeling better now but to rule out the possibility of coronavirus, she said she wanted to undergo the virology test.According to her, she faced the risk of infection as she was deployed at the flu corner and had to visit the emergency department to perform her duties. She said her consultant doctors had advised her to undergo the virology test.Amritsar civil surgeon Dr Prabhdeep Kaur Johal said doctors attending to her would have given her the best advice. Despite several attempts, GMC principal Dr Sujata Sharma did not answer the phone for comments.Sources said two PG students of the medical college who had symptoms of coronavirus and were admitted in the isolation ward were discharged after they tested negative.In Ajnala, a 25-year-old youth reported to the civil hospital saying he had symptoms. Senior medical officer, Ajnala civil hospital said the youth came to hospital with flu and fever but got better after initial treatment.

Title: BSF ups its defences against Covid-19
Content: CHANDIGARH: As Punjab is one of the states hit the worst by the coronavirus , the Border Security Force (BSF), which guards the 553km Indo-Pak border of the state, has been taking extraordinary measures to keep troops safe.While those on leave have been asked to stay home till April 15, a strict protocol is being used for those deployed to along the border. “We are frontline border guarding forces and cannot keep our troops inside the campus or cantonment area. All preventive measures and guidelines related to health are being followed while deploying troops. All BSF deployment areas and camps have been sanitised and quarantine centres have been prepared in BSF hospitals and campuses to meet any eventuality,” said the spokesperson of BSF (Punjab frontiers).He also informed that troops assigned to guard the boarder were being regularly shifted and sanitised to avoid any kind of spread of virus.Ground training has also been suspended and only briefings are being done by the BSF in their camps. Even the strength of office staff has been reduced and others have been asked to stay at home. Nobody is allowed to move out or move inside BSF camp areas.Sources, however, confirmed that the border force had minimised contact with its Pakistan counterpart to avoid any kind of spread of virus. A meeting with Pakistan Rangers is necessary whenever there is any incident of smuggling or intrusion on the border. The force has already stopped the movement of general public to attend the retreat ceremony between India and Pakistan on the Attari-Wagah border in Amritsar and Hussainiwala in Ferozepur in Punjab in view of coronavirus.Punjab is one of the worst0hit states in the country as far as spread of coronavirus is concerned. Thirty-eight positive cases and a death have been reported in the state till now. The state government has imposed a curfew to prevent its spread. The state has a large population of NRIs and others who had returned from abroad after the outbreak of the deadly disease in other parts of the world.In Punjab, BSF guards the Indo-Pak border which comprises a 518-km stretch on land and 33km riverine area. It is manned by 19 BSF battalions, one unit of BSF’s water wing, an artillery and other force multipliers. In all, 212 villages of Amritsar, Gurdaspur, Ferozepur, Tarn Taran, Pathankot and Fazilka are located near the border guarded by BSF.

Title: Many Ludhiana colonies lock in, banning even friends and relatives from entering
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: Looks like the fear of coronavirus is finally being distilled pure into the hearts of city’s residents. They are beginning to take the lockdown announced by the Prime Minister seriously. In many areas of the city, people have locked down their localities to prevent outsiders from entering the streets even.

In many areas people have either closed their gates or they have closed down the entrance to the colony. Huge banners tell people to stay away and not spread coronavirus. Some people are afraid to the extent that they have pasted papers outside their houses with a message that nobody should visit their house till the curfew is on.

A resident of Durgapuri in Haibowal, Shakti Sharma, said, “We have closed down all four gates to the locality so that no outsider can enter. It is advisable to stay inside. The government is trying to prevent the spread of this disease and it is our duty as citizens to help the government in this task by staying inside.” He said when curfew was imposed in the beginning, many two-wheeler riders were moving about in the locality, but since March 24 they closed the gate permanently so that nobody can come inside.

Another resident from Sector 32, Harish Kumar , said, “My son had put up a poster outside our house for the people and friends that due to coronavirus nobody should visit our house. Now, some of my relatives also implemented the same outside their houses.” He said it foolhardiness to go outside, even if to check if police was there or if anybody else was moving about in roads. He claimed that at the moment every person should think about his or her family nothing else. “Only that person, who will stay at home no matter, will win this game,” he added.

Meanwhile, residents in Lohara Colony , Giaspura, have closed the entry of their street for the outsiders. One of the residents, Jeet Singh, claimed that when they all are staying at home there is no reason why they should allow others to come. He said they have closed the entrance for outsiders because they do not know who is a carrier of this disease.He also said there is nothing wrong in being extra cautious.

Another resident from Kailash Nagar, Sanjay Kumar , said, “If we will not control this disease here then our situation will also be like Italy and other affected countries. Foreign countries have better health facilities even then they are unable to control this disease. If this disease spreads in our country, it will be a disaster as we do not have enough health facilities.” He said in his colony, all residents decided to keep the doors closed even for relatives.

Title: The exodus continues: On foot, bicycles, without work and hope
Content:
LUDHIANA: Hundreds of migrant workers are leaving Ludhiana daily due to confusion arising out of coronavirus lockdown.

The TOI came across several groups of labourers walking home on GT Road and along railway lines. The workers were mostly from Uttar Pradesh and Bihar and employed at Ludhiana factories. They said they were leaving the city as they were now without work.

Some of the workers were of the view that they were worried for their families back home, who too were now under lockdown. They said as there was no alternative to reach their villages, they were forced to take the journey on foot.

According to another group of workers who left the city on bicycles on Saturday night, they would be able to reach their villages in Uttar Pradesh in about three days.

Rakesh Kumar of Sitamarhi district in Bihar, who worked in a hosiery unit, said he along with his wife and two children had to leave for his state because of no work due to closure of the factory where he worked. He said though they would suffer, they had no option than to cover such a long distance on foot, as they would at least get something to eat there.

Another daily-wager from Bareilly in UP said he has expended all his resources and with the remaining money he could at least reach his village and spend time with his dear ones. He added that without work it was very hard to survive in the city.

With the administration issuing orders for conditional restart of the units, some migrant workers said they might cancel their plans to return home. “We are ready to follow all the norms if factories are allowed to work in a way that the disease does not spread. The government should set up a monitoring system to ensure that norms are followed by all units,” said a migrant worker, Suresh Paswan .

Title: Ludhiana: Labourer arrested for wife’s murder
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: The police on Sunday arrested a man for killing his wife in Gahi Bhaini village of Koomkalan . According to police, the man suspected his wife of having illicit relations with someone. It is alleged the man was in an inebriated condition when he killed his wife with the wooden leg of a cot.

The accused has been identified as Sukhbir Singh (25), a labourer, who had married Kamaljit Kaur (22) three years ago. The couple has a one-year old son from this marriage.

Kamaljit’s brother Beant Singh of Bhagpur village of Machhiwara said Sukhbir was a habitual drinker who used to thrash Kamaljit Kaur in an inebriated condition. The family had intervened several times when they fought, and also warned him, but to no avail.

He added that on Sunday, Kamaljit telephoned him and complained that Sukhbir was thrashing her. After receiving the call, he — along with his mother Balwinder Kaur — rushed to her house.

“When we reached there, the neighbours and villagers were already gathered there. Sukhbir’s brother Jagtar Singh said his brother had murdered Kamaljit, and when he tried to intervene, Sukhbir thrashed him too,” added Beant.

Thereafter, Beant called the police. Sub-inspector Paramjit Singh, SHO at Koomkalan police station, said, “The accused used to suspect his wife of infidelity. On Sunday morning, he indulged in a spat with her and murdered her with the wooden leg of a cot.”

The police have arrested him when he was trying to escape.

Title: CM Jai Ram Thakur asks those stranded to remain where they are
Content:
File photo of Jai Ram Thakur

SHIMLA: With people within the state and those stranded outside desperate to reach their homes, chief minister Jai Ram Thakur has requested such people to remain stationed wherever they are as the state government was not allowing any intra-state and inter-state movement in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.

He said the movement of people within the state from one district to another and also from outside the state must be checked at any cost. He said those persons who had already entered the state must be kept in quarantine centres established in the border areas, so that they do not mix with other people.

Thakur said this while interacting with DCs through video conferencing from Shimla on Sunday to take stock of the situation in wake of curfew in the state.

He said adequate arrangements must be made for proper food and shelter to the stranded people. He added the district administration must ensure that there was no inconvenience to the people and sufficient essential commodities were made available to them.

He asked the DCs to motivate such people to remain stationed wherever they were and ensure proper arrangement for their food and shelter. The CM said they should also be motivated and assured that the government was committed to taking their care and they need not to worry. He said there was no dearth of funds for providing adequate relief to those stranded.

Thakur said in order to facilitate the people of the state stranded in Delhi or Chandigarh, control rooms had been established in Himachal Bhavans in New Delhi and Chandigarh. He said as far as possible, efforts would be made to provide food and shelter to them in these bhavans.

Chief secretary Anil Kumar Khachi asked the DCs to discourage exodus from one district to another and also from other states. He said labourers and other workers from the other states must be discouraged to travel outside the state and should be kept in the camps.

DGP S R Mardi said no vehicle carrying people from other states would be allowed to enter Himachal Pradesh and strict action would be taken against the violator.

Title: Passes issued to feed stray dogs, activists say not enough
Content:
Representative image

LUDHIANA: After almost a week’s wait, four members of Animal Protection and Welfare Society have been given curfew passes. The passes, the society members rue, will hardly serve the purpose as they are allowed to feed the strays once a week that too for two hours.

The society president, advocate Vijay Kumar Sharma , said, “Due to the lockdown, all shops, hotels and restaurants are closed and people are confined to their houses. Stray dogs and other animals are dying because of hunger and lack of medicine. We had sought permission to give food to the stray animals twice a day. But we have been given a go-ahead of once a week for two hours (from 6pm to 8pm). And only four of the 200 members of the society have been given the passes. It’s of little help.”

Now, the society has decided that teams of two-member each will help stray animals in their respective areas. “This will enable us serve the animals while following the curfew restrictions. Residents who want to donate food for these animals can contact at these numbers: 9814714698, 7888754036, 98788838788 and 843777008,” he added.

The Animal Welfare Board of India had instructed the authorities to take care of the stray animals but it seems they are not worried about them, he said.

Title: Indian Railways restarts commodity parcel service almost after 50 years
Content: CHANDIGARH: The Indian Railways has re-introduced special parcel service, which was discontinued in 1974, to ensure supply of commodities across India. Although passenger train services have been discontinued due to Covid-19 restrictions, freight trains are running across the country and their speed has increased to 40 kmph from 30 kmph.The railways has decided to carry essential commodities to different parts of the country in freight trains, and will run special parcel bogies to carry small quantities of essential items. The special trains and bogies can carry items like dairy products, medical equipment and medicines, groceries, edible oil and other food items. The movement of parcel specials will be from point to point, as per rules and a minimum of five parcel bogies for the same destination can be loaded.“This service can be backbone for suppliers whose commodities are stuck in absence of smooth road transportation,” said railway officials, who explained that the service had been discontinued as it was not cost effective.Three parcel bogies are being planned in the Ambala division of Northern Railway — two from Ambala and one from Chandigarh. One Ambala bogie will ply between Ambala and Ludhiana, and the other till Ludhiana via Chandigarh. The Chandigarh parcel bogie will run till Jaipur.In the Ferozepur division, a single parcel bogie will deliver products of an MNC from Moga till Assam. The division is seeking more rakes to effectively implement this service, as it just has one bogie for this service.Ambala divisional railway manager G M Singh said the service would benefit people sending small consignments. The service would be reviewed periodically, he added.Ferozepur divisional railway manager Rajesh Aggarwal , recalling the old system, said even a single bogie was booked to supply wheat or any essential commodity at that time. Now, they would also supply dairy products, but in the 1970s due to lack of refrigerated bogies, no perishable products could be transported on these special trains, he added.

Title: Mansa teachers contribute over Rs 3 lakh to CM fund
Content: MANSA: To support underprivileged and take forward the fight against coronavirus (Covid-19), government teachers in Mansa district have announced to donate over Rs 3 lakh. Gurdeep Singh , head teacher of government primary school in Khudal Kalan village, has announced to donate Rs 75,000.Social science teacher Jasbir Singh of government senior secondary school, Gandu Kalan, would donate his one-month salary of Rs 65,000 to the chief minister relief fund through the state education department. Rajdeep Singh Bareta , who is posted as head teacher of government primary school in Jalbehra, and Ram Singh Jhalbuti , head teacher of government primary school of Bhava, have also announced to donate their monthly salaries of Rs 60,000 each. These teachers are also making students and their parents aware of coronavirus and telling them ways to save them.Apart from these four, more teachers have contributed in varying amounts, taking the figure to above Rs 3 lakh.

Title: Haryana sets up shelter homes for labourers
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The Haryana government has set up 129 shelter or relief homes across the state. Food is being provided to 29,328 labourers staying in these homes. Haryana chief secretary, Keshni Anand Arora said directions have been issued to all districts to closely monitor and stop the movement of migrant labourers. She said migrant labourers in each district should be immediately shifted to the shelter or relief home and provided with enough food. She shared this information on Sunday while presiding over the crisis coordination committee meeting through video conferencing.

The chief secretary directed officials concerned to set up health camps on state borders to provide migrant labourers with the facility of thermal screening and other medical tests. She also directed officers concerned to increase the number of relief and shelter homes.

Directing officials to intensify checking of migrant labourers’ movement on inter-state borders, she asked them to consider turning stadiums in their respective districts into temporary shelters for labourers. No one should be allowed to move out on roads, she added.

The chief secretary said a nodal officer should be appointed to track the number of migrant labourers staying in shelter or relief homes. She informed officers that according to the directions issued by National Highways Authority of India (NHAI), stay and food arrangements of labourers under the authority would be made by them. Thereafter, all district administration officers will coordinate with the NHAI to provide stay and food arrangements for such labourers.

She directed senior officers of the district administration to ensure that only those who have passes and have been given permission by the ministry be allowed to move. The chief secretary directed officers to ensure that workers in various industrial units of the state be given their salaries as well as food and lodging facilities. Such facilities should also be provided to unorganised labour, she said.

Arora underlined the need for strict compliance with the 14-day quarantine instructions and said it should be ensured that no one from neighbouring states is allowed to enter Haryana.
